webTitle: Congo's Kabila dead, Belgian government says

fields.headline: Congo's Kabila dead, Belgian government says
fields.trailText: President Laurent Kabila has been assassinated, according to Belgian Foreign Ministry  officials, an event that could throw the vast Central African country into further turmoil.
fields.body:
President Laurent Kabila has been assassinated, according to Belgian Foreign Ministry officials, an event that could throw the vast Central African country into further turmoil.

"From two sources of whom we are 100 percent certain, we can confirm that Kabila has died. He was probably shot by one of his guards," Foreign Ministry spokesman Koen Vervaeke said.

The Belgian officials gave no further information, and the report could not be confirmed. Belgium is Congo's former colonial ruler.

Asked about the report, Interior Minister Gaetan Kakudji said: "The Belgian Minister of Foreign Affairs can say what he wants but I will make my announcement tomorrow."

A member of Kabila's security entourage said on condition of anonymity that the bodyguard had shot the president in the back and right leg. Kabila was alive and was being treated by doctors, he said without elaborating.

French diplomats in Paris also said they believed Kabila had been shot but was alive. Intelligence officers in Rwanda said they had unconfirmed reports that Kabila was killed in the intense shooting at the presidential palace, which lasted half an hour.

Rwanda supports rebels fighting to topple the Congolese strongman.

Kabila's government would not be publicly drawn on their president's condition, or even whether he'd been shot.

"President Kabila is alive and everything is OK," said Congolese General Francois Olenga.

The conflicting reports came hours after witnesses told of 30 minutes of gunfire around the home of Kabila, who has been fighting multiple rebel armies for more than two years. It was unclear who was responsible for the shooting.

A presidential helicopter landed at Kinshasa's main hospital, a government official who witnessed the event said, adding there were unconfirmed reports that the aircraft was carrying Kabila's son, Joseph Kabila, who had apparently been injured. The younger Kabila is the head of Congo's military.

Presidential aide Eddy Kapend went on national television shortly after the gunfire ended to appeal for calm, but he made no mention of the incident.

The bleary-eyed Kapend ordered that all airports and borders be closed, appealing to the armed forces and civil society leaders to help maintain order.

"The Congolese people need your serenity and your discipline," he said.

Later, an 8pm to 6am curfew was announced by Kakudji as having being ordered by Kabila himself.

Kakudji also put all fighting units in Kinshasa on alert until further notice.

In the neighboring Republic of Congo, a senior military official said it was unclear who was in control of the Kinshasa government after Kabila was wounded. The official declined to be named.

Amid the confusion of the shooting, Kinshasa residents hurried home and many streets were quickly deserted. Truckloads of armed soldiers patrolled the streets in the capital city of the vast Central African nation.

Large numbers of troops in armored vehicles and on foot blocked off roads near Kabila's hilltop residence not far from downtown Kinshasa. The presidential residence, known as the Marble Palace, is usually heavily guarded by troops and a North Korean-made tank.

As darkness fell, a tense calm enveloped the capital.

Kabila has been fighting a civil war since August 1998, when rebel forces backed by Kabila's former allies, Rwanda and Uganda, turned against him. In the war's early stages, the rebels reached the outskirts of Kinshasa before being turned back by Kabila's army, which is now supported by Angola, Namibia and Zimbabwe.

Speaking from Brussels, Kin-Kiey Mulumba, a spokesman for one of the main rebel movements insisted Kabila was dead.

"It was a palace coup. Soldiers from Kabila's escort fired at him. He took bullets directly. Immediately, the doctors took him to the main hospital, but he died."

Mulumba said the shooting proved that the Congolese people wanted a change, but denied that rebels had anything to do with it.

"Something big happened in our country this afternoon. People want change," he said.

Kabila came to power in May 1997 following a Uganda- and Rwanda-sponsored rebellion against former dictator Mobutu Sese Seko, who ruled the nation then called Zaire.

webTitle: Agencies concerned over online adoptions

fields.headline: Agencies concerned over online adoptions
fields.trailText: There is nothing to stop people going overseas and buying children advertised for adoption on the internet, agencies warn. David Batty reports
fields.body:
Adoption agencies have warned there is nothing to stop people from going abroad to buy children advertised for adoption on the internet after a Welsh couple paid £8,200 to an online US adoption agent for two six-month-old girls.

Alan and Judith Kilshaw from Buckley, North Wales, travelled to the US in November to buy the baby girls from California-based adoption agent Tina Johnson after the couple saw her advertisement on the internet.

Mr Kilshaw has said adoption procedure in the UK is "over-regulated" and people are regarded as being "unsuitable" for "silly reasons".

Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering (BAAF), said the case showed the need for international regulation of online adoption. The Adoption (Intercountry Aspects) Act 1999, which comes into force in January 2002, will improve the regulation of inter-country adoption.

A spokeswoman for the National Assembly for Wales said "The aim of this act is to deter incidents like this case and make them an offence. But it is too early to say whether this case would be illegal as the regulations have not been confirmed."

She added that it was unclear whether the Kilshaws have acted illegally under current legislation, as the US is a "designated country" whose adoptions are recognised by UK law.

"It seems a court order was made to allow the Kilshaws to take the children out of the US but they have to return there in June for an adoption order hearing. If an adoption order is made, it will be recognised in this country."

According to BAAF, the court order, apparently granted in Arkansas, means the Kilshaws do not have to be approved by the Home Office as having gone through UK assessment procedures.

Deborah Cullen, BAAF legal consultant, said: "The immigration people could say 'well this is a bit rum and we want to have some more checks done' but basically British law says that these people have been recognised as the children's parents. It is quite hard for the immigration authorities to say 'no, sorry'."

The Liberal Democrats have called for a kitemark system for approved websites listing children available for adoption.

Health spokesman Paul Burstow MP said: "A kitemark system could make people more aware of the quality of adoption websites."

Felicity Collier, chief executive of the BAAF, said: "The language used to describe the desperate situation of the children on some of these websites is awful and may attract the attention of paedophiles."

Welsh health minister Jane Hutt will be liaising with Flintshire social services - which cover the area where the Kilshaws live - to see what investigations will be taking place into the adoption.

Keith McDonogh, director of children's services for Flintshire county council, said the council had started investigating the case and the children's welfare was its paramount concern.

webTitle: Newcastle to spend as Domi joins Paris

fields.headline: Newcastle to spend as Domi joins Paris
fields.trailText: Newcastle's Didier Domi is expected to return to his former club Paris St-Germain in a £3.5m deal, allowing Wayne Quinn to complete a permanent switch from Sheffield United to Tyneside.
fields.body:
Didier Domi is expected to return to his former club Paris St-Germain from Newcastle United in a £3.5m deal later this week, allowing Wayne Quinn to complete a permanent switch from Sheffield United to Tyneside.

Quinn, the England Under-21 international on a month's loan, made his Newcastle debut in Saturday's 3-1 victory over Coventry. Bobby Robson hopes to finalise his £1.5m transfer as soon as Domi, absent without leave in Paris since before Christmas, is off-loaded.

Leicester's manager Peter Taylor still hopes to solve his goalscoring problems by signing the former Italy striker and Lazio player-coach Roberto Mancini, now a free agent, on a short-term deal. "The deal is not dead yet," said Taylor. "We may well be having talks with him later this week to see what his position exactly is."

West Ham will attempt to resurrect Lorenzo Amoruso's transfer when the unsettled Italian defender returns from Rangers' mid-season break in Florida. Amoruso made conciliatory noised yesterday before leaving to play in a series of friendlies. Earlier it appeared the £3m-plus deal had fallen through when talks over personal terms broke down.

Christian Vieri has berated Internazionale's fans and says he will no longer celebrate his goals at the San Siro until they get off his back. The Italy striker said after scoring Inter's equaliser against Parma on Sunday: "It's not fair to barrack a player who has been out for nearly 10 months and is doing everything he can to play again and get back into form."

webTitle: Gregory prays for Angel of mercy

fields.headline: Gregory prays for Angel of mercy
fields.standfirst: Ellis gives vote of confidence but manager's future is shaky
fields.trailText: Despite a vote of confidence from Doug Ellis, John Gregory is hoping that Aston Villa's record signing Juan Pablo Angel will save his season - and his job.
fields.body:
Doug Ellis has greeted the arrival of Aston Villa's most expensive signing Juan Pablo Angel by issuing a double vote of confidence - in himself and his manager John Gregory.

The Colombian striker completed his £9.5m move from River Plate of Argentina yesterday, a transfer that will silence, at least temporarily, the fans' rising dissatisfaction with Ellis.

But the Villa chairman, 77, is adamant neither age nor disgruntled supporters will force him to relinquish the job he has held for almost 20 years.

"I am chairman and I plan to remain chairman," he said. "I have no intention of resigning. I am mentally alert, physically agile and can still take on anyone."

Ellis's determination to continue suggests his tenure of office is in the lap of the gods but there is one decision that remains his: he wants Gregory to be at the club as long as he is chairman, despite reports of a serious rift between the pair.

Tensions boiled over just after Christmas when Gregory humiliated his chairman by making personal criticisms of him in a Sunday paper.

Yet during the inevitable dressing-down of the chastened Gregory, Ellis made it clear he wanted him to be a long-term fixture at Villa Park.

"The chairman repeated to me what he told me in May," Gregory said. "He wants me to be the last manager to work under him at Aston Villa."

Ellis hopes he has raised Gregory's chance of going the distance by sanctioning the signing of the 25-year-old Angel.

"We've backed John Gregory to the hilt on this signing in every respect," Ellis added. "Payments for transfers can usually be spread but in this case we have had to pay cash and settle the account straight away. He chooses the players and he picks his team - there is no interference from us."

Angel's arrival ends a six-month quest for a quality striker by Gregory, who now must hope a player he sees as the one to reignite Villa's season does not turn into an expensive flop.

Despite Ellis's encouraging sentiments, Gregory's position must be tenuous after both his criticisms and his team's recent record.

Villa have won only one Premiership game in the last 10 and with fixtures to come against Manchester United, Leeds and Ipswich he may be heading for the exit door come the end of the month.

But Gregory is confident Angel can deliver - "he can score goals of all kinds, tap-ins and spectacular ones. That's what he does. His recent record of 17 from his last 17 games speaks for itself and he is hungry for them. In one game I watched him, he had five shots in the first five minutes.

"He knows what is expected of him: he realises we've suffered in the past two seasons because we have not had someone to convert chances. He is confident he can put that right."

Angel's arrival is set to threaten David Ginola's brief time at the club. Recently he has partnered Dion Dublin up front but, with Gregory favouring a 3-5-2 formation and Paul Merson excelling in the free role Ginola might otherwise occupy, the Frenchman may find himself sidelined.

Ginola was substituted at half-time in Villa's dismal display against Liverpool on Saturday. "I was very disappointed with him," said Gregory. "The least I expect from any player is for them to come off at the end knowing they have given their all."

With Angel ineligible to play in tomorrow's FA Cup replay against Newcastle Ginola may get another chance. But the newcomer is set to play a part at Old Trafford on Saturday.

"I've been on holiday since the Argentinian season ended just before Christmas so I am not fully match fit," said Angel. "But I am very keen to get started and settled in England."

Gareth Barry has started talks over a new contract with Villa. Gregory is keen to tie the central defender to a five-year deal that would keep him at the club until 2006.

webTitle: A office where women's rights are being won

fields.headline: Happy days
fields.standfirst: From sex war to sex law
fields.trailText: The future is bright, the future is orange - and yellow and red, with daisies on the loo seats, cartoons and a clutch of awards on the walls, a turnover of £2m and a commitment to work-life issues. "Our view is that we can't afford not to operate like this," says Cathy Callus, 39, training director of Happy Computers. "It's about getting the most out of our staff."
fields.body:
The future is bright, the future is orange - and yellow and red, with daisies on the loo seats, cartoons and a clutch of awards on the walls, a turnover of £2m and a commitment to work-life issues. "Our view is that we can't afford not to operate like this," says Cathy Callus, 39, training director of Happy Computers. "It's about getting the most out of our staff."

The company, based in London, offers IT training. Set up by Henry Stewart in his back room a decade ago, it employed 20 people last year, now has 40 (a quarter male) and is still recruiting. Callus works four days a week; Stewart, 41, spends Thursday mornings in his children's school; another employee works only in term time.

Jane Rostron, 38, joined four years ago. She has worked both a three-day and a four-day week, and during maternity leave she brought her daughter into the office once a month to keep up to date. "It made the whole process seamless," she says. "Working here isn't an easy ride, you have to be seen to succeed, but the culture is wonderful because it's so human."

Maternity leave is six weeks on full pay, six weeks on half; the job is held for nine months with additional unpaid leave granted for a further five years. Fathers are given five days' paid leave and up to four months' unpaid.

Salaries are an open book, staff choose their own job description and mistakes are "celebrated" as a chance to learn from failure. Everyone is encouraged to join a union and to try another person's job to understand how the system works. "We look for attitude and train for skill, so qualifications matter less," Callus says. "We believe in teamwork and positivity - if you are interested in status, there's no place for you here." Each person spends a day a month on voluntary work and is given £75 a year to donate to charity.

It is said a major hurdle in the adoption of flexibility and a work- life agenda is that 97% of Britain's companies employ under 20 staff. Stephen Alambritis heads the Federation of Small Businesses which represents 160,000 small companies, 40,000 run by women. He says the government may permit a clause that will allow a small business to opt out of, say, extending parental rights if it can be proved this may harm the company. He also warns that too many "extras" attached to female employment might mean some bosses resist hiring women - a move he is at pains to condemn.

Happy Computers' experience, however, is that a modernised workplace boosts profits. Since staff stay, reduced recruitment costs have saved £40,000 in the past 12 months - and turnover is up 37%. "Our approach isn't complicated," Stewart explains. "We believe people work best when they feel good about themselves."

webTitle: From sex war to sex law

fields.headline: From sex war to sex law
fields.standfirst:
For a quarter of a century, the Equal Opportunities Commission has been fighting for women's rights. So how far have we got - and how far do we still have to go? Yvonne Roberts reports and checks out one office where the battle is being won

Happy days
fields.trailText: For a quarter of a century, the Equal Opportunities Commission has been fighting for women's rights. So how far have we got - and how far do we still have to go?  Yvonne Roberts  reports and checks out one office where the battle is being won.
fields.body:
Tomorrow, the Equal Opportunities Commission celebrates its 25th birthday. It was set up in a rush in 1975 to coincide with the establishment of the Equal Pay and Sex Discrimination Acts, legislation intended to expedite a new world for women and ethnic minorities. Initially a sickly child, the EOC, under its chair of two years Julie Mellor, has begun to show teeth - but what of the state of women?

A quarter of a century ago, the 42nd attempt to get equal pay on to the statute books was finally successfully guided by Barbara Castle, then minister of employment. Companies were given five years to adjust. Not untypically, one company issued a list of "discrimination factors", among them the willingness to work overtime. The lads were kept ahead of the girls who were instantly handicapped because of the kids at home.

And now? These are contradictory times. Some say the battle is over, others are too exhausted to know, while if polemicists are to be believed, men have cause to be mad about women. With the collapse of heavy industry and the high divorce rate, some men argue that they are emasculated and excluded from home and work, forced into what was once the woman's role: second-class citizen.

The EOC is using its celebrations to challenge some of this thinking. Aware that equality for women has always required that men, too, should be liberated from the straitjacket of gender stereotyping, it has commissioned research which analyses how far women and men have actually come. Does the traditional breadwinner rest in peace? An increasing number of men under 35 look after their children - it's just that they don't call it childcare. According to one study, 80% of 18-24-year-olds disagree that "a man's job is to earn the money; a woman's . . . to look after the home and family".

The EOC is calling for a national debate on how to forge a social contract for the 21st century between men and women, employers and employees, government and the electorate. One that draws on notions of modern citizenship and builds on Labour's recognition that childcare and the work-life issue is no longer a private affair but a central part of its economic strategy and a matter of social justice.

More persuasive than rhetoric, however, is the clout carried by profit and loss. Put bluntly, the present jalopy of a system - in which the average male works a 47-hour week and the family remains invisible - costs a packet. For instance, days lost to stress alone are estimated to cost British industry£3.8bn per year.

At the same time, the rewards of those (few) businesses who are pro-active are obvious. One recent survey of the FTSE-100 companies showed that the quarter who have a 21st-century agenda on discrimination and flexibility had shares which, on average, over a five-year period from 1993, had risen by 141%, compared with the FTSE average of 78%.

In spite of this, the pay gap has shifted little since the 80s. It stands at 18% for full-time female employees but a whopping 39% for 5m part-timers. Much attention is paid to the half a million working women (out of 12m) who pay tax at the top whack but, on average, a full-time man earns £21,877, a woman £15,438.

"As a society," Mellor says, "we've accepted equality as part of the wallpaper. But in truth we've stagnated."

Class, race and qualifications divide women but they have discrimination in common. The middle skilled childless woman has a lifetime earnings gap of £241,000 compared with her male colleague. A mother of two pays an extra penalty of £140,000. If a woman takes a year out to have a family, she returns to a job paying 16% less.

Research published by the EOC last week revealed that many employers are complacent about pay. Only one in five has adopted the EOC's voluntary code of practice; only 35% have taken a pay audit. Secrecy hides the crime.

Gail Cartmail is equality officer for MSF, a union with 400,000 members, a third of them female. It has just launched an equal pay strategy and what it has already learned about pay scales, Cartmail says, has "proved a bit of a shock". Among underwriters and brokers, for instance, full-time women earn 56p for every £1 earned by a man. "Confidentiality is a requirement of some jobs but we want everybody talking about pay," she says.

Unequal pay is about cash, job segregation, the low value attached to caring, the part-time penalty, the attitudes of managers and a female tendency to undersell ourselves. As part of its Valuing Women campaign, the EOC demonstrated how prejudice remains alive and well among line managers. Some still see women as less ambitious and committed, so they deny them bonus-related pay. The problem is not helped by the weakness in the Sex Discrimination and Equal Pay Acts - it took 14 years for speech therapists to win £12m in back pay.

Next month, the EOC's Equal Pay Task Force will publish its report. It might advise stronger legislation; compulsory pay audits and contract compliance. What is also required is class action and the clout to demand profound structural change. Mellor would like a duty placed on the public sector to eradicate discrimination.

Heather Wakefield of Unison says local government faces "a massive equal pay problem", exacerbated by the consequences of privatisation. The average salary is £15,000, the average age 43; seven out of 10 employees are women and they are expressing their frustration with their feet. Equality and flexibility must be part of the solution.

Local authorities say they are unable to fund the the pay gap and Wakefield says the government must. "If it eliminated discrimination, it would reduce the national pay gap and set the private sector an example." Unison's aim at branch level is Educate, Negotiate, Litigate.

Of course, in the long term, a critical mass of women entering the workforce is bound to have an impact. In 1970, they represented a third, now they represent half. In 1975, only 35% of higher education students were female; now that figure is 55%. In December, employment minister Tessa Jowell gave a thoughtful speech in which she emphasised the need to tackle gender stereotyping in schools, to offer retraining, to use citizenship lessons to tackle boys' attitudes to caring and to listen to equal pay recommendations. The government also intends to extend parental rights. Much more is needed.

Twenty-five years ago, equality and space for commitments outside paid work were considered the business of bolshie women. Now, at least, they are recognised as the concern of both sexes and issues at the heart of society.

webTitle: Leboeuf on course to join Monaco

fields.headline: Leboeuf on course to join Monaco
fields.trailText: The new broom sweeping through Chelsea should finally see Frank Leboeuf move to Monaco this week in a deal worth around £3m. He has played 197 games for Chelsea since arriving from Strasbourg for £2.5m in 1996, but has fallen victim to the coach Claudio Ranieri's drive to lower the average age of his squad.
fields.body:
The new broom sweeping through Chelsea should finally see Frank Leboeuf move to Monaco this week in a deal worth around £3m. He has played 197 games for Chelsea since arriving from Strasbourg for £2.5m in 1996, but has fallen victim to the coach Claudio Ranieri's drive to lower the average age of his squad.

It is understood Monaco have yet to increase their £2m offer for the 33-year-old France defender to meet Chelsea's £3m valuation. Leboeuf argues that because he has not asked for a transfer he is owed £1m for the remainder of his contract.

However a deal is almost certain to go through this week, and the Marseille-born defender was in France on Sunday tying up loose ends. "I have had some great times with Chelsea, but I feel a need to go back to France and rediscover my home region," he said.

"It is now time for me to move on and win trophies with Monaco. They share my ideas, and they deserve better than to be where they are at the moment - 14th in the table."

IFK Gothenburg are interested in taking Manchester United's Jesper Blomqvist back to Sweden. The 26-year-old, whose deal expires in the summer, joined United from Parma for £4.4m in 1998 but last played in the 1999 European Cup final, when he was substituted. An ankle then a knee injury have sidelined him since.

"If he can't play before his contract expires then United will probably not extend it, and he knows that we want him to join us," said Gothenburg's coach Roger Gustafsson.

Blackburn's Jeff Kenna, 30, has asked for a move after becoming disillusioned at his lack of opportunities. Bolton's goalkeeper Jussi Jaaskelainen will miss the rest of the season with cruciate-ligament damage.

Brentford fans will today step up their campaign to buy the club from the chairman Ron Noades. A delegation will meet the government-sponsored organisation Supporters Direct to enlist its help in setting up a trust similar to the one which has taken over Lincoln. Noades has refused fans the first option on buying the club, saying he has other purchasers lined up.

Brentford sustained reported losses of £1m last year and Noades is looking to sell Griffin Park at the end of the season to raise about £6m towards the cost of a stadium in Feltham, near Heathrow airport.

webTitle: Congo's Kabila shot and wounded, officials say

fields.headline: Congo's Kabila shot and wounded, officials say
fields.trailText: Congo's embattled President Laurent Kabila has been shot and wounded by one of his own bodyguards during an attempted coup d'etat, a senior security official said.
fields.body:
Congo's embattled President Laurent Kabila has been shot and wounded by one of his own bodyguards during an attempted coup d'etat, a senior security official said.

Intelligence officers in Rwanda, which supports rebels battling Kabila's government, however, said they had unconfirmed reports that Kabila was dead. Senior Congolese officials insisted their president was alive.

"President Kabila is alive and everything is OK," said Congolese Gen. Francois Olenga. He gave no further details.

A member of Kabila's security entourage said on condition of anonymity that a bodyguard had shot the president in the back and right leg. Kabila was alive and was being treated by doctors, he said.

A senior military official in the neighbouring Republic of Congo also said Kabila had been wounded, adding it was unclear who was in control of the Kinshasa government. The official, who also declined to be named, spoke from his country's capital of Brazzaville.

The conflicting reports came hours after witnesses told of 30 minutes of gunfire around the home of Kabila, who has been fighting multiple rebel armies for more than two years. It was unclear who was responsible for the shooting.

A presidential helicopter landed at Kinshasa's main hospital, a government official who witnessed the event said, adding there were unconfirmed reports that the aircraft was carrying Kabila's son, Joseph, who had apparently also been injured. The younger Kabila is the head of Congo's military.

Presidential aide Eddy Kapend went on national television shortly after the shooting ended to appeal for calm, but he made no mention of the incident.

The bleary-eyed Kapend ordered that all airports and borders be closed, appealing to the armed forces and civil society leaders to help maintain order.

"The Congolese people need your serenity and your discipline," he said.

Amid the confusion, Kinshasa residents hurried home, and many streets were quickly deserted. Truckloads of armed soldiers patrolled the streets in the capital city of the vast Central African nation.

Large numbers of troops in armored vehicles and on foot blocked off roads near Kabila's hilltop residence not far from downtown Kinshasa. The presidential residence, known as the Marble Palace, is usually heavily guarded by troops and a North Korean-made tank.

Uganda and Rwanda support Congolese rebels who have been fighting to overthrow Mr Kabila since August 1998. In recent months, the Rwandan-backed rebels have beaten back Congolese troops and their Zimbabwean allies.

Mr Kabila took over the country in May 1997 after overthrowing the long-term ruler, Mobutu Sese Seko, changing the country's name from Zaire to Congo when he became president.

webTitle: Congo's Kabila reported dead

fields.headline: Congo's Kabila reported dead
fields.trailText: There have been unconfirmed reports that the president of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Laurent Kabila, has been killed today in a coup attempt in the nation's capital, Kinshasa.
fields.body:
There have been unconfirmed reports that the president of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Laurent Kabila, has been killed today in a coup attempt in the nation's capital, Kinshasa.

"He has died. He was shot by unknown people...earlier today ... I am 101% sure he is dead," a senior Ugandan intelligence source in Kampala told the Reuters news agency by telephone, saying his information came from intelligence sources in Kinshasa.

"The situation now is very unclear," he said, adding that he did not know who was in control of the city.

A regional security official in Kigali, Rwanda, said he had spoken to soldiers in Congo who had confirmed to him that Kabila, who has been fighting multiple rebel armies for more than two years, had been shot and killed in the bedroom of his palace.

"Three hours ago, some (government) soldiers burst into Kabila's bedroom and shot him dead. I am talking to people who were part of the action. I am sure that he is dead," the source told Reuters. But another regional military source said Kabila was shot and wounded and was taken to a hospital where he was in an intensive care unit.

A government source in Zimbabwe also told Reuters Kabila had been wounded and not killed.

Belgium's foreign ministry earlier reported that shots had been fired around the presidential palace.

"Our ambassador reported shots being fired around the palace," said spokesman Michel Malherbe.

He said the ambassador reported that telephone lines had been cut in Kinshasa. Television and radio broadcasts have also been interrupted, Mr Malherbe said.

Presidential aide Eddy Kapend went on national television shortly after the shooting ended to appeal for calm, but he made no mention of the incident.

Mr Kapend ordered all airports and borders to be closed, appealing to the armed forces and civil society leaders to help maintain order.

Uganda and Rwanda support Congolese rebels who have been fighting to overthrow Mr Kabila since August 1998. In recent months, the Rwandan-backed rebels have beaten back Congolese troops and their Zimbabwean allies.

Mr Kabila took over the country in May 1997 after overthrowing the long-term ruler, Mobutu Sese Seko, changing the country's name from Zaire to Congo when he became president.

webTitle: CD-rom reviews: The Catch Up CD-rom & Cell City

fields.headline: CD-rom reviews
fields.trailText: The Catch Up CD-rom | Cell City
fields.body:
The Catch Up CD-rom (Catch Up Project, £37.35)

Age Key stage 2, especially Year 3

Pupils and teachers will find this useful when addressing spelling. It has five differentiated games comprising a set of hierarchical activities designed to help less able pupils. The program is self-correcting and records the time taken to complete each activity. It reinforces the "look, say, cover, write, check" method of learning spellings. Children use it best for 10-20 minute sessions and can access it unsupervised. It has strong curriculum links and supports both the literacy hour and other relevant lessons. Written activities are needed away from the computer as a follow-up.

Cell City (Anglia Multimedia, £45+ VAT, tel 01603-760000)

Age 14-16+yrs

A biology-based program ideal for GCSE candidates. Students can zoom in and out of cells or find out what each part does. Video clips can be run before trying an interactive test. Students appreciate the instant feedback, which suggests parts of the cell to re-examine before retesting. The program is ideal for a revision club or a group of more able students, but it has its place within the mainstream. It has strong curriculum relevance and can be used when teaching both GCSE science double award and biology. It has a depth of detail that goes beyond GCSE level and would have value at KS5. It helps students grasp difficult concepts.

Read full evaluations of this programs at www.teem.org.uk

webTitle: Education book reviews

fields.headline: Education book reviews
fields.trailText: Uncle Billy Being Silly, by Michael Rosen and The Leap, by Jonathan Stroud
fields.body:
Uncle Billy Being Silly, by Michael Rosen, illustrated by Korky Paul (Colour Young Puffin, £3.99)

Age 5-9

Rosen has a direct line to the logic young children use to build a picture of their lives. This fine collection of observations and poetry, not all of them new, skilfully combines Rosen's loose-limbed, laid-back style with Korky Paul's riotous illustrations. Ideal for children emerging from the disciplines of the reading scheme, this can also inspire their creative writing. Rosen is not locked into a beginning-middle-end technique, and the results are therefore airy but penetrating. The end result can even seem precarious and chaotic, but don't be fooled - it speaks directly to the audience, encouraging everyone to speak for themselves.

The Leap, by Jonathan Stroud (Red Fox, £4.99)

Age 12-16

Launching a new teenage imprint, Definitions, The Leap makes uncomfortable, compelling reading. Charlie has witnessed the drowning of her best friend, Max, but is convinced that he can still be reached and that she is the one to do it. Her distress at the death translates into bizarre behaviour, dreams and nightmares, witnessed by her perplexed brother and mother. It is the relationship between brother and sister that provides the spine of the story. James is frustrated at Charlie's apparent heedlessness, but ultimately tries to understand and so saves her life. The boy's short fuse, in the face of his sister's distracted grief, is sensitively depicted, as is Charlie's devastation at her loss.

webTitle: Milburn blasts management failures at Bedford hospital

fields.headline: Milburn blasts management failures at Bedford hospital
fields.trailText: Health secretary Alan Milburn has blamed "management failures" for the "bodies in the chapel" scandal at Bedford hospital and said trust chief executive Ken Williams was "right to resign". Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Health secretary Alan Milburn has blamed "management failures" for the "bodies in the chapel" scandal at Bedford hospital and said trust chief executive Ken Williams was "right to resign".

He said the NHS inspectorate, the commission for health improvement (CHI) will examine the trust's management systems during a visit to the trust in a fortnight's time.

In a damning emergency statement on the incident in the Commons, Mr Milburn condemned it as "totally and utterly unacceptable".

He said: "This was not a cash problem in the hospital. It was not a capacity problem in the hospital. It was a management problem in the hospital."

Mr Milburn disclosed that he had been advised that an additional purpose-built mortuary facility was "at no stage full" while bodies were stored in the chapel.

"There were no policies or procedures in place in the hospital to ensure that the bodies of deceased patients were treated with respect and dignity at all times," he said.

"The events in Bedford last week should never have happened. They need never have happened. I am deeply sorry they did."

In his statement, Mr Milburn said preliminary inquires had shown that in the past, bodies had been kept in the chapel of rest when the mortuary was full.

He said the government's guidance on treating the dead with dignity and respect had not been "adequately implemented" and welcomed the decision of Mr Williams to step down.

"In the circumstances that was the right thing to do."

An initial verbal report on the incident had been made to NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp and a full report would be published later. Mr Milburn said that in the past there were no clear guidelines about ensuring dignity and respect for deceased patients.

Guidance had been issued in May last year and repeated again in November. "In Bedford that guidance was not adequately implemented." He said: "The preliminary inquiries appear to show that in the past when the mortuary facility was full the deceased were kept in the chapel of rest.

"Following the issue of guidance in May, an extra purpose-built mortuary facility was purchased.

"I am advised that the additional facility was at no stage full. It was functioning normally apart from a minor problem with the doors.

"The problem was reported on Monday of last week but final action was not taken until Thursday. During that period last week bodies were placed inappropriately in the chapel of rest."

Hospital management had failed to implement the clear national guidance and failed to resolve immediately this local problem. "The issue should and could have been sorted out on the spot. Instead deceased patients were denied their dignity. That should never happen in any part of the NHS."

Mr Milburn denied that what had happened at Bedford was a reflection of what was happening across the country.

The Health and Safety Executive will visit Bedford hospital on Thursday and CHI will begin an independent inspection on January 29.

"The inspection will now cover this matter as part of its wider inspection of the hospital," he said. Shadow health secretary Dr Liam Fox described the Bedford chief executive as a "scapegoat" and asked Mr Milburn if it was true that the same practice had been followed in the hospital for many years.

Consultants had raised the issue of a shortage of pathology facilities, but it was not until photographs appeared in newspapers that any action was taken.

"Is it true that the chairman was also asked to resign but declined to do so?" demanded Dr Fox.

"The government forces the managers to spend money on political initiatives, such as the waiting list initiative, rather than improving pathology services," raged Dr Fox.

He turned to Mr Milburn: "We see pathology as a priority, but you would rather it was spent on treating non-urgent cases within 18 months.

Dr Fox continued "The NHS is being used to deliver ministerial targets, rather than dealing with the clinical priorities of doctors and their patients."

webTitle: Livingstone given US lesson in fighting crime

fields.headline: Livingstone given US lesson in fighting crime
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: He was here to learn how a rightwing mayor has delivered a city with low crime and civic pride, but for Ken Livingstone it was a day of priorities - he visited New York's Bronx zoo to see a tiger salamander.
fields.body:
He was here to learn how a rightwing mayor has delivered a city with low crime and civic pride, but for Ken Livingstone it was a day of priorities - he visited New York's Bronx zoo to see a tiger salamander.

Among mayor Rudy Giuliani's many edicts has been to ban certain animals, like snakes and alligators, from the city limits. It seems salamanders and newts were not on the list.

That may have helped Mr Livingstone strike a more conciliatory tone towards the mayor he once branded as insensitive to blacks. "When you meet someone in person it's always different than when you read about them in the press," said Mr Livingstone following a breakfast meeting with Mr Giuliani at the mayor's Manhattan residence, Gracie Mansion.

The two mayors, iconoclasts after their own fashion, appeared to warm to each other over the ham, eggs and bagels. This was despite the fact that the press release from Mr Giuliani's office never mentioned Mr Livingstone's appearance at the prayer breakfast in honour of Martin Luther King, who's birthday yesterday was a national holiday.

"Though we come from opposite political wings, we face very similar problems and have similar solutions," Mr Livingstone said.

Among those problems is fighting crime and Mr Giuliani never loses an opportunity to boast that New York crime was again cut last year by nearly 6%.

There were still more than 600 homicides in New York City last year, three times as many as in London. But Mr Livingstone wants to raise London boroughs' tax revenues to add more police and sought Mr Giuliani's advice on how to deploy them.

The London mayor also praised his counterpart's success in reducing the number of New Yorkers on the dole by 400,000, though only 119,000 jobs were found for them.

Mr Livingstone, eyeing a development plan for Trafalgar and Parliament squares, wants to hear, when he sits down with Mr Giuliani today, how New York has turned the porn capital of America, Times Square, into a Disneyfied business and media mecca in a few years.

London's mayor visited companies in Wall Street and the Downtown Business Alliance's neighbourhood, on which he would like to model the new Oxford Street business district.

He later tried to drum up American investment for London at a World Trade Center lunch.

After lunch, Mr Livingstone again rode Bob Kiley's upgraded subway to Harlem, where he was to meet black business leaders of the Upper Manhattan empowerment zone.

webTitle: Court in dark as imperial weights go on trial

fields.headline: Court in dark as imperial weights go on trial
fields.standfirst: Lights go out as defiant greengrocer is put in dock for refusing to go metric and selling bananas by pounds and ounces
fields.trailText: Lights go out as defiant greengrocer is put in dock for refusing to go metric and selling bananas by pounds and ounces.
fields.body:
The battle of the imperial bananas began in earnest yesterday, but only after two foreign units of measurement had caused chaos.

The German ohms and French amps in the electricity system at Sunderland magistrates court blacked out the building just as the last stand of the pound and ounce was due to begin.

The bench, barristers and a circus of imperial weights and measures experts shifted boxes of law books half a mile - or a little less than a kilometre - uphill to the city council chamber for the start of a far-reaching EU test case, drawing on sections of Magna Carta, Latin tags and the fuel problems of his lawyer's Bentley, in which greengrocer Steve Thoburn is hoping to defend the traditional British right to ignore the metric system.

"This dates back to the 1864 Metric Weights and Measures Act," said his barrister, Michael Shrimpton, a constitutional expert. EU insistence on metric-only sales rode roughshod over parliament. "We have always tolerated eccentricity in this country, and if a customer wants to go to Mr Thoburn and order 0.45359337 kilos of bananas instead of a pound, that act says he is perfectly entitled to do so."

Mr Thoburn's stand is for pounds and ounces devotees to be allowed the same flexibility, which his market stall in Sunderland allows them to do. He denies two counts of selling bananas in imperial weights only to undercover staff of Sunderland city council, which has brought the prosecution.

Eleanor Sharpston QC, for the council, said that the case was about enforcing the will of parliament, rather than Brussels, and avoiding confusion in shoppers' minds. She said: "This prosecution is entirely brought to enforce a valid act of parliament which is the law of the land."

Mr Shrimpton said Mr Thoburn, 36 and a father of two, was a John Hampden of the weighing scales, whose "courage has implications far beyond greengrocers, bananas and the fair city of Sunderland". He told the court: "The European is entitled to his policy. What he is not entitled to do is to apply that policy in defiance of the British parliament."

The case hinges on whether the EU's 1994 units of measurement regulations, nodded through by the Commons without serious discussion, take precedence over the 1985 Weights and Measures Act, which continued the century-old tradition of allowing businesses and customers to opt for either system.

Mr Shrimpton admitted that petrol sales had in effect sold the metric pass. He said: "I never understand what 110 litres is when I put it into my Bentley."

He drew strength from the number of journalists in court from the United States, the world's main bastion of imperial measures, and pointed out that the undercover raid had taken place - "whether significantly or not, I don't know" - on July 4.

There had been no need for cloak and dagger work, he said, as Mr Thoburn not only made no attempt to hide his love of pounds and ounces, but also actually shouted it, in the manner of market traders.

The case is the first of a potential series involving recalcitrant retailers across Britain, whose loyalty to imperial measures is supported by the UK Independence Party and celebrities. Goodwill messages for Mr Thoburn have been winged to Sunderland by Jilly Cooper, Keith Waterhouse and Ian Botham among others.

The leader of the UKIP, Jeffrey Titford, who admitted being a European MP, said: "This case will highlight the way that the EU is imposing its will on British culture." His confidence in victory was echoed by Vivian Linacre, director of the British Weights and Measures Association, who said: "Ultimately this will go our way, but it could go all the way to the House of Lords first."

The legal costs are expected to top pounds 250,000, but the affair has been commercially encouraging for Mr Thoburn who is a local hero in Sunderland.

He recently expanded his market stall to include a shop over the road, where he hopes that his confiscated imperial-only scales will eventually have pride of place.

The case continues.

webTitle: Comment: Abolishing powers of the Lords would be a scandal

fields.headline: To abolish the powers of the Lords would be a scandal
fields.standfirst:
Illiberal New Labour wants to hold all of the decision-making power

Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: Illiberal New Labour wants to hold all of the decision-making power.
fields.body:
The greatest vice of the New Labour mind is intolerance. It may often not know, at first, what to think itself. It has little guiding ideology. It often seeks the opinion of focus groups - tiny minorities raised to the level of universal science - before deciding what exactly to do about even the biggest issues in the fields of crime, or schooling, or healthcare, or the euro. But other minorities are not so exalted. Once the hesitations of the New Labour mind have been settled, dissenters have to be marginalised. This paradox, of uncertainty coexisting with intolerance, is the unique spectacle New Labour has brought to British politics.

The intolerance doesn't invariably start at the top. The determination to ban hunting with dogs seems to be mainly an impulse springing from the urban grass-roots. Its intransigence is a way of compensating for the absence of moral compass in many other areas. It sweeps aside all arguments there might be about the science, the economics, the social costs, the rural consequences and the libertarian price with a Jacobin insistence that such quibbling cannot be permitted to override the class reasons to abolish hunting or the hypocritical assertion that the issue is all about animal pain.

On each of those aspects, as the Burns report showed, there is much to be said on both sides. There is no conclusive case either way on the science, the economics, the social costs or the rural consequences of a ban. The liberty question, on the other hand, is extremely clear. In the absence of a conclusive case for abolishing a sport that has been part of British country life for centuries and is harmless to the majority who rail against it, the libertarian case should be decisive. If, that is, the politicians in whose hands the decision rests have a secure grasp on the rights of minorities. Not only does New Labour, as we will see when it votes tomorrow, wallow in scorn for the hunting minority, so do the Liberal Democrats, whose official position, declared by Simon Hughes with blind indifference to anything recognisable as liberalism, is for a ban.

A few cabinet ministers, to their credit, do not go that far. Jack Straw and Robin Cook won't vote for a ban. But they will then find themselves immersed in a larger issue, where their instincts are unlikely to be so reliable. For the hunting bill, though nodded through by the last-gasp class-warriors of the Commons, will be stalled in the Lords. This is part of the plan. Let the warriors have their red meat in the Commons, but then recognise that the Lords will stop it being finally devoured before the election, thus perhaps giving hope to rural voters that the hunt may in fact survive. Fat chance. But another casus belli will be in place for a much more serious onslaught, against the second chamber.

This is a case of intolerance at the very top. Mr Blair is committed to a second stage of reform of the Lords, which has been much debated. It is an extremely thorny issue, on which it was always possible nothing further would be done. The manifesto needs to declare what shape an intended reform will take, and there are voices gathering to press for something more radical than even the copious discussions of the past three years have envisaged.

With the second chamber, the choice for any democrat has to lie between making it more legitimate or less potent. So far, Labour has taken, however mildly, the legitimacy option. By excluding most hereditary peers, and preparing to reduce the control of political patronage over new life peers, it has given the Lords the appearance of modernity. Largely bogus though this is, it has been embraced to some effect by the peerage. They have grown stroppy in their obstructions and pious about their rights. In the last session they stopped some measures, like the bill to limit jury trial, and, by exerting incessant pressure on the government's timetable, amended several others.

So legitimacy has its costs for government. It also raises the hideous question of what to do next. An elected element, however small, would only make legitimacy more of a pain. The other day Mr Blair reacted with severity to the notion that the Lords should be anything more than a "revising" chamber, in terms that made clear his resistance to it being a rival to the Commons. He spoke not just against anything like equality between the houses, but, it seemed, against the smallest degree of even temporary equivalence - which is what the Lords can now claim when exercising their modest powers to delay measures and sometimes, depending on the timetable, kill them.

What's therefore under discussion is the impotence option. Why not reduce the Lords' powers still further, to ensure it can't do the kind of things it did as the last session was struggling to its end? Why, when you get down to it, should unelected persons ever have decisive influence over the will of the people as represented by a mandated government? Isn't it time, in all contemporary truth, to deploy the Lords as a forum to which revision work may be subcontracted, but to insist that, if ever its revisions displeased the government, they could simply be chucked away? Since we do not plan to make the Lords more legitimate, how can we tolerate the defiling of democracy that is represented by its power?

A fair number of New Labourites would like to follow this logic. It would bring the attractions of single-chamber government without the odium of openly introducing one. There might be a second-chamber recruitment problem later. Meanwhile most of the peerage already present would be happy with their gongs, and any opposition the Commons might offer to serious Lords reform would be neutered at a stroke.

Only a government with an impaired sense of constitutional propriety could even contemplate such a scheme. New Labour may balk at trying to carry it through. In the end, the party might prefer the humiliation of failing to reform House of Lords' membership to the outrage of liquidating its powers. But such liquidation would be consistent with the traits to be seen in a political movement which is already in the throes of shifting from inferiority complex to arrogant self-regard, as a product of its impending second election victory.

For power does corrupt. Until now, New Labour has thought of its power as contingent. Soon that phase will be over. The government is full of good and honest political workers. But they see their task as urgent, blocked by a thousand obstacles, one of which surely need no longer be an undemocratic second chamber. They can't believe such a place might sometimes be wiser than they are. They don't easily see the need for checks and balances to the onward march of their well-meaning project.Already having more executive power than any government in the western world, they are impatient for more. If they get another large majority, the issue would seem to be: is there anywhere the hounds will be let loose?

They can't believe such a place might sometimes be wiser than they are. They don't easily see the need for checks and balances to the onward march of their well-meaning project.Already having more executive power than any government in the western world, they are impatient for more. If they get another large majority, the issue would seem to be: is there anywhere the hounds will be let loose? hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: Mixed picture for teacher training courses

fields.headline: Mixed picture for teacher training courses
fields.standfirst: An increase in teacher training applications, but it's not a uniform picture, writes Lee Elliott-Major
fields.trailText: An increase in teacher training applications, but it's not a uniform picture, writes Lee Elliott-Major.
fields.body:
University teacher training courses for secondary schools have seen an increase in applications for biology, chemistry, art, languages and social studies this year, but falls in applications in mathematics, history and geography.

The main increase in applications overall is for primary teacher training, which is up 13%, but there has also been an increase of 4% in the number applying for secondary teaching places. The rise in applications has come from both males and females, although women still make up the majority of those applying to the graduate teacher training registry.

A total of 17,709 people applied for teacher training by 15 December 2000, the main deadline for courses starting in autumn 2001. This is an increase of 9.7% on the 16,145 who had applied by the same time the previous year.

There are however wide variations is the numbers applying to different secondary school subjects. The biggest proportional increases have come in chemistry, modern languages and social studies, business studies and information technology, all of which saw applications up by over a third compared with last year. Applications in biology and art are also up by over a fifth.

Applications however are down in French (-9.2%), history (-7.3%), geography (-5.6%), maths (-3.8%) and English (-2%).

The biggest increase for primary teachers meanwhile is for those teaching 5-8 year olds, with applications up by just under 15% on last year.

Women take up the majority of teacher training places, representing 13783 of the 17709 applications this year.

This year the teacher training agency is offering £6,000 teacher training salaries and bonuses for teachers in England. An additional Ôgolden helloÕ of £4,000 is available for those working in.secondary shortage subjects - mathematics, science, modern foreign languages and technology.

webTitle: Women have finally toppled men off their last academic pedestal

fields.headline: Ladies first
fields.standfirst: Women have finally toppled men off their last academic pedestal, says  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Women have finally toppled men off their last academic pedestal, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
For the first time female students outnumbered male students in the first-class degrees gained at university, according to last year's degree results. The figures represent yet another educational milestone for females after an academic year in which they have outperformed males in GCSEs, A-levels, and now university finals.

University admission figures last week revealed that females now make up 55% of new undergraduates with the best A-level grades.

While for some time women have dominated the numbers of graduates securing upper seconds, men have always gained more first-class degrees. The annual trend helped spawn theories that male students excelled in exams - that they were less risk-averse than women who were more systematic, steady learners.

All this has changed, as reflected in figures for the degree finals in 2000 just released by the Higher Education Statistics Agency.

Just under 11,000 female students secured top class honours (almost 1,000 up on the 1999 figures), compared with 10,800 firsts for male graduates. Meanwhile, 67,500 females secured upper seconds compared with just over 42,000 males.

The figures show that a higher proportion of men taking exams still secured first-class degrees. But as 54% of those taking finals were women, they now produce more firsts in total. The performance of women graduates is also improving year on year.

More men than women were awarded the two poorest degree grades. Male graduates registered 8,400 thirds and 13,200 passes compared with 5,700 thirds and 12,200 passes for women. Overall, 265,000 undergraduate degrees were awarded to full-time and part-time undergraduates in UK universities.

The figures represent another symbolic breakthrough for women students and make further uncomfortable reading for education ministers, who are concerned over the widening educational gap between the sexes.

Julia Higgins, professor of polymer science, at Imperial College, London, welcomed the news: "What would be most pleasing is if the results fluctuated each year." She said the results are likely to vary for different subjects.

Diana Warwick, chief executive of Universities UK, said: "It's good to see women graduating with such high honours in larger numbers. It is excellent news for universities that they are enabling so many more people, both men and women, to succeed."

The number of undergraduates gaining degrees increased by 1% from 1999 to 2000. Of those gaining degrees in 2000, 8% got first-class honours, the same proportion as 1999. Just over 43% gained an upper second, compared to 42% in 1999. One in 10 graduates gained their award through part-time study.

The results vary for different subjects areas and universities. At Cambridge, for example, where men still outnumber women in student enrolments, more men secure firsts. Just under 24% of male finalists gained firsts in 2000 - 1,234 in total, com pared with just 17% of female graduates - 701 in total.

The numbers of women gaining postgraduate qualifications are also increasing faster than for men. Overall, 8% more postgrad degrees went to women in 2000 over the previous year. Over 64,000 women received postgraduate degrees, against 58,500 men. The biggest percentage increases among female postgrads were in computing science, veterinary science, humanities, and arts and design, up 30%, 22%, 17% and 17% respectively.

webTitle: Teacher shortage forces another school to send pupils home

fields.headline: Teacher shortage forces another school to send pupils home
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Government officials were taken by surprise yesterday when another school hit by staff shortages announced emergency cuts to its timetable.
fields.body:
Government officials were taken by surprise yesterday when another school hit by staff shortages announced emergency cuts to its timetable.

Though it has set up a special unit to avoid schools having to go to a short week, the Department for Education learned only yesterday morning of the move by St Mary's high school in Cheshunt, Hertfordshire, to send home 11 to 13-year-olds for one school day per fortnight.

Fourteen-year-olds will also miss an hour's tuition twice a week. In all, 320 of the 941 pupils would be affected. The acting head Judith Reeve said she had taken the decision because she was unable to fill three vacancies despite contacting 18 supply agencies in the last four weeks.

"We are the equivalent of three teachers short, which has resulted in 58 lessons a week being uncovered," said Mrs Reeve.

The school is short of teachers in maths and history, she said. It also needs part-time cover for English, geography, boys' PE, food studies and an adviser on careers and personal and sexual education.

Last night, after concerted government activity, the school was offered two teachers from a supply agency and the offer of an Australian teacher in two weeks' time. It was not clear whether the school would accept the offer.

Government sources were "disappointed" the school had not alerted the department or the local education authority earlier. Ministers are angry that schools may be rushing to cut the timetable without exploring other options. The St Mary's decision was symptom of "a problem, not a crisis", said a department of education spokeswoman.

It emerged yesterday that Reading council is offering £50 a night to the families of pupils prepared to put up teachers moving to the town. It is also offering £150 a week to staff who have to travel more than 50 miles to get to work.

Ironically figures released today show a 10% rise in graduate teacher training applications - 13% for primary, 4% for secondary - by December 15, 2000 compared with the same date last year. Figures for the same dates released two weeks ago showed a 16.1% drop. The Graduate Teacher Training Registry blamed the Christmas post and a delay in processing applications.

 Just how serious is the teacher shortage? And what should the government do about it? Join the online debate at www.educationunlimited.co.uk today at 4pm and interrogate Ralph Tabberer, head of the Teacher Training Agency (responsible for the "Can Teach" campaign), Gwen Evans of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, and Graham Lane of the Local Government Association.

webTitle: Comment: the current teacher shortage is inevitable

fields.headline: Gradgrind with a twist
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The current teacher shortage is not so much entirely predictable as entirely predicted.
fields.body:
The current teacher shortage is not so much entirely predictable as entirely predicted. The so-called education "reforms" initiated by the Tories and continued by David Blunkett were carried out in the context of a concerted attack on teachers' competence and values. Why would anyone want to belong to a profession that is undervalued, over-scrutinised and simultaneously blamed for so many social problems?

I feel particularly aggrieved about the current situation. My children were at primary school as the Tory underinvestment in schools began to bite and when staff were adjusting to the new demands of SATs. Their school was forced to make cuts. The first to volunteer for redundancy were the older, more experienced, "instinctive" teachers, adored by the children but who knew they couldn't cope with new bureaucratic demands. There was no money for building or repairs and extra activities such as swimming were abandoned.

Now at secondary school they are hit by chronic staff shortages. Nationally, the number of unfilled posts in secondary schools rose this month to over 1,200. Anecdotally the situation is known to be far worse. Many teachers are taking subjects for which they are not qualified and there is heavy reliance on "holiday" teachers. Australians, New Zealanders and French are the dominant groups. Great. The outcome of all those feverish reforms is the au-pair-isation of education.

The government blames low pay and spiralling housing costs, especially in the south-east. But why is teaching disproportionately affected? Many middle-aged teachers who would normally be settled in housing have left the profession. But pay has never been the only issue. Teaching has always been underpaid because it was possible to exploit other motivations - love of a particular subject, enthusiasm to communicate it to the next generation, and the enjoyment of being with young people as they learn. Satisfaction, as in any job, comes when those values are central to the profession as a whole. Self-esteem comes when pupils and society at large endorse those values.

But these factors have been systematically marginalised in teaching. Admittedly, social factors played a part in destroying respect from parents. But these pale into insignificance compared with the huge gulf between teachers' core motivational values and what they are being asked to do. Time and again we hear how teachers feel drowned by bureaucracy, by hours spent on form filling, writing out lesson plans, submitting documents for assessments and focusing on endless new initiatives, from SATs, to league tables and performance-related pay.

No satisfaction comes from reaching these new targets as most teachers don't think they are worth the paper they are written on. More students may get starred As but teachers think the exams are easier and that the skills required to get such results are to do with fulfilling narrow targets rather than true education.

So throwing money at this crisis is not likely to solve it. High salaries won't necessarily tempt teachers back. A new report by the National Association of Head Teachers shows that even with London salaries nudging £100,000 there's still a dire recruitment crisis. Last year 65% of all jobs had to be re-advertised. Now we hear rumours that the government finally intends to spend money rebuilding and refurbishing old schools. Like Railtrack's overdue track renewals, this will only make things worse in the short term. Good teaching relies on a degree of predictability.

Blair and Blunkett's enthusiastic adoption of the Conservatives' educational policies, still rankles with me, in particular their renewing Chris Woodhead's contract. Now that he has departed on his own terms, history is exposing what his critics knew all along: his judgments were as personally motivated and ideological as those of the "Marxist" bogeymen he liked to attack. Only last week research showed that media studies degrees are the fifth best for employment. So much for Woodhead's claim that such "vacuous" courses do not lead to jobs.

Woodhead's values suited Blair and Blunkett's own grim view of education: Gradgrind with a contemporary twist for the classic dual-income working parents who want to weigh and measure their children's achievements as proof that they've done it all right as well as had it all.

The only remedy is for this lot to go back to basics - and I don't mean the three Rs at age-appropriate levels. They need to open up a general debate about what we want children to know; about how to inspire affection, loyalty, morality, care for the environment while encouraging independent thought and self-reliance. It's only when the ideas are worth teaching that we'll get teachers worth having.

webTitle: Bergkamp agrees new Arsenal contract

fields.headline: Bergkamp agrees new Arsenal contract
fields.trailText: Dennis Bergkamp has ended months of speculation about his future by signing a two-year extension to his contract which will keep him at Arsenal until 2003.
fields.body:
Dennis Bergkamp has ended months of speculation about his future by signing a two-year extension to his contract which will keep him at Arsenal until 2003.

"This contract will almost certainly be the last one I ever sign which means I'll be finishing my career here at Arsenal," a delighted Bergkamp told icons.com.

"I'm delighted with this because I feel a really strong bond with the club now - I almost consider myself an Arsenal fan."

Bergkamp joined Arsenal in 1995 from Internazionale and was a key member of the side that won the Premiership in 1998. But he has spent much of this season overshadowed by Thierry Henry and has only managed two goals in 21 appearances.

Last October, Bergkamp complained the club had shown him a "total lack of respect" when negotiations began on a new contract and said he believed he was being frozen out.

But today he was delighted to sign a new contract, admitting: "I've stayed for the right reasons - because I love playing for Arsenal," he said on Tuesday. "I've been here for nearly six years now and had some great times.

"Some of the sentiments that people have offered me have made me quite emotional. I don't mean to sound melodramatic, but when people say that I'm really important and valued here it's quite touching," he added.
