webTitle: Living with Down's syndrome

fields.headline: Life with Brenda
fields.standfirst: Bertha Limacher was told that her daughter, who had Down's syndrome, would die as a teenager. But Brenda lived to be 52.  Esther Addley  on a remarkable story of love and sacrifice
fields.trailText: Bertha Limacher was told that her daughter, who had Down's syndrome, would die as a teenager. But Brenda lived to be 52. Esther Addley on a remarkable story of love and sacrifice.
fields.body:
Bertha Limacher has never had so many strangers in her home. The BBC have been in, she says, and Meridian, and a number of the papers. She has her treasured photographs to hand, ready to show off. The man from the local paper asks Bertha to lean over the pictures, arms around her husband and daughter, and point at them. He snaps the shutter a couple of times. It is too much for Mr Limacher, who covers his face with his hand and breaks into rasping sobs.

It is just over a week since Bertha's daughter Brenda Marshall died. It was a messy, public, deeply distressing death. Early last Friday morning, Bertha found her daughter in bed, moaning. She had been suffering from a bad chest infection and had been complaining for a few days of feeling very unwell; Bertha couldn't rouse her. She called an ambulance, and took her to hospital, 45 minutes from their home on the Isle of Sheppey in Kent.

They arrived before 7am. Brenda spent much of the morning on a trolley in a corridor outside the X-ray department. The hospital was busy, there were no ward beds available, and the nurses were rushed off their feet. Bertha, who is 76 and disabled, had to get Brenda onto a bed pan, with the help of her grandson's partner, who is pregnant. Finally, at 3.30pm, a ward bed was found for Brenda, almost nine hours after she arrived at the hospital. She slipped into unconsciousness, and died the following evening of pneumonia. She was 52.

Brenda Marshall's death has become the latest in a long line of supposed NHS failures. Press reports have implied that if she had been given a bed earlier she might have lived, although the family don't know if they believe this. Their grief is ragged, devastating. But, says Bertha, she always knew she would lose Brenda: she just hoped she wouldn't go before her.

Brenda Marshall was born with Down's syndrome, and to her mother and her sister Robina, 45, the sorry manner of her death is the least interesting part of her story. For more than half a century, Bertha has been responsible for every aspect of her daughter's care. Brenda couldn't walk more than a few steps without becoming breathless, could not wash or dress herself, and had to use a commode during the night. In her last few years she needed help in the toilet. As Bertha herself became more aged and less able, the needs of her daughter became more demanding. "I tried to treat her like an adult," says her mother, "but it was like caring for a baby for 52 years."

Down's syndrome is not a disease from which people can be said to "suffer". It is, rather, a genetic abnormality, in which babies are born with an extra chromosome. Those with the condition are prone to a number of illnesses, including heart problems, difficulties with hearing and vision, and thyroid disease. Their experiences, however, can vary enormously. Many people with Down's syndrome live very full and independent lives, holding down jobs and sustaining relationships. Others require much more intensive care.

Bertha was 24 when Brenda was born in 1949, at her home in west London. She was her first child, and Bertha didn't know much about babies, she says, but she knew something was wrong. "She was a bit funny, she used to go blue, and it would take me hours to feed her. I don't know if she couldn't suck, or what." She took the baby to her doctor, who referred her to Great Ormond Street hospital for tests. "They turned round and said that she was a 'mongol'. They called them mongols in those days. And of course I didn't know what a mongol was. I came out crying my eyes out."

The hospital, she says, offered no explanation as to what was wrong with her baby, or the kind of difficulties she could expect. "They just said to me, 'Do you want to put her away, or do you want to keep her?' And I said, 'Good God, I wouldn't want her put away!' So they just sent me away from the hospital."

Brenda started to walk when she was three, copying her younger brother. After a few steps, however, she would have to crouch down to regain her breath. When Brenda was six or seven, Bertha's mother bought her granddaughter a wheelchair. "She said, 'You can't let her go about like that,'" says Bertha. "Mum paid for the wheelchair. Nobody else helped. I had no support. Nothing at all."

At the age of 10, Brenda started at a special school for people with learning disabilities. "She loved it," says Robina. "She used to go in fancy dress. They tried to teach the children to read and write, but Brenda wasn't able. But she loved books all her life. She collected books about Diana, and she had some horse books; she loved them." Then, when Brenda was 13, Bertha was given the first detailed information about the nature of her health problems. Brenda had a series of tests that established that she had a hole in her heart which, doctors said, was inoperable. All of her teeth were also removed, something which was once not unusual with people with the condition. Bertha was told that her daughter could expect to live no more than six years.

From there their lives settled into a pattern that was both extraordinary and utterly mundane. From the day she left school at 16, Brenda attended a series of day centres for people with Down's syndrome. She was a very placid person, says her mother, and lived a happy life, "as far as we know". Brenda had a boyfriend, Gordon Robins, when she was in her late teens. "He used to come to the house," says Bertha. "She wanted to get married and have children. He actually asked me if he could marry her, and I said, 'I don't think so, darling.'"

Bertha feels that at the time she was the only one who could provide properly for her. "Brenda couldn't do anything," she says. "She couldn't walk far, and she couldn't cook or anything like that. She couldn't open a tin of baked beans. She couldn't read or write, she just managed to write her own name, and then towards the end she couldn't even do that."

Bertha had cared for her father until he died, then when her mother became too unwell to cope with her large London house, the whole family moved to a bungalow in Sheppey. Her mother was alive until five years ago. "I used to go to work; I used to clean. I had to work to make ends meet." But she could only take jobs that allowed her to be at home while Brenda was home. She could never leave her on her own. More than once, Brenda's heart stopped completely. "A couple of times, not just recently, she actually died in front of us and [my husband] massaged her heart and got it going again." It happened if Brenda got very agitated or upset. Deaths, in particular, upset her.

There is increasing evidence, as the general care for people with Down's syndrome improves, that they may be more susceptible to Alzheimer's disease, from as young as 30. Brenda had always prided herself on remembering everyone in the family's birthday, including those of all of Robina's 10 children. But in her last years, she started to forget simple things like the day of the week, or would get confused as to which room was which. Bertha could no longer cope on her own, and had to have someone in to wash and dress Brenda; someone to do her hair, someone to look after her feet. It was arranged through the social services, but the cost was met by the family. It was only in the last few months, when Brenda started at a new day centre, that she was allocated a one-to-one carer.

Brenda Marshall's family were not trained in the latest, politically correct, ways to look after people with Down's syndrome. No one thought to tell them. Had their daughter been born a few decades later, she might well have been able to attend a mainstream school. Brenda would have had support from a health visitor as she was growing up, and she would probably have been referred to an educational psychologist, a social worker and a psychologist. Brenda might well have been able to have lived independently in sheltered accommodation; she might have married.

Brenda's story illustrates how far things have come in the way we treat people with learning disabilities. And yet there is still some way to go. A recent report from the Down's Syndrome Association said 28% of parents of a child with the syndrome felt their child had been discriminated against in terms of health care.

But there's no doubt that Brenda was lucky: her family loved her fiercely and was instinctively hostile to anything that diminished her individuality. Healthcare professionals had talked to the family about different "classifications" of Down's syndrome. "They used to be As, Bs and Cs," says Robina, "the As were the best." Brenda, they were told, was an A. "But they are not a number. They have all got a name. They are all individuals. Brenda said to me once, 'I'm not the different one, you are.' As far as Brenda was concerned, all her friends were Down's syndrome; we were the odd ones out."

After spending the best part of her life as a carer, Bertha feels utterly lost without Brenda. She doesn't know what she'll do with her daughter's porcelain dolls; she doesn't want to give her books to a library in case they are destroyed. "I find at the moment I can have a longer lie in bed," she attempts to joke. Her voice cracks. "I used to have to get up at half past five; this morning I didn't get up until nine o'clock."

webTitle: Dear doctor: Dr Ann Robinson

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.trailText: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.body:
An earful of wax

Q: I am forever fishing large globs of wax out of my ears. If I leave it to gather, as my wife says I should, my ears hurt and I get progressively more deaf. When the wax build up becomes unbearable, the practice nurse syringes them for me. Last time I went, the GP sent me away with a flea in my ear, saying syringing is potentially harmful and not warranted. Is he right?

A: We naturally extrude our ear wax onto our pillows, collars and friends and shouldn't need artificial irrigation to remove it. Using a hearing aid, earplugs or cotton buds will all tend to push wax further into the ear. Syringing is offered by most GP surgeries but there is no evidence that it does more good than harm. I love syringing ears and was distressed to learn that I may be causing ear irritation, dizziness, perforated eardrums, pain and tinnitus. Fancier methods of wax removal involving microscopes, probes, suction and forceps are usually only available in hospital ENT departments and are similarly unproven. Wax softening drops all seem to work fairly well with fewer side effects than syringing. Nearly a third of wax-blocked ears will clear themselves within five days if left alone.

I can't stop him crying

Q: My three-month-old baby is happy and playful all day. At six in the evening, he starts crying and doesn't stop until we all fall asleep exhausted at around midnight. He's putting on weight and has been seen by my GP, health visitor and a paediatrician, all of whom say he's fine! I'm resigned to the fact that it's colic but am worn out, fed up and at my wits' end every evening. Any suggestions?

A: Babies grow out of colic by the age of five months, but parents and carers may take much longer to recover from the strain and sleeplessness. Any baby can get colic, which is defined as crying that lasts over three hours at least three times a week in an otherwise healthy baby. Experts don't know what causes colic - some say it's just that some babies cry more than others and it's no more abnormal than babies who happen to cry very little. webTitle: Nintendo rethinks £20m ad account

fields.headline: Nintendo rethinks £20m ad account
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Nintendo is reviewing its £20m pan-European advertising account currently held by Leagas Delaney, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Nintendo is reviewing its entire pan-European advertising account, worth at least £20m, currently held by Leagas Delaney.

The review comes in advance of the launch later this year of its next generation games console, Gamecube.

In December the company revealed it was looking for an agency to launch Gamecube in the UK, but the latest review is thought to include the wider range of products including the new Game Boy Advance hand-held console and the Pokemon range of video games.

Both David Gosen, Nintendo Europe's managing director of sales and marketing, and Leagas Delaney were unavailable for comment but it is understood that Nintendo is in talks with at least three London agencies about its account.

Shortly after his own appointment from BSkyB in August 1999, Mr Gosen consolidated Nintendo's strategic and creative account into Leagas Delaney.

Since then Nintendo has faced even fiercer competition with its rivals launching their next generation offerings.

Late in 1999 Sega launched its Dreamcast console and more recently Sony introduced its PlayStation 2 format.

Microsoft is also gearing up to bring its Xbox gaming console to market in 2002.

webTitle: Can Saddam be tackled without sanctions?

fields.headline: Can Saddam be tackled without sanctions?
fields.standfirst:
As sanctions against Iraq are being reconsidered, Guardian diplomatic editor Ewen MacAskill asks what they've achieved and examines possible future approaches to Saddam's regime

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: As sanctions against Iraq are being reconsidered, Guardian diplomatic editor Ewen MacAskill asks what they've achieved and examines possible future approaches to Saddam's regime.
fields.body:
A fundamental review of sanctions against Iraq is under way in London and Washington, 10 years after they were imposed at the start of the Gulf war.

The sanctions have been criticised by many - including United Nations staff who worked in Baghdad - for their appalling impact on the civilian population.

But they are also becoming increasingly irrelevant, ignored by neighbouring countries.

Two questions now need answering. What is the point of continuing with sanctions and what could they be replaced by?

The Iraqi leadership is treating the tenth anniversary as if Baghdad had won the war, with a "victory" speech by president Saddam Hussein planned.

Given that Iraq was forced out of Kuwait and suffered terrible losses to its army, this defiance seems misplaced.

But neither Iraq's military defeat nor the ensuing economic sanctions have diminished Saddam, who has emerged over the last six months as strong as he has ever been.

The UN sanctions, pursued enthusiastically now only by the US and Britain, are chaotic. The alliance of Western and Arab countries that supported their imposition a decade ago has broken down.

Sanctions-busting by fellow Arab countries, as well as Russia and France, has become so commonplace that it no longer makes news.

The land borders too have become so porous that Iraqis with money can get almost anything they want. Lowly Iraqi officials, even in small towns, have access to the latest computers, supposedly on the list of banned goods.

The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, in a press statement to coincide with the anniversary of the outbreak of the war, said: "It is high time to revisit the sanctions policy against Iraq.

"If British companies are already in negotiations for lucrative contracts [*reference needs explaining - today's story in the paper], then the days of wholesale sanctions are clearly numbered."

The Foreign Office and, in particular, the minister of state, Peter Hain, are touchy about any suggestion that the sanctions policy might have failed or that they are conducting a review of the policy. They fear that any changes will be seen as weakness.

A Foreign Office spokesman said that there was a widespread misapprehension about the purpose of sanctions. Many believe they were imposed to topple Saddam and, by that measurement, sanctions had obviously failed.

But the spokesman insisted that the purpose was containment and that the sanctions had been successful in preventing Saddam from rebuilding his arsenal of weapons of mass destruction.

The sanctions policy has already undergone changes. The sanctions no longer cover absolutely everything and, over the last few years, more consideration has been given to the humanitarian concerns, freeing up Iraqi oil revenue for food.

What further changes take place depends on the new US administration of George W Bush. The Foreign Office likes to maintain the fiction that its policies are independent of the US and, in some areas they are, such as re-establishing links with countries including Iran and Libya.

However, over Iraq, the Foreign Office is waiting to see what the US administration comes up with.

The Foreign Office is putting forward a number of proposals to Washington, including an end to the US and British bombing of Iraq's southern border and a shift in emphasis in sanctions to more specific targets, such as a ban on military equipment.

The present buzzword for this selective approach is "smart" sanctions.

Mr Bush is likely to opt for a tougher approach to Iraq than Bill Clinton. He comes with a lot of baggage: it was his father who prosecuted the war and his secretary of state, Colin Powell, who led the anti-Iraq alliance.

In the meantime, Saddam has become stronger, mainly as a result of the hostility in Arab countries towards Israel since the start of the Palestinian uprising in September. It is a time for Arabs to unite, even with Saddam.

The policy of sanctions towards Iraq is busted, but the US and Britain still have to work out an alternative approach.

Engagement with the rest of the world, encouraging Iraqis to travel and have access to the world's media, seems like a sensible way of undermining the regime, but neither Washington nor London appears enamoured of that route.

The US and Britain see Saddam as a danger to the Middle East and the world in general, and they will try to keep him contained. The policy might change but that objective will remain the same.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, is due to hold talks with Baghdad in February to discuss ways of ending UN sanctions by allowing UN weapons inspectors back into Iraq.

In the past, Saddam has always opposed the return of the weapons inspectors. He may be more inclined to accept them now, as he would be agreeing from a position not of weakness but of strength.

If this happened, sanctions would be lifted within months.

webTitle: Equality still a long way off

fields.headline: Equality still a long way off
fields.standfirst: Equal Opportunities Commission chairwoman Julie Mellor looks at what has been accomplished in the 25 years since the Equal Pay and Sex Discrimination Acts, and outlines what needs to be done in the future to guarantee real equality
fields.trailText: Comment Equal Opportunities Commission chairwoman Julie Mellor looks at what has been accomplished in the 25 years since the Equal Pay and Sex Discrimination Acts, and outlines what needs to be done in the future to guarantee real equality
fields.body:
Twenty-five years ago women were still very definitely second-class citizens. They could still be sacked and excluded from jobs simply because of pregnancy, or just for being female. Women were seen as mothers and housewives first and employees second. Men's jobs were far more important because they were seen as the breadwinners.

We have had laws to protect against sex discrimination for 25 years, but we still don't have real equality for women and men. Research the EOC published last week shows that women do not receive the same pay and bonuses as men and as many as 12% of part-time workers do not have access to occupational pension schemes. This despite the fact that it is illegal under the Sex Discrimination Act to exclude part timers from benefits enjoyed by full timers.

Legislation doesn't necessarily guarantee equality or hold all the answers - we also need changes in attitudes, values and working practices. One area ripe for change is to stop making women feeling guilty for not being at home when they are working to provide for their families financially. It's time to recognise that both sexes work and both sexes look after their families.

The government's green paper, Work and Parents, is a step in right direction. Our top priority is to improve the rate of maternity pay, as well as giving flexibility for both parents to take time off work when they need to.

We need to recognise that work and home and the interests of women and men are inextricably linked. British fathers work the longest hours in Europe and many are prevented from spending time with their children. Yet work-life balance is still seen as a women's issue.

In Parliament, working hours of more than 60 hours a week exclude men as well as women. The new institutions of Scotland and Wales are leading the way because they don't work during school holidays or hold debates late into the night. Family-friendly policies must be at the heart of the modernisation agenda for all public bodies.

Women have made a great deal of progress in education but now attention is focused on boys' underachievement. Equality is about both sexes being able to fulfil their potential. It is not a battle between the sexes - that view is part of the problem. We need to raise the achievement level of boys and girls and help girls and boys make informed choices from a wide range of subject and job options.

Parents have an important part to play too. Our focus group research tells us parents who express strong support for equality still tend to treat their sons and daughters differently. Equal opportunities is not put into practice either at work or at home.

In her article in the Guardian, Yvonne Roberts says over time the critical mass of women entering the workplace will bring about change. I believe change won't happen as long as women remain in low-paid, low-status jobs and this won't change until men are more active at home. To break the lifecycle of inequality we need to change attitudes, values and working practices. We have drawn up a 10-point vision aimed not just at government but individuals, parents and employers. It's time to change the rules.

webTitle: BBC appoints Salmon to race job

fields.headline: BBC appoints Salmon to race job
fields.standfirst: Jan 15: Journalists target minorities
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: The BBC has appointed Peter Salmon as diversity champion for race., writes Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 15: Journalists target minorities
fields.body:
The BBC has appointed Peter Salmon to step into the position vacated by Tony Hall, of diversity champion for race.

The board-level appointment comes a week after the director general, Greg Dyke, launched a high-profile attack on the ethnic make-up of the corporation, which he described as "hideously white".

Joy Francis, a former Pride editor and founder of the Creative Collective - a journalists' pressure group aimed at boosting recruitment from ethnic minorities - said she welcomed Mr Dyke's initiative, but criticised the BBC for "leaving itself open to further accusations of racism".

Ms Francis said that although the Collective did not object to the race adviser being white, she said that "they could always have delayed the announcement until they found the appropriate person".

Mr Salmon, the BBC's director of sport and a former controller of BBC1, will take over from Mr Hall when he leaves the corporation in April.

Mr Dyke wants to boost the levels of black and Asian senior management staff from 2% to 4% by the end of next year.

Ms Francis said "After Greg Dyke's frustrated outburst about the lack of ethnic minority staff in management roles, it seems at odds with this to appoint a champion of diversity who is a senior, white male manager."

She added: "If they were doing their job as an equal opportunities employer seriously, they wouldn't need quotas."

A BBC spokesman said that the diversity champion for race needed to come from the executive committee and there was no black or Asian executive at this level.

Broadcaster Trevor Phillips said Mr Salmon was "a good choice".

Mr Phillips said: "It doesn't matter if he's white as long as he's got the guns to make things happen.

"We'll have to see whether he really does make things happen."

webTitle: Bodies in chapel chief was no 'scapegoat'

fields.headline: Bodies in chapel chief was no 'scapegoat'
fields.trailText: NHS officials have denied they made a "scapegoat" of the chief executive allegedly forced to resign over the Bedford hospital scandal and say the inicident was not due to underfunding.
fields.body:
NHS officials have denied they made a "scapegoat" of the chief executive allegedly forced to resign over the Bedford hospital "bodies in the chapel" scandal.

They rejected claims made by senior hospital doctors that the incident - where several bodies were left on the floor of a hospital chapel because of mortuary storage problems - was caused by NHS underfunding.

Consultants at the hospital claimed the incident had occurred because money earmarked for pathology services had been directed into meeting government waiting list targets, and that trust chief executive Ken Williams had been "forced" to take the blame.

Today the NHS confederation expressed reservations that Mr Williams had been so swiftly moved from the job before an official inquiry into the affair had been completed.

But Peter Houghton, eastern regional director of the NHS executive, defended the decision: "This was not a matter of funding. There was more than appropriate capacity for the bodies of dead patients to be kept in appropriate conditions at the mortuary. This was a problem that could have been easily solved and needed to be dealt with straight away.

"I understand the consultants are claiming that Ken Williams has been made a scapegoat in this matter. The plain fact is that at the end of the day the chief executive is the accountable officer. Being an honourable man, Ken Williams recognised this and agreed he should stand down."

Mr Williams told reporters on Monday afternoon, the day the story broke, that he was not going to resign. But two hours later, NHS officials said he had "agreed" to step down.

His departure followed massive press and media coverage of the story, including a Mirror picture of the bodies in the chapel which resulted in the identification of one of the bodies by relatives.

Richard Rawlins, a surgeon at Bedford hospital and a member of the British Medical Association's consultants' committee, said the incident reflected wider problems in the NHS. He said: "This is not new and not confined to our hospital, if you went to any hospital around the country you would see the same thing.

"It does concern us and what makes consultants angry is this scapegoating of management out of political expediency. It is not their fault and it not just a problem of money. The money is there but it is a question of priorities." He added: "The problem is that managers are not being able to spend the money in the way they want.

"The government forces the managers to spend the money on political initiatives such as the waiting list initiative, rather than on improving pathology facilities.

"We see pathology as a priority but Mr Milburn [health secretary] would rather it was spent on treating non-urgent cases within 18 months. We would rather see the money spent on people already in our care, whether dead or alive, than on people who are yet to be treated."

Shadow health secretary Dr Liam Fox called for an independent inquiry into the incident. He said: "The resignation of the chief executive does not remove the need for an independent inquiry.

"We have evidence that these practices have been going on for at least three years and that there are major management problems in this hospital which require detailed investigation

"Any such investigation must be completely independent, with outside bodies scrutinising all aspects of the direction of management and any political interference in clinical priorities and the treatment of patients.

"This is given fresh impetus by the revelations of Dr Rawlins, who indicated that funding was available for better mortuary facilities but it was being diverted into the government's waiting list initiative to satisfy Tony Blair's demands."

Mr Williams was not available for comment last night. A spokeswoman for the hospital said the chapel of rest was used because the hospital's temporary mortuary, designed to be used when the mortuary was full, was broken.

She said it was used on a number of days last week and up to eight bodies were laid out in the chapel, none for more than 24 hours.

Mr Houghton said: "It appears that this has happened on rare occasions in the past when the mortuary was full."

He said Department of Health guidance insisted that patients should be treated "with respect and dignity" and "that was certainly not the case at the hospital last week". He said: "On this occasion, despite having a temporary mortuary available, bodies were stored on the floor in totally inappropriate conditions.

"The reason the additional temporary facility was not being used was because of problems with the doors, not because there were no places available. This problem had caused a porter to injure himself.

"No policies or procedures for dealing with a full mortuary were in place. The decision and the reasons behind it were not raised with senior management of the hospital."
fields.bodyText: NHS officials have denied they made a "scapegoat" of the chief executive allegedly forced to resign over the Bedford hospital "bodies in the chapel" scandal. They rejected claims made by senior hospital doctors that the incident - where several bodies were left on the floor of a hospital chapel because of mortuary storage problems - was caused by NHS underfunding. Consultants at the hospital claimed the incident had occurred because money earmarked for pathology services had been directed into meeting government waiting list targets, and that trust chief executive Ken Williams had been "forced" to take the blame. Today the NHS confederation expressed reservations that Mr Williams had been so swiftly moved from the job before an official inquiry into the affair had been completed. But Peter Houghton, eastern regional director of the NHS executive, defended the decision: "This was not a matter of funding. There was more than appropriate capacity for the bodies of dead patients to be kept in appropriate conditions at the mortuary. This was a problem that could have been easily solved and needed to be dealt with straight away. "I understand the consultants are claiming that Ken Williams has been made a scapegoat in this matter. The plain fact is that at the end of the day the chief executive is the accountable officer. Being an honourable man, Ken Williams recognised this and agreed he should stand down." Mr Williams told reporters on Monday afternoon, the day the story broke, that he was not going to resign. But two hours later, NHS officials said he had "agreed" to step down. His departure followed massive press and media coverage of the story, including a Mirror picture of the bodies in the chapel which resulted in the identification of one of the bodies by relatives. Richard Rawlins, a surgeon at Bedford hospital and a member of the British Medical Association's consultants' committee, said the incident reflected wider problems in the NHS. He said: "This is not new and not confined to our hospital, if you went to any hospital around the country you would see the same thing. "It does concern us and what makes consultants angry is this scapegoating of management out of political expediency. It is not their fault and it not just a problem of money. The money is there but it is a question of priorities." He added: "The problem is that managers are not being able to spend the money in the way they want. "The government forces the managers to spend the money on political initiatives such as the waiting list initiative, rather than on improving pathology facilities. "We see pathology as a priority but Mr Milburn [health secretary] would rather it was spent on treating non-urgent cases within 18 months. We would rather see the money spent on people already in our care, whether dead or alive, than on people who are yet to be treated." Shadow health secretary Dr Liam Fox called for an independent inquiry into the incident. He said: "The resignation of the chief executive does not remove the need for an independent inquiry. "We have evidence that these practices have been going on for at least three years and that there are major management problems in this hospital which require detailed investigation "Any such investigation must be completely independent, with outside bodies scrutinising all aspects of the direction of management and any political interference in clinical priorities and the treatment of patients. "This is given fresh impetus by the revelations of Dr Rawlins, who indicated that funding was available for better mortuary facilities but it was being diverted into the government's waiting list initiative to satisfy Tony Blair's demands." Mr Williams was not available for comment last night. A spokeswoman for the hospital said the chapel of rest was used because the hospital's temporary mortuary, designed to be used when the mortuary was full, was broken. She said it was used on a number of days last week and up to eight bodies were laid out in the chapel, none for more than 24 hours. Mr Houghton said: "It appears that this has happened on rare occasions in the past when the mortuary was full." He said Department of Health guidance insisted that patients should be treated "with respect and dignity" and "that was certainly not the case at the hospital last week". He said: "On this occasion, despite having a temporary mortuary available, bodies were stored on the floor in totally inappropriate conditions. "The reason the additional temporary facility was not being used was because of problems with the doors, not because there were no places available. This problem had caused a porter to injure himself. "No policies or procedures for dealing with a full mortuary were in place. The decision and the reasons behind it were not raised with senior management of the hospital."

webTitle: Couple fights to keep twins adopted on internet

fields.headline: Couple fights to keep twins adopted on internet
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A British couple is fighting to retain custody of two six-month-old girls after they paid £8,200 to an online California-based adoption agent for the twins.
fields.body:
A British couple is fighting to retain custody of two six-month-old girls after they paid £8,200 to an online California-based adoption agent for the twins.

Alan and Judith Kilshaw of Buckley, north Wales, travelled to the US in November to buy the baby girls from adoption agent Tina Johnson after the couple saw her advertisement on the internet.

But Johnson, who runs online adoption agency Caring Hearts, had previously sold the twins to another couple, Richard and Vickie Allen of San Bernadino, California, for £4,000. The Allens are now demanding that the Kilshaws return the girls.

In what they say is an attempt to warn other prospective clients about the dangers of paying to adopt children abroad, the Kilshaws told their story to the Sun newspaper. They said that when they arrived in San Diego last year, they paid an arrangement fee to Tina Johnson and took possession of the twins, who they named Belinda and Kimberley.

The twins had been put up for adoption by their natural mother, Tranda Wecker, 28, of St Louis, Missouri. Ms Wecker and Ms Johnson allegedly tricked the Allens into handing the twins back to Ms Wecker, telling the couple that the mother wanted a couple of days alone with her daughters to say goodbye.

Instead, Johnson handed the babies over to the Kilshaws. When confronted by the Allens' in-laws, the couple fled with the twins and Ms Wecker to Arkansas, a state with more relaxed adoption laws than California. There they finalised the adoption before travelling back to the UK at the end of December.

The Allens have contacted the FBI to investigate the matter. Meanwhile, the girls are living with the Kilshaws in Buckley on six-month holiday visas. The couple say they will fight to retain custody of the twins.

Felicity Collier, chief executive of British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, says: "This case demonstrates why private adoption is illegal in the UK.

"We often hear criticisms by prospective adopters about the checks that are carried out before adoptive parents are considered suitable and comparisons are made with the ease with which people can adopt in the US."

She adds: "It is totally unacceptable to BAAF that children are sold to the highest bidder. It is vital that people who wish to adopt from overseas take proper advice before they enter such a minefield."

webTitle: Express website staff to sue for redundancy

fields.headline: Express website staff to sue for redundancy
fields.standfirst:
Timetable of events
More Express stories
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: Express website staff have confirmed they will go ahead with legal action, reports Amy Vickers.
Timetable of events
More Express stories
fields.body:
Staff from the now defunct Express Newspapers websites confirmed today that they will go ahead with legal action to secure redundancy payments.

The 46 Express Digital Media staff, who have not been paid since December 15, claim that there has been a cynical legal ploy of "pass the parcel" with their contracts to avoid making redundancy payments.

They are seeking full contractual and redundancy payments from Express Newspapers and administrator Seymour Pierce.

Michael Streeter, spokesman for EDM, said: "We have had a very positive meeting with Thompsons, who are among the best employment lawyers in the country, and we are delighted that legal action can go ahead.

"The more we find out about what has happened to our websites, the stranger it gets. Some of the things that went on are straight out of Alice in Wonderland."

The websites, Express.co.uk, Sportlive.co.uk, Allaboutparents and Companyleader, were put into liquidation on January 9.

Former Express Digital Media staff claim the sale of the sites was designed to avoid paying staff their dues. They are backed by their trades unions, the National Union of Journalists and the Graphical, Paper & Media Union.

The liquidation of the Express Digital Media businesses means that neither United Business Media, Express Newspapers nor Seymour Pierce are liable to pay redundancies.

Instead, the burden falls on the taxpayer by way of small statutory redundancy pay.

webTitle: Timetable of events at EDM

fields.headline: Timetable of events
fields.standfirst: A summary of events at Express Digital Media
fields.trailText:
November 22 2000:
Lord Hollick, chief executive of United News & Media, sells Express Digital Media to Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell along with Express Newspapers. EDM's 46 staff are surprised as they had previously been told they would stay with Hollick's internet group, Xilerate. Both United News & Media and Northern & Shell assure staff that their employment contracts and existing terms and conditions will be honoured.
fields.body:
November 22 2000:
Lord Hollick, chief executive of United News & Media, sells Express Digital Media to Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell along with Express Newspapers. EDM's 46 staff are surprised as they had previously been told they would stay with Hollick's internet group, Xilerate. Both United News & Media and Northern & Shell assure staff that their employment contracts and existing terms and conditions will be honoured.

November 24:
The 46 staff are warned by Northern & Shell that the websites may be closed.

November 30:
Northern & Shell issues letters to the 46 staff, signalling the start of a "consultation" period with a view to redundancy and closure of sites.

December 13:
First consultation between N&S and staff representatives, NUJ and GPMU Unions. N&S confirms that EDM staff are all employees of Express Newspapers.

December 14:
Representatives of Seymour Pierce, a firm of stockbrokers, arrive at EDM office at 5.30pm and announce that EDM has been acquired by SP Investments, an offshoot of Seymour Pierce, which was registered in Guernsey just hours before. Seymour Pierce says it intends to find buyers for the sites, but denies any connection with Richard Desmond or Northern & Shell. The sites are suspended and staff are put on paid "gardening leave". EDM staff are given letters assuring them that their employment contracts will be honoured, should they be made redundant following a 30-day consultation period.

December 15:
Express Newspapers pays 46 staff their salaries but withdraw the funds hours later. Seymour Pierce then pay staff their net salaries but do not pay tax, national insurance or any other contributions. 18 EDM representatives meet executives from Seymour Pierce/SP Investments at the latter's offices, with questions relating to the future of the business.

January 5 2001:
A spokesman for SP Investments tells the media that rumours that EDM will be put into liquidation are "a load of bollocks". He adds that a deal with potential buyers is "weeks away". Later that day SP Investments applies to put EDM into liquidation. Since December 18, neither the EDM staff or their representatives have received any communication from SP Investments and no consultation has taken place.

January 8:
EDM staff discover, via a creditor, that SP Investments has applied to put EDM into liquidation. Phone calls to SP Investments are not returned. Receiver confirms to EDM staff that the application has been made. Contrary to written assurances given by SP Investments, staff will not receive salaries due on 15 January, nor any notice payments to which they are entitled under the terms of their employment contracts. Similar assurances about honouring the notice and redundancy terms set out in staff employment contracts had been given by United Business Media and Northern & Shell.

January 9:
Liquidation granted.

webTitle: Government 'ahead of online targets'

fields.headline: Government 'ahead of online targets'
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: The government claims it it is more than a year ahead of its internet targets with 40% of services online, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The government has jumped on the latest batch of internet numbers from the National Statistics Office and hailed itself as more than a year ahead of its online targets.

More than 40% of government services are now on the internet, claims the report, a figure already way ahead of the prime minister's modest target of delivering 25% of government services electronically by 2002.

Targets have now been revised to a more ambitious goal of 75% of government services being online by 2002.

The research also revealed that nearly one in five adults who use the internet have accessed government services.

"There is much work still to be done, but new technology is helping us turn public services inside out," said Cabinet Office minister Ian McCartney.

"For the first time they'll be organised around the convenience of the citizen - from small businesses and young mothers to victims of crime - rather than the bureaucracy of government."

The government is investing more than £1bn over the next three years to support the drive.

In the coming months, new services such as interactive TV travel advice and online applications for enterprise grants will be added to the range of services the government already provides.

webTitle: Dailly joins West Ham in £1.75m deal

fields.headline: Dailly joins West Ham in £1.75m deal
fields.trailText: Christian Dailly is to join West Ham, manager Harry Redknapp has revealed - just hours after claiming the player was about to sign for Everton.
fields.body:
Christian Dailly is to join West Ham, manager Harry Redknapp has revealed - just hours after claiming the player was about to sign for Everton.

Leicester had also been chasing the Scottish international defender, but after spending four days mulling over his decision, Dailly has finally decided to go to Upton Park in a £1.75m deal.

Redknapp told Sky Sports.com TV: "He's going to come to West Ham. I'm very pleased - he's a good player and a Scottish international.

"There was talk of Leicester and Everton being interested and I just left it to the lad. I let him make his own decision in his own time. I think the other offers were the same as ours so it was just a football decision.

"We have spent £5m of the Rio Ferdinand money [£18m] and got three players with that, and I think we now have a better squad."

But earlier today Harry Redknapp was in much more melancholy mood, telling the official West Ham website that Dailly would choose Everton as his new club.

"There's no good news at all," he told them. "It looks like Dailly is going elsewhere, to Everton, which was always a possibility as it's nearer home for him.

"It's amazing how suddenly Everton and Leicester appeared after it became news that we were going to buy him. But what can you do, you know? You've just got to get on with it and see what happens."

Dailly, who joined Blackburn from Derby in a £5.3m deal in 1998, looks likely to make his first appearance for West Ham against Charlton on Monday night.

webTitle: TV ratings January 15

fields.headline: BBC bulletin hits new low
fields.trailText: 1.15pm TV overnights: BBC1 last night suffered its lowest ratings yet for its 10pm news bulletin, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
BBC1 last night suffered its lowest ratings yet for its new 10pm news broadcast, giving ITV bosses cause for optimism as the two gear up for a head-to-head news battle next week.

Just 3.4m viewers tuned in to the BBC's main evening bulletin, giving it a share of 14%.

The news came on top of a lacklustre performance last week, with the Ten O'Clock News drawing audiences of fewer than 5m every night to give it an average share of just 20.4% - equal to its current lowest average to date.

Only last week the BBC was claiming a ratings victory in its decision to axe its Nine O'Clock News and replace it with a 10pm bulletin.

Ratings are expected to suffer when ITV's News at Ten returns on January 22.

Elsewhere yesterday, the US blockbuster movie Jumanji, broadcast at 8.25pm on BBC1, notched up a respectable 6.7m viewers to give it a share of 25%.

But the success story of the evening was ITV's A Touch of Frost, which attracted 13.4m viewers to give it more than half of the total peak-time audience.

The Weakest Link continues to be BBC2's star performer in spite of its 5.15pm slot. Yesterday the show attracted 4.5m viewers, making it the highest-rating show of the afternoon.

webTitle: De Beers stores promise 'exclusivity and energy'

fields.headline: De Beers stores promise 'exclusivity and energy'
fields.standfirst: Jan 16: De Beers opens branded shops
fields.trailText:
1.45pm update: Today's De Beers/LVMH marketing pact heralds a new style of global jewellery store, reports Daniel Rogers.
Jan 16: De Beers opens branded shops
fields.body:
The De Beers/LVMH marketing pact announced today will herald a new style of global jewellery store, according to leading design consultants.

De Beers has confirmed that it is rolling out a string of branded "flagship" jewellers in the world's most prestigious cities.

Rita Clifton, chief executive of brand consultancy Interbrand, believes there is a clear gap in the market for a modern jeweller to compete with stuffy traditional outlets.

"English jewellers such as Tiffany's or Asprey have a rather hushed, referential atmosphere and there is potential to create a store which combines exclusivity with more energy," she said. "Here it can learn from LVMH's Louis Vuitton shop.

"De Beers has transformed the marketing of diamonds from commodities to products which are surrounded by an emotional buying experience. It must now move to the next stage which is the service accompanying the purchase."

Atoosa Afshar, European retail marketing manager for Fitch, agreed. She said: "LVMH has proven itself to be passionate about innovation.

"The Louis Vuitton brand was dormant but LVMH has modernised it to become young and relevant. It is now one of the most sought after brands among young people.

"Attitudes to luxury are changing and brands need to be more accessible to a wider audience. It's going to be about creating a new retail experience in this sector," she added.

However, Ms Clifton of Interbrand issued a word of warning to the wider De Beers Group, which is based on huge mining interests in Southern Africa.

"De Beers must consider some of the darker political issues nestling in the background and ensure its working practices are as clean as possible, right through to its backyard."

webTitle: BT set to sell Airtel stake

fields.headline: BT set to sell Airtel stake
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Telecoms giant BT is set to dump its stake in Spanish operator Airtel before the end of the year, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telecoms giant BT is set to dump its stake in Spanish operator Airtel before the end of the year as part of its debt reduction plans.

A BT spokesman confirmed that it was in talks with main shareholder Vodafone and the Airtel management to offload its 17.8% stake through a flotation.

"We reckon that it should go ahead as soon as possible and before the end of the calendar year," said the spokesman.

"If disposing of our holding is right for us, then we will do it, but there is a long way to go yet."

BT recently announced the partial sale of its property portfolio, which is expected to shave £2bn off its £30bn debt burden.

Today's announcement underlines that minority stakes in its European interests are next in the firing line, although BT says it remains committed to the west European market.

The spokesman said an Airtel share offering would not clash with its planned flotation of BT Wireless, its mobile phone subsidiary.

BT is already facing competition for investors' funds from Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom, which are floating their wireless operations this year.

webTitle: MG Rover turns the corner

fields.headline: MG Rover turns the corner
fields.standfirst: Longbridge hopes middle-range car will put it into profit next year
fields.trailText: MG Rover, the car group that used to embody Britain's industrial decline, is on track to return to profitability next year, and is planning to assert its independence by designing and building a new medium-sized car on its own, according to its new chief executive.
fields.body:
MG Rover, the car group that used to embody Britain's industrial decline, is on track to return to profitability next year, and is planning to assert its independence by designing and building a new medium-sized car on its own, according to its new chief executive.

Kevin Howe said yesterday the group should make a small profit in 2002 after slashing the large losses it inherited from BMW. In 1999, the last full year in German ownership, Rover, including Land Rover which is now part of Ford, lost some £840m. But the now cash-rich car company expects to reduce its own losses to below £100m this year.

Speaking at the Longbridge plant near Birmingham, where a new R75 body shop began production yesterday, Mr Howe said sales this year should be around 190,000 compared with 205,000 in 2000 and should rise to "in excess" of 210,000 in 2002.

Mr Howe said it should begin trading profitably early next year after launching three new MG saloons, variants of the MGF sports car, and a R75 estate over the next few months. The "performance gap" will have to be closed by trading.

From 2004 MG Rover has to start repaying some of the around £500m interest-free loan given by BMW to the 4-man consortium that bought the group, valued at £749m, for a nominal £10 last year.

The loan paid in instalments does not become due until 2049 but, if Rover becomes profitable, it will, in 3 years, pay £25m or 25% of its annual earnings - whichever is the lesser amount - to BMW.

Rover also stands to gain more money from the Bavar ian-based group when agreement is reached on its entire assets and liabilities. But Mr Howe said that the group needed no external financing as it had ended last year with more cash than when it started. Output of the R25 and R45 will remain constant at 2,600 a week but that of the R75, the upmarket model, will rise from the current 600 to 945 in March and 1,200 in September.

The key decision on Rover's future - how to design and fund a new £250-£300m medium-sized car to replace the R25 and R45 series - will be taken in the first half of 2001, with production planned for 2004. Rover is said to be seeking a collaboration agreement with Malaysia's Proton car company, to produce a new platform (basic frame of chassis and engine compartment) - and win economies of scale from common components.

But Mr Howe said this was only one of four options and indicated a strong preference for "going it alone". "It is the best front-wheeled platform in the world and designed to spawn other products. We could probably shorten it and develop an excellent medium car off it," he said. "Early art designs show it looks great and is technologically great."

Another option would be to develop it with a supplier but Mr Howe said: "We could develop that ourselves. And our business cost planning assumes we pay for everything ourselves." Rover now employs just under 5,500 and could hire more labour later this year.

Unions at Vauxhall are planning a ballot on industrial action at the decision to end car production at Luton with the loss of 2,200 jobs. Conciliatory talks with General Motors senior executives in Zurich yesterday were fruitless.

webTitle: Ministers urged to set up inquiry into Gulf war syndrome

fields.headline: Ministers urged to set up inquiry into Gulf war syndrome
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Gulf war veterans today renewed their calls for a public inquiry into the health hazards associated with the depleted uranium weapons used in the conflict.
fields.body:
Gulf war veterans today renewed their calls for a public inquiry into the health hazards associated with the depleted uranium weapons used in the conflict.

The Royal British Legion and the National Gulf Veterans and Families Association urged ministers to act over the illnesses they say have hit many soldiers.

Operation Desert Storm, the international mission to liberate Kuwait, began 10 years ago today. In the period since, veterans have reported chronic fatigue, hair loss and various types of cancer that they attribute to depleted uranium (DU) weapons.

Defence chiefs insist there is no evidence of a "Gulf war syndrome", or that the DU shells cause illness. However, Italy, Germany and Greece have all pushed for a moratorium on the use of the weapons.

More than 100,000 DU shells were fired during the Gulf war, to knock out Iraqi armour. Approximately 30,000 were fired in the 1999 Kosovo conflict and a further 10,000 in the latter stages of allied operations in Bosnia.

Soldiers from Italy, France, Belgium and Portugal who served in the Balkans have also been diagnosed with cancer, especially leukaemia.

The Royal British Legion urged ministers not to wait for a link to be proved before setting up a public inquiry.

"The government could remedy its past failure to act openly in the interests of veterans and families," it said in a statement.

The association has launched an appeal to fund care and DU testing for sick veterans it claims have been abandoned by successive defence ministers.

Jan 16: A lorra viewers switch off
Top 30 TV shows of 2000
fields.body:
ITV bosses today said they were more than happy with the performance of Blind Date in the ratings.

A spokeswoman said Blind Date had gone up three places in the top 50 and maintained a following with generation after generation.

Of presenter Cilla Black she said: "Cilla is an entertainment phenomenon. She has maintained her position for 18 years. She is an absolute fixture of the entertainment scheduling and Blind Date has not noticeably dropped its share.

"That is why she keeps coming back."

webTitle: Competition: The school I'd like

fields.headline: The school I'd like
fields.standfirst: Dea Birkett on a competition which asks children what they  really want from school
fields.trailText: Dea Birkett on a competition which asks children what they really want from school
fields.body:
The movement for a fully comprehensive school system was being launched. "Youth culture" was said to be ruling Britain. The Boy's Own Paper folded and the pill became available on prescription, even to the unmarried. There were student sit-ins throughout the country and a massive Legalise Pot demonstration in Hyde Park. A controversial and outspoken teacher called Rhodes Boyson was set to take over the headship of the newly formed comprehensive Highbury Grove. Tony and Caroline Benn, redesigning themselves, were moving their children from Westminster preparatory school to Holland Park comprehensive. A report by the Comprehensive Schools Committee was to recommend that all direct grant schools be integrated into the comprehensive system. It was a time of immense educational change. Yet all of these changes - from the arrangement of the classes to the colour of the pencils - were being instituted by those who would never be taught at the establishments themselves. Adults.

This was the background against which, in November 1967, The Observer launched a competition called The School I'd Like. It was a radical idea in a revolutionary age. Young people were being asked to dream of, then design, their perfect school. The users of the system, not the controllers, were being consulted.

It was the heady late 60s, and the pupils were as idealistic as the era. They wanted to abolish exams and bells. They wanted to be able to dedicate themselves to a single piece of work for a whole week if it was important. Some said all teachers were to be retired before they grew too old, a suggested maximum age limit being 33, "so they would be in a position to advise on modern problems should a pupil require it". Literature teachers should be poets, geography teachers explorers, history teachers political activists. Relevance was everything: maths should be about income tax.

A 14-year-old from Manchester said, "Mrs McCormick would not tell us to read The Formation of a Cave, Chapter 22. Instead we would be taken to the Peak District and visit caves." And they almost all, without exception, wanted a fully comprehensive education system. A rebellious 17-year-old wrote: "Comprehensives without rules and streams and exams. Comprehensives with laughter and learning and communication. That's what I want, man. But it costs bread and that's needed for our next nuclear submarines." They were against all kinds of segregation, whether by sex, class or ability.

Their entries, almost 1,000, arrived in all forms - poems, plays, drawings, architectural plans, photo-essays, and an adolescent's thoughts: "Don't get panarchy, I don't want anarchy, Just sympathy, For the pimply."

Amongst these diverse entries was one by John Clifford, 17 years old and a boarding pupil at Clifton College, Bristol. "I hated my school. It was horrible, built on bullying, conformity and violence with a Christian gloss on it. So the competition was very important to me," he remembers. "I never told anyone at the school. It was about self-expression, self-affirmation. I was dreaming of being a writer, and had no self-confidence. My writing wasn't encouraged at school. It was immensely important that my writing get some sort of affirmation from outside." John Clifford was a winner in the 1967 School I'd Like. Now aged 50, he is an established playwright and lecturer in the drama department at Queen Margaret University College in Edinburgh.

Two years after the competition, in 1969, Penguin published a book of extracts from the entries, edited by Edward Blishen, a pioneer of the comprehensive system. A couple of years ago, Dr Ian Grosvenor, an historian at the School of Education at Birmingham University, came across a copy of this out-of-print paperback in a secondhand bookstore. He was intrigued. Together with a colleague, Catherine Burke, a lecturer at the School of Education at Bretton Hall College, they set up a discussion forum on the web about pupil input to school design. From this initiative, the Guardian has decided to run a second competition, a generation after the first, to give pupils a voice once more in their education. Using any form to express themselves - from digital imagery and videos to old-fashioned pen and ink - young people will again be able to design The School I'd Like. In 1967, the first prize was £25. Today, the winner will receive £10,000 worth of computer equipment for their school.

Apart from the prize, has anything actually changed since the first competition? "The institution of schooling changes less than other institutions," says Catherine Burke. "If someone fell asleep on an operating table 100 years ago and woke up now, they wouldn't recognise where they were. But if someone fell asleep at their school desk 100 years ago and woke up now, they'd see exactly the same elements. The blackboard, the desks, the person with all the knowledge at the front, children arranged in groups of age... In spite of all the experimentation, it has remained the same."

This competition is a chance for young people themselves to propose changes for the coming century. It is no easier a challenge than it was over 30 years ago. "At that time there was an element of experimentation in teaching, and teachers were more free to organise their teaching how they wanted during the day," says Burke. "Kids also have changed. They've been trained to see their schooling in a particular way. They ask things like, 'How would the competition benefit us? How will we fit it in?' Yet at the same time we have a government saying that it's important to have more democracy and participation in schools."

We hear much mumbling about the need to involve pupils in the educational process under schemes such as school councils. But a recent survey of over 2,000 school students by the Institute of Education showed that simply introducing a token council can increase children's scepticism. The forums for listening are still few and far between. "When we have the whole debate around education, which we do continually, we always ask the parents, we always consult the teachers' unions, we ask businesses. We still haven't got to the stage where the voice of the consumer, the person being processed, is actually heard," says Peter Facey, chief executive of the British Youth Council. "Some school councils are doing a good job at an individual school level. That's fine for micro changes. But when we're talking about fundamental changes affecting all school pupils, then they're not involved.

"There's nobody who can say, 'I'm a school pupil, I've been elected by my peers, and I can say x, y, z... And that's a big gap. We need a mechanism to consult on the major changes that affect every pupil."

Burke predicts that, in an atmosphere where pupil involvement occurs at this local level, there will be fewer proposals for grand schemes than in the first competition and more calls for small, incremental changes. "Pupils today are very interested in small details, such as the chairs. They wished their chairs were shaped in a different way and made more comfortable." The physical environment was also important to the original 1967 entrants and, with such a large stock of Victorian school buildings, probably still will be. There were pleas for trees, colours, comfort, common rooms and soundproofing. The physical and mental were considered inextricable from each other. "No engraved desks, arranged in ranks, or uniforms. How could you bear the drabness? Didn't you care that each child was an echo of his neighbour?" wrote 14-year-old Melanie.

Chris Watkins, a reader at the Institute of Education, paints a gloomy picture of the future of education from the pupil's perspective. He believes we fail to listen at our peril. "Much of the research on how you get higher achievements points to what the kids said in 1967 - more time for important work, and more pupil control. Yet everything has gone completely in the opposite direction to what the kids wanted," he said. The entrants of the 1967 competition clearly came out against exams. Yet they have not gone away, but become even more entrenched. The continued emphasis on results has led to a warping of educational priorities.

"The kids think they do the learning for their teachers nowadays, so they get good results for the school, not for themselves," he said. Watkins was recently sent to assess a new London secondary school. New schools are a rare opportunity to include pupil opinion from the outset, but it's an opportunity that is rarely taken up. "They had whiteboards instead of blackboards. Bells have been replaced, but simply by electronic buzzers, known as The Pips. It's just a Victorian model of learning dressed up as something else," says Watkins.

There is one way in which more children's views are being taken into account in this competition. In 1967, the competition was only open to secondary school pupils. This School I'd Like is open to every child. "The decision to ask the primary school child to comment on their schooling and voice their concerns, hopes, feelings and ideas for change comes as a natural today," says Burke.

But are we really ready to listen to all children? Peter Facey hopes so. "A school is never going to be run by pupils. We're not suggesting a revolution," he says. "But when we discuss standards, exams, the changes in education, there should be some attempt to involve pupils. They affect them more than they affect anybody else. There needs to be a change of attitude so that pupils have an active say in what's happening to them."

This second The School I'd Like competition is giving young people this chance. Perhaps, this time, we'll listen.

What you could win

Each winner will receive three Toshiba laptops, with back packs to carry them in, along with a digital camera and a projector, and a selection of compatible Microsoft software for their school. The total value of each prize is around £10,000. The runners-up will win digital cameras for their schools.

How to enter

Are you a pupil?

Is your school just as you want it to be? Or are there things you would change? Is the building right? Should you sit exams? Are you allowed to express yourself? Are uniforms a good thing? If there are things about your school you would like to change, here's your chance. Our competition is open to every pupil between the ages of five and 18. You can enter as an individual: simply complete our entry form (email education@theguardian.com with 'The School I'd Like' in the subject field) and send it with your entry to the freepost address provided by the closing date (Friday March 30).

Your entry can take any form. Simply tell us what your ideal school would be like, and tell us any way you like - write a poem or a play; paint a picture; make architectural plans or even a scale model; produce photo-essays, or a video. Or simply write an essay in good old pen and ink. A short poem can make the point as well as a huge project; an icon can be as emotive as a three-act play. What we are looking for is originality, imagination, vision and - above all - the genuine views of children and young people.

Are you a teacher?

We realise that teachers don't have much time to do work with children that falls outside the national curriculum. The beauty of The School I'd Like is that teachers can adapt it to suit their needs.

The opportunities for English, art or DT teachers are perhaps the most obvious. An English teacher could ask pupils for a poem or a piece of persuasive or polemical writing, a DT teacher could ask pupils to build a scale model, for example or draw a plan. But the competition also supports many other elements of the national curriculum: knowledge and understanding of places for geography key stage 2, for example, or developing skills of participation for citizenship at key stage 3.

You can think big, or think small. Pupils could be set the task as a one-off piece of homework (you could then submit the work of all the pupils in the class, or simply send us the best responses - either way, our judges will look at each piece of work as an individual entry, so ask pupils to write their name on the top of their work). Or you could be more ambitious. You could get a whole class to collaborate on a collective entry (if you do this, remember to ask one of the children to include a description of how this was accomplished).

What we are looking for is originality, imagination, vision and - above all - the genuine views of children and young people. By taking part, you and your pupils will be contributing to a new archive that is being set up at Bretton Hall College of the University of Leeds. All work submitted will be kept there and used as a basis for research. So even if your pupils do not win, their views will be heard and will remain as a record for future educationalists.

Are you a parent?

You could encourage your own child(ren) to enter as an individual (see Are you a pupil? above). The prize will be awarded to their school.

The categories

The competition is open to all children and young people aged five to 18. There are three categories: primary (years 1 to 6); lower secondary (years 7 to 9 inclusive); and upper secondary (years 10 to 13 inclusive). Multiple entries can be submitted using one entry form (see Are you a teacher, above) but each category entered must be accompanied by a separate entry form. Entries must reach us by the closing date.

The judges

The judges of The School I'd Like competition are: Tim Brighouse, Director of Education for Birmingham Education Authority; Lee Hall, writer of the hit film, Billy Elliott; Richard Lomer, head of government sales, Toshiba; Catherine Burke, lecturer in education, Bretton Hall College, University of Leeds; Becky Gardiner, editor of Education Guardian; and John Clifford, playwright and winner of the original 1967 Observer School I'd Like competition.

What next?

Now it's up to you. What do you think school should be like? How could it be better? What would you do differently? You can think big, you can think small. Whatever your ideas are, start talking, start planning, and then get to work. When your entry is ready, send it in to the freepost address provided below, accompanied by an entry form. If you are sending in multiple entries (eg, you are a teacher sending in individual entries from every member of your class) you only need to complete one entry form per category. And remember too that your entries need to be with us by Friday, March 30, 2001.

You can also order more forms by email - click here for more details. If you do, you must include your full postal address.

If you would like to discuss The School I'd Like competition with anyone, you can email Catherine Burke at: cburke@bretton.ac.uk.

We regret that your entries cannot be returned. They will remain the property of the Guardian and will be kept as an archive at Bretton Hall College of the University of Leeds. The details of winners and runners-up will be published in Education Guardian on Tuesday May 22, 2001.
