They've been trained to see their schooling in a particular way. They ask things like, 'How would the competition benefit us? How will we fit it in?' Yet at the same time we have a government saying that it's important to have more democracy and participation in schools." We hear much mumbling about the need to involve pupils in the educational process under schemes such as school councils. But a recent survey of over 2,000 school students by the Institute of Education showed that simply introducing a token council can increase children's scepticism. The forums for listening are still few and far between. "When we have the whole debate around education, which we do continually, we always ask the parents, we always consult the teachers' unions, we ask businesses. We still haven't got to the stage where the voice of the consumer, the person being processed, is actually heard," says Peter Facey, chief executive of the British Youth Council. "Some school councils are doing a good job at an individual school level. That's fine for micro changes. But when we're talking about fundamental changes affecting all school pupils, then they're not involved. "There's nobody who can say, 'I'm a school pupil, I've been elected by my peers, and I can say x, y, z... And that's a big gap. We need a mechanism to consult on the major changes that affect every pupil." Burke predicts that, in an atmosphere where pupil involvement occurs at this local level, there will be fewer proposals for grand schemes than in the first competition and more calls for small, incremental changes. "Pupils today are very interested in small details, such as the chairs. They wished their chairs were shaped in a different way and made more comfortable." The physical environment was also important to the original 1967 entrants and, with such a large stock of Victorian school buildings, probably still will be. There were pleas for trees, colours, comfort, common rooms and soundproofing. The physical and mental were considered inextricable from each other. "No engraved desks, arranged in ranks, or uniforms. How could you bear the drabness? Didn't you care that each child was an echo of his neighbour?" wrote 14-year-old Melanie. Chris Watkins, a reader at the Institute of Education, paints a gloomy picture of the future of education from the pupil's perspective. He believes we fail to listen at our peril. "Much of the research on how you get higher achievements points to what the kids said in 1967 - more time for important work, and more pupil control. Yet everything has gone completely in the opposite direction to what the kids wanted," he said. The entrants of the 1967 competition clearly came out against exams. Yet they have not gone away, but become even more entrenched. The continued emphasis on results has led to a warping of educational priorities. "The kids think they do the learning for their teachers nowadays, so they get good results for the school, not for themselves," he said. Watkins was recently sent to assess a new London secondary school. New schools are a rare opportunity to include pupil opinion from the outset, but it's an opportunity that is rarely taken up. "They had whiteboards instead of blackboards. Bells have been replaced, but simply by electronic buzzers, known as The Pips. It's just a Victorian model of learning dressed up as something else," says Watkins. There is one way in which more children's views are being taken into account in this competition. In 1967, the competition was only open to secondary school pupils. This School I'd Like is open to every child. "The decision to ask the primary school child to comment on their schooling and voice their concerns, hopes, feelings and ideas for change comes as a natural today," says Burke. But are we really ready to listen to all children? Peter Facey hopes so. "A school is never going to be run by pupils. We're not suggesting a revolution," he says. "But when we discuss standards, exams, the changes in education, there should be some attempt to involve pupils. They affect them more than they affect anybody else. There needs to be a change of attitude so that pupils have an active say in what's happening to them." This second The School I'd Like competition is giving young people this chance. Perhaps, this time, we'll listen. What you could win Each winner will receive three Toshiba laptops, with back packs to carry them in, along with a digital camera and a projector, and a selection of compatible Microsoft software for their school. The total value of each prize is around £10,000. The runners-up will win digital cameras for their schools. How to enter Are you a pupil? Is your school just as you want it to be? Or are there things you would change? Is the building right? Should you sit exams? Are you allowed to express yourself? Are uniforms a good thing? If there are things about your school you would like to change, here's your chance. Our competition is open to every pupil between the ages of five and 18. You can enter as an individual: simply complete our entry form (email education@theguardian.com with 'The School I'd Like' in the subject field) and send it with your entry to the freepost address provided by the closing date (Friday March 30). Your entry can take any form. Simply tell us what your ideal school would be like, and tell us any way you like - write a poem or a play; paint a picture; make architectural plans or even a scale model; produce photo-essays, or a video. Or simply write an essay in good old pen and ink. A short poem can make the point as well as a huge project; an icon can be as emotive as a three-act play. What we are looking for is originality, imagination, vision and - above all - the genuine views of children and young people. Are you a teacher? We realise that teachers don't have much time to do work with children that falls outside the national curriculum. The beauty of The School I'd Like is that teachers can adapt it to suit their needs. The opportunities for English, art or DT teachers are perhaps the most obvious. An English teacher could ask pupils for a poem or a piece of persuasive or polemical writing, a DT teacher could ask pupils to build a scale model, for example or draw a plan. But the competition also supports many other elements of the national curriculum: knowledge and understanding of places for geography key stage 2, for example, or developing skills of participation for citizenship at key stage 3. You can think big, or think small. Pupils could be set the task as a one-off piece of homework (you could then submit the work of all the pupils in the class, or simply send us the best responses - either way, our judges will look at each piece of work as an individual entry, so ask pupils to write their name on the top of their work). Or you could be more ambitious. You could get a whole class to collaborate on a collective entry (if you do this, remember to ask one of the children to include a description of how this was accomplished). What we are looking for is originality, imagination, vision and - above all - the genuine views of children and young people. By taking part, you and your pupils will be contributing to a new archive that is being set up at Bretton Hall College of the University of Leeds. All work submitted will be kept there and used as a basis for research. So even if your pupils do not win, their views will be heard and will remain as a record for future educationalists. Are you a parent? You could encourage your own child(ren) to enter as an individual (see Are you a pupil? above). The prize will be awarded to their school. The categories The competition is open to all children and young people aged five to 18. There are three categories: primary (years 1 to 6); lower secondary (years 7 to 9 inclusive); and upper secondary (years 10 to 13 inclusive). Multiple entries can be submitted using one entry form (see Are you a teacher, above) but each category entered must be accompanied by a separate entry form. Entries must reach us by the closing date. The judges The judges of The School I'd Like competition are: Tim Brighouse, Director of Education for Birmingham Education Authority; Lee Hall, writer of the hit film, Billy Elliott; Richard Lomer, head of government sales, Toshiba; Catherine Burke, lecturer in education, Bretton Hall College, University of Leeds; Becky Gardiner, editor of Education Guardian; and John Clifford, playwright and winner of the original 1967 Observer School I'd Like competition. What next? Now it's up to you. What do you think school should be like? How could it be better? What would you do differently? You can think big, you can think small. Whatever your ideas are, start talking, start planning, and then get to work. When your entry is ready, send it in to the freepost address provided below, accompanied by an entry form. If you are sending in multiple entries (eg, you are a teacher sending in individual entries from every member of your class) you only need to complete one entry form per category. And remember too that your entries need to be with us by Friday, March 30, 2001. You can also order more forms by email - click here for more details. If you do, you must include your full postal address. If you would like to discuss The School I'd Like competition with anyone, you can email Catherine Burke at: cburke@bretton.ac.uk. We regret that your entries cannot be returned. They will remain the property of the Guardian and will be kept as an archive at Bretton Hall College of the University of Leeds. The details of winners and runners-up will be published in Education Guardian on Tuesday May 22, 2001.

webTitle: Police recruitment figures up by 74%

fields.headline: Police recruitment figures up by 74%
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Police recruitment has risen by 74% in the past year, the Home Office revealed yesterday, on the eve of publication of recorded crime figures showing a further jump in violent crime.
fields.body:
Police recruitment has risen by 74% in the past year, the Home Office revealed yesterday, on the eve of publication of recorded crime figures showing a further jump in violent crime.

The crime figures, covering the year to September 2000, will be the final ones published before a May general election and will form the statistical base on which the politicians will battle for the law and order vote.

Ministers forced on the defensive today are likely to point to separate figures in the British crime survey showing a fall in violent crime. The survey measures crime in England and Wales by asking people about crimes they have experienced in the past year.

Ministers say the latest police recruitment figures show they are on course to meet their commitment to increase numbers by 3,000 a year, over and above any recruitment planned by local police forces.

Until this month 5,268 recruits had entered police training college, compared with 3,030 at the same point last year. In the last financial year 3,964 recruits went through the college, but based on the latest figures as many as 7,000 will be trained this year.

Total police numbers cannot be predicted because resignations and early retirements are so variable. The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, has attacked Labour for presiding over a 3,000 fall in police numbers since 1997.

A Home Office spokesman said training colleges were "full to bursting point, and it shows we have turned the corner on numbers". The figures did not simply represent requests for information in response to a recruitment campaign.

The latest official figures show that police numbers rose by 440 between March and September last year after three years of decline.

Although ministers are embarrassed by the violent crime figures, they will will point to the fall in burglary and car crime.

webTitle: Budget clash could be Livingstone's biggest yet

fields.headline: Budget clash could be Livingstone's biggest yet
fields.standfirst: London councils' call for the mayor to rein in his spending plans could become their biggest clash so far, writes Simon Parker
fields.trailText: Analysis: The Association of London Government's (ALG) current challenge to Ken Livingstone's budget is not the first time the boroughs have clashed with the mayor, but it could become their largest row yet, writes Simon Parker
fields.body:
The Association of London Government's (ALG) current challenge to Ken Livingstone's budget is not the first time the boroughs have clashed with the mayor, but it could become their largest row yet.

Mr Livingstone wants to raise extra money from the boroughs to boost the metropolitan police. In particular, he hopes to recruit 1,050 extra officers. While councils agree with this aim, they are worried that the mayor's proposed budget will force up the average London council tax by 5%, or more than £40, from its current level of £780. This is before the boroughs add in increases to pay for education, social care and other key services. If they post increases at roughly the same level as last year, it could mean an average London-wide increase of more than 10%.

The councils fear they will take much of the blame for the increase, and have called for the mayor to rein in his spending plans, cutting back by £84m, but still recruiting the extra officers. As ALG chairman Sir Robin Wales said: "The proposed increase is far too high and could seriously undermine the work of London boroughs that have striven to keep council taxes at a reasonable level."

The boroughs may well be able to win the support of the London assembly in their quest for cutbacks, and this could prove crucial. One of the assembly's few powers is that of vetoing the mayor's budget on a two-thirds vote. In practice, this means members of the Conservative and Labour groups voting together.

Publicity hungry assembly members may jump at the chance of a high profile confrontation with the mayor, which could provide both great headlines and the opportunity to take the taxpayers' side against the mayor. The assembly's budget committee has already warned the mayor that he must make more savings in his proposed police budget.

Other rows have focused on Mr Livingstone's veto over large planning projects, and his desire to see more social housing in the capital. These have already created friction over developments proposed by Lambeth and Wandsworth councils. His plans for congestion charging have drawn opposition from Conservative boroughs, including Westminster and Kensington and Chelsea.

These disagreements have occurred despite the government's best efforts to ensure the two sides have very separate responsibilities. The mayor's role is strategic, providing London with much-needed central coordination on issues such as policing and economic development, while the boroughs keep their portfolio of powers over council-wide issues. Where the two have clashed is on the strategic issues that have a direct impact on councils.

According to Tony Travers, an expert on the capital's new politics at the London School of Economics, these conflicts were always likely to happen: "This is just London politics reverting to type in some ways. The whole history of London government is characterised by disputes between upper and lower tier authorities, and it would be a miracle if the new arrangements didn't lead to quite regular disagreements."

This is not to say that the boroughs have been excluded from Mr Livingstone's "big tent" approach to politics, which has already seen him bring people from all parties into his administration. The mayor has joined the ALG, which allows him to engage in regular dialogue with the capital's councils, and the relationship shows no sign of falling apart.

Len Duvall, a member of the London assembly and former leader of Greenwich borough council, summed up the current state of play: "The mayor's still finding his way and establishing a relationship. It's about getting the process right and developing an understanding - do they really talk to each other and understand each other?"

If the two sides want to avoid an embarrassing stand-off over the budget issue, they will have to answer Mr Duvall's question, and quickly.

Livingstone's proposed budget for 2001-2

 Greater London Authority core functions: £38.4m. Includes mayor's office, assembly and secretariat

 Transport for London: £23.6m

 Metropolitan Police Authority: £1.996bn

 London Fire and Emergency Planning: £319m

 Total budget: £2.377bn

webTitle: Figures show increase in violent crime

fields.headline: Figures show increase in violent crime
fields.standfirst:
Special report: policing crime
See the full crime figures
fields.trailText: Violent crime and street robberies rose sharply again last year for the ninth time in 10 years, according to recorded crime statistics for England and Wales released by the Home Office today.
fields.body:
Violent crime and street robberies rose sharply again last year for the ninth time in 10 years, according to recorded crime statistics for England and Wales released by the Home Office today.

The Home Office confirmed that, although overall crime fell slightly, by 0.2%, in the 12 months to September 2000, there was a worrying rise in assaults and muggings.

Overall violent crime rose by 8%, with robbery rising by 21%, but the violent crime rise is half that of the year before, when it was 16%.

Four of the eight metropolitan forces in England and Wales recorded overall falls, but their success was outweighed by increases in Greater Manchester (up 1.7%), Merseyside (up 2.4%), the Met (up 3%) and West Midlands (up 3.2%).

London's Metropolitan police force recorded the highest number of robberies in the country at 5.6 robberies for every 1,000 residents. The West Midlands police followed with 4.1 offences per 1,000 residents, followed by Greater Manchester at 3.7%.

Central Newcastle had the highest number of incidents of violence against the person, with 236.5 for every 1,000 residents.

Despite the increase in violent crime, the home secretary, Jack Straw, labelled the statistics "encouraging". He placed particular emphasis on the fall in recorded burglary and vehicle crime.

Burglary fell by 8%, the seventh consecutive fall, while thefts of vehicles fell by 7% and thefts from vehicles fell by 6%. The number of sexual offences recorded also fell slightly, by 0.4% - the first fall for five years.

Mr Straw said: "These figures show the continuing success of effective action against crime. As a result of excellent work by the police, local councils, community groups and others, recorded crime fell over the 12-month period.

"Overall crime in England and Wales has fallen over recent years and is continuing to fall. But it is still far too high and we must continue to work together to bring it down further."

Both Labour and the Conservatives consider the numbers on crime and policing crucial to the upcoming general election. While Mr. Straw attempted to focus on the lowest overall crime rate in 10 years, Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe pointed out falling numbers of police officers.

Labour will take comfort that a record 822 officers began training this month - a 74% increase on January 2000. And 5,268 have already joined the force since April - the start of the financial year - compared to just 3,963 in 1999-2000, the Home Office said.

Mr Straw set aside £1.6 billion in a bid to plug the shortfall, with 9,000 extra officers needed by 2004.

But as police numbers continued to drop to a 10-year low, and violent crime figures increased, the Conservatives accused Labour of failing on crime.

Miss Widdecombe said: "These figures are a cynical manoeuvre to cover up government embarrassment over the huge rise in violent crime and, looked at in context, they are not even that exciting.

"Labour has presided over a fall of 2,500 police since the last general election and this modest rise in the recruitment will not reverse that decrease before the election."

Home office minister Charles Clarke attempted to counter the criticism when he revealed today that the government would soon be announcing moves to make it more attractive for experienced officers to carry on after they complete 30 years' service.

fields.trailText: Today's good news is that Department of Health staff are now officially allowed to log on to the internet for personal use - and that includes keeping up with the news, comment and analysis at SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.body:
Today's good news is that Department of Health staff are now officially allowed to log on to the internet for personal use - and that includes keeping up with the news, comment and analysis at SocietyGuardian.co.uk

And as well as health news, we've the latest stories from the rest of the public and voluntary sectors.

The top stories today are:

News: NHS 'must speed up change'

The president of the General Medical Council, Sir Donald Irvine, will today vent his frustrations at the unwillingness of doctors to move faster to change the old NHS paternalistic culture.

http://www.societytheguardian.com

Local government: Imperial weights go on trial

Sunderland council has begun a legal battle against a greengrocer who sold bananas by pounds and ounces.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/localgovt

News: Child protection training is 'inadequate' warn social workers

Social workers have warned that current training does not guarantee adequate experience of child protection.

http://www.societytheguardian.com

Health: NHS to get £500m internet boost

The government has launched a £500m plan to wire up the NHS to the internet revolution, with the aim of improving standards of care and speeding up access to treatment and health information.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health

Regeneration: 'Neighbourhood managers' to boost run-down areas

England's poorest areas are set to gain new "neighbourhood managers" charged with ensuring communities get the best deal out of the government's regeneration and funding programmes.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/regeneration

Social care: Call to toughen up children's commissioner's role

MPs are today set to debate proposals to strengthen the powers of the new children's commissioner for Wales, amid calls for similar posts to be set up throughout the UK following the tragic death of Anna Climbie.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/socialcare

webTitle: Police try to include whites in ethnic roll call

fields.headline: Police try to include whites in ethnic roll call
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The number of black officers in the Metropolitan Police is significantly lower than first thought, after police wrongly tried to claim that white Irish officers were an ethnic minority, it emerged today.
fields.body:
The number of black officers in the Metropolitan Police is significantly lower than first thought, after police wrongly tried to claim that white Irish officers were an ethnic minority, it emerged today.

The Home Office said that it was "deeply concerned" about a series of errors made by police in the collation of national statistics.

The most notable error was the figure released on the supposed increases in ethnic minority officers working in England and Wales.

Paul Wiles, director of research development of statistics at the Home Office, said that the Metropolitan Police had originally said that the number of ethnic officers working for the force had increased by 218 between March and September 2000.

In fact, the increase was just four, Mr Wiles said. The mistake was made because officers classified as "white Irish" and "other white", such as people from Australia, were included in the total of ethnic minority officers.

Mr Wiles said: "I am deeply concerned about these errors. This has been a cock-up."

He said that a special task force was now been created, including Home Office statisticians, to ensure that the problem did not happen again.

webTitle: Vinnie gets Wilde with journalist

fields.headline: Vinnie gets Wilde with journalist
fields.trailText: Vinnie Jones has stormed out of an interview with an American magazine, after a series of questions took a dig at his macho image.
fields.body:
Vinnie Jones has stormed out of an interview with an American magazine, after a series of questions took a dig at his macho image.

Jones, promoting his film Snatch which is released in the US this weekend, walked out after being asked whether he was bisexual and whether he thought cars would ever be made out of cheese.

The problems started when Jones was asked: "What's your opinion of the idea that all men are essentially bisexual?" by Stuff 4 Men journalist Jon Wilde - to which he responded: "I don't know what you're getting at but you're fucking giving me the right hump. Ask something else."

But Wilde refused to change tack, telling him: "You seem to have a soft side. Aren't you really a bit of a teddy bear?"

By now an angry Jones was getting less and less impressed. "You're taking the piss now, aren't you?" he responded. "You're having a dig. If you're taking the piss, I'll give you a right-hander. Do I look like a teddy bear? I've worked hard in my life and I don't expect people to take the piss. One thing I ain't is a fucking teddy bear."

Relations between the two men deteriorated further when Wilde asked the former football hard-man: "Do you think you could take me?"

"I could always handle myself. I'm from the street. I had enough fights in my younger days. I was always up for a fight on a Friday night. I was pretty good at it too," was Jones' response.

Wilde then goaded: "Yeah, but could you take me?" Only for Jones to bite back: "I don't want to talk about that shit. Ask me something else."

But Wilde's next question: "Can you see a time when cars will be made from cheese?" proved too much for Jones - and he stormed out of the interview.

webTitle: Eriksson gets the prankster treatment

fields.headline: Eriksson gets the prankster treatment
fields.trailText: A local radio DJ pretending to be Kevin Keegan made a prank phone call to Sven-Goran Eriksson yesterday, and in the midst of a barrage of jokes from the Stan Boardman handbook, may have confirmed that David Beckham will be England's permanent captain.
fields.body:
A local radio DJ pretending to be Kevin Keegan made a prank phone call to Sven-Goran Eriksson yesterday, and in the midst of a barrage of jokes from the Stan Boardman handbook, may have confirmed that David Beckham will be England's permanent captain.

Mike Maguire, a DJ on Manchester's Century FM, reached the new England coach at home in Italy. After extending his best wishes, Maguire soon got down to it, claiming he'd "seen Seaman lobbed from 30 yards" and that he once bought a Pavarotti CD for £30 - "I wanted three tenors!"

Eriksson, who appears to have found the Pavarotti gag amusing, didn't get involved in conversation, insisting instead that he and Keegan should "meet for lunch or something" when he returns to England.

That failed to dissuade Maguire who asked Eriksson: "Listen, Sven, David Beckham, he's going to be the new England captain, yeah?" To which he replied, "I think so", which could confirm that the Manchester United midfielder will hold onto the armband he wore in last year's friendly against Italy, or could just be someone trying to get off the phone.

All will no doubt be revealed when Eriksson picks his first England squad for the friendly against Spain next month.

webTitle: In brief: veteran stars top two Radio Times polls

fields.headline: Veteran stars top two Radio Times polls
fields.standfirst: Plus: Cary Grant honoured by his home town of Bristol; Roger Moore escapes without serious injury after car crash
fields.trailText: Plus: Cary Grant honoured by his home town of Bristol; Roger Moore escapes without serious injury after car crash
fields.body:
 Paul Newman (pictured) has beaten out the likes of Tom Hanks, James Stewart and Marlon Brando to be named the greatest movie star of all time in a poll of film experts commissioned by the British TV listings magazine, Radio Times. The star of Hud and Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid emerged victorious when votes were tallied across a number of categories, including acting range, box-office success, Oscar nominations and (that old staple for a family publication) marriageability. Meanwhile a separate poll of Radio Times readers threw up a different result by naming Sean Connery as their all-time great. The Scots-born actor rated a respectable eighth in the experts' list.

 The city of Bristol, birthplace of actor Cary Grant, looks set to honour its famous son with a series of events this September. On screen, Grant (the star of a galaxy of film classics including Bringing Up Baby, The Philadelphia Story, Notorious and North by Northwest) exuded a cosmopolitan sophistication. Off screen, his origins were rather humbler. Grant was born Archie Leach in the Fishponds neighbourhood of Bristol in 1904, then decamped to the US in the 1920s. Grant died in LA in 1986 but will be belatedly celebrated in his hometown with a statue, film retrospective and commemorative festival.

 It must have seemed like a case of art imitating life for former Bond star Roger Moore, who walked free from what might have been a serious car wreck in Sweden at the weekend. Debonair Moore, now 73, cheated death when the car he was travelling in with partner Christina Tholstrup was rammed by another vehicle as the pair were en-route from the airport to a TV studio. Officials said that the pair escaped injury because of their airbags.

webTitle: Advertising growth to slow

fields.headline: Advertising growth to slow
fields.standfirst: Jan 11: Falling ad spend sparks slowdown fears
fields.trailText:
12pm: Advertising growth will be much slower this year according to the Bellwether Report, writes Claire Cozens.
Jan 11: Falling ad spend sparks slowdown fears
fields.body:
The advertising market will continue to grow this year. However, media owners should keep the champagne on ice as the rate of growth will be much slower than it was in 2000.

These are the findings of the latest Bellwether Report, an overview of Britain's ad industry published quarterly by the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising.

The latest report, out today, is based on interviews with a panel of more than 200 UK marketing professionals representing all key business sectors.

Rupert Howell, IPA president, put a positive spin on the findings.

"Marketing spend looks as if it will continue to grow this year, albeit at a slower pace," he said. "Estimates for this year look positive.

"The Bellwether Report has now been in existence for a full year and has fulfilled my expectations. It is a key indicator of the state of the UK economy."

Just under half the companies surveyed said they had increased their ad budgets for 2001, while total annual marketing spend is expected to reach £33bn.

However, a significant number of respondents were more cautious. More than 18% reported a decrease in ad spend, showing business confidence to be waning.

The strongest growth is expected to be in direct marketing, which is much a cheaper option than above-the-line advertising.

Some 40% of companies questioned said their 2001 direct marketing budgets were up on last year.

webTitle: The transfer crisis made simple

fields.headline: The transfer crisis made simple
fields.standfirst:
It is the issue that all of European football is obsessed with but what is really going on? Vivek Chaudhary provides the answers
Latest: Uefa issues deadline to Fifa
fields.trailText: It is the issue that all of European football is obsessed with but what is really going on? Vivek Chaudhary provides the answers
fields.body:
Why does the European Commission want to change the football transfer system?

The commission believes that all workers within Europe should have the same rights. This includes the right to resign from your job and change employer, after a specified period of notice. The commission believes that footballers should be given the same rights as ordinary workers in the European Union and have the right to terminate their contracts, following a period of notice, and move to another club. Two years ago the commission ordered football to change its transfer system.

Why is football so concerned?

Football believes that this could lead to anarchy within the game. There would be no stability as players could walk out on contracts. Clubs in turn could terminate the players' contracts. Small clubs could go bankrupt and they would not earn money from developing young players because those players could terminate a contract and join another club. Players' wages, particularly those at the top end of the game, would spiral out of control.

What was football's response?

For two years virtually nothing. Then last summer Sepp Blatter, the president of Fifa, announced that the transfer system was dead and that the organisation would comply with the commission. This incensed Uefa, which fears that, if the commission gets its way, then professional football as we know it will collapse. A joint Fifa/Uefa working party on the transfer system was established and a number of proposals submitted to the commission.

What are those proposals?

A ban on transfers for players aged 18 or under. Players to honour contracts for a specified period of time but Fifa and the commission and Uefa disagree over how long this should be. An arbitration system to be established that would compensate clubs when a player wants to break a contract unilaterally.

What is the latest row between Fifa and Uefa about?

After spending several months trying to forge a united front Fifa last week submitted a document on the transfer system to the European Commission without consulting Uefa. Fifa wanted to give players the right to terminate contracts at three months' notice simply because they disagree with team selection or strategy. Uefa believes that clubs and players need greater stability and contracts must be honoured for between three to five years.

What was Uefa's response?

Very angry. There were rumours of a possible breakaway from Fifa. Uefa is the richest and most influential football federation in the world and believes that Fifa has acted in an unprincipled manner by submitting a document to the commission without consultation. Uefa insists that Fifa withdraw the document and that a new set of proposals be submitted.

What was Fifa's response?

Fifa insists that its document does not contain concrete proposals and that it was just meant for discussion.

What else concerns Uefa about the commission's plans?

Apart from length of contract, Uefa also believes that a better compensation system needs to be worked out for players who move clubs. Uefa wants a system to take into account a player's commercial worth, not just the time remaining on his contract and the number of appearances, as the commission and Fifa want. Uefa argues that David Beckham, for example, is worth a lot more to Manchester United in terms of his commercial value to the club. This should be taken into account when settling compensation.

What does the commission say?

The commission appears pleased with Fifa's proposals but not so happy with Uefa, claiming that many of its ideas still contravene European law. The commission insists it is concerned only with international transfers and that domestic transfers will not be affected. Privately Uefa believes that, as with the Bosman ruling, any change will inevitably affect domestic deals. The commission has promised to resolve the matter by the end of the month.

How will the new transfer system work?

A player will have the right to terminate his contract following a specified period of notice. If there is any disagreement the matter will go to arbitration, where compensation will be worked out. Players will have to stay at their club for a specified period of time.

What happens next?

The commission could impose the changes on football but this appears unlikely, given that it would be extremely unpopular. If Fifa insists that its document should be accepted, then this could lead to a split within world football with Uefa breaking away. Political leaders including Tony Blair are also becoming interested in the issue and sport might be given special status exempting it from European law. Uefa's executive committee is to discuss the matter this week and meetings are also planned with Fifa to try to resolve the issue.

In the future will there still be transfer fees?

Yes, but not as high as they currently are. Clubs will not want to pay multi-million-pound fees for players who will have the right to walk out on contracts following a specified period of notice.

How much will players be paid?

Salaries of over £100,000 a week will be common. The money clubs save on transfers will be diverted towards higher wages as a way of keeping star players. Loyalty bonuses, share options and other financial incentives will also be included in players' contracts in an attempt to persuade them to remain with their clubs.

So, is a new system good news for players?

Gordon Taylor, representing the European players' unions, believes so. However, only those at the top end of the game, who will be able to command high salaries and pick and choose clubs, are likely to benefit. For players at the bottom end of the professional game there are likely to be greater insecurity and fewer jobs.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Hollywood envoys to attend Bush celebration

fields.headline: Hollywood envoys to attend Bush celebration
fields.trailText: Hollywood's top Republicans prepare to welcome George W Bush to the White House amid fears that the new president will wage a moral crusade against mainstream entertainment
fields.body:
Hollywood looks set for an uneasy truce with the incoming Republican administration this week as the ire of a heated election campaign subsides into the inevitable victory celebrations in Washington DC. Various heavy-hitters from the film and music industries will be in town for celebration parties leading up to the inauguration of George W Bush on January 20.

Despite the public smiles, however, it appears that the cosy relationship between Hollywood and the White House that flourished during the Clinton era is now well and truly kaput. The motion picture industry was a favoured whipping boy throughout the 2000 presidential race, with Congress threatening to legislate against film advertising which it was claimed was targeted at an underage audience.

While Hollywood came in for criticism from both the Republicans and the Democrats (in the person of vice presidential hopeful Joe Lieberman), it is generally thought that Bush's incoming administration, more to the right than observers predicted, will wage more of a moral crusade against mainstream entertainment.

On the West Coast, top producer Jerry Weintraub (Ocean's Eleven, The Avengers) has been rallying support for a united Hollywood welcome for Bush, who is a long-time friend. But Tinsletown's representation in Washington still appears limited to die-hard Republicans. Due to welcome Bush at the exclusive Texas Black Tie and Boot Ball at the Marriott Wardman Hotel this Thursday are a rash of old troopers, including Arnold Schwarzenegger, Bruce Willis, Chuck Norris, Robert Duvall and Sylvester Stallone.

webTitle: NewsCorp axes more internet jobs

fields.headline: NewsCorp axes more internet jobs
fields.standfirst: FT: Murdoch ends dot.com joyride
fields.trailText:
11.45am: Rupert Murdoch will axe more internet jobs as he attempts to get the Sky Global Networks flotation off the ground. By Dan Milmo.
FT: Murdoch ends dot.com joyride
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch will axe more internet jobs at his News Corporation empire as he attempts to get the mammoth Sky Global Networks flotation off the ground.

Online staff at UK satellite broadcaster BSkyB are the next in line, according to reports in the Financial Times.

Murdoch has spent £1.3 bn on internet projects since mid-1999 but decided at a crunch budget meeting last summer that online projects were no longer a priority in the face of a looming debt crisis.

"The company is looking everywhere for cash. The financial people are being very diligent, looking under every rock for money," said one senior NewsCorp executive.

Another executive at the budget meeting in News Corp's LA offices said: "It was a pivotal moment when we saw the hockey stick model for the internet business was not going to happen.

"We had all been brought back down to earth a fair bit."

Mr Murdoch has already shown the door to 200 staff at his News Digital Media arm as he tries to restore investor confidence ahead of the £27bn Sky Global share offer.

The NewsCorp chief has ordered a clampdown on acquisitions to conserve cash resources.

Last month debt monitors Standard & Poor's threatened to downgrade News Corporation to junk bond status.

Such a rating would saddle the group with crippling interest payments on its loans and jeopardise the imminent flotation of his global TV empire.

The flotation of NewsCorp's digital broadcast businesses has been delayed in part by a combination of market turbulence and uncertainty over the company's shareholder structure.

However, the missing key to a successful float is a strong presence in the US satellite TV market.

Mr Murdoch aims to solve that problem by snapping up DirecTV from owner General Motors.

News Corporation has embarked on a ruthless purging of its internet ventures to cut costs and help fund the DirecTV acquisition, which would go a long way to pushing Sky Global onto the market. Acquisition activity has already been capped by Mr Murdoch.

Mr Murdoch's executives have denied the about-turn in internet strategy is linked to cost-cutting.
fields.bodyText: Rupert Murdoch will axe more internet jobs at his News Corporation empire as he attempts to get the mammoth Sky Global Networks flotation off the ground. Online staff at UK satellite broadcaster BSkyB are the next in line, according to reports in the Financial Times. Murdoch has spent £1.3 bn on internet projects since mid-1999 but decided at a crunch budget meeting last summer that online projects were no longer a priority in the face of a looming debt crisis. "The company is looking everywhere for cash. The financial people are being very diligent, looking under every rock for money," said one senior NewsCorp executive. Another executive at the budget meeting in News Corp's LA offices said: "It was a pivotal moment when we saw the hockey stick model for the internet business was not going to happen. "We had all been brought back down to earth a fair bit." Mr Murdoch has already shown the door to 200 staff at his News Digital Media arm as he tries to restore investor confidence ahead of the £27bn Sky Global share offer. The NewsCorp chief has ordered a clampdown on acquisitions to conserve cash resources. Last month debt monitors Standard & Poor's threatened to downgrade News Corporation to junk bond status. Such a rating would saddle the group with crippling interest payments on its loans and jeopardise the imminent flotation of his global TV empire. The flotation of NewsCorp's digital broadcast businesses has been delayed in part by a combination of market turbulence and uncertainty over the company's shareholder structure. However, the missing key to a successful float is a strong presence in the US satellite TV market. Mr Murdoch aims to solve that problem by snapping up DirecTV from owner General Motors. News Corporation has embarked on a ruthless purging of its internet ventures to cut costs and help fund the DirecTV acquisition, which would go a long way to pushing Sky Global onto the market. Acquisition activity has already been capped by Mr Murdoch. Mr Murdoch's executives have denied the about-turn in internet strategy is linked to cost-cutting.

webTitle: Charlotte Raven: Why Ang Lee's film is rubbish

fields.headline: Crashing bore, wooden drama
fields.standfirst: Charlotte Raven dares to differ from the unanimous acclaim for Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.trailText: Charlotte Raven dares to differ from the unanimous acclaim for Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.body:
In the past year, I have only left two films before the end. One was South Park: The Movie; the other was Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. As I waited in the pub for my friend, I wondered why I felt so much like I did when I first saw Star Wars. This was meant to be a highbrow flick, not a blockbuster, and yet I came away with the same problems I had with George Lucas's flabby epic. I was unsatisfied with the characterisation, underwhelmed by the mythic pomposity and bored to tears by the fight sequences.

The other thing it reminded me of was Tomb Raider. Like the game, Crouching Tiger was a quest for nothing in particular in a pseudo-legendary setting against high-jumping adversaries. Its protagonists' faces were as immobile as Lara Croft's, who at least has the excuse of not being real. Because they were oriental, everyone presumed this was understatement, rather than woodenness.

I have no doubt that if Crouching Tiger had been in English, the script would have seemed unforgivably banal. In Chinese, delivered inscrutably, it seemed to contain multitudes. Critics have referred to its "moral power" and "mythic echoes". The same could be said of Star Wars. In both cases, the morality is that it's better to be good than bad. A great lesson for a 10-year-old, but hardly for a grown-up audience.

It's fair enough to say you liked Crouching Tiger as a spectacle. What I object to is the Guardian-reader tendency to attribute greater meaning to something just because it has an arthouse veneer. Some did the same with American Beauty - another piece of pseudy rubbish that gestured towards great truths and delivered a truckload of cliches about repressed suburbanites. The day they make a film located in suburbia that shows happy people living honestly - that's when I'll commend a director's originality.

webTitle: Gullit attacks Chelsea

fields.headline: Gullit attacks Chelsea
fields.trailText: Ruud Gullit has attacked his former club Chelsea, claiming they "could have been one of the major clubs in Europe" if they hadn't got rid of him.
fields.body:
Ruud Gullit has attacked his former club Chelsea, claiming they "could have been one of the major clubs in Europe" if they hadn't got rid of him.

"After I was sacked, it's been going downhill ever since for the fans," he added.

This isn't the first time that Gullit, who has admitted he was "bruised" by his departure from Chelsea over a wage dispute almost three years ago, has expressed his bitterness.

When Gianluca Vialli was dismissed from Stamford Bridge earlier this season amid reports of dressing-room unrest, Gullit reflected that "what goes around, comes around".

And today, the Dutchman - who won the FA Cup with Chelsea in 1997 and took them to second place in the table just before he left - continued his criticism of the club, claiming: "I think Chelsea could have been one of the major clubs in Europe. But they decided to take another route and this is the consequence.

"I thought I had done something well and proved myself," he continued. "After I was sacked, it's been going downhill ever since for the fans."

Chelsea supporters will remember that, under Vialli, the club won the Cup Winners' Cup, FA Cup, Coca-Cola Cup and Super Cup, and also reached the Champions League quarter-finals - which was a better haul than Gullit achieved during his years with the club.

webTitle: De Beers to open jewellery shops

fields.headline: De Beers to open jewellery shops
fields.trailText: 11.15am De Beers is set to open branded jewellery shops in major cities with luxury goods group LVMH, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
The first De Beers-branded jewellery shops are likely to open in Paris, London, Milan and New York within the next 18 months, it emerged this morning.

In the first confirmation of its 50:50 retail venture with Bernard Arnault's luxury goods group LVMH, De Beers said it wanted to open a small number of "flagship retail stores located in the world's most prestigious cities to provide the consumer with the opportunity to experience the De Beers brand in full".

The diamond supplier, which controls 60% of the market for rough diamonds, is relinquishing its rights to the prestigious De Beers brand to the new venture in a bid to boost flat global demand for the gems.

It is renaming its core business the Diamond Trading Company.

The new venture, headed by Myron Ullman, LVMH group managing director, will launch a range of De Beers-branded diamond jewellery and a string of branded shops.

The range is expected to be the first in a number of products which will in time stretch to diamond watches, handbags and other glittering fashion accessories.

The brand will benefit from the marketing war chest of Bernard Arnault's luxury group, which also includes Tag Heuer watches, Louis Vuitton leather goods and the famous Paris jeweller Chaumet.

Arnault recently added Donna Karan's fashion range to his growing portfolio.

Gary Ralfe, De Beers group managing director, said: "Diamonds are the ultimate luxury product and as the world's leading luxury goods groups; LVMH is the ideal partner to develop the potential of the De Beers name among consumers."

De Beers has become frustrated with a moribund market in diamonds but has not been able to enter retail directly for regulatory reasons.

The global jewellery market it supplies is highly fragmented and none of the major players has more than a small share.

Hence the £33bn world diamond jewellery business is open to a participant with a strong brand name.

webTitle: El Salvador quake victim buried alive for 33 hours

fields.headline: Buried alive for 33 hours, a victim pleads: 'Get me out, please hurry'
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Each time the earth trembled, Sergio Moreno let out a cry of distress and pleaded with rescue workers to set him free, "Get me out, please hurry, I cannot breathe."
fields.body:
Each time the earth trembled, Sergio Moreno let out a cry of distress and pleaded with rescue workers to set him free. "Get me out, please hurry, I cannot breathe," the 22-year-old musician, his legs pinned down by the weight of fallen overhead beams, begged Mexican rescue worker Jose Alfredo Espejelo.

Mr Espejelo lay close to him inside the cramped shell of a destroyed house, under 10ft of thick mud. He had crawled into the collapsed building to cut some of the cement blocks weighing on Mr Moreno's body. "I tried to give him energy, encouragement, telling him that soon it would be all over," he said.

The two men passed almost 10 hours together underground, until at last Mr Moreno was dragged free, 33 hours after the giant earthquake which hit El Salvador on Saturday.

"I was amazed by his strength, his will to survive, to live; it gave us all energy to carry on," Mr Espejelo said.

But early yesterday morning, as Mr Espejelo and other rescue specialists from Spain, Mexico and Guatemala were back digging for more survivors, Mr Moreno was fighting for his life in an intensive care unit in a hospital in the capital, San Salvador.

"It is a miracle that he survived all those hours under the earth - but now he is in a very critical condition," said a senior surgeon, Dr Eduardo Castillo.

Dr Castillo said it had been necessary to amputate Mr Moreno's left leg, and the survivor might have to undergo further surgery to amputate the lower part of his right leg. The pianist's parents, Juan Cruz and Leticia del Carmen, wept as the doctor asked them for permission to carry out the operation.

"All we can do is commend our son to God, and into your hands," Ms del Carmen told the doctors.

Determination

Mr Moreno's fate has become a symbol of the tragedy of El Salvador's worse natural disaster in almost 20 years - and a symbol of the determination of Salvadoreans to overcome one more in a long line of adversities - civil war, hurricanes, earthquakes - which have marked the tiny country's recent history.

Police said last night that 594 deaths had been confirmed throughout the country. Two thousand people had been injured, 4,692 houses destroyed and 16,148 damaged. Most of the 1,000 people still missing were residents of Las Colinas, six miles east of San Salvador.

With rescuers giving up hope of finding any more survivors, the authorities continued the mass burials, saying the identities of many who died might never be known. There are no refrigeration facilities and bodies have been piled up in an alley near the quake-triggered landslide which covered Las Colinas.

With aftershocks as strong as 5.4 on the Richter scale rattling the unstable mass of soil and rubble, there was no safe place to keep the bodies.

Some corpses lay on the pavement as if the victims had lain down for a nap. Some were covered in garbage bags. President Francisco Flores asked Colombia to send 3,000 coffins.

One of the handful to be rescued, Mr Moreno had been painting his newly rented two-storey cement-block home in Las Colinas when the quake struck. He had just returned from living in the United States, where, like many of his compatriots, he earned money to send back to his parents in El Salvador.

A talented pianist, he toured with a Tex-Mex band called Algodun, a favourite among the expat community in the US. After moving back to San Salvador, he planned to study computing at university.

Mr Moreno's cousin, Miguel Angel Rivera, was helping him to do up the house on Saturday morning, but left to buy more paint from a local store. "I told him, I'll be back soon; I'll come back later to help you some more," he said.

As Mr Rivera turned the corner the first waves of the 7.6 magnitude quake triggered the mudslide from the giant Cordillera mountain range. It swept through the lively middle-class community, uprooting trees, dragging debris along in its path, and laying waste to more than 400 houses.

By last night rescue workers had pulled more than 200 bodies out of the remains of Las Colinas. Sniffer dogs were searching for traces of life beneath the mud - although emergency services workers fear that their effort will be in vain.

The 300-square metre disaster area is now littered with scraps of clothing, piles of debris, sheets of unread newspapers, and the twisted iron of crushed vehicles.

The site where Mr Moreno's house stood is still cordoned off, and has not been touched since the young man was dragged to safety late on Sunday night, unconscious and bleeding heavily.

Mr Espejelo said: "It is a wonderful experience rescuing someone - but this is all very, very hard."

webTitle: Earthquake toll could top 1,600

fields.headline: Earthquake toll could top 1,600
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: More than 600 bodies have been recovered and a further 1,000 people are still missing in El Salvador following the massive earthquake which struck the Central American state at the weekend.
fields.body:
More than 600 bodies have been recovered and a further 1,000 people are still missing in El Salvador following the massive earthquake which struck the Central American state at the weekend.

Another man was dragged alive from the rubble yesterday. The quake, which measured 7.6 on the Richter scale, also killed six people in neighbouring Guatemala.

The authorities have begun mass burials, admitting the identities of many who died may never be known. As the ground dries out, the chances of finding alive anyone buried in houses wrecked by a mudslide are diminishing.

Aftershocks as strong as magnitude 5.4 have rattled the unstable soil and rubble. Saturday's earthquake, off El Salvador's Pacific coast, was felt as far north as central Mexico - more than 1,100 miles away.

Britain's department of international development is donating £600,000 aid.

webTitle: No extra EastEnders before Easter

fields.headline: No extra EastEnders before Easter
fields.standfirst: Jan 15: EastEnders goes four-times-a-week
fields.trailText:
11.30am: EastEnders' fourth weekly episode will not air until after Easter, according to BBC drama's Mal Young. By Jason Deans.
Jan 15: EastEnders goes four-times-a-week
fields.body:
The fourth weekly episode of EastEnders will not be introduced this side of Easter, according to BBC controller of continuing drama Mal Young.

Mr Young said scripts were still being commissioned for the fourth weekly episode of the soap. He added that the extra instalment would launch after Easter, which falls in mid-April this year.

"We've got to get it right," he said. "The quality of the show has to be retained, as well as the quality of the people's working lives."

ITV Network Centre planners are understood to have been working on the assumption that the fourth weekly EastEnders could launch as early as the beginning of March.

Mr Young said he had been planning for the introduction of the new episode for 14 months.

One of the key decisions has been to retain a five-day working week, so that the cast and crew still get their weekends off, he added.

"The idea is that they work their socks off till Friday, then get their weekends."

Barbara Windsor, who plays Mitchell family matriarch Peggy in the soap, said the cast had thought the show might go to five days a week and was "pleasantly surprised" that it was only four.

Ms Windsor added that the actors were "very pleased" about the move, especially because some had been "worried about having to work every Saturday and Sunday". "We like our weekends off," she said.

A number of other changes will be introduced in order to allow the extra episode to be shot between Monday and Friday.

Mr Young said eight to 10 new characters would be introduced to help fill the extra 30 minutes a week.

In addition, existing characters - including the Slater family, who were introduced last year with one eye on the launch of a fourth episode - will be used more.

"This gives us the ability to make sure everyone has really good storylines and a good crack of the whip," added Mr Young.

EastEnders will also take over studio C at Elstree on a permanent basis, displacing Top of the Tops, which is moving to a new base elsewhere.

Added to the soap's existing home in Elstree's studio D and stage one, this will allow the production team to have a bigger choice of sets.

Mr Young said the EastEnders backlot at Elstree would also be expanded, with greater use made of locations immediately around Albert Square, such as the tube station.

"People will see a bit more and there will be some new buildings," he added. "We'll show people a bit more of the Walford that exists around Albert Square."

Daytime soap Doctors has been used as a training ground for writers and directors who would now be moving onto an expanded EastEnders production team, Mr Young said.

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours do a handy impression of Kevin Keegan
fields.trailText: Liverpool are hoping to replace Robbie Fowler with West Ham striker Frederic Kanoute, reports the Star. The paper says that Gerald Houllier has been "dazzled" with Kanoute's form this season, and if he can offload Fowler for £14m he will then move for Kanoute.
fields.body:
Liverpool are hoping to replace Robbie Fowler with West Ham striker Frederic Kanoute, reports the Star. The paper says that Gerald Houllier has been "dazzled" with Kanoute's form this season, and if he can offload Fowler for £14m he will then move for Kanoute.

Meanwhile, Liverpool have denied any interest in Coventry goalkeeper Chris Kirkland. "Every time I say I like a player it gets reported that I am going to make a bid for him," Houllier told Teamtalk. "A figure of £7m came up in Kirkland's case and I think it is ridiculous. It is stupid and I think it is being done to destabilise us."

Hertha Berlin centre-back Marko Rehmer could be at Highbury next week to talk about a summer transfer to Arsenal, reports the Daily Mail. Rehmer's agent Joerg Neubauer said: "Marko knows about the training facilities at Arsenal after the Germany squad were allowed to use them before the World Cup qualifier with England in October. But maybe he wants to go over and see Arsene Wenger. He could do that after Hertha return from a training camp in Marbella next Sunday."

Arsenal are also watching Blackburn's David Dunn and Dean Aston of Crewe, according to the Star.

West Ham are hoping to revive the £3m transfer of Lorenzo Amoruso when he returns from Rangers' mid-season break in Florida, reports the Mail. Hammers managing director Paul Aldridge admitted: "We still hope a sensible solution can be arrived at but we will have to wait and see."

West Ham are also hoping to sign Norwegian U-21 defender Ragnvald Soma for £2.3m later today. Bryne chairman Svein Bragstad told Planet Football: "I can confirm that we are in talks with West Ham about Soma. They have made a bid and we expect to have an agreement during today."

And West Ham could be also ready to make a bid for Vicenza striker Luca Toni, reports Planet Football. The website claims the Hammers had Toni watched against Lecce at the weekend.

Newcastle defender Didier Domi will move to Paris Saint Germain in "a matter of hours", reports Teamtalk. The website claims the two clubs have agreed a £3.5m for the player.

Southampton midfielder Hassan Kachloul is poised to complete a £1.5m move to Ipswich, reports the Daily Express.

Sunderland manager Peter Reid has expressed an interest in Swansea's 20-year-old winger Stuart Roberts, reports the Star - but he faces competition from Manchester City and Southampton.

webTitle: El Salvador quake: Property scheme blamed for many deaths

fields.headline: Contested property scheme blamed for many deaths
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: A fiercely contested private property development, engulfed in a mudslide when the earthquake struck El Salvador, was yesterday being blamed for the high number of casualties in the worst affected area.
fields.body:
A fiercely contested private property development, engulfed in a mudslide when the earthquake struck El Salvador, was yesterday being blamed for the high number of casualties in the worst affected area.

The earthquake was unusual for Central America in that its main victims lived in a middle-class suburb, Las Colinas. Normally the victims of earthquakes in the region live in shanty towns and cheap homes built on the sides of hills or in the least safe areas of a city.

The municipal government for the area had tried to prevent a private construction company from building mansions on the hilltops over Las Colinas - "the foothills" - but had failed after a long legal battle. "They took us to court, sued us for $4.5m and won," city controller Jose Noe Torres told the Los Angeles Times. "This is the result."

Jose Luis Rodriguez, whose mother-in-law was one of the victims, said: "The earthquake was the work of God but this, this is the work of man."

As an example of local feeling about the construction, residents booed President Flores when he visited the disaster site over the weekend.

What has also emerged is the increasing sophistication of rescue operations in the region. Many of the deaths that have traditionally followed an earthquake, through disease or the inability of the rescue teams to trace survivors quickly, can now be avoided.

Stockpiles of medical equipment, clean water, blankets and tools are kept at an emergency warehouse in Miami so that they can be flown to wherever they are needed in Central America. While organisations like the Red Cross, Unicef and the Pan American Health Organisation have acquired much experi ence on the ground and provide swift aid, newer organisations like the France-based Telecom Sans Frontières, providing telecommunication assistance, have entered the field.

A spokesman for TSF, which is sponsored by France Telecom and Inmarsat, said they take satellite phones to disaster areas which can be used by rescue workers to communicate with each other in places where telephone and power lines are almost certainly not functioning. The phones can also be used for survivors to contact relatives. There are now eight such TSF workers in El Salvador. "They scan the news wires and leap on a plane often without a visa," said the spokesman, who described the TSF team as "action-man types".

The earthquake also demonstrated the wide range of international cooperation, with the Mexicans sending troops, the Colombians sending coffins, the Spanish sending sniffer dogs, the Americans sending medical supplies and a variety of international aid organisations, including many British ones, pooling resources.

• The government yesterday announced it has committed more than £600,000 in aid to El Salvador as British charities launched appeals.

The international development minister, George Foulkes, said the government would "respond sympathetically" to further requests for assistance.

The EU said it was sending £1.27m in emergency aid.

The British Red Cross El Salvador Earthquake Appeal Line is 08705 125 125, or donations can be made via the website, The British Red Cross

Unicef's El Salvador Earthquake Children's Appeal call 0345 312 312, or make donations online at Unicef

Buried alive: Earthquake rescues

November 1999 Duzce, Turkey. Sefa Cebec, a 42-year-old-woman, was rescued after spending more than 100 hours buried under a six-storey block of flats in freezing temperatures. She was pulled out by an Israeli rescue team just as it was planning to leave.

September 1999 Athens, Greece. A woman was revived 45 hours after being buried beneath a collapsed factory.

September 1999 Taipei, Taiwan. Two brothers were rescued after 130 hours buried in a Taipei apartment block. Sun Chi-Kwang, 20, walked out of the wreckage while his brother Sun Chi-feng, 25, was brought out on a stretcher. They stayed alive by eating apples from a fridge lying next to them, which had also prevented debris crushing them. Chang Ching-hung, a six-year-old boy, was dug out after surviving 87 hours sandwiched between concrete slabs ina wrecked building.

August 1999 Golcuk, Turkey. Four-year-old boy Ismail Cimen entombed for 146 hours in a dark nook under a collapsed balcony of his apartment block. His relatives had already prepared a grave for him. Adalet Cetinol, 57, a disabled woman, was buried alive for 131 hours before rescue teams pulled her from the rubble of her home. She had kidney problems but was otherwise unhurt.

January 1995 Japan. A barking dog led rescuers to its owner, Chiyoko Amakawa, 65, who had been buried for 53 hours. She was badly bruised but suffered no broken bones.

July 1990 Philippines. Pedrito Dy, 27, survived 14 days in the collapsed Hyatt Hotel in the Baguio mountains. Two others were rescued after 11 days. They survived by drinking their urine and sipping raindrops that leaked down a lift-shaft.
Richard Nelsson

webTitle: Resignations and attacks leave Schröder rocking

fields.headline: Resignations and attacks leave Schröder rocking
fields.standfirst: With pressure increasing on his cabinet, John Hooper explains why the German chancellor's poll ratings are falling
fields.trailText: With pressure increasing on his cabinet, John Hooper explains why the German chancellor's poll ratings are falling.
fields.body:
Rarely can so many cabinet members have been in hot water as is the case in Germany today.

The finance minister is under attack over his use of air force jets for allegedly non-official purposes. The defence minister has been criticised for failing to heed warnings over the use of depleted uranium.

The labour minister is under fire for failing to get through a reform of the pensions system. And two of their colleagues are being asked to explain away their pasts.

It has emerged that, in the 1970s, the foreign minister was a streetfighting Marxist radical and that, in the 1990s, the health minister ran into serious money problems after her finances became entangled with those of a friend who was caught trying to perpetrate a forged currency scam.

All that is to say nothing of the previous health minister, the erstwhile agriculture minister and their former colleague in charge at transport.

The first two resigned this month amid uproar over the government's botched handling of the spread of BSE to Germany.

The third went at the end of last year after pleading guilty in court to charges of financial wrongdoing in the days when he was a football club chairman.

Yet, arguably, the member of the cabinet who is under closest scrutiny of all is its boss, the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

This week, for the first time since late 1999, when the opposition Christian Democrats were first hit by a scandal over illegal party funding, a poll showed Mr Schröder's Social Democrats trailing in second place.

There is evidence from other polls that that an important reason for this is concern among voters over the chancellor's leadership abilities.

Mr Schröder has protested that this is unfair. At a press conference last week, after his health and agriculture ministers had both resigned on the same day, he complained that the media, having bayed for cabinet blood, had then switched to deploring the number of departures since he took power in late 1998.

His first finance minister, Oskar Lafontaine, also left the cabinet after only few months in office, protesting at the chancellor's leadership style.

Mr Schröder's point is a fair one. Germans set inordinate store by solidity and continuity. In most other European countries, nobody would think it particularly unusual for a government to lose four ministers in more than two years.

In Italy, you could lose four governments in the same period and nobody would turn a hair.

But that is not the whole story. The BSE crisis and Mr Schröder's response to it have revived the central, nagging worry over his performance as chancellor.

The concern is that, while he is good at politicking, he is not at all good on policy.

In one sense, his reshuffle last week was a masterpiece. Mr Schröder's party is in coalition with the Greens. Before last week's resignations, the Social Democrats held agriculture and the Greens health. The chancellor proposed that the two portfolios be switched around.

It was an offer the Greens could scarcely refuse. Even before the BSE crisis erupted, they had argued that the disease was the result of precisely the kind of agriculture they deplored.

The portfolio was taken up by no lesser figure than the Greens' joint leader, Renate Künast.

The net result, though, has been a huge boost to the Social Democrats. They have ended up with the much more powerful health ministry, while their partners' (and rivals') most talented younger leader has set off on what many commentators see as suicide mission.

Ms Künast has little knowledge or experience of farming, and the Greens' demand for a switch to organic methods is not one that can bring short-term results.

In terms of party politics - as an example of politicking - then, Mr Schröder's response was dazzling. But did it have anything to do with a broader vision of where Germany should be heading?

The chancellor implied that it did. He said that he believed that German agriculture should go "green". But that is not what he seems to have believed when he gave the agriculture portfolio to Ms Künast's predecessor, a farmer and a passionate advocate of intensive methods.

Once again, Mr Schröder has left an impression that he sees ideological principles as mere implements in a box of tools he uses to maintain good relations with his party.

It was the same in late 1999 when he had his back to the wall after a series of regional election defeats that left-wing Social Democrats blamed on his espousal of "Third Way" reform.

Overnight, the chancellor switched into old-fashioned interventionist mode and bailed out an ailing construction group. It secured him an easy ride at that year's party conference, but it profoundly disconcerted foreign investors and put a question mark over his commitment to the sort of policies adopted by Tony Blair in Britain.

That question mark has never gone away. One moment, Mr Schröder is handing out swingeing tax cuts; the next he is endorsing Germany's thoroughly archaic legislation on shopping hours.

The ship he captains has shown itself to be remarkably seaworthy. It has come through storms and squalls alike. But it is by no means clear to the passengers which course it is on.

And so it is perhaps only natural that they should be alarmed when, every so often, a member of the crew gets washed off the deck.
