webTitle: Our attitude to death

fields.headline: Lost rites
fields.standfirst:
A few hours earlier, the seven corpses photographed on the floor of a hospital chapel were living, breathing people. Now they are simply objects, waste to be disposed of. And that, writes Sarah Boseley, rather than what it says about the NHS, is why the picture has shocked us

The photograph which horrified Britain
fields.trailText: A few hours earlier, the seven corpses photographed on the floor of a hospital chapel were living, breathing people. Now they are simply objects, waste to be disposed of. And that, writes Sarah Boseley, rather than what it says about the NHS, is why the picture has shocked us.
fields.body:
Six bundles of what we must guess were once living, breathing, excitable and beloved human beings lie in a neat double row on the floor of a hospital chapel. The seventh we don't have to guess at, and betrays the awful truth of the other wrappings. This was a man. Part of his face is visible at one end, and at the other, his lower legs and feet protrude from beneath a yellow blanket.

This photograph of corpses lying on an unrefrigerated floor in Bedford Hospital, which appeared in newspapers yesterday, has caused horror and dismay. It has provoked a new outcry over the state of the National Health Service, in which one hospital had nowhere to store the dead. The hospital mortuary was full and a temporary one was out of action because of problems with the doors.

Yet it could be argued that there is no more respectful place to store bodies in a crisis than in the hospital chapel. Public hygiene would not have allowed them to stay there for long. And in an age when we are used to hearing about patients waiting in corridors on trolleys, why are we so shocked by the idea of corpses lying for a time on the floor? Could the truth be that the horror the picture instils in us has less to do with our worries over NHS resources than some deeply held feelings about what is due to the dead, and some even deeper anxieties about facing the only thing inevitable for all of us?

Jenny Hockey, a senior lecturer in social policy at Hull University, and one of the authors of Beyond the Body: Death and Social Identity, thinks our usual contact with death, in an age where 70% die in hospital, is limited and cosmeticised. If you go to the funeral director's viewing parlour, you see something that resembles the person you loved - dressed in their clothes, perhaps made up. "But what that looks like," she says of the picture at Bedford, "is a heap of rubbish. Our bodies are us. Perhaps increasingly we use our bodies to make statements about who we are, what with the emphasis on dress and fashion and cosmetic surgery and breast implants. But at the end of the day we are just an object, and something to be disposed of."

The bundled bodies were once seven individuals who probably never met in life. They haven't the option to avoid each other in death. "They are jumbled together. It gives you images of the pauper's grave - holocaust imagery and all the mass graves."

Individual achievement in life has long given us the right to individuality when it ends, with a grave bearing our name. Only paupers did not use to get one. The Anatomy Act of the 1830s made it legal for their bodies to be used for dissection. "To have your body given into the hands of people who didn't know you was the final insult," says Hockey.

Somehow, the exposed feet, which have flopped apart lifelessly, are the most shocking part of the Bedford photograph. Having your toes turned up is a metaphor for death, Hockey points out. Dead bodies have been pictured with a luggage label tied to the big toe. It is a powerful image. Hands and feet - once so strong and active - are stilled.

Of course, the fact that the bodies were in a hospital makes it worse. "This is an institution which we hope we can trust, but have lots of worries about. This is like confronting our worst fears. You put yourself in their hands and this is how you end up," says Hockey. A growing trend towards woodland burials, secularised ceremonies in which friends and family celebrate the passing, and young victims of Aids planning their own last rites, assert the importance of individuality to the end and beyond. But bundled bodies on a floor is "like being stripped of who we are by an institution".

Social anthropologist Leonie Kellaher, from the University of North London, thinks the picture is disturbing because of a strange mixture of associations. "It is the kind of scene we associate with famine. They are bound up like something from Ethiopia. It is not a mortuary scene with which people will be familiar, and yet it is in a hospital." In this country, burials take place in coffins, except in the Muslim community where bodies can be wrapped and faces exposed.

She and co-author Doris Francis are working on a book, provisionally entitled The Secret Cemetery. Much of what happens to dead bodies is still secret, Kellaher says, even if they are no longer rifled for their pituitary glands and spare parts as they once were. Processes like the laying out are a mystery to most of us. It wasn't always like that. In the East End in the 1930s, people died at home and a local woman, whose job it was, would prepare the body for viewing in the front room. "She would do it at home because people couldn't afford the funeral expenses. Children would visit dead babies."

Most of us now die a medicalised death. Families are unsure whether they can cope with a death at home. So we have no control over the body of our parent when he or she dies. We expect the hospital to behave in as reverent a fashion as we would. But it doesn't always happen that way.

Malcolm Johnson, chair of the National Funeral College, says that the moral panic over the bodies in the chapel is maybe "an example of being shocked by what we don't know . . . How many people have been to a mortuary? People have no sense of what is custom and practice. There are a lot of things hospitals do at the end of life that are reprehensible."

As soon as a patient dies, he says, "they whisk the body off at great speed. Very often they lie about on trolleys here and there just covered up - sometimes in corridors or waiting outside the mortuary," says Johnson. Their personal effects are put in a black bin-liner to be handed to the relative.

But in an increasingly secular society, where vast numbers of people would say, if asked, that a human being is nothing more than some recyclable material after death, what is this worry about the treatment of our mortal remains? According to Tony Walters, director of the MA course in death and society at Reading University, it has existed in human culture for a very long time, and it runs very deep.

"We are reasonably comfortable with skeletons because they are in their final state, but something in between that and the live body moving around is a very problematic object, especially a freshly dead corpse which somehow looks alive and yet isn't.

"It is why human societies deal with their recently dead in a highly ritualised fashion. All societies create quite well understood ritual rules about how the dead but not buried should be handled. Even a reasonably free society like ours, not governed much by etiquette, has rules. When they are broken, we feel disgust, which is what has happened with these pictures."

It is quite difficult for hospitals to get it right, he says. They are bureaucratic, pragmatic, technology-oriented places. It doesn't mean that they can cope any better with the newly dead. Morticians and others who handle bodies as a routine have their own shield, which is often black humour. We all need a filter.

"Neither the sun nor death can be looked at steadily," said the 17th-century writer la Rochefoucauld. Archaeologists have revealed the death rituals and rites of civilisations through past ages, to the Pyramids and beyond. The deepest act of degradation to someone who has died is to treat their remains without respect. It happened to the Jews in the last war. It happened in past centuries to traitors in England who were hanged, drawn and then quartered.

Death is shocking because we do not understand it, and cannot control it. Religion helps us to cope, as do secular rituals and social rules. When the rules are flouted, and bodies are not tended and cared for in the way we expect, whether in a war like Kosovo or on a hospital floor, we all feel the offence - because it brings home the grim nakedness of death.

fields.bodyText: Six bundles of what we must guess were once living, breathing, excitable and beloved human beings lie in a neat double row on the floor of a hospital chapel. The seventh we don't have to guess at, and betrays the awful truth of the other wrappings. This was a man. Part of his face is visible at one end, and at the other, his lower legs and feet protrude from beneath a yellow blanket. This photograph of corpses lying on an unrefrigerated floor in Bedford Hospital, which appeared in newspapers yesterday, has caused horror and dismay. It has provoked a new outcry over the state of the National Health Service, in which one hospital had nowhere to store the dead. The hospital mortuary was full and a temporary one was out of action because of problems with the doors. Yet it could be argued that there is no more respectful place to store bodies in a crisis than in the hospital chapel. Public hygiene would not have allowed them to stay there for long. And in an age when we are used to hearing about patients waiting in corridors on trolleys, why are we so shocked by the idea of corpses lying for a time on the floor? Could the truth be that the horror the picture instils in us has less to do with our worries over NHS resources than some deeply held feelings about what is due to the dead, and some even deeper anxieties about facing the only thing inevitable for all of us? Jenny Hockey, a senior lecturer in social policy at Hull University, and one of the authors of Beyond the Body: Death and Social Identity, thinks our usual contact with death, in an age where 70% die in hospital, is limited and cosmeticised. If you go to the funeral director's viewing parlour, you see something that resembles the person you loved - dressed in their clothes, perhaps made up. "But what that looks like," she says of the picture at Bedford, "is a heap of rubbish. Our bodies are us. Perhaps increasingly we use our bodies to make statements about who we are, what with the emphasis on dress and fashion and cosmetic surgery and breast implants. But at the end of the day we are just an object, and something to be disposed of." The bundled bodies were once seven individuals who probably never met in life. They haven't the option to avoid each other in death. "They are jumbled together. It gives you images of the pauper's grave - holocaust imagery and all the mass graves." Individual achievement in life has long given us the right to individuality when it ends, with a grave bearing our name. Only paupers did not use to get one. The Anatomy Act of the 1830s made it legal for their bodies to be used for dissection. "To have your body given into the hands of people who didn't know you was the final insult," says Hockey. Somehow, the exposed feet, which have flopped apart lifelessly, are the most shocking part of the Bedford photograph. Having your toes turned up is a metaphor for death, Hockey points out. Dead bodies have been pictured with a luggage label tied to the big toe. It is a powerful image. Hands and feet - once so strong and active - are stilled. Of course, the fact that the bodies were in a hospital makes it worse. "This is an institution which we hope we can trust, but have lots of worries about. This is like confronting our worst fears. You put yourself in their hands and this is how you end up," says Hockey. "It is the kind of scene we associate with famine. They are bound up like something from Ethiopia. It is not a mortuary scene with which people will be familiar, and yet it is in a hospital." She and co-author Doris Francis are working on a book, provisionally entitled The Secret Cemetery. Much of what happens to dead bodies is still secret, Kellaher says, even if they are no longer rifled for their pituitary glands and spare parts as they once were. Processes like the laying out are a mystery to most of us. It wasn't always like that. webTitle: Redford to produce Che Guevara biopic

fields.headline: Redford to produce Che Guevara biopic
fields.trailText: Robert Redford is to executive produce a biopic based on the journal which Che Guevara kept while on a journey around South America as a young student
fields.body:
Robert Redford will serve as the executive producer of The Motorcycle Diaries, a film biopic of revolutionary hero Ernesto "Che" Guevara. Based on the man's own memoirs, the film will chart Guevara's wild early years in 50s South America. Chile's Walter Salles (creator of the acclaimed Central Station) will direct.

First published in 1998, The Motorcycle Diaries are Guevara's own first-hand account of his adventures as a 23-year-old medical student. Posing as a qualified doctor and an expert in the treatment of leprosy, Che lived rough for a time in Argentina and Brazil, living on his wits, hitching rides and stealing food. But this footloose, Huck Finn-style voyage is thought to have politicised the middle-class student.

Guevara later became instrumental in overturning the Batista regime in Cuba and became an icon for students and civil rights campaigners in the US. After the Cuban Revolution, Guevara became active in Marxist uprisings throughout Central America. He was murdered along with his depleted rebel army in Bolivia in 1967.

The Motorcycle Diaries will be produced under the banner of Redford's Wildwood Enterprises and financed by a joint deal between the German media firm Kirch and the Italian broadcaster Mediaset. But the film's production schedule remains a problem. It is thought that the film will not shoot until Salles has completed his next film The Assumption of the Virgin, starring Juliette Binoche. No casting for The Motorcycle Diaries has yet been announced.

 More about Che Guevara.

webTitle: Bodies scandal chief quits

fields.headline: Bodies scandal chief quits
fields.standfirst: The photograph which horrified Britain
fields.trailText: Ministers were furious last night that their efforts to rebuild public confidence in the NHS had been dented by disturbing photographs of bodies lying on the floor of a chapel at Bedford hospital.
fields.body:
Ministers were furious last night that their efforts to rebuild public confidence in the NHS had been dented by disturbing photographs of bodies lying on the floor of a chapel at Bedford hospital.

Ken Williams, the hospital's chief executive, resigned after an internal NHS inquiry found that up to eight bodies at a time were stored on the floor of the chapel of rest, without refrigeration and wrapped only in sheets.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, was said to have been "distressed and appalled" when he was told that the mistake was made after the hospital's temporary mortuary was decommissioned because the doors needed oiling.

Mr Williams said: "We failed on this particular occasion."

Peter Houghton, the NHS executive regional director of the eastern region, said: "The appalling pictures that appeared in newspapers in the past two days have brought to light a totally unacceptable practice at Bedford NHS Trust.

"This has caused considerable distress not only to friends and relatives of the deceased and the general public but to staff within the hospital. Guidance insists that patients are treated with respect and dignity. That was certainly not the case last week."

The episode was particularly infuriating for ministers who had been bracing themselves for stories of difficulties for patients caused by winter pressures on the health service. This was the last hurdle that Tony Blair needed to surmount before calling an early general election in May.

So far the NHS has escaped normal winter pressures and flu levels have been lower than usual for this time of year. The bad publicity was unnecessary and avoidable.

Mr Houghton refused to lay the blame on Mr Williams personally, instead citing more general management problems. "This was a failure of management guidance," he said. "Ken Williams has discussed the findings of the investigation with the chairman of the trust, Professor Andrew Blowers and myself, and felt it right to stand down. I respect his decision."

But Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said the resignation did not remove the need for an independent inquiry. "We have evidence these practices have been going on for at least three years. There are major problems in this hospital that require detailed investigation," he said.

"Any such investigation must be completely independent, with outside bodies scrutinising all aspects of the directions to management and any political interference in clinical priorities and the treatment of patients."

Mr Houghton said the practice of using the chapel of rest as a makeshift mortuary ended last Friday, but he admitted that the practice had occurred before, despite Department of Health guidance issued in May last year insisting that patients are treated with respect and dignity.

He said: "This was clearly not taken on board by the trust's management. Despite having a temporary mortuary available, bodies were stored on the floor in totally inappropriate conditions."

An initial NHS inquiry took place yesterday at the hospital to establish why the temporary mortuary, bought last year to cope with anticipated winter deaths, was closed.

A hospital spokeswoman said the main mortuary was full and the temporary one was closed for "health and safety reasons" when a porter injured his hands trying to open the door.

The hospital insisted that no bodies would have been kept in the chapel for more than 24 hours.

Department of health sources said the action yesterday demonstrated that the NHS was determined to act swiftly to tackle mistakes.

The family of 77-year-old Basil Riches, from Bedford, said they had been horrified by recognising him in newspaper photographs and were planning to take legal advice.

"The whole family is devastated," said Mr Riches' son-in-law, Garry Weaver, who had travelled to England from the US with his wife Julie for Mr Riches' funeral.

"No one from the hospital got in touch to say there was a problem with the mortuary. We haven't had an apology of any kind from the hospital. He has lost all of his dignity. He was a good man who paid his taxes. He didn't deserve this," he said.

Ms Weaver said: "The hospital is going to have to answer an awful lot of questions for leaving people like that just on the floor, discarded like a piece of trash."

webTitle: IT student - sex industry worker?

fields.headline: Risqué business
fields.standfirst: As e-commerce faces meltdown, students enrolling on internet courses could find themselves facing a career in its only saviour - the sex industry.  Mike Haynes reports
fields.trailText: As e-commerce faces meltdown, students enrolling on internet courses could find themselves facing a career in its only saviour - the sex industry. Mike Haynes reports
fields.body:
Less than 12 months ago it all seemed so rosy. Jeff Bezos, the founder and chairman of Amazon, was Time Magazine's man of the year. The National Portrait Gallery presented its 21 leaders for the 21st century, which included several internet entrepreneurs. And everyone was going to make a killing from lastminute.com. How different does it look now? The Financial Times ended the last year quoting an analyst at Merrill Lynch - "People now feel nauseous when you mention the word 'internet', whereas in March it was the new paradigm."

Which is all rather embarrassing if you look at the current UCAS guide and the courses that are hurriedly being prepared for the 2002 issue. There, internet studies and e-commerce is the big growth area.

With higher education institutions pushed to compete in the market place, the internet and e-commerce seemed to be the place to be. Course planning structures were streamlined, new courses rushed out and old ones modified. But now the internet bubble has burst it is not only academic investors in lastminute.com who are left with egg on their faces.

In the 2000 UCAS guide, 13 institutions offered degrees in some aspect of the internet and a further three in internet engineering. For 2001 more than 30 institutions are listed under "internet" alone, offering some 130 degree courses. Some institutions appear to have got swept up more than others. Lincolnshire and Humberside list nearly 30 courses involving the internet, Anglia 19 and Bolton Institute of Higher Education 11. But look beyond the internet section and there is more. In straight business studies, a dozen institutions are offering new e-commerce degrees with Brunel having created three degree routes. And this is to say nothing of the business information technology degrees and the modifications introduced to make other, seemingly "old-fashioned" degrees that much more more alluring.

How did so many in higher education get caught up in the internet and e-commerce bubble? Just as in the real market it is hard to separate real opportunities from the hype; the same problems exist in the pseudo-market of higher education. The search for quick-fix growth areas to establish institutional profiles, the idea of academic entrepreneurship, the aim of attracting funding from cash-rich (but unprofitable) internet firms, as well as the fear of being left out, have all helped to turn heads and drive institutions forward into this new area with scant regard for its real potential.

And what exactly will courses in e-commerce, internet business and marketing teach? In the heady days of the bubble, the talk was of "new paradigm" theory. At the level of the global economy the internet was creating a new industrial revolution that would perpetuate high growth, high productivity and low inflation. E-commerce was said to have rewritten the rule book. Profits no longer mattered, nor did sales. What was important was customer base measured in website hits, which provided the evidence for future potential and inflated share prices.

Now all of this is gone. In the B2C area (business to consumer) big company after big company has crashed. Never mind, said the pundits, the real potential is to B2B (business to business) - until reality forced a more sober view there. Still others insisted that the real potential was hardware and software development, then the puncturing of the boom hit this sector, too. (In California, B2C now means "back to college" as disillusioned twenty-somethings who skipped university to make dot.com millions rethink their options).

The irony is that much of the e-economy has been a gigantic value destroyer. With capital more or less free, venture after venture has been started, buoyed up only by hot air and misguided expectations and universities have meekly followed. Now it has exploded. There is no new paradigm and e-commerce has not rewritten the rules of business success.

But this presents a problem. Traditional business studies courses developed the idea of teaching by example. Does this still apply to e-commerce courses? Business studies has also taught by means of case studies with students solving real problems. But what inspiration will they get from a diet of case studies of failures such as Boxman, Clickmango, boo.com or "successes" such as lastminute.com or Amazon, which have yet to show any profit at all?

The hope of those putting forward this rash of new courses is that the e-economy will come right in the end and when the first students graduate a more stable growth path will have emerged. Just as railways survived the first railway manias, so will the internet and e-commerce. But cynics can equally point to the tulip-buying investment mania of the 17th century. Tulips, too, survived but they hardly formed the basis of a new wave of capitalist development. And in any case, try searching the UCAS guide for degrees in railway or tulip studies.

But the lack of honesty in the evaluation of the internet and e-commerce goes further. Sex is the one area that is booming on the internet. This is not surprising because sex is the most widely used search term. But the central role of selling sex on the internet and e-commerce activity is systematically obscured by the way that sex sites are excluded from published lists of top sites.

Last year, Forester Research suggested that successful US sex sites expected 50 million hits a month and generated incomes of $5m-$10m. Annually they estimated that US internet sex sites produce $1bn of revenue and are growing faster than any other part of the e-economy. By the middle of the decade their revenues will be over $5bn. This is not only big business but highly profitable e-business. Indeed, at one stage some estimates suggested that the major ity of e-commerce activity was in the "adult" industry and if the share has fallen it is possibly still the biggest single e-commerce market.

How much of this will figure in any of these new university and college courses? Like top-shelf publishing and video development, internet sex sites invite universal condemnation yet underpin a vibrant sector that is more closely related to the mainstream than most people understand.

Mari Kim Coleman, Britain's managing director of internet research group MMXI, says: "Porn sites are among the top 20 sites in some countries. Adult entertainment is the 11th most popular category on the internet in Britain."

When an international conference on streaming video over the internet was held last October, entrepreneurs from the "adult industry" boasted that sex sites provided the successful business model for the internet: an expectation of moving into the black within six months of start-up with profit margins of 20% - an achievement that puts Amazon's long search to break even into context.

To achieve this, the sex site developers told how they had produced the easiest sites to navigate in order to attract the biggest market. They compared their success with a failed start-up such as boo.com whose software was so sophisticated that many people could not access it. Indeed, even the technology of the internet itself to a considerable extent has been driven by the needs of the sex industry (including the much talked about broadband) as sites try to trap surfers with faster loading and more attractive images.

None of this happens accidentally. Sex sites need specialists in web design, marketing, e-commerce, security, encryption and so on. They also need people able to manipulate photo images (you didn't think those pictures of Britney Spears were real, did you?) and to design the technology to do this. And they need the legal protection of teams of lawyers who know about internet law etc. All of which means that, like it or not, the legitimate and less legitimate "adult industry" is absorbing a lot of internet talent and it is likely to absorb a significant group of those who come out of the 2001 UCAS cohort.

Yet when a group of enterprising Edinburgh graduates were found last year to have set up highly profitable Antigua-based sex sites they were roundly condemned. What seemed to upset people most was that, competing with the new higher education courses, they were offering business advice about how to emulate their own success. Under pressure from the British police they were deported from Antigua but appear to have merely shifted their sites' locations and presumably continue to rake in large profits.

Whether they will appear on the new courses as an inspirational model is doubtful. This is the one area these students won't be allowed to study and the one area their teachers will be reluctant to research. Indeed, accessing the real growth area of the internet and e-commerce is not only forbidden on university computers it can get staff and students dismissed - which is why some of the research for this piece was done at home!

 Mike Haynes lectures in European studies at Wolverhampton University

This is not surprising because sex is the most widely used search term. But the central role of selling sex on the internet and e-commerce activity is systematically obscured by the way that sex sites are excluded from published lists of top sites. Last year, Forester Research suggested that successful US sex sites expected 50 million hits a month and generated incomes of $5m-$10m. Annually they estimated that US internet sex sites produce $1bn of revenue and are growing faster than any other part of the e-economy. By the middle of the decade their revenues will be over $5bn. This is not only big business but highly profitable e-business. Indeed, at one stage some estimates suggested that the major ity of e-commerce activity was in the "adult" industry and if the share has fallen it is possibly still the biggest single e-commerce market. How much of this will figure in any of these new university and college courses? Like top-shelf publishing and video development, internet sex sites invite universal condemnation yet underpin a vibrant sector that is more closely related to the mainstream than most people understand. Mari Kim Coleman, Britain's managing director of internet research group MMXI, says: "Porn sites are among the top 20 sites in some countries. Adult entertainment is the 11th most popular category on the internet in Britain." When an international conference on streaming video over the internet was held last October, entrepreneurs from the "adult industry" boasted that sex sites provided the successful business model for the internet: an expectation of moving into the black within six months of start-up with profit margins of 20% - an achievement that puts Amazon's long search to break even into context. To achieve this, the sex site developers told how they had produced the easiest sites to navigate in order to attract the biggest market. They compared their success with a failed start-up such as boo.com whose software was so sophisticated that many people could not access it. Indeed, even the technology of the internet itself to a considerable extent has been driven by the needs of the sex industry (including the much talked about broadband) as sites try to trap surfers with faster loading and more attractive images. None of this happens accidentally. Sex sites need specialists in web design, marketing, e-commerce, security, encryption and so on. They also need people able to manipulate photo images (you didn't think those pictures of Britney Spears were real, did you?) and to design the technology to do this. And they need the legal protection of teams of lawyers who know about internet law etc. All of which means that, like it or not, the legitimate and less legitimate "adult industry" is absorbing a lot of internet talent and it is likely to absorb a significant group of those who come out of the 2001 UCAS cohort. Yet when a group of enterprising Edinburgh graduates were found last year to have set up highly profitable Antigua-based sex sites they were roundly condemned. What seemed to upset people most was that, competing with the new higher education courses, they were offering business advice about how to emulate their own success. Under pressure from the British police they were deported from Antigua but appear to have merely shifted their sites' locations and presumably continue to rake in large profits. Whether they will appear on the new courses as an inspirational model is doubtful. This is the one area these students won't be allowed to study and the one area their teachers will be reluctant to research. Indeed, accessing the real growth area of the internet and e-commerce is not only forbidden on university computers it can get staff and students dismissed - which is why some of the research for this piece was done at home!  Mike Haynes lectures in European studies at Wolverhampton University

webTitle: Newsplayer counts on Frost interviews

fields.headline: Newsplayer counts on Frost interviews
fields.standfirst: Dec 14: Frost puts interviews online
fields.trailText:
10.15am: Online archive firm Newsplayer is counting on Sir David Frost's reputation to open doors to the lucrative US market, reports Dan Milmo.
Dec 14: Frost puts interviews online
fields.body:
Online archive firm Newsplayer is counting on Sir David Frost's reputation to open doors to the lucrative US market.

The company teamed up with the world-famous broadcaster in December to sell hundreds of his interviews with the rich and famous over the net, and now Newsplayer expects the dollars to start rolling in.

"The US market is strategically and commercially very important to us, and Sir David is the key to entering it," said Paul Duffen, Newsplayer chief executive.

"He has an enormous amount of respect in the US, and we are going there next week to sell the TV syndication rights."

In a boost to the company's profile, Sir David today joined the Newsplayer board as non-executive director.

Sir David is set to make millions from the internet venture, which will enable him to cash in on his formidable collection of interviews including historic encounters with US president Nixon, Yasser Arafat and Mikhail Gorbachev.

Mr Duffen added that Sir David will "open doors" across the Atlantic, and the company is looking to make similar deals over the next year.

"Our proposition is very straightforward - we will make revenue from your content. We can go to people with a solution to making revenue from their archive," said Mr Duffen.

However, Newsplayer's maiden results today showed the company is still finding its feet, with a pre-tax loss of £2.6m and turnover of £128,000.

The company is prepared to wait for high-speed internet access to take root in the UK and around the world before the revenues start to flow in, although it launches an ambitious programme for UK schools next month.

Newsplayer's key selling point is its massive archive of footage from the ITN and Reuters news services, which cover the key events of the last century and last over 1,000 hours.

But accessing the material remains an issue, and Mr Duffen added that interactive and internet TV was a development that will fit Newsplayer, with the US again the most obvious target market.

"We provide content and the likes of AOL are internet broadcasters, so they are a potential client for us," he said.

In order to work around its small cash balance of £6.8m, Newsplayer is looking to build more joint ventures in the mould of the Sir David Frost deal. It has already signed up Microsoft, Yahoo! and BT as business partners.

"We will look to acquire content, but the last thing we want to do is pay for it. It has not limited our choices so far," said Mr Duffen.

webTitle: New contract for CNN's Amanpour

fields.headline: New contract for CNN's Amanpour
fields.standfirst: Jan 11: CNN braced for job cuts
fields.trailText:
9.30am: CNN's chief international correspondent, Christiane Amanpour, has signed a new contract, reports Matt Wells.
Jan 11: CNN braced for job cuts
fields.body:
CNN's award-winning chief international correspondent, Christiane Amanpour, has signed a new contract with the broadcaster, ending speculation that her future was in doubt.

The news organisation said that it had signed Amanpour in what it described as a 'multi-year' contract.

Her role will be expanded: she becomes CNN's chief "troubleshooter", anchoring special event coverage and breaking news programmes.

She will also prepare several one-hour "signature" pieces each year and will report for CNN*s websites, including CNN.com Europe.

There had been fears that, as CNN strove to cut costs, high-salaried stars would be eased out. But CNN stressed it was committed to Ms Amanpour.

Eason Jordan, chief news executive and newsgathering president for the CNN News Group, said: "Christiane has been at the very heart of CNN's internationally renowned reporting over the years.

"She is an exceptionally talented and an incredibly courageous journalist, and as we commit ourselves to reporting from every part of the world we are extremely proud and pleased to have Christiane working alongside us at CNN."

Ms Amanpour said: "I'm delighted to be staying with CNN, which remains committed to gathering and reporting serious international news and broadcasting it in the United States and across the world."

webTitle: In brief: Oliver Stone to quit film-making

fields.headline: Oliver Stone to quit film-making
fields.standfirst: Plus: Winona Ryder may star in biopic of tragic Irish journalist; Billie Piper pulls out of film debut in Tabloid TV
fields.trailText: Plus: Winona Ryder may star in biopic of tragic Irish journalist; Billie Piper pulls out of film debut in Tabloid TV
fields.body:
 Oscar-winning director Oliver Stone has revealed in an American magazine that he plans to stop making movies when he has finished his next two projects. The 54-year-old director, who is currently working on Beyond Borders with Ralph Fiennes, told Premiere that the project after Borders will be his "final moviea funeral oration." However, Stone, who has often caused controversy with films such as Platoon, Wall Street, JFK and Natural Born Killers, promises that his final project will be more light and fluffy. "It's going to be a date movie, you'll see," he told the magazine. "I've never done something like this."

 Winona Ryder is rumoured to be in negotiations to star in a new film about the life of Veronica Guerin, an Irish journalist who was gunned down in 1996 after her continual investigations into the drug barons of Dublin. According to entertainment site showbiz Ireland, Jerry Bruckheimer, who has just finished filming Pearl Harbour, has bought the rights to the project. "Veronica made a difference, everyone can identify with that. The ambiguities in her character make her more appealing with that. Why would a woman, who has a husband and a young son and who gets shot, still keep going? What drives her? Did she take the threat seriously?" said Bruckheimer, who hopes to start filming in Ireland next May. Oscar nominee Joan Allen played a character based on Guerin last year in When the Sky Falls which was written by Michael Sheridan, a friend and fellow journalist for the Sunday Independent where she worked.

 According to reports in today's tabloids, teenage pop singer Billie Piper has been forced to pull out of her debut film role in Tabloid TV because boyfriend, Chris Evans, believes one of the less sympathetic characters is based on him. Piper's management apparently called the film's producers on Sunday to say the singer was pulling out of the project. Piper now faces legal action for breaking her contract. A senior source on the film set says, "We have been told that Chris put pressure on Billie and told her not to take part. Everyone is furious." Last night a spokesman for Billie said, "She is unwell. It's nothing very serious but she won't be filming today or Tuesday. As far as I'm aware she will be returning to film her scenes."

webTitle: Casting news: Malkovich gets romantic for Claude Lelouch

fields.headline: Malkovich gets romantic for Claude Lelouch
fields.standfirst: Plus: Ice Cube buddies up to Mike Epps for diamond heist; and will it be third time lucky for Tim Allen?
fields.trailText: Plus: Ice Cube buddies up to Mike Epps for diamond heist; and will it be third time lucky for Tim Allen?
fields.body:
 Long a favourite of European film-makers, John Malkovich, star of the forthcoming Shadow of the Vampire (pictured), is to appear in the French drama And Now Ladies and Gentleman for French writer-director Claude Lelouch. The film circles around the love affair between a crime boss (Malkovich) and a barroom singer (Patricia Kaas). But Malkovich was not the immediate choice for the role. Lelouch has confessed that he originally wrote the part with Dustin Hoffman in mind, and then briefly considered home-grown star Daniel Auteuil before alighting on his final choice. Production begins next month.

 Three Kings star Ice Cube will star in the buddy action-comedy All About the Benjamins for debut director Kevin Bray. The four-square former rapper will perform alongside old cohort Mike Epps (Next Friday) as a bounty hunter and his charge who unwittingly become embroiled in a diamond heist. The film will be backed by Absolute Entertainment.

 It seems to be a case of sticking with who you know for Tim Allen - all set to star in Joe Somebody, the comic's third collaboration with director John Pasquin. Allen had been poised to begin filming a sequel to his 1994 outing The Santa Clause until the project ran into script difficulties and he is also toying with an adaptation of Dr Seuss's The Cat in the Hat. Allen has worked with Pasquin on The Santa Clause and Jungle 2 Jungle, as well as on various episodes of his Home Improvement TV sitcom.

webTitle: Ad industry welcomes ITV strategy shift

fields.headline: Ad industry welcomes ITV strategy shift
fields.standfirst: Jan 15: ITV ditches peak-time target
fields.trailText:
9am: The advertising industry has welcomed ITV's announcement yesterday that it will target the BBC in 2001, writes Claire Cozens.
Jan 15: ITV ditches peak-time target
fields.body:
The advertising industry has welcomed ITV's announcement yesterday that it will target the BBC in 2001.

Ad agencies said that it made sense for ITV to focus on defending its audience from an increasingly populist BBC1.

"From an advertising point of view it is important that the commercial sector performs well so it makes sense for ITV to see the BBC as the main competitor," said Jim Marshall, chairman of the media policy group at the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising, which represents agencies.

"The BBC is potentially the most competitive of the broadcasters and has shown that it is quite happy to be populist."

Mr Marshall said he would have preferred a firmer commitment from ITV on audience share in 2001, but added: "Targets can only work if they are very specific anyway.

"ITV found itself with some very negative PR last year when it failed to make its targets so I can understand why they've decided to do things differently this year."

Bob Wootton, director of media services at the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, also reacted favourably to the announcement.

"ITV has demonstrably listened to advertisers' concerns. The all-embracing audience share figure made ITV a hostage to fortune and measuring itself in relation to the most competitive mass-market TV channel - BBC 1 - is more relevant in the changing broadcast landscape." he said.

"ITV has also recognised our members' concerns for specific audiences and there is a renewed commitment to daytime audiences, a commitment to ABC1 and 16 to 24-year-old audiences - the advertisers' Holy Grail."

Elsewhere, media buying agencies broadly welcomed the news.

"There was a very strong sense of ITV competing. They have come up with lots of new ideas and a very cohesive package," said Jerry Hill, Initiative Media group chief executive.

David Peters, broadcast planning director at Carat, said that while last year was not ITV's best, the broadcaster was well placed to improve its performance in 2001.

"I think they're doing the right think in targeting the BBC and it is good to see they're not putting all their eggs in one basket in terms of programming," he said.

webTitle: DoubleClick hires privacy expert

fields.headline: DoubleClick hires privacy expert
fields.trailText: 9.30am: DoubleClick, the US online ad firm embroiled in a privacy dispute last year, has hired a European privacy expert, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
DoubleClick, the US online advertising firm which was embroiled in a privacy dispute last year, is attempting sure there is no repeat within its European operations.

The firm was investigated by US watchdogs following allegations that it was tracking customers' surfing habits and logging the information in a marketing database.

DoubleClick in the UK has just appointed online privacy expert Amanda Chandler as director of data protection, and she admitted that current EU privacy laws were chaotic.

"The European directive on data protection is being distributed in different countries at different times." she said.

"We are living in a state of flux, so it is very difficult to be certain whether the one interpretation is definitive. My role will be to keep abreast of these developments for our clients."

Ms Chandler, who worked at the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner, will also ensure that DoubleClick follows the UK Data Protection Act.

"The internet is a very complex thing and it is early days for the industry. There is still a lot of work to be done as the law develops," she added.

In order to settle last year's dispute, DoubleClick appointed lawyer Jules Polonetsky as chief privacy officer and established privacy guidelines.

He is determined that the company, which runs and tracks online adverts for clients, will lead the way in internet privacy.

"We take great pains to ensure that we follow data protection laws, and we are leading the privacy issue in terms of best practice," he said.

webTitle: Salford estates fight to turn back tide of decay

fields.headline: Salford estates fight to turn back tide of decay
fields.trailText: Run down is a description which barely conveys the extent of boarded up properties, graffiti and litter associated with the Seedley and Langworthy estates in Salford, where residents already have a say in their community, writes Helen Carter
fields.body:
Run down is a description which barely conveys the extent of boarded up properties, graffiti and litter associated with the Seedley and Langworthy estates in Salford, where residents already have a say in their community.

The estates, with 75% of the housing owner occupied, suffer from a phenomenon which many thought had disappeared in the early 1990s. Terrace houses once worth £30,000 are now routinely sold for as little as £3,000.

The Seedley and Langworthy Partnership is working to regenerate the areas. At the next board meeting, the issue of whether it needs a neighbourhood manager will be discussed.

The partnership has six members who are residents on its board, which meets every six weeks.

Locals can also voice their concerns via the Seedley and Langworthy Initiative, which brings together four of the area's residents' associations.

Hazel Blears, Salford MP, who chairs the partnership, said: "One of the exciting things about the neighbourhood managers is they work across local authorities, health services and police to exercise political muscle. I will be seeking to get this issue on the agenda at the next partnership meeting."

She said the partnership was absolutely committed to making sure the project was community led.

"We have got a master plan, which is a vision for the next seven to 10 years. There are four main tasks - improving the living environment, young people, crime and community safety and economic development skills."

She said people in the area had lost confidence and there was a lot of conflict and anger.

"We want to recreate the sense of community which we had 30 years ago. Where people would look out for each other and not just shut their door and walk away."

Many people living there feel that the speed of change is too slow.

It takes time to filter money from the single regeneration budget through to the community. In 1999 the partnership secured a £13.7m SRB grant.

But the money is being used in many positive ways. Victims of repeated crimes can get money to buy alarms and window locks.

In April the Sure Start Centre will open, a place where young families can go for advice on healthy liv ing. It will include mothers and toddlers groups, a community cafe and toy library.

The Seedley and Langworthy Initiative has a shop on Langworthy Road, which opened in 1999 where residents can voice concerns about problems on the estate.

Marion Gattens, who chairs the initiative, said the majority of people in the area used the shop. "They will go in if they have a problem with their housing benefit or rubbish accumulating outside. People feel that they will get answers to their questions and that we will have some sort of clout to deal with the council."

She blames many of the estates' problems on unscrupulous landlords rehousing people there in the 1990s who had previously been evicted from council estates.

"They only wanted people on income support because there was more money in it," she added. "Then other people would leave the street and those left behind would not have the support of their neighbours. I live around here and half my street have left - it can be quite frightening."

But she said the area was improving and the Chimney Pot community centre had reopened and was being used by older children.

webTitle: Quick fixes give fillip to East End experiment

fields.headline: Quick fixes give fillip to East End experiment
fields.trailText: The experience of 3,800 households in West Ham and Plaistow in one of the most deprived parts of London's East End shows what the government is trying to achieve in the latest version of its neighbourhood renewal policy. John Carvel reports
fields.body:
The experience of 3,800 households in West Ham and Plaistow in one of the most deprived parts of London's East End shows what the government is trying to achieve in the latest version of its neighbourhood renewal policy.

A year ago they were chosen to be in the first wave of a new approach to making regeneration stick. The theory was that local people would be encouraged to take ownership of projects by electing representatives on to a partnership board with power to decide how the renewal budget would be spent. Instead of concentrating on repairing the bricks and mortar of run-down estates, the projects would be geared to tackle the whole range of social problems including unemployment, crime, education, health and social networks.

The first success came in elections to the partnership board in June. Turnout at 30% was well above average for the council in the London borough of Newham.

John Thorne, a Newham councillor and chairman of the partnership board, said local people were more inclined to vote because they saw they could have a direct influence on a local regeneration budget worth £54.6m over 10 years.

Many of the schemes will take years to come to fruition. For example the partnership has decided to demolish two high rise blocks of flats on the Brooks Road estate in Plaistow and renovate three. It is expected to recommend reorganisation of tenancies so that pensioners do not live on the same decks as families with young children.

But the project has also implemented quick changes requested by the community. They include three teacher's assistants for classes in the top year at Portway primary school to help children from a wide range of ethnic backgrounds make the transition to secondary school.

Improved lighting has been installed in a crime blackspot. Facilitators have been appointed at GP surgeries to deal with social problems that might be damaging patients' physical or mental health.

But officers have had difficulty solving problems that require action by different local and central government agencies.

Tracy Boscott, deputy co-ordinator of the project's delivery team, said the apparently simple task of dealing with an abandoned car could be lost in overlapping procedures operated by the police and the council's removal services. The plan to appoint neighbourhood managers announced yesterday would help to resolve these problems because they would have enough clout to make services user-friendly.

The new deal for communities scheme in Newham is being run in four small areas with some of the borough's most serious deprivation. But this part of east London is also benefiting from economic growth.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, visited it yesterday and saw the Excel docklands exhibition centre which is expected to create 14,000 jobs. Officials from the benefits agency are helping to train the local unemployed to take advantage of these opportunities.

He said the neighbourhood renewal scheme was "a classic example of how public money reaps huge rewards for the country and for the individuals concerned".

But other forces are at work in the area. Sir Robin Wells, leader of Newham council, said new transport links were helping the borough to record the fastest rise in house prices in London. Unemployment is below 10,000 for the first time since the 1970s.

webTitle: Hatfield: the warnings that Railtrack ignored

fields.headline: Hatfield: the warnings that Railtrack ignored
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Documents revealing that senior rail managers, including Railtrack officials, were fully aware of a cracked rail at the site of the Hatfield crash at least 10 months before the fatal accident last October, but failed to remedy it, have been obtained by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Documents revealing that senior rail managers, including Railtrack officials, were fully aware of a cracked rail at the site of the Hatfield crash at least 10 months before the fatal accident last October, but failed to remedy it, have been obtained by the Guardian.

Internal documents from Balfour Beatty Rail Maintenance Ltd, the contractor appointed by Railtrack to maintain the Hatfield section, show for the first time that two separate recommendations to replace a suspect section of the track where the derailment later occurred, were ignored.

The two key recommendations from the site manager to the area maintenance engineer came in November 1999 and January last year.

A fax on November 17 1999 proposed that the section of track from London should be rerailed within six months. The work should therefore have been completed by May 17 at the latest. The Hatfield crash occurred exactly five months later, on October 17.

The second document obtained is a Balfour Beatty track inspection sheet dated January 11 last year. The same area is recorded by the site manager as having "gauge corner cracking" which was "showing bad". The request was repeated to rerail the track within six months.

Railtrack was formally told of the problem on December 6, 1999. It has only publicly conceded that it was aware of the situation in January last year and that the section was reassessed for rerailing last July.

Some work was completed in May. The fatal section of the Hatfield line was treated by grinding on September 4 and 5 as part of the "planned preventative maintenance to stop rail breaks and improve ride quality", Railtrack said. The rest was due to be finished last November.

Industry sources told the Guardian last night that Balfour Beatty staff in the Hitchin area, where the Hatfield site is situated, had been concerned about the state of the rails, but no remedial action was taken.

The documents do not explain why speed restrictions were not imposed when it became known that the track was deteriorating.

The company wrote to Railtrack on December 6 1999 to inform it of the problem. There followed a joint visit to the site by Railtrack and Balfour Beatty on February 15 last year "to look at pricing and re-railing".

Balfour Beatty said that by the end of last March, Railtrack had "got it in their programme", but asked Jarvis, another contractor, to do the work because it carries out renewal work for Railtrack on the east coast main line between London and the Scottish border.

The work was scheduled for May, the materials were delivered but only half the job was carried out.

Balfour Beatty said: "The expectation was that the work should have been completed, but it was not. We accept that we have the authority to impose speed restrictions, but this was not done."

Railtrack said the site was due for rerailing in the spring of last year "but, for whatever reasons, it did not happen." Asked why no speed restrictions were enforced, a spokesman replied: "That is one of the matters which the current investigation is examining".

It said its maintenance contractors employed a "rapid response provision", allowing them to impose speed restrictions or "order the immediate replacement of rail".

Railtrack said it could not comment directly about the November and January recommendations to replace the suspect track, but claimed that "the cost of rerailing the track is never an issue where safety is concerned". After the Hatfield crash, Railtrack identified another 300 sites throughout the country where gauge corner cracking was severe. This led to the introduction of hundreds of extra speed restrictions.

Railtrack's woes mounted last night as it threatened to pull out of the £2.5bn second stage of the Channel Tunnel rail link in a worsening financial crisis which will leave it with £8bn of debt by 2003.

Its chief exeutive said the company would have debts of £3bn by the end of the year, rising by a couple of billion a year thereafter. The Hatfield crash has so far cost it £600m.

webTitle: Court in dark as imperial weights go on trial

fields.headline: Court in dark as imperial weights go on trial
fields.standfirst:
Lights go out as defiant greengrocer is put in dock for refusing to go metric and selling bananas by pounds and ounces

The issue explained:
Weights and measures
fields.trailText: Lights go out as defiant greengrocer is put in dock for refusing to go metric and selling bananas by pounds and ounces.
fields.body:
The battle of the imperial bananas began in earnest yesterday, but only after two foreign units of measurement had caused chaos.

The German ohms and French amps in the electricity system at Sunderland magistrates court blacked out the building just as the last stand of the pound and ounce was due to begin.

The bench, barristers and a circus of imperial weights and measures experts shifted boxes of law books half a mile - or a little less than a kilometre - uphill to the city council chamber for the start of a far-reaching EU test case, drawing on sections of Magna Carta, Latin tags and the fuel problems of his lawyer's Bentley, in which greengrocer Steve Thoburn is hoping to defend the traditional British right to ignore the metric system.

"This dates back to the 1864 Metric Weights and Measures Act," said his barrister Michael Shrimpton, a constitutional expert, who accused EU insistence on metric-only sales as riding roughshod over parliament. "We have always tolerated eccentricity in this country and if a customer wants to go to Mr Thoburn and order 0.45359337 kilos of bananas instead of a pound, that act says he is perfectly entitled to do so."

Mr Thoburn's stand is for pounds and ounces devotees to be allowed the same flexibility, which his market stall in Sunderland allows them to do. He denies two counts of selling bananas in imperial weights only to undercover staff of Sunderland city council, which has brought the prosecution.

Eleanor Sharpston QC, for the council, said that the case was about enforcing the will of parliament, rather than Brussels, and avoiding confusion in shoppers' minds. She said: "This prosecution is entirely brought to enforce a valid act of parliament which is the law of the land."

Mr Shrimpton said Mr Thoburn, 36 and a father of two, was a John Hampden of the weighing scales, whose "courage has implications far beyond greengrocers, bananas and the fair city of Sunderland". He told the court: "The European is entitled to his policy. What he is not entitled to do is to apply that policy in defiance of the British parliament."

The case hinges on whether the EU's 1994 units of measurement regulations, nodded through by the Commons without serious discussion, take precedence over the 1985 Weights and Measures Act, which continued the century-old tradition of allowing businesses and customers to opt for either system.

Mr Shrimpton admitted that petrol sales had in effect sold the metric pass. He said: "I never understand what 110 litres is when I put it into my Bentley."

He drew strength from the number of journalists in court from the US, the world's main bastion of imperial measures, and pointed out that the undercover raid had taken place - "whether significantly or not, I don't know" - on July 4. There had been no need for cloak and dagger work, he said, as Mr Thoburn not only made no attempt to hide his love of pounds and ounces, but actually shouted it, in the manner of market traders.

The case is the first of a potential series involving recalcitrant retailers across Britain, whose loyalty to imperial measures is supported by the UK Independence Party and celebrities. Goodwill messages for Mr Thoburn have been winged to Sunderland by Jilly Cooper, Keith Waterhouse and Ian Botham among others.

The leader of the UKIP, Jeffrey Titford, who admitted being a European MP, said: "This case will highlight the way that the EU is imposing its will on British culture." His confidence in victory was echoed by Vivian Linacre, director of the British Weights and Measures Association, who said: "Ultimately this will go our way, but it could go all the way to the House of Lords first."

The legal costs are expected to top £250,000, but the affair has been commercially encouraging for Mr Thoburn who is a local hero in Sunderland.

He recently expanded his market stall to include a shop over the road, where he hopes that his confiscated imperial-only scales will eventually have pride of place.

The case continues.

webTitle: NHS 'must speed up change'

fields.headline: NHS 'must speed up change'
fields.trailText: The president of the General Medical Council, Sir Donald Irvine, will today vent his frustrations at the unwillingness of doctors to move faster to change the old NHS paternalistic culture. Sarah Boseley reports
fields.body:
The president of the General Medical Council, Sir Donald Irvine, will today vent his frustrations at the unwillingness of doctors to move faster to change the old NHS paternalistic culture.

His hard-hitting speech will warn that the government is waiting in the wings to take over if public confidence in the medical profession is not restored.

Sir Donald, whose agenda for reform of the profession has been consistently blocked by hard-line members of the British Medical Association, will say that much more must be done to demonstrate that doctors are no longer arrogant inhabitants of ivory towers.

"The cultural flaws in the medical profession show up as excessive paternalism, lack of respect for patients and their right to make decisions about their care, secrecy, and complacency about poor practice. webTitle: Stourton denies he's being axed

fields.headline: Stourton denies he's being axed
fields.trailText: 8.45am: BBC Radio 4 Today show presenter Ed Stourton has dismissed reports that he is to be dropped for being too posh, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC Radio 4 Today show presenter Ed Stourton has dismissed weekend newspaper reports suggesting he is to be dropped from the show for being too posh.

"It's nonsense," said Mr Stourton, who is on location filming a BBC2 series in Europe this week.

"I have spoken to my lords and masters and I can quite categorically deny that it's true."

Mr Stourton added that he was in the middle of his one-year rolling contract, which is not up for renewal again until September.

"I'm puzzled as to where the story came from," he said. "It doesn't really fit with the remit of the programme. Today is so ruthlessly anti-dumbing down in its culture."

A friend of Mr Stourton suggested the rumour had surfaced as part of "the vicious politics within the Today programme about who replaces John Humphrys" as one of the show's main presenters.

"It's a classic bit of cut-throat BBC politics," this source said.

webTitle: Jazz review: John Ellis Big Bang

fields.headline: Jazz review
fields.standfirst: John Ellis Big Bang,  Jazz Cafe, London   ****
fields.trailText: John Ellis Big Bang, Jazz Cafe, London ****
fields.body:
Either there are a lot of Mancunians in London who are following Manchester's thriving young jazz underground, or the charisma of singer/pianist John Ellis's Big Bang has reached those parts of the population most localised jazz phenomena don't reach. The Jazz Cafe was jammed on Sunday for the London leg of the Big Bang's current tour, its first venture outside of the north-west - although, as Ellis has admitted, a good many of his musicians have already gravitated south for work and made a lot of friends doing so.

Ellis is a dynamic 32-year-old who might be conveniently described as a cross between Django Bates and Jools Holland, and who is by repute a mover and shaker in the creative music of his home city. Big Bang, the vigorous 12-piece that evolved out of his Frank Zappa tribute band in 1995, is an irrepressible outfit that sustains the effect of somebody conducting an animated conversation at a loud party for a couple of hours. It also packs some excellent soloists.

The band can snap in and out of pumping 1940s big-band swing, raucous jazz-funk, soul vocals and Hammond organ barrages without pausing for thought. In guitarist Mike Outram, trombonist Chris Bridges, and the rugged keyboard interjections and punchy ensemble playing of Ellis himself, there are individual voices as strong as the main events.

Big Bang was preceded by another young Manchester outfit, the Stuart McCallum Quartet; they looked like Big Issue vendors, and played a scalding brand of guitar-led jazz-funk driven by exhilaratingly thrashy percussion.

Big Bang themselves began with a sermonising Charles Mingus-like overture, switched into headlong funk for a wild solo from Outram, behind which the others began to clap, and travelled via wandering contrapuntal horn lines back to the main theme.

Ellis established that his jazz roots were as strong as his party instincts with a late-Duke Ellington blues that made the saxes elegantly reproduce the authentic swell and withdrawal of the maestro's reed sound. A subtle orchestral original that followed had its intertwining lines delivered with Big Bang's characteristic firmness and vigour, before turning into a Latin groover.

Big Bang makes vocals a central strength of its show, with three singers, including the leader, unfurling a sharply arranged repertoire mingling the eager clamour of contemporary pop with a cheesy jauntiness from Cuban dance music. Ellis's opinion is that you can raise hell in a provincial city without anybody in the wider world hearing the faintest tinkle of it, but maybe in Big Bang's case that's about to change.

webTitle: Side lines

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: Having finished off the Hogmanay gin and run out of vivid combinations of root vegetables to pulp into soup, Sidelines left the confines of her wintry city cell and ventured out into the genuine countryside at the weekend.
fields.body:
Having finished off the Hogmanay gin and run out of vivid combinations of root vegetables to pulp into soup, Sidelines left the confines of her wintry city cell and ventured out into the genuine countryside at the weekend.

Green space sartorial decisions are confounding at best, dictated as they are by that unknowable crispy/muddy underfoot duality, affording an unfortunate opportunity for bulkiness. I was forced to content myself with the knowledge that I was at least wearing my scarf draped in exactly the right way. My glamorous companion was a study in textured grey.

And so to the forest. The actual business of walking presented further problems. Competitive acorn gathering aside, what exactly does one do? Active stretching felt like a possibility only for a moment. As the sun proferred its mandarin glow through the naked trees, it became evident that there were no aminals to pat, not even a badger. But there is a glimmer of hope.

Ecologists are presently working to reintroduce the beaver to the British mainland, four centuries after they were skinned and boiled to extinction. Baby beavers hold hands when they sleep. So it is only a matter of time, surely, before they are happily holding hands with Sidelines on a forest jaunt.

webTitle: Analysis: Pan-European political parties' recruitment crisis

fields.headline: The party's over
fields.standfirst: Throughout Europe and across the political spectrum, parties are finding it ever harder to attract and retain members
fields.trailText: Throughout Europe and across the political spectrum, parties are finding it ever harder to attract and retain members.
fields.body:
When Gordon Brown appealed for volunteers the other day he was not suggesting people rushed out to protect birds or conserve stately homes - even though the National Trust (2.5m members) and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (1.04m) are among the country's largest voluntary organisations. The chancellor had something more socially committed in mind.

Yet what he did not say was that the largest voluntary organisations with social purpose are political parties. The omission was typical. In terms of moral worth, joining a housing association or neighbourhood group is held in much higher esteem than becoming a Tory or Labour member. Yet the effectiveness of volunteering depends critically on the public policies for which councillors and MPs vote. And birds, too. "We have more members than all the parties put together," said the RSPB proudly yesterday. Fine, but who if not voluntary members of political parties are going to work to get their people into office to to pass the laws that protect wildfowl and their habitats?

Political participation is increasingly a minority sport. Membership figures as supplied by the parties themselves are notoriously unreliable. That is because party managers, right as well as left, cleave to a Leninist idea of mass membership, refusing to accept the elitist, minoritarian nature of what they do. But official figures are all we have got. They say Labour has 361,000 dues-payers, the Tories 350,000 and the Liberal Democrats 90,000. Approximately 50,000 other people belong to the other parties, green and nationalist.

Whatever else is new about New Labour, it has had no lasting effect on people's willingness to join in. The John O'Farrell syndrome - my party, thick and thin - looks increasingly out of date. Yet Tony Blair might take comfort from the fact that decline is universal. A new study* describes "the sheer extent and consistency of decline to the end of the 1990s. Not only have levels of party membership continued to decline as a proportion of the electorate, a trend already apparent at the end of the 1980s, but there is now also compelling evidence of a major decline in the absolute numbers of party members across all the long-established European democracies."

The chart shows how things stand. In the UK party membership has fallen by half since 1980 but in France by nearly two-thirds and in Italy by 51% - a loss of some 2m members, many of them former adherents of the Communist party. In Germany total membership declined only slightly (9%) because of an influx of new members from the east.

Party membership grew in the Iberian peninsula, Greece, Hungary and Slovakia. The non-democratic pasts of those countries suggest a love affair with democracy - how long will it last? The most active countries, politically speaking, are Austria - which just shows that activism is not the same as liberalism - Finland, Norway, Belgium and Switzerland. They are all smallish. But so are the Republic of Ireland and the Netherlands, where participation is low.

Party decline looks like it is part and parcel of a well-attested social phenomenon - the privatisation of our lives and retreat from the "public space". Parties are in the same empty place as trade unions and churches.

The big question becomes: can democracy be supported by minorities? Membership decline and the increased cost of mounting election campaigns have put the squeeze on party finances. Labour has had no choice but to accept becoming a rich person's party. The question in the UK now is whether new restrictive rules on donations to be administered by an independent electoral commission are sustainable. (Ironically, its new chair, Sam Younger, has come from the "proper" voluntary sector; he was chief of the UK Red Cross.) If we need parties - and how else do governments emerge? - governments may need to pay for them. Elsewhere in Europe the state has been stepping in, though public money for parties is often earmarked for education and youth work.

The authors of the paper mentioned below - Peter Mair is a professor at the University of Leiden in the Netherlands - say the key ratio is that linking party membership to the size of the electorate. In the 20 countries they studied it is now just under 5%. That means politics is "carried" by the one in 20 citizens who belong to formal political organisations. There are some signs that decline may have bottomed out, though much depends on age - the Tory party is not alone in facing big problems in rejuvenating its ranks.

Numbers do matter, says Paul Whiteley of Sheffield University, because party organisation has an effect on who wins at elections. But parties these days buy in phone banks and pay for mail shots. Perhaps fears of a "democratic deficit" are misplaced. A large chunk of non-participants (a third of the electorate are now effectively out of it) seem happy to let others make the choices. Of those who vote, a majority is happy to be served with choices formulated by the deviants who do party work. For Labour and the Tories membership around the 300,000 mark may be easily enough. After all there is no reason small numbers should allow leaders to be any more Napoleonic. It may even be that the more party members see themselves as an elite, the less likely they might be to accept leaders who seek to call all the shots.

*Peter Mair and Ingrid van Biezen, Party members in 20 European democracies 1980-2000, Party Politics 7:1, 2001.

webTitle: Blair invites bids for extra funds to relieve inner city poverty

fields.headline: Blighted residents to get cash and control
fields.standfirst: Blair invites bids for £131m extra funds to relieve poverty
fields.trailText: Blair invites bids for £131m extra funds to relieve poverty.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday promised a fundamental change in the philosophy of government to tackle deprivation by unleashing the ideas and energy of people living in blighted communities.

"Government can't do it all. Government today is your partner in this process of regeneration, not your master," he said as he invited inner city communities - including religious groups - to bid for £131m over three years to relieve poverty. The money is additional to the £800m set aside over three years for a neighbourhood renewal fund.

The prime minister set a target to get all social housing run by local authorities and housing associations to a decent standard by 2010 and to complete a third of renovations by 2004.

Other 2004 targets include no secondary school with less a quarter of its pupils getting five good GCSEs and no area having a burglary rate more than three times the national average. Over the same period the government is committed to bringing deprived areas closer to the national average for employment and health.

The most novel initiative was to appoint neighbourhood managers with enough clout to tackle problems in the overlapping agencies of central and local government.

Mr Blair said the most important aspect was the abandonment of the top-down approach to regeneration taken since the 1950s. "It was expensive, it offered some short-term improvement, but it never took root. Many inner city areas became even worse."

With the exception of Michael Heseltine's efforts in Liverpool in the 1980s, the reaction was to write off the inner city as a hopeless case.

More resources would be offered to communities that took responsibility for how the money was spent - giving control over budgets to improve policing, education, health and the environment.

The key vehicle for reform identified in the report are 88 local strategic partnerships, a coalition of public, private, voluntary and community sector organisations. To the relief of local councils, the action plan published yesterday said: "The normal presumption will be that local authorities will lead in establishing, bringing together and encouraging partnerships".

The partnerships, working through consensus, must set up a local renewal strategy. Services such as the police or the housing department will "remain responsible and accountable for decisions on ther own services and the use of their own resources". Government offices of the regions can intervene if they believe the local partnership is failing.

These partnerships, covering the 88 most deprived local authorities, will act as the conduit in bids for the £800m over three years in the fund.

The partnerships will also appoint on a pilot basis a neighbourhood manager - "someone people can to turn to if they face a problem". The managers will operate in neighbourhoods with fewer than 2,000 households and must contain a ward in the 10% of the most deprived areas in the country.

Previous attempts to hand council services to local communities failed partly because of an absence of a local professional coordinator. Analysts also claim past neighbourhood offices never had control of the delivery of council services.

There is also frustration, the social exclusion unit concedes, at the slowness of progress, including the three years the unit has taken to prepare yesterday's neighbourhood renewal action plan. It emerged yesterday that neighbourhood managers will not start until the end of the year, and in only 15 of the 88 eligible partnership areas.

The shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, said the neighbourhood managers proposal was "ill thought through.

"The managers appear to have no real powers. Neighbourhood involvement requires empowering local communities, not just appointing salaried busybodies."

Don Foster, the Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, described the proposals as an action replay.
