webTitle: Comment: Depleted uranium compensation claims

fields.headline: Ministry with a vested interest
fields.standfirst:
Suppressed information about uranium risks could open them up to claims for compensation
Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Suppressed information about uranium risks could open them up to claims for compensation
fields.body:
Ten years ago today, a coalition led by the US launched a massive air and land attack to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. The fall-out is still with us, and not only because Saddam remains in power, refusing to allow in UN weapons inspectors or because US and British aircraft patrolling the no-fly zones continue to attack Iraqi targets.

The war also bequeathed its legacy of huge and unexplained health problems which have left over 5,000 British veterans ill, and more than 500 dead, over 130 from cancer.

A decade ago, Colin Powell, then the US top military officer and from next week secretary of state, practised his doctrine of "overwhelming force". For the first time British and US soldiers went into battle armed with shells tipped with depleted uranium.

DU shells, as John Spellar, the British junior minister, explained in the Commons last week, are "ideally suited for use as a kinetic energy penetrator in anti-armour munitions". They also have potentially serious health risks, an unsurprising fact which the Pentagon has been warning about for decades.

The Ministry of Defence here also drew up health warnings. They were given to some bomb disposal units before the war, but not to other soldiers, including tank crews.

Jeremy Hanley, Spellar's predecessor, told the Labour MP Paul Flynn in 1993 that the omission was "regrettable", but was attributable to the "urgency attached to bringing into service such a critical capability". Last year, Spellar said a warning to British troops advising on how to avoid breathing in DU dust never reached its destination.

These failures could yet lead the ministry open to the charge of negligence.

The MoD insists there is no evidence of DU causing illnesses among veterans. Yet it has undermined its own publicly stated confidence by the nature of its reaction to the concern sweeping across Europe about the possible effect of DU on veterans from Bosnia and Kosovo (and civilians living in the battlefields there).

While governments across Europe set up special screening programmes, ministers here kept mum. When the Guardian reported the MoD had changed its mind, officials denied the story. The next day, Spellar confirmed the u-turn but confined it to Balkans veterans. Unsurprisingly since many more DU rounds were fired in the Gulf war than in the Balkans, veterans of that conflict were furious. A few days later, on his return from Sweden, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, announced it would be extended to Gulf war vets.

Anger compounded by a deep lack of trust in the MoD led to a spate of leaked reports, some from inside the ministry, some from the US, showing how exposure to DU could cause cancer.

One MoD report, first dismissed by officials as the work of a "trainee", turned out to have been written by what it now calls an "experienced military officer". The officer was not apparently experienced "in that particular area", though his report was endorsed by senior personnel.

The MoD downplayed the risk of cancer from insoluble DU dust - stressed in the MoD report as well as American ones - and leaned on other scientific studies to dismiss DU as a cause of leukaemia, the illness which sparked off the recent outcry (partly politically inspired) in Italy.

The MoD discredits leaked reports, saying that the only reliable ones are those it officially publishes. Put another way, it only publishes reassuring reports. Certainly, it has a strong vested interest in suppressing information which could open itself up to demands for compensation.

The MoD says that "given the concern and confusion" the leaked documents have generated, it now intends to publish them "with a suitable commentary". But the ministry also admits it has not yet devised an effective test for DU screening and awaits a report from the Royal Society.

We wait to see whether the MoD's promise of publication includes the full report on which a leaked summary concluding that DU dust increased the risks of "lung, lymph and brain cancers" was based. The warning has been dismissed by Sir Keith O'Nions, the MoD's chief scientific adviser, as "not part of the advice given to ministers".

Then we learn that the American manufacturer of DU-tipped weapons used in the Phalanx anti-missile system used on US and British ships is ending production replacing DU by tungsten. In 1989, the US navy noted that the "tungsten penetrator provides improved... effectiveness while eliminating safety and environmental problems associated with DU".

The MoD says it will not phase out Phalanx weapons until they have been used up, probably by the year 2003. The problem, it says, is that it is more expensive.

It is not surprising that vets do not trust the MoD, a ministry with a track record of concealing information, including the presence of organophosphates used in pre-Gulf war vaccinations. The previous government had to apologise for that. Hoon, a cautious lawyer, might be wise to distance himself from his scientists.

webTitle: John Carvel on Blair's new deal for London's deprived East End

fields.headline: Quick fixes give fillip to East End experiment
fields.trailText: The experience of 3,800 households in West Ham and Plaistow in one of the most deprived parts of London's East End shows what the government is trying to achieve in the latest version of its neighbourhood renewal policy.
fields.body:
The experience of 3,800 households in West Ham and Plaistow in one of the most deprived parts of London's East End shows what the government is trying to achieve in the latest version of its neighbourhood renewal policy.

A year ago they were chosen to be in the first wave of a new approach to making regeneration stick. The theory was that local people would be encouraged to take ownership of projects by electing representatives on to a partnership board with power to decide how the renewal budget would be spent. Instead of concentrating on repairing the bricks and mortar of run-down estates, the projects would be geared to tackle the whole range of social problems including unemployment, crime, education, health and social networks.

The first success came in elections to the partnership board in June. Turnout at 30% was well above average for the council in the London borough of Newham.

John Thorne, a Newham councillor and chairman of the partnership board, said local people were more inclined to vote because they saw they could have a direct influence on a local regeneration budget worth £54.6m over 10 years.

Many of the schemes will take years to come to fruition. For example the partnership has decided to demolish two high rise blocks of flats on the Brooks Road estate in Plaistow and renovate three. It is expected to recommend reorganisation of tenancies so that pensioners do not live on the same decks as families with young children.

But the project has also implemented quick changes requested by the community. They include three teacher's assistants for classes in the top year at Portway primary school to help children from a wide range of ethnic backgrounds make the transition to secondary school.

Improved lighting has been installed in a crime blackspot. Facilitators have been appointed at GP surgeries to deal with social problems that might be damaging patients' physical or mental health.

But officers have had difficulty solving problems that require action by different local and central government agencies.

Tracy Boscott, deputy co-ordinator of the project's delivery team, said the apparently simple task of dealing with an abandoned car could be lost in overlapping procedures operated by the police and the council's removal services. The plan to appoint neighbourhood managers announced yesterday would help to resolve these problems because they would have enough clout to make services user-friendly.

The new deal for communities scheme in Newham is being run in four small areas with some of the borough's most serious deprivation. But this part of east London is also benefiting from economic growth.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, visited it yesterday and saw the Excel docklands exhibition centre which is expected to create 14,000 jobs. Officials from the benefits agency are helping to train the local unemployed to take advantage of these opportunities.

He said the neighbourhood renewal scheme was "a classic example of how public money reaps huge rewards for the country and for the individuals concerned".

But other forces are at work in the area. Sir Robin Wells, leader of Newham council, said new transport links were helping the borough to record the fastest rise in house prices in London. Unemployment is below 10,000 for the first time since the 1970s.

webTitle: Railtrack's £600m bill threatens Channel Tunnel link

fields.headline: Railtrack's £600m bill threatens Channel Tunnel link
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack last night threatened to pull out of the £2.5bn second stage of the Channel Tunnel rail link as it gave notice of a worsening financial crisis which will leave it with £8bn of debt by 2003.
fields.body:
Railtrack last night threatened to pull out of the £2.5bn second stage of the Channel Tunnel rail link as it gave notice of a worsening financial crisis which will leave it with £8bn of debt by 2003.

On a day in which it admitted it was in trouble, and was expecting to incur "a significant loss" this year as a result of the Hatfield rail crash, Steve Marshall, its chief executive, said: "We have no intention of going belly up."

But he admitted the company was financially "stretched," adding: "We are making no bones about that."

Mr Marshall said Railtrack hoped to complete the second stage of the high speed Channel Tunnel link from Ebbsfleet on the M25 in Kent into central London. But this depended on resolving its financial problems with the strategic rail authority, which could bring forward the promised payment of government grants.

The crisis follows confirmation by Railtrack that the Hatfield rail crash has so far cost it £600m. The loss, the first in the company's history, will be borne by its shareholders.

Eric Martlew, Labour MP for Carlisle, continued the political push for a review of Railtrack's role. He is promoting a private member's bill instructing John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, to set up an inquiry into the company.

Mr Martlew said: "There is strong public support for a government stake in Railtrack. We need to start a debate because Labour could be on the defensive on this issue in the forthcoming election."

Railtrack is about to start delicate negotiations with the two rail regulatory authorities to bring forward a payment of £1bn, which is part of a £15bn package of state aid allocated to Railtrack over the next five years.

Mr Marshall said that if the money was not forthcoming in staggered payments then Railtrack's programme to improve the national network would be "an unrealistic challenge".

He said the mounting debt was "pretty breathtaking. We will have debts of more than £3bn at the end of this year, and it will be rising by a couple of billion a year thereafter."

Most of the £600m from the Hatfield rail crash will go to the 25 train operating companies in compensation. It is esti mated that only about £150m of this is being passed on to passengers. A further £180m of the total is the amount Railtrack has spent on replacing cracked rails, with a further £20m on flood replacement work.

Until Hatfield, Railtrack's performance delays were running at 20%; they have since soared to 70%. This will incur fines from the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, of at least £300m over the next five year period, unless Mr Winsor accepts that there are extenuating circumstances.

Mr Marshall said that an independent report into gauge corner cracking, the main cause of the Hatfield crash, would be published in the next two weeks. The report will blame Railtrack and its contractors for incompetence and bad management.

Railtrack was meanwhile warned by the rating firm Standard & Poor yesterday that its credit rating might be downgraded. The company's bonds could be put on a credit watch which would have a devastating effect on investors.

webTitle: Matthew Engel: Humanity and royalty

fields.headline: Hearing you loud and clear, ma'am
fields.standfirst:
Victoria was more the people's queen than today's incumbent

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Victoria was more the people's queen than today's incumbent.
fields.body:
Given the disloyalty to the crown that has been rampant elsewhere in these pages over the past few weeks, it should be stressed at once that this column hereby wishes Princess Margaret a full and speedy recovery. One was also distressed to learn that the Queen Mother stumbled at Sandringham on Sunday. So greetings to you too, ma'am.

In return, there is a small request. Could you both give a ring when convenient please, because something extraordinary has just struck me. After a lifetime spent as a loyal-ish subject of your sister/daughter and watching the family on telly doing whatever, one knows exactly what you look like but has no idea what you sound like. And a quick survey in the pub suggests one is not alone.

This is the reverse of the situation in the middle class's other favourite long-running soap. In The Archers, the voice of, say, Eddie Grundy is instantly recognisable but not his face. In The Royals it's the other way about. Does Princess Margaret, as one would like to imagine, have a lived-in, husky voice, combining Fenella Fielding, Edith Piaf and a soupcon of Hyacinth Bucket? Maybe you've met her, or remember her on Desert Island Discs (1981) or saying "Goodnight" on Children's Hour (1940). Otherwise, who could know?

I did hear the Queen Mother at the pageant for her 100th birthday. She spoke for about 10 seconds, which slightly dented the theory that she has a Gracie Fields-style Lankysheer accent. But for normal conversation the Queen keeps an entirely different voice from the familiar husband-and-I drone. So the file on her mother is still open. Even the BBC archive apparently has very little.

The Queen Mother is, of course, the link with a distant royal past. She was already alive on January 22 1901, a century ago next Monday, when Queen Victoria died. Instinctively, you think that royalty must since then have become infinitely more accessible and closer to the public. Maybe not.

Though Victoria's voice remains a mystery for obvious reasons, her innermost thoughts are available. In 1868 she published Leaves from the Journal from Our Life in the Highlands, followed 16 years later by More Leaves. We think of her as an infinitely remote and forbidding figure, but in the context of the time publishing her diary was the equivalent of submitting to interview by Anthony Clare.

There are no major indiscretions of state ("Gladstone came round. What a slimy fat puffball!"). And Victoria was no Alan Clark in the matter of style either. Most of her material is descriptive, but unfortunately her powers of description are rather lim ited. The road to Blair Atholl is "beautiful"; the morning they sailed to Arran was "beautiful"; so were the Kingussie road, the Falls of Garbhalt, Alt-Na-Giuthasach, and even the Rev McLeod's sermon.

Occasionally, things are "provoking". Indeed, by 1866 something very provoking had happened - her beloved husband, Prince Albert, was dead. And what made her journals something other than laughable was the transparency of her emotions. In the first volume it was not just the scenery that was beautiful. Life was too. Albert strides through the book in his tweeds, killing a stag every few pages, informing Victoria at every turn in the road that a particular sight was just like Germany, Switzerland or Italy, and she repeating his every banality as though it were a piercing insight.

The second volume is far more sombre. Her grief, bordering on obsession, suffuses every page, even the ones dominated by her servant (and alleged lover) John Brown. In both she comes across as very human and rather endearing. There was a wonderful moment when she and Albert were incognito and stopped at the inn at Dalwhinnie: "There was hardly anything to eat .. only tea and two miserable starved Highland chickens. No potatoes! No pudding and no fun ."

Her family were horrified by the whole business: the Prince of Wales, the future Edward VII, called the Journals "twaddle" and complained that he was never mentioned. The Queen replied that he was mentioned five times and it would have been more if he visited his mamma more often. The Duke of Cambridge said publication was "an act of insanity".

Well, they were huge best-sellers (the royalties went to charity, not royalty) and there is some evidence that the public response did much to counter incipient republicanism in the years when the Queen was shut away in mourning. Much of the criticism was pure snobbery: the family were furious that she wrote about Brown as if he were some sort of equal.

We thus have more insight into the heart and mind of the Queen who is a hundred years dead than the one who is a hundred years alive. This may explain something of the royal family's current troubles.

matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

webTitle: Saddam poses as fairy godfather to US poor

fields.headline: Saddam poses as fairy godfather to US poor
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Iraq
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: President-elect George W Bush's plans to cut government aid to the poor and let private philanthropists shoulder the burden is already reaping its reward. It was announced yesterday that 100m euros had been donated to impoverished Americans by a certain S Hussein of Baghdad.
fields.body:
President-elect George W Bush's plans to cut government aid to the poor and let private philanthropists shoulder the burden is already reaping its reward. It was announced yesterday that 100m euros had been donated to impoverished Americans by a certain S Hussein of Baghdad.

Despite a decade of biting international sanctions and a poverty rate in Iraq of more than 50%, Saddam Hussein has apparently decided to mark the tenth anniversary of the Gulf war by sending humanitarian aid to America's inner cities and rural poor.

A statement put out by the Iraqi News Agency (INA) said a special commission would be set up to help supervise the distribution of the funds.

Given the current state of relations between the two countries, it is unlikely that the US will allow Saddam's uniformed lieutenants to wander the streets of the Bronx or east Washington, distributing his dole, which would work out at about $3 for each American living under the poverty line.

The INA statement said the UN would be told of the donation, suggesting that its aid workers might help implement the programme.

The UN in New York said it had had no word from Baghdad about the donation, and its response would depend on where the money was coming from.

Since the Gulf war Iraq has been allowed to use the proceeds of its oil sales only to buy food, medicine and other essentials for its own people.

"It's unclear if this is money the government of Iraq has lying around or if it comes from the oil-for-food deal," the UN spokesman said.

"If it is from the oil-for-food deal, then it would have to go before the security council sanctions committee, to see if [it] would be allowed."

The committee is still bemused by Saddam Hussein's previous philanthropic outburst, in December: the promise of €1bn - he refuses to talk dollars - to help the Palestinian struggle against Israel.

In the West Bank and Gaza they are not holding their breath: his earlier promises to send troops came to nothing.

But his claim to have so much cash to send abroad may end up hurting his efforts to have the sanctions lifted. Some security council members are said to have questioned whether the sanctions regime is tough enough, if he has so much money to give away.

webTitle: Net pulls civil courts into 21st century

fields.headline: Net pulls civil courts into 21st century
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Litigants will be able to sue over the internet and judges deal with preliminary applications by email, under government plans unveiled yesterday to bring the Victorian county court system into the 21st century.
fields.body:
Litigants will be able to sue over the internet and judges deal with preliminary applications by email, under government plans unveiled yesterday to bring the Victorian county court system into the 21st century.

People will be able to launch small claims by computer, filling in a claim form on screen and sending it through to a processing centre by a mouse click.

A working prototype demonstrated yesterday by the Lord Chancellor's Department minister, David Lock, is ready to be put on a website. But ministers want to provide more back-up help for users before going live.

Under the plans, outlined in a consultation paper, Modernising the Civil Courts, county court offices, where paperwork is processed, would be rationalised and centralised. The aim is to move as far as possible to a "virtual" or paperless court for the early stages of a case, though trials would still take place in a courtroom. Many steps which now have to be taken by post, such as asking for a judgment against a defendant who has produced no defence, will be able to be done by telephone or internet.

Through the internet and call centres, litigants will have 24 hours a day, seven days a week access to information about the progress of their cases and how to file a claim.

People without access to a computer will still be able to use the internet system through the Citizens' Advice Bureau or libraries, and could still go to a hearing centre in person or apply by post.

Under a pilot scheme launched last July, judges in three centres - the court of appeal, Leeds and Cardiff county courts - are experimenting with video-conferencing for brief court applications, allowing lawyers and parties to take part without the need to travel to court.

Video-conferencing was used for the first high court application to decide the fate of the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary, although the judge, Mr Justice Johnson, had complaints about its efficiency.

Other pilots planned include:

 A scheme at Preston county court, to be launched on February 5, to explore the use of email to reduce the need to attend court. Litigants will email the judge with interim applications - those that need decisions before the case goes to trial.

 Touch screen kiosks, to be launched shortly to provide advice, information and court forms at libraries in Telford and Madeley in Shropshire. They will include a video link to the local Citizens' Advice Bureau so customers can access on-screen advice.

Mr Lock said the county court procedures had not changed much in 150 years. Courts still opened from 10am to 4pm, the typical hours for Victorian businesses.

County courts were "scattered through the country in a way which owes more to history than to logic or needs today", he added.

"We want to use internet technology to provide round the clock access. It's very important that we preserve the best elements of traditional and face-to-face justice in our courts while at the same time accessing the benefits of new technology."

London's 16 county courts may be rationalised down to about four. In other centres, underused courts could be closed and hearings held in rooms at magistrates courts, coroners courts or local council buildings.

But Mr Lock denied that the exercise was about closing county courts and said the geographical spread of courts was unlikely to be affected.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
French tests on soldiers clear
Zanu-PF wins by-election
Three executed in Saudi Arabia
fields.body:
French tests on soldiers clear

The French defence ministry said yesterday that tests on five soldiers who served in the Balkans and are now suffering from cancer and other malignant illnesses revealed no traces of depleted uranium.

Nato's medical advisory body met in Brussels to look at the risks from exposure to depleted uranium in shells.
AP, Paris

Zanu-PF wins by-election

Zimbabwe's Movement for Democratic Change yesterday lost a parliamentary seat to President Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF in a by-election marred by violence and intimidation. Retired army colonel Claudious Makova won Bikita West in the rural south-east by 5,992 votes.
Andrew Meldrum, Harare

Three executed in Saudi Arabia

A daughter convicted of killing her father, and her mother who helped her, were among three people beheaded in Saudi Arabia yesterday, making 10 executions this year.
AP, Riyadh

webTitle: South African cabinet snubs MPs' advice on graft inquiry

fields.headline: Anger as South African cabinet snubs MPs' advice on graft inquiry
fields.trailText: The South African government has been accused of riding roughshod over democracy in rejecting a parliamentary demand for the leading anti-corruption investigator to join the inquiry into an arms deal involving British and other foreign firms.
fields.body:
The South African government has been accused of riding roughshod over democracy in rejecting a parliamentary demand for the leading anti-corruption investigator to join the inquiry into an arms deal involving British and other foreign firms.

President Thabo Mbeki was recommended by the justice minister, Penuell Maduna, yesterday to defy the request that Judge Willem Heath should join the three agencies investigating alleged irregularities in the 43bn rand (£4bn) deal.

The parliamentary public accounts committee ordered the inquiry after the auditor general reported that there might have been kickbacks and nepotism in the awarding of contracts, and questioned why the original cost of 29bn rand had risen by almost a third in a year.

The committee wants to know whether the government is paying twice as much as necessary for 52 Hawk trainer and Gripen fighter planes supplied by a consortium of the British company BAE Systems and Saab of Sweden. BAE says it has done nothing wrong.

Although Mr Mbeki must decide who conducts the investigation, Mr Maduna's recommendation and the public vilification of Judge Heath by the African National Congress leave little doubt that the government intends to defy MPs.

But the judge has such a reputation as an anti-corruption crusader - due as much to his public relations as to any great exposure of graft by his special investigations unit - that the government seems to have made a political blunder in ignoring him.

The agreement - the biggest in South Africa's history - to buy planes, ships and submarines from Britain, Germany and other European countries has never been popular. When the contracts were signed in 1999 they were widely condemned as a waste of limited resources which could be used for education and housing and to combat the Aids pandemic.

Mr Maduna said he rejected Judge Heath's participation because of a recent constitutional court ruling that a sitting judge cannot work for a branch of the executive.

In a statement which appeared to prejudge the inquiry, Mr Maduna said there was no evidence that "any maladministration or malpractice took place, that any state assets or state funds were paid to anybody".

But there is little doubt that the government's rejection of Judge Heath has left people feeling that it has something to hide.

The Pan Africanist Congress MP Patricia de Lille raised the corruption issue in parliament more than a year ago, when she said a group of "concerned" ANC MP's had come to her. She gave Judge Heath documents which alleged that senior ANC politicians received bribes from arms consortiums and awarded spin-off contracts to their relatives.

Yesterday she said the government would be shooting itself in the foot if it defied parliament. "At issue is the constitutional accountability of the executive to parliament."

"To exclude him [Judge Heath] now will signal to the international community that democracy is under attack and that corruption is rampant in South Africa."

The Archbishop of Cape Town, Njongonkulu Ngungane, said that if Mr Mbeki overrode parliament it would "pose a very serious threat to the country's fragile democracy" and put South Africa on "the downward, slippery road to becoming a banana republic".

The Inkatha Freedom party, whose leader, Manogosuthu Buthelezi, sits in Mr Mbeki's cabinet, denounced the move as "outrageous'"

The ANC is clearly happy to find reasons to exclude Judge Heath. It has clashed with him over funding for his unit and the amount of corruption he claims to have uncovered. It has also accused the judge, who once served in the apartheid-era black homeland of Ciskei, of "being in cahoots with opposition parties".

Judge Heath is abroad and not expected to respond before his return on Thursday.

Where it has gone wrong

Despite its opponents' allegations in connection with the arms deal, there have been no credible or proved accusations of corruption by the South African government. But it has been guilty of other serious political misjudgments:

Aids

President Thabo Mbeki tried to backpedal after he was denounced for questioning the link between HIV and Aids. His rating in South Africa, which has the largest number of HIV-infected people in the world, fell sharply

Zimbabwe

The softly softly approach to Robert Mugabe has proved as ineffective as the British stick waving. But Mbeki has more to lose: the prospect of economic collapse in Zimbabwe sending large numbers of people into South Africa and destabilising the region.

Lesotho

The military intervention in Lesotho in 1998 was a military and political blunder. The public reacted sharply when well-armed but badly prepared South African forces ran into trouble against poorly equipped opponents and Lesotho's capital was virtually razed in the fighting.

webTitle: Letters: No threat to cancer rolls

fields.headline: No threat to cancer rolls
fields.trailText: Prof Gordon McVie and Sir Paul Nurse are wrong to suggest that the GMC is threatening the fullness and accuracy of cancer registries (Letters, January 9).
fields.body:
Prof Gordon McVie and Sir Paul Nurse are wrong to suggest that the GMC is threatening the fullness and accuracy of cancer registries (Letters, January 9).

Guidance on patient confidentiality issued by the GMC last year after extensive public consultation advised doctors to seek patients' consent before reporting incidences of cancer. This reflected our view that patients have a right to know about, and usually to control, disclosures of information about their health. These are also requirements of the common law and the Data Protection Act.

However, in view of the concerns this raised about the possible effect upon the completeness of the information held by cancer registries, the GMC provided an 11-month breathing space for doctors and hospitals to put appropriate mechanisms in place for seeking and recording consent, or for legislation to be brought forward to require the disclosure of data. All 200,000 doctors on the GMC register have received written notification of this interim measure.

The health and social care bill provides for the secretary of state to issue regulations to allow disclosure of confidential information in specific circumstances, when in the public interest or in the interests of patient care, without patients' consent.

While the GMC does have some concerns that the bill might reduce the rights of patients to expect information about them to be held in confidence, it does suggest that the breathing space provided by the GMC has proved helpful and that there is no threat to cancer registries.
Andrew Ketteringham
General Medical Council

webTitle: More rail chaos mars station reopening

fields.headline: More rail chaos mars station reopening
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: It should have been the day when Leeds had a fully functioning railway station. But after four weeks without a train service optimistic commuters arrived at Leeds station yesterday only to find that - yet again - they could go nowhere by rail.
fields.body:
It should have been the day when Leeds had a fully functioning railway station. But after four weeks without a train service optimistic commuters arrived at Leeds station yesterday only to find that - yet again - they could go nowhere by rail.

The station, in England's second largest financial centre, closed for emergency track repairs before Christmas with a promise from Railtrack that it would reopen two weeks ago.

Since then two deadlines have passed. But Railtrack confidently predicted that yesterday services would resume as normal. They did not.

Most services were suspended and many more were delayed. The chaos was compounded by unforeseen electrical faults, Railtrack said.

A spokesman said services would "gradually" return to normal but admitted it could take up to two weeks for all necessary work to be carried out.

Railtrack said work would carry on all night at Leeds to get services running normally by this morning.

"We thought everything would be all right for Monday, but clearly we made a mistake and it's gone wrong," the spokesman said.

Buses were once again drafted in at short notice to shuttle passengers to their destinations but many travellers were left stranded as the buses failed to cope with the numbers.

Nigel Patterson, managing director of Northern Spirit, one of the train operators affected by the disruption, said: "I am extremely disappointed because if we had been told yesterday, there would have been something we could have done... we could have had all the buses back up and running."

One commuter, Michael Hosby from Leeds said,: "They say the train is coming, then just take if off the screens when the time comes for it to leave."

Business leaders warned yesterday that the continuing rail chaos was seriously affecting the region's economy.

Nigel Kissack, from Leeds-based financial services firm Pinsent Curtis, said: "Post-Hatfield our transport costs have soared and the whole thing has been hugely expensive in terms of wasted time spent on delayed trains."

webTitle: Letters: child abuse

fields.headline: First post
fields.trailText: As we have seen, child abuse does not stop at the border between England and Wales.
fields.body:
Today parliament will debate the children's commissioner for Wales bill which is a welcome step towards improving the well-being of the children of Wales. But the NSPCC is concerned that the legislation before parliament may restrict the commissioner's ability to review and investigate appalling child deaths, such as that of Anna Climbie. We believe the bill must extend the commissioner's remit to allow him to look at all aspects of a child's death, not just those areas devolved to the national assembly for Wales and to report freely on his findings.

As we have seen, child abuse does not stop at the border between England and Wales. Similar posts must be created in the rest of the UK, with wide-ranging powers to investigate, report and act.
Mary Marsh
Chief Executive, NSPCC

webTitle: Soccer chief loses high court gamble

fields.headline: Soccer chief loses high court gamble
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: The flamboyant soccer chairman George Reynolds lost a legal gamble yesterday after his DIY case against a chief constable was thrown out by the high court.
fields.body:
The flamboyant soccer chairman George Reynolds lost a legal gamble yesterday after his DIY case against a chief constable was thrown out by the high court.

The former safecracker, who has made a fortune from chipboard worktops since leaving jail, faces a £50,000 bill for police costs after conducting his own case.

He was forced to back down during the week long case at Middlesbrough, where he claimed wrongful arrest, unlawful imprisonment and malicious prosecution after a domestic incident eight years ago.

Judge Michael told the chairman of third division Darlington FC: "You know as a businessman Mr Reynolds, once you engage in litigation there tends to be a winner and tends to be a loser. Those who play with fire, are in danger of having their fingers burned."

After the case, Mr Reynolds said that his eight years of legal homework had been worthwhile. "The judge has been very, very fair. I am not too disappointed and I feel I am getting out in public exactly what I want to get out."

The judge ruled that Mr Reynolds had failed to prove his case against Barry Shaw, chief constable of Cleveland police, and had admitted during the hearing that officers had been right to arrest him in August 1992. He was held overnight in a cell after a telephone call from his former sister-in-law alleging criminal damage during acrimonious divorce proceedings with his first wife.

Mr Reynolds, 64, had said before the case that he had saved £64,000 by dispensing with a barrister and representing himself. He made a name for frugality with football fees at one stage in his career in charge of Darlington.

The deputy chief constable of Durham, Paul Garvin, said: "Mr Reynolds made accusations of adultery, conspiracy, perverting the course of justice and of a police cover-up and a vendetta. All of these claims I, and the other officers, find offensive."

webTitle: Letters: Warm welcome to the volunteers

fields.headline: Warm welcome to the volunteers
fields.trailText: "How much do they pay you for doing this?" inquires pupil after pupil of their volunteer tutor. They are always amazed by the experience of someone coming "just to help me". The 750,000 citizens of all ages from 12-89 who give an hour a week to one child can raise their reading level by a year in one term. They do not replace teachers, they support them and a good proportion of the younger ones actually join them.
fields.body:
"How much do they pay you for doing this?" inquires pupil after pupil of their volunteer tutor. They are always amazed by the experience of someone coming "just to help me". The 750,000 citizens of all ages from 12-89 who give an hour a week to one child can raise their reading level by a year in one term. They do not replace teachers, they support them and a good proportion of the younger ones actually join them.

The announcement of £300m to "transform the relationship between the state and the voluntary sector" (Brown hails advance of Britain's volunteer army, January 15) is greatly welcome, but needs one more ingredient: persuading other professionals, social workers, nurses, doctors, librarians and police officers to welcome and deploy the energy, experience and time that volunteers offer.

Anna Climbie's social worker was overloaded, so was Maria Colwell's. In New York, support teams of screened and trained volunteers see children at risk daily, calling back later if they are not available. Any concern is instantly reported.

In a London doctors' group practice the involvement of volunteers reduced hospital appointments by 35% and drug consumption by 30%. Research shows 11m people in the UK would volunteer if asked. How much longer should we allow professionals to ignore volunteer support?
Elisabeth Hoodless
Executive director, CSV
information@csv.org.uk

Winchester
WatsonGeof@aol.com

robjackson74@yahoo.co.uk

webTitle: Leader: Iranian rough justice

fields.headline: Iranian rough justice
fields.standfirst: Jailings are a prelude to a divisive election
fields.trailText: Jailings are a prelude to a divisive election.
fields.body:
The prison sentences imposed on eight Iranian intellectuals and journalists who attended a reform seminar in Berlin are not only vindictive and unjust; they also represent the latest skirmish in an intensifying political battle in Tehran ahead of presidential elections due next June. The revolutionary court's weekend verdicts followed the condemning to death last month for "anti-state activities" of a dissident cleric, Hasan Yousefi-Eshkevari, who also attended the Berlin meeting. Among those now facing lengthy jail terms are Mehrangiz Kar, a leading advocate of women's rights who is said to be suffering from breast cancer, but who has been denied permission to seek treatment abroad; and Akbar Ganji, a top investigative journalist who was given 10 years, plus an additional five in internal exile. Mr Ganji has been a marked man since he published a series of articles linking the killing of up to 80 dissidents in recent years to hardliners in the upper reaches of Iranian mullahdom. His newspaper, along with about 30 other publications, has now been shut down as part of a campaign by conservatives to stifle freedom of speech.

The verdicts have brought protests by Germany and the reported delaying of a visit to Iran by Chancellor Gerhard Schröder. This latest evidence of rising intolerance may further discourage others within the EU, like the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who have given long-distance moral support to reform efforts by President Mohammad Khatami that include an official investigation into the dissident murders. The landslide victory of like-minded reformers in parliamentary polls last spring has given rise not to an opening of Iranian society, as many there hoped, but to a clerical-led backlash. Britain's resumption of diplomatic relations has not yet brought closer ties and Mr Cook, despite several attempts, has yet to visit Tehran.

Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's supreme spiritual leader and Ayatollah Khomenei's heir, has increasingly moved into the political arena in recent months, forcing the resignation of the popular, liberal culture minister, Ataollah Mohajerani, and vetoing press freedom legislation. But the clerical establishment is by no means united in opposing Mr Khatami's bid to build a law-based civil society, which it knows enjoys vast public support. This latest judicial travesty is but a foretaste of what could become a dangerously divisive election season.

webTitle: 'William Tell' stunt goes wrong

fields.headline: 'William Tell' stunt goes wrong
fields.trailText: It should have been the highlight of a daring circus act. But something went wrong when Alain Jamet aimed his crossbow at the apple on his wife's head and missed. The arrow struck the woman just above the eye.
fields.body:
It should have been the highlight of a daring circus act. But something went wrong when Alain Jamet aimed his crossbow at the apple on his wife's head and missed. The arrow struck the woman just above the eye.

The couple, known as "Grey Arrow," were performing in front of some 4,500 spectators as part of the first World Circus Festival in Paris on Sunday when the accident happened.

Cathy Jamet was seriously injured and taken to hospital.

"This act is a bit like William Tell," said Sophie Edelstein, one of the organisers of the festival and artistic director of the Pinder-Jean Richard circus. "It's very dangerous and demands a high level of accuracy."

She said the accident reminded everyone that circus performers often risked their lives to entertain the public.

"We are all a bit shocked but this could have happened to the tightrope walker, or the trapeze artist. It comes with the territory," she said.

Cathy Jamet is due to be released from hospital in about two weeks. "I am sure she will want to get back in the ring very quickly," Ms Edelstein said.

webTitle: Leader: urban regeneration from top to bottom

fields.headline: Tough and tender
fields.standfirst: Urban regeneration from top to bottom
fields.trailText: Urban regeneration from top to bottom.
fields.body:
If you think ending child poverty is difficult, try regenerating the nation's poorest estates. As the social exclusion unit (SEU) set out in a powerful report in 1998, there have been eight national programmes to rehabilitate disadvantaged urban areas in the last 30 years. Three decades on, deprivation is worse, social disadvantages even more concentrated, and the gap between these communities and the comfortable majority is even wider. Now a ninth attempt is to be made, working with the 88 English local authority areas where the 840 poorest wards - 10% of the total - are situated.

Time for the cynics to move in and say it is hopeless. Why try? But wait. Contrary to the silly jeers from the Tory shadow environment secretary yesterday, this is not a shoot-from-the-hip electoral gimmick. Few social policies have been more carefully thought through, beginning with the SEU's 1998 report, followed by 18 separate taskforces, a consultative document and a national strategy. Few people in Whitehall are unaware of the daunting challenge.

Redistribution of mainstream services will be part of the plan, but yesterday's initiative is not just important for the poor. It is crucial for the entire country. The nation is acutely short of land and is already one of the most overcrowded countries on the globe. Only by regenerating our urban areas - including the most blighted - will the shrinking countryside get proper protection. Remember, almost 90% of our population lives in an urban area.

Tony Blair spoke yesterday of two lessons his policymakers have learned. First, the mistake of tackling social problems in isolation: "You can spend money on housing, but if the schools aren't good and crime is rife, the housing soon deteriorates." The second, which is important for this centralising government, is that Whitehall can offer to help local areas trying to rebuild their communities, but it cannot do it for them.

The package has an interesting mix of central and devolved powers. The aim is for each of the 840 poorest wards to have an action plan. At the centre, mainstream services - education, health, home office, employment - will be set specific targets, which they will be expected to help deprived areas to meet by 2004. All schools will be expected to get at least 25% of their children through five A to Cs at GCSE level; sub-standard housing in all 840 wards must be reduced by one-third; no area should have a burglary rate more than three times the average. Social reformers have tried to "bend" mainstream services to help the poor for years, but accountability until now has stopped at local level. It is time to try something different. Just where precise responsibility lies between local and Whitehall has still to be clarified.

At the local level each area will be expected to appoint a strategic partnership involving all public services plus private and voluntary sector representation. Below them, there will be neighbourhood boards and in 30 wards on a trial basis, neighbourhood managers. They will be expected to coordinate the many different services. It has already been tried out successfully, but to a more limited agenda, in several cities.

Local councils will feel this is an erosion of their power, but it is not as undemocratic as it looks. Neighbourhood boards will have to negotiate extra funds. It is in their interests to have councillors on board. Meanwhile, Whitehall needs to improve its joined-up credentials. Will Gordon Brown please abolish VAT on urban regeneration to level the playing field with green field development?

webTitle: Bugles call in the battle for Tolstoy's legacy

fields.headline: Bugles call in the battle for Tolstoy's legacy
fields.standfirst:
It sounds like a struggle for the soul of Russia - will the state or the family decide who should safeguard the writer's earthly possessions?

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Will it be war or peace? The descendants of Russia's greatest novelist, Count Leo Tolstoy, have taken up arms against Kremlin plans to put much of his legacy in the care of a curator they regard as a family enemy, and there is no sign that they will lay them down.
fields.body:
Will it be war or peace? The descendants of Russia's greatest novelist, Count Leo Tolstoy, have taken up arms against Kremlin plans to put much of his legacy in the care of a curator they regard as a family enemy, and there is no sign that they will lay them down.

The Tolstoy heritage industry is lovingly tended by the writer's great-great-grandson, Vladimir Tolstoy, who is admired for his innovative way of running the Tolstoy estate at Yasnaya Polyana, 120 miles south of Moscow, one of the few state museums in Russia said to earn their keep and even make a little profit.

But the arts minister, Mikhail Shvydkoi, has appointed the Tolstoy scholar Vitaly Remizov director of the three Tolstoy museums in Moscow.

It has caused a bitter row, brought threats of retaliation from Yasnaya Polyana, and perhaps put foreign exhibitions on Tolstoy in jeopardy.

In his later years Tolstoy was celebrated as one of the world's foremost pacifists. But Vladimir is not minded to turn the other cheek.

"If this appointment goes ahead I will organise protests, meetings, petitions," he said yesterday after fraught talks with Mr Shvydkoi.

"I represent the views of the family."

It is a formidable family, ranged across the globe from America to Sweden, France and Italy, as well as in Russia. It has considerable clout when it comes to looking after the 19th century genius's legacy.

Which leaves Mr Remizov, who holds the Tolstoy chair at the teacher training college in Tulna, near Yasnaya Polyana, in a tricky position.

He seemed bemused yesterday, and said he had been kept in the dark.

"I know nothing about the appointment. I'm coming to Moscow tomorrow to see the minister and find out what's going on."

He and Vladimir Tolstoy have crossed swords before. "We try to maintain diplomatic relations," said Vladimir, who replaced Mr Remizov as director of the family estate in 1994.

He told the newspaper Izvestiya that on the day Mr Remizov was sacked he took with him all the manuscripts of the studies on Tolstoy.

"He had no right to. Dozens of papers. Then they appeared in various publications ... He dissolved the Yasnaya Polyana archives."

Even worse, he said, he ordered rebuilding and the felling of a forest on the estate, famed for its orchards and woodlands.

The Tolstoys' intention is to keep everything in the family.

The novelist's grand-daughter Sophia, who was the poet Sergei Yesenin's last wife, directed the country estate and the Moscow museums until her death in 1957, when the management of the various properties was separated.

The museums are the handsome Moscow villa where Tolstoy's 13 children lived, the smaller Moscow house where he spent his childhood in, a third Moscow building associated with him, and the railway station at Astapovo, south of the city, where he died in 1910.

Vladimir Tolstoy said: "I've got enough work to do at Yasnaya Polyana. "But historically it would be just for me to be the head of it all. All the museums are one indivisible whole. If I was proposed as new head, I wouldn't disagree."

Mr Shvydkoi clearly does disagree. He is making a name for himself as a taboo-breaker, taking on the most sacred names in the Russian arts. Soon after his appointment last year he engineered a purge of senior figures at the Bolshoi ballet and opera and ordered radical changes at the company.

He told Izvestiya that there were a lot of unresolved problems at Yasnaya Polyana.

"I doubt whether such a fine speaker as Vladimir Tolstoy could run several museums."

Vladimir retorted that giving the job to Mr Remizov would jeopardise the lucrative prospect of exporting Tolstoy exhibitions to the west.

He is currently cooperating in a Tolstoy project for Edinburgh next year. He said that it might be cancelled.

Behind the battle for the great writer's legacy may lie a very contemporary Russian feud over money, private property and the public good.

Mr Shvydkoi said he believed that the wealthy Tolstoy diaspora wanted to privatise all the Tolstoy properties and estate and gain control of the lot. "But this is public property".

Vladimir Tolstoy said: "Talk of privatisation is simply not true, and Shvydkoi knows that. It will all remain with the state."

He told Izvestiya that there were a lot of unresolved problems at Yasnaya Polyana. "I doubt whether such a fine speaker as Vladimir Tolstoy could run several museums." Vladimir retorted that giving the job to Mr Remizov would jeopardise the lucrative prospect of exporting Tolstoy exhibitions to the west. He is currently cooperating in a Tolstoy project for Edinburgh next year. He said that it might be cancelled. Behind the battle for the great writer's legacy may lie a very contemporary Russian feud over money, private property and the public good. Mr Shvydkoi said he believed that the wealthy Tolstoy diaspora wanted to privatise all the Tolstoy properties and estate and gain control of the lot. "But this is public property". Vladimir Tolstoy said: "Talk of privatisation is simply not true, and Shvydkoi knows that. It will all remain with the state."

webTitle: Aeroplane grounded by the mouse that soared

fields.headline: Aeroplane grounded by the mouse that soared
fields.trailText: Two hundred Swiss holidaymakers took off 24 hours late from Zurich yesterday after spending an unscheduled night in an airport hotel because their Boeing 767 was grounded by a Caribbean brown mouse.
fields.body:
Two hundred Swiss holidaymakers took off 24 hours late from Zurich yesterday after spending an unscheduled night in an airport hotel because their Boeing 767 was grounded by a Caribbean brown mouse.

"I can confirm that pest control operatives recovered a dead mouse in the plane cockpit soon after 10am this morning," said a spokesman for SAirGroup, the Swiss aviation conglomerate that owns the aircraft.

"We are obviously sorry for the inconvenience caused to our customers, but mice represent a very real threat to aeroplanes and a management decision was taken not to run any unnecessary risks."

Any kind of rodent was a danger once on the loose in an aircraft, the spokesman explained, not so much because of the panic it might induce among the passengers but because of the unforeseeable and potentially catastrophic consequences of it gnawing through cables and control lines.

The runaway rodent was spotted an hour before landing by the co-pilot on the inbound flight from the Dominican Republic. It subsequently evaded the best efforts of half a dozen cleaning staff to hunt it down and refused to be tempted by mousetraps primed with Swiss cheese.

The outbound flight, a charter to Cancun, Mexico, operated by an SAirGroup subsidiary, Balair, was scheduled to take off at 11.40am on Sunday but was delayed until yesterday morning after the company could bring in a firm of pest control experts who sealed the plane's doors and pumped gas through the cabin.

"Fortunately, this kind of incident is not very common," the spokesman said. "In the past we have used cats with some success, but they can take rather a long time because they tend to think it's all a game. We needed the plane faster than that."

webTitle: Home truths that drive fight for Palestine

fields.headline: Home truths that drive fight for Palestine
fields.standfirst:
Right to return 50 years after they took flight, the fate of 3.7m Arab refugees is now the biggest hurdle to peace

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Right to return 50 years after they took flight, the fate of 3.7m Arab refugees is now the biggest hurdle to peace.
fields.body:
Khalil al-Maqdah holds the key to the Middle East conflict in his bedside locker. Wrapped in a cheap plastic shopping bag are documents from the last days of the British mandate in Palestine showing him to be the rightful owner of a house and land in what is now Israel.

Now said by his family to be 110 years old, Mr al-Maqdah lives close to the Mediterranean in a shabby house in the warren of alleyways that make up the Ein al-Hilweh refugee camp at Sidon, south of Beirut. Ein al-Hilweh and the other camps in Lebanon hold the most militant Palestinian refugees. If Israel and the Palestinian leadership ever sign a peace agreement, these are the people who have to be persuaded to accept it.

Mr Maqdah's documents, brown with age and held together with clear tape, carry the stamp of the British crown's land registry office and his black, inky thumbprint. This certificate of registration, number 140,008, confirms that in 1946 he bought a three-bedroomed house and adjoining land in the village of al-Ghabissiyeh, near the northern coastal town of Akko (formerly Acre), in Galilee.

Mr Maqdah, who worked for the British drilling for water, also has a claim on his late wife's home in a nearby village, al-Menshiyyeh.

Mr Maqdah clings to the document, which is still legally binding, as proof of his right to return to Galilee. But Israel, during negotiations on the final shape of a settlement, expressed its determination not to recognise the right of return of the refugees scattered round the Middle East, insisting that allowing an influx of so many Palestinians would be suicidal for the Jewish state.

Mr Maqdah's document is crucial if peace is to be achieved. If he and his family - and all the other refugee families holding similar documents - can be persuaded to compromise, peace is possible. If they decide they will settle for nothing less than a return to the site of their former villages, any peace settlement is a long way off.

Switching reluctantly from the Hizbullah channel, where he was keeping up with the latest incidents in the Palestinian uprising, Mr Maqdah recalls the traumatic events that led to his exile in 1948 during the first Arab-Israeli war.

"The Jews arrived after the second world war. I laughed because I was not used to seeing men and women walking down the road together. The Jews told me they would take our land."

He said he fled "because the Jews began occupying our lands, killing our kids. We did not have weapons at the time. The English did not even allow us to carry a small knife." Mr Maqdah crossed the border into Lebanon at the height of the fighting. "I thought I would be away for a week or two and then go back."

Fifty-three years later, he and 3.7m others live in refugee camps in Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, the West Bank and Gaza. Does he think he will see his village again? "I hope so. I hope my death is in Palestine, not here."

Mr Maqdah left Israel as a widower with eight sons. Today, five generations of his family live in the camp and the family has grown to 180.

The love of homeland and hatred of Israel have not lessened with successive generations - the younger members are violently passionate about realising Mr Maqdah's dream. His grandson, Munir al-Maqdah, 41, was born in the camp. "I love my grandfather. We smell Palestine through my grandfather," he said.

Munir has only ever seen a video of al-Ghabissiyeh, which has been in ruins since 1948. In theory, the family could move back and rebuild. But that option is not available to most refugees, whose homes have been taken over by Israelis or flattened to make way for high-rise blocks and shopping malls.

Mr Maqdah's other village, al- Menshiyyeh, is buried under a military airstrip.

Munir is soft-spoken and could pass for an Islamic scholar or poet. In fact, he is a fighter with Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement who left school at the age of 10 to train as a commando for raids into Israel.

According to Jordanian and Lebanese newspapers, he is top of the Israeli wanted list. He is also wanted in Jordan where, four months ago, he was sentenced to death in absentia for terrorism.

Ein al-Hilweh has a high concentration of guns and men experienced in fighting. The Lebanese army, wary of the Palestinians, has the camp surrounded, controlling access in and out. No cement, cable wire or any other material that might make for permanent homes is allowed in: the Lebanese are adamant that the refugees' presence is temporary.

Munir is commander of all the Fatah gunmen in Lebanon. Although nominally under the leadership of Mr Arafat, he publicly opposed him for signing the Oslo agreement with Israel in 1993 and is even more vehemently opposed to the compromises discussed between the Israeli and Palestinian leaders in the last month.

Under the proposed peace deal, only a limited number of refugees would be allowed to return to Israel: the Israelis have so far indicated a willingness to accept about 100,000 but that figure could rise, perhaps to a ceiling of about 300,000. The remainder would resettle in those countries where they live at present, or return to the Palestinian Authority, setting up new homes (and even cities) in the West Bank or Gaza. Compensation would be paid for lost property.

Munir is not interested in compensation, resettlement in Lebanon or a move to the Palestinian Authority's West Bank or Gaza. His home, like 98% of Ein al-Hilweh's 80,000 refugees, is in Galilee: that is their soil and they want it back.

"I swear it is not a dream. It is going to happen sooner or later. As they [the Israelis] left like rats from south Lebanon, they will leave the holy land. They should leave it and save their lives before they go back in body bags," he says.

If the Israelis were prepared to give them back their land, it would not mean the end of Jews in the region, he says. "Before '48, we used to live with one another. If we go back to the way it was before, then we would be neighbours. We would have no reason to fight them."

The Israelis have tried several times to assassinate Munir. In 1996, they fired three anti-tank missiles at his home in the camp. He says that if he was killed, he would expect his sons to take up the fight.

His nephew, Ahmed, represents the fourth generation. He is 18, still at school, well-educated, speaks good English and his rhetoric is even more hardline than his uncle's. "I refuse to go to Gaza or the West Bank. I want only to go to my village," he says.

"If Arafat makes peace with the Jews, it will be bad. We can't live with the Israelis. We can't trust them. They have to leave Israel and go back to where they came from. All my friends think like me."

He says he might go to America, Canada or Europe to complete his education. A sign of wavering? "No. I can go away for a bit but not for good. If I do not come back, the Palestinian issue will be forgotten."

There are Palestinians elsewhere who, in quiet moments, are prepared to admit they could be flexible. But there was no willingness to be flexible by anyone interviewed at the Ein al-Hilweh camp.

In the plastic bag with the documents of ownership, Mr Maqdah Sr has a recent photograph of himself sitting up in bed, surrounded by the youngest members of his family, the fifth generation, of whom Abdullah, nine months, is the youngest. The children are proudly holding up the documents of land registration. The dream, unreachable as it seems, is passed to the next generation.

webTitle: Comment: Israel's changing view of the 1948 Arab exodus

fields.headline: Expulsion or flight?
fields.standfirst:
Israel's changing view of the 1948 Arab exodus

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's changing view of the 1948 Arab exodus.
fields.body:
A few years ago I was surprised to hear Limor Livnat, a leading hard-right Likud party politician and, at the time, Israel's communications minister, refer in a television interview to Israel's "expulsion of the Palestinians" in the first Arab-Israeli war of 1948.

It may have been a slip of the tongue but it was indicative of the gradual but relentless sea change taking place in the nation's collective memory and in Israel's classrooms of the traumatic, revolutionary circumstances of Israel's birth. During the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s it was heresy to assert that even some of the 700,000 Arabs who were displaced during that war were expelled.

Israeli educators, historians and, to a lesser extent, journalists shied away from dealing with that painful aspect of Israel's birth. And government spokesmen continued to mouth the official line - that the Arab refugees fled their homes "voluntarily" or at the command or advice of Arab leaders.

As Israel's founder and first prime minister, David Ben-Gurion, never tired in 1949 of saying to visiting UN and American officials: "Israel did not expel even one Arab."

The historical record is quite different. The refugee problem, to be sure, was caused by the 1948 war, which the Palestinian Arabs and the Arab states triggered by rejecting and forcibly trying to block the implementation of the UN partition plan which endorsed the establishment of a Jewish state.

But in the course of the war, Israeli forces went on the offensive and attacked and conquered some 400 Arab villages and about a dozen Arab towns which often served as the bases of the Palestinian irregular forces.

These attacks were the main reason for the flight of the civilian population. There was also a series of outright expulsions by Israeli troops of Arab communities and occasional Arab orders to individual village communities to evacuate.

During the spring and summer of 1948 large scale evacuations were initiated by local Arab leaders and the Arab Higher Committee (the Palestinians' national leadership) of women, children and the elderly, a process that undermined the staying power of the adult males left behind to guard the villages and who, soon after, also fled their homes.

At the same time, most of Israel's leaders, officers and officials were eager to see as few Arabs as possible remain inside the emerging Jewish state, for good military and political reasons.

From April to August 1948 the Israeli establishment, including the cabinet, decided in principle to bar a return of the refugees, thus assuring their continued dispossession and, for many, statelessness. At the same time, Arab states, for political reasons, did little to absorb and rehabilitate the refugees.

During the past decade-and-a-half, Israeli scholars have begun to rewrite the history of Zionism, Israel and the Arab-Israeli conflict.

This re-examination reflects the maturing and gradual liberalisation of Israeli society and has begun to change the public's understanding of the country's past. School textbooks are being rewritten and the "new historiography" is gradually displacing the old in universities. How this has affected current political attitudes in Israel is difficult to assess.

Most of the architects of the Oslo peace process from 1992 to 1993, including the then prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, and his foreign minister, Shimon Peres, were probably propelled towards a more conciliatory attitude towards the Palestinians by the general liberalisation of Israeli society and global trends favouring self-determination.

In addition, the Palestinian intifada, which had begun in 1987, had demonstrated that Israel could not hold the Palestinians in thrall in perpetuity. Paradoxically, the current intifada may prove to have a regressive effect on Israeli politics and attitudes towards the Palestinians.

The spectacle of Palestinian rejection of the reasonable terms offered by President Clinton and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak (Israeli withdrawal from 95% of the West Bank and the Arab half of Jerusalem, and Palestinian statehood), and insistence on the refugees' right of return to their homes, towns and villages in pre-1967 Israel is alienating most Israelis and undermining the sympathy that the past decades of suffering and peace negotiations have engendered.

Almost all Israeli Jews, including myself, believe that whatever the rights and wrongs of 1948, and whoever was to blame for the creation of the Palestinian refugee problem, a solution based on their repatriation to Israel would spell the destruction of the Jewish state.

Professor Benny Morris teaches history at Ben- Gurion University, Beersheba, Israel. He is the author of The Birth of the Palestinian Refugee Problem, 1947-1949 (Cambridge UP, 1988)

webTitle: Sculptor happens upon an ideal rebel

fields.headline: Sculptor happens upon an ideal rebel
fields.trailText: For once in his life Gavin Turk, founder member of the Britart pack, whose creations include images of himself as Marat, Sid Vicious and Che Guevara, was both at a loss for words and quite unsure whether he was being a work of art or not.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
For once in his life Gavin Turk, founder member of the Britart pack, whose creations include images of himself as Marat, Sid Vicious and Che Guevara, was both at a loss for words and quite unsure whether he was being a work of art or not.

As he began a two week residency devoted to Che Guevara, in a post-industrial space in east London, there was not a beret or a cigar in sight.

The only "revolution" was written in white paint on an orange wall. "Don't know who did that, it's great, isn't it?" Turk said.

When Gavin Turk was born, in the late 1960s, Che Gavara, the event he is creating at the Foundry in Shoreditch, as part of the Year of the Artist, would have been called "a happening".

There will be talks, films, music, poetry as well as several events on the timetable labelled: "activists meet & organise". There is also a red banner, proclaiming Hasta La Victoria Sempre!, which he found in the street.

Turk explained that he became interested in Che Guevara two years ago when he was trying to think of a defining image of the 20th century. He became fascinated less in the Cuban revolutionary, killed by American trained Bolivian soldiers in 1967, than by the manipulation of his image since then, through the iconic poster. "It's a zeitgeist thing," he said. "The very fact that everyone is here today is testament that people are still very interested and intrigued by this."

His own work has constantly re-examined the artist's image and inspiration. His degree show at the Royal College of Art was an entirely empty studio, apart from an English Heritage plaque proclaiming "Borough of Kensington Gavin Turk Sculptor Worked Here 1989 - 1991."

He was one of the young British artists, including Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin, shown in the Royal Academy's notorious Sensation, which created the Britart phenomenon.

He collected material for Che Guevara by advertising in the papers inviting anyone interested in Che to phone a number: he would never have responded to such an invitation himself, he said, but 80 people, including students, academics and political activists, did.

Despite the public interest, yesterday the artist seemed in the grip of a most unusual attack of self doubt. "Maybe the question of whether it's art or not is not so important - but I'm not dissing art either."

The journalists who went to yesterday's launch press conference were told they would become part of the work of art.

It may all end in a fortnight with a passionate Che Guevara rally at Shoreditch town hall in east London. Or not. "It all depends how this takes off, how much interest there is, really. We'll let you know," one of the organisers said.

He was one of the young British artists, including Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin, shown in the Royal Academy's notorious Sensation, which created the Britart phenomenon. He collected material for Che Guevara by advertising in the papers inviting anyone interested in Che to phone a number: he would never have responded to such an invitation himself, he said, but 80 people, including students, academics and political activists, did. Despite the public interest, yesterday the artist seemed in the grip of a most unusual attack of self doubt. "Maybe the question of whether it's art or not is not so important - but I'm not dissing art either." The journalists who went to yesterday's launch press conference were told they would become part of the work of art. It may all end in a fortnight with a passionate Che Guevara rally at Shoreditch town hall in east London. Or not. "It all depends how this takes off, how much interest there is, really. We'll let you know," one of the organisers said.

webTitle: Filipinos confident of freeing Briton's kidnapped stepdaughter

fields.headline: Filipinos confident of freeing Briton's kidnapped stepdaughter
fields.trailText: Filipino negotiators attempting to obtain the release of the six-year-old stepdaughter of an Inverness man were last night confident of success, having concluded that her kidnapping was a family quarrel.
fields.body:
Filipino negotiators attempting to obtain the release of the six-year-old stepdaughter of an Inverness man were last night confident of success, having concluded that her kidnapping was a family quarrel.

The optimism came as Douglas Grant, 50, the stepfather of Eiman April Grant, arrived in the Philippines yesterday, against the advice of the local military negotiators and the Foreign Office.

Colonel Saulito Aromin, the commander of the troops on the island of Basilan where Eiman was seized last Wednesday, said last night after a day of negotiating that he hoped the girl would be freed within a few days.

"We are optimistic [of a speedy resolution] because it's a family affair," he said. "We now know this is all about a quarrel between two cousins over a court decision involving a plot of land."

Col Aromin said he thought Eiman probably did not even realise she had been abducted. "The girl is in high spirits and good health," he said. "She is completely innocent of what's happening around her, because she is with her uncle."

Four gunmen burst into the home of the girl's mother, Mina Rasul Grant, and she allegedly was unable to pay them the 100,000 pesos (£1,300) they demanded.

At first it had been feared the men were members of an Islamic separatist group. But, said Col Aromin, "neither the Moro Islamic Liberation Front nor the Abu Sayyaf are involved," referring to the two main secessionist movements. The latter was responsible for kidnapping more than 60 people last year, many of whom were foreigners seized from a Malaysian resort island and held up to five months until millions of pounds in ransom money was paid.

Army and police commanders then thought Mrs Grant herself was involved, but they now believe she is innocent. "It is clear now that this is retaliation against the wife," Col Aromin said.

The authorities think that Eiman was taken to the heavily forested area of Parang by people linked to her great uncle, Jubaran. It is unclear how much land is involved in the family dispute, but Col Aromin said the kidnappers did not seem to be demanding money: "They have only asked for some cash to buy some food and nothing in ransom."

Authorities also reject the big ransom theory because the kidnappers took only Eiman, a Philippine national, and left behind her half sister, Khadija, aged 22 months, who is the daughter of Mr and Mrs Grant and so a British national.

Foreigners always attract bigger ransom demands from kidnappers in the southern Philippines, a fairly lawless area where abductions are common.

Col Aromin said it was impossible to predict how long it would take to complete the negotiations. "We have to look out for the safety of the child first. So if that means a couple more days, then so be it. There are still one or two problems to be resolved," he added, without elaborating.

To ease the pressure on the kidnappers, the 750 soldiers searching for Eiman were ordered not to advance on the camp. Col Aromin said he was not pleased Mr Grant had arrived: "This only makes things worse. Not only might it affect the kidnappers, but it might also encourage other armed gangs to get involved."

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Gerard Le Claire, a 35-year-old Briton, has been named among nine people killed in a helicopter crash 600 miles north of the Mongolian capital, Ulan Bator.
fields.body:
Briton among crash dead
Gerard Le Claire, a 35-year-old Briton, has been named among nine people killed in a helicopter crash 600 miles north of the Mongolian capital, Ulan Bator. Mr Le Claire, director of environmental services at the planning department in Jersey, was on secondment with the UN.

Gardener finds ageing bombs
A road in High Wycombe, Buckinghamshire, was closed after a resident found a cache of second world war bombs in a garden yesterday. Two controlled explosions were carried out.

Developers dies in air accident
A Southport developer died when the plane he was piloting crashed near Stafford. Philip Chester, 40, was a partner in the Merseyside-based firm Falconer Chester. His passenger, Peter McLaughlin, 38, from Crosby, received rib injuries.

Queen to sell spare stamps
The Queen is to sell part of her British and Empire stamp collection. Charles Goodwyn, keeper of the collection, said yesterday duplicates and surplus items would be offered at the auctioneers Spink in London on May 17 to fund "a programme of enhancement".

Driver alleges Halford assault
North Wales police are investigating a taxi driver's complaint that he was assaulted by Alison Halford, former Merseyside assistant chief constable and now a Labour member of the Welsh assembly. Ms Halford, of Ewloe, north Wales, denies the allegation, relating to an incident on Sunday night.

14-year-old dies at council home
A 14-year-old has died of a suspected drugs overdose at Kerelaw secure unit in Stevenston, Ayrshire.

Strathclyde police said the unnamed boy had returned from home leave on Sunday but yesterday morning staff had been unable to waken him. Glasgow city council, which manages the residential school, said an inquiry had begun.

EastEnders four times a week
The BBC's EastEnders is be screened four times a week from later this year, to match ITV's Coronation Street, which introduced a fourth episode in 1996.

In Walford, east London, the cast was told at lunchtime yesterday. Queen Vic landlady Peggy Mitchell (Babs Windsor) said: "I'm thrilled."

Dublin MP given jail sentence
Ireland's high court yesterday gave Liam Lawlor, MP for Dublin West, a three-month sentence and a IR£10,000 fine for contempt of court.

Lawlor, 55, will be jailed for a week and then have his term suspended, if he co-operates with a tribunal investigating planning corruption. He is to appeal to the supreme court today.

Hope yet for All Saints
Girl band All Saints, said to be about to split up, was nominated for the Best British Group award at this year's Brits ceremony, along with Coldplay, Radiohead, Moloko and Toploader. R&B star Craig David was nominated for four awards.
