webTitle: The battle to shape Liverpool

fields.headline: The battle to shape Liverpool
fields.standfirst: Home-grown builder vies with the Duke of Westminster for redevelopment of Chavasse Park
fields.trailText: Home-grown builder vies with the Duke of Westminster for redevelopment of Chavasse Park
fields.body:
A first glance and it is just a patch of green parkland on the edge of Liverpool city centre, but it is probably the most important piece of real estate anywhere in the country.

The battle for control of Chavasse Park represents the missing piece in the jigsaw of the renaissance of a city once regarded as Britain's basket case.

The park links the heart of Liverpool with the bars, restaurants and museums on the waterfront around the 19th-century Albert Dock, the largest group of Grade 1 listed buildings in the country, drawing more than 5m visitors annually.

Chavasse Park is a ragged shape and is easily recognisable for the huge steel yellow submarine - a visual testament to the Beatles' hit film.

For years, Liverpool has not been short of symbols of a proud cultural and industrial past. But until recently it has been stuck in a timewarp, unable to grab the urban riches which have revitalised other cities. Now all that has changed.

Two developers are fighting it out for control of Chavasse Park, a 20 acre site worth millions of pounds - for the privilege of redeveloping a centre which could cost £200m.

On one side, is a controversial self made builder from Liverpool. On the other is one of Britain's wealthiest men.

Bill Davies, chairman of Walton Group, is up against the Duke of Westminster, chairman of Grosvenor Group Holdings, who owns much of Belgravia in central London and swaths of rural England.

Grosvenor has produced plans as part of the city's £800m Bluecoat Triangle development, which embraces the Chavasse site, as well as a large chunk of the city.

Green land

It is understood that the Grosvenor plan, launched next week, will essentially retain Chavasse Park as green land.

The Bluecoat Triangle plan divides Liverpool into four quarters for development. The first quarter in Hanover Street would retain and renovate derelict buildings. The plans are thought to widen Paradise Street, creating a boulevard.

Originally the Chavasse site was due to be the location of a national discovery park. But the plans were abandoned when millennium commission grants were not secured.

It then emerged that the property developer Walton Group, which had made an agreement with Liverpool city council's previous Labour administration in 1996, was legally entitled to develop the land as a retail complex following the failure of the discovery park plan, an ambitious multimedia centre.

The developer and the council have been locked in legal battles ever since. Last summer, Mr Davies launched a high court action claiming the council had breached his human rights by delaying considering a planning application.

Mr Davies claimed the council was deliberately trying to block his proposal in favour of the Bluecoat Triangle scheme.

"I have been disappointed that the city council has not been prepared to enter into a serious dialogue about the detail of the scheme, which after all is being designed to satisfy the requirements of our contract with them."

Mr Davies, 65, said he had been prepared to invest in the city in good times and bad. But Walton Group has often been accused of dragging its feet on the redevelopment of other key sites in Liverpool, including the Exchange Flags building.

The company has been asked by English Partnerships, the £4.45m grant for the renovation of the Exchange Flags building.

"English Partnerships has made a detailed investigation into a £4.45m city grant paid to the Walton Group during 1992-94," said a spokeswoman. "Various discrepancies have been identified in claims for grant funding and legal proceedings have been issued."

Aspirations

Mike Storey, leader of Liverpool city council, described Chavasse Park as a wonderful piece of land. "We must ensure that there is a development which fits our aspirations for the 21st century. It is the missing piece of the jigsaw puzzle which brings everything together in Liverpool."

Louise Ellman, Labour MP for Liverpool Riverside, said she felt there was something strange about the way the original agreement was made between the council and Walton. It was essential that the legal position of ownership of the land was clarified. "Given the importance of the site, it is essential that we are confident about the developers," she said.

Although dogged by controversy, Walton has not been short of style. One of the most respected architects in America has designed Chavasse Park's flagship building. Philip Johnson is renowned for designing the International Place in Boston and Momentum Place in Dallas.

"The Chavasse Park design brings a world-class landmark, tying the city centre to the waterfront," he said. "Liverpool has to recreate the water. We have the dock; we have the water; we have the city. But they don't seem to meet."

Steve John, spokesman for Walton Group, said the site could be as important to Liverpool as the Guggenheim Museum was to Bilbao.

He said that research commissioned in 1999 found that although 5.2m visitors came to Liverpool, the majority parked their cars at Albert Dock and visited the attractions there, but did not cross the busy three-lane carriageway linking it to the city centre. In the Walton Group's plan, a footbridge would solve this problem.

Mr John added that the plan, which would be completed in 2004, could work alongside the Bluecoat Triangle scheme, due to open in 2007-08.

But Walton Group's plan was severely criticised by the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment, an independent review body of planning applications.

In its report, the commission concluded: "We found very little which we could support in this project... It would cause a fundamental shift in the city's retail centre of gravity which would be to the detriment of existing areas; in terms of regeneration of the city centre it would make things worse rather than better."

A spokesman for Grosvenor said the Bluecoat Triangle plan was something it was very committed to because it shared the objectives and aims of the city council - to regenerate the heart of Liverpool.

"The scheme breathes new life into Liverpool and it is a fairly substantial mixed use of retail, leisure and residential with a contemporary feeling," he said.

It has yet to be seen whether the duke or the home-grown builder will triumph in the battle for Chavasse Park.

webTitle: Resources:  Key stage 3

fields.headline: Should there be a ban on hunting?
fields.trailText: Resources: Key stage 3, the parliamentary vote
fields.body:
A vote by MPs tomorrow could bring a ban on hunting with dogs a big step closer. For the League Against Cruel Sports, this would mean the end of a 76-year campaign. For fans of field sports, any decision to forbid the hunting of foxes, deer, hares and mink would threaten centuries-old countryside traditions.

Surveys suggest most people in Britain oppose blood sports. But, say hunting enthusiasts, it is unfair for city people to judge lifestyles they do not understand, and unjust for Parliament to ban them. But it looks as if this is what Parliament will do tomorrow when MPs are given the freedom to vote how they like, "according to conscience". Normally MPs are expected to support the views of the political party they belong to.

MPs will have to opt for one of three courses of action, instead of the usual yes/no decision. They will be able to vote for a complete ban, for strict outside regulation of hunting with dogs, or for a voluntary system in which hunting people would supervise their own activities.

Even if the vote goes against hunting, huntsmen in England and Wales will not be hanging up their red coats just yet. The same three choices have to be debated in the House of Lords, and it is possible that they will reverse the MPs' decision.

The government can overturn the Lords' vote but they may not have time to do so before the next general election, expected to be in May. The laws may change sooner in Scotland because the Scottish Parliament, which is also discussing these issues, does not have a House of Lords. Hunting deer with dogs is already illegal in Scotland.

The present hunting bill follows a major independent inquiry into hunting, the Burns Report, published last June. It agreed that the welfare of foxes was "seriously compromised" by being chased and caught by hounds. Supporters of hunting argue that hunting foxes is just as humane as the other methods used to kill them. Their opponents say that death for foxes and hares does not come with a single bite from the first dog, but while they are being torn to pieces by the pack. They also argue that the stresses animals suffer when chased can kill them - even if they escape.

The Burns Report estimated that up to 8,000 jobs could be lost if hunting was banned. There is already huge unemployment in rural areas. Then there are the moral arguments. Should people take pleasure in killing animals? Then again, would people care so much if rats were the quarry? If the issue features in an election, it may be to the advantage of the Labour Party, which does well when young people vote. Few subjects get young voters involved as much as hunting.

A ban could also be positive for the health of Prince Charles, who recently broke a bone in his shoulder by falling from his horse while fox-hunting.

Quotes<BR

'The English country gentleman galloping after a fox - the unspeakable in full pursuit of the uneatable' Oscar Wilde

'The issue of hunting has become a litmus test of the government's commitment to a society of tolerance and democracy' Sam Butler, chairman, Countryside Alliance

'I believe that hunting with dogs is a barbaric practice that in no way can be justified as sport' Sir Paul McCartney

There is already huge unemployment in rural areas. Then there are the moral arguments. Should people take pleasure in killing animals? Then again, would people care so much if rats were the quarry? If the issue features in an election, it may be to the advantage of the Labour Party, which does well when young people vote. Few subjects get young voters involved as much as hunting. A ban could also be positive for the health of Prince Charles, who recently broke a bone in his shoulder by falling from his horse while fox-hunting. Quotes

webTitle: Resources: The state of divorce in the 21st century

fields.headline: The state of divorce in the 21st century
fields.trailText: Resources: Key stage 4, the future of marriage
fields.body:
Times are hard for marriage. Tying the knot is not what makes happy families, says the government - what matters is the quality of the relationship between mothers and fathers, however they choose to live together. It's a view that upsets church leaders, who want the government to say that marriage is the best choice. This month also sees the 30th anniversary of the Divorce Reform Act.

The Divorce Reform Act helped to remove blame from the ending of a marriage by recognising for the first time that they can reach a point of "irretrievable breakdown".

Britain starts 2001 with divorce rates twice that of any other European Union country - nearly one in three marriages collapse. It is feared by some that the traditional family is on the way out. They argue that by reducing the stigma of divorce, the Act has actually contributed to our high levels of marriage breakdown. But is the law responsible and what, if anything, should governments do to deal with the problems affecting people's private lives?

It is hard to appreciate how things have altered without a sense of the past. Until 300 years ago it was the church, through its ecclesiastical courts, that controlled marriage. Divorce was not an option for anyone except Henry VIII!

The 1857 Matrimonial Causes Act made divorce for adultery more generally available, but it was only in 1923 that women got the same rights to divorce as men. In 1937, a new Act created a number of "matrimonial offences" for which people could seek a divorce. But the law did nothing for marriages that just failed - a big problem with the coming of the second world war (1939-45), which separated couples.

It was only with the Divorce Reform Act, in 1971, that people were able to escape marriages that had become "empty legal shells". Apart from variations in Scotland, the Act still forms the basis of Britain's divorce law today. The biggest changes since it was passed have involved simplifying the process, creating the "quickie divorce".

Meanwhile, changing attitudes have meant that, increasingly, children are born to cohabiting, unmarried couples. What worries people most about divorce is the damage it could do to children. It has been claimed that it affects everything from their mental health to their ability to enjoy relationships. Others argue that living with two miserable parents is much worse for a child than seeing them apart, but happy.

The government is now considering another big reform that would require people to undergo a period of reflection, or mediation, before dissolving the marriage. And, despite the government's promise to promote good relationships of all kinds, there is evidence that it is still committed to encouraging marriage. This view is in the national curriculum and soon people planning to marry will receive a free advice book called Married Life. What effect these measures will have remains to be seen.

Did you know...

 The average cost of a white wedding is £13, 723.

 Four in 10 marriages end in divorce; in London, it's 50%.

 22% of children live only with their mothers - a threefold increase on 1971.

 Four in 10 petitions for divorce are based on unreasonable behaviour; 30% on adultery.

 In 1997, there were 310,000 marriages - the lowest recorded figure for the century.

Citizenship (Knowledge 1a) rights and responsibilities; (Skills 2a) topical political, moral and spiritual issues; (2b and c) express and justify views. English En1 (1 a-g; 2a-f; 3a-e; 4 a-d)

Debate the issues, or use in drama; En2 (1c-d) History of divorce; En3 (1e-h) Write about divorce and marriage. RE Marriage and divorce is a key topic in most RE courses.

Age: Reception

The manufacturer says: This creative project has been specifically designed to teach early skills through play. Provides the foundation for early language and mathematical understanding through shopping.

Ruth Moyler, nursery teacher, Dog Kennel Hill School, London, SE5, says: "A wonderful product - we loved it. A thoroughly enjoyable way for three- to four-year-olds to learn about shopping concepts.

"There was space for cooperative play between four children at one time. I found that elongating the square by using three panels with a table at the back was the best format. All four panels together was too much stimulation for the age group.

"It is a versatile resource which we will probably also use as a puppet show; the bank section could be used higher up the school.

"The door is too small for an adult to get through, which could be problematic for a teacher trying to reach a child quickly.

"But overall, both teacher and kids were impressed. I'm very pleased we don't have to give it back!"

webTitle: Resources: What if we took our cars off the streets?

fields.headline: What if we took our cars off the streets?
fields.trailText: Resources: Key Stage 2, changes in the environment
fields.body:
The way we travel is damaging our environment. In England alone, in the second half of the 80s, an area as big as Bristol was taken for road-building and parking. And cars are not only gobbling up our countryside. Climate change is one of the greatest environmental threats facing the world today.

Did you know three in 10 homes in Britain do not have a car? Thirteen million people use buses, and bikes and walk. According to environmental pressure groups these people, pedestrians, are always considered after motorists. In the last decade, however, people have begun to recognise that traffic congestion and pollution can severely affect our quality of life, particularly in cities and towns. The government now says it wants to "make walking a more viable, attractive and safe option".

It has told all local authorities that when they write their transport policies they must encourage pedestrians by making walking safer.

The new emphasis on foot power will mean there will be more places where walkers come first - where they will have what is called "pedestrian priority". Historic towns and cities, such as York, are now providing signed walking routes which link places of interest. In Bristol, priority walking routes have been created to help commuters and shoppers get from their homes to the city centre.

In London the council, police and transport providers are working to establish a "capital route" through the heart of London's West End, where roads will be well maintained and streets will not be too crowded. In Wakefield and Birmingham, the local councils have introduced 20 miles per hour speed limits near schools to discourage driving and to make it safer for children to walk to school.

One of the new schemes which emphasises pedestrian priority is the "home zone". It is a street where people on foot come first and where cars travel at walking pace. Most of the time there are no cars in the street so even small children can play outside safely. Streets become places where people walk, cycle or simply sit and chat. There are seats and plants. The whole point of a home zone is to create a place where children can safely play in the street without speeding cars.

Key features of home zones

Home zones have been common in Europe for 25 years. For example, over 6,500 home zones or "woonerf" streets have been introduced in the Netherlands since the late 1960s. They share common features:

 Changes in priority - drivers have to give way to cyclists and pedestrians.

 Very low speed limits - top speed 10mph or less

 Emphasis on new status - signs, seating, street furniture and plants.

Should a local street be closed to traffic?

Would you like to see a home zone in your town? You could carry out a survey of the views of people in your town about the benefits and drawbacks of making a street near you a home zone. Discuss with your class the questions you should ask to make a thorough questionnaire. If you plan to close a street you will need to look at the local map and discuss the routes traffic could take to avoid your home.

Did you know?

Britain's laws do not give councils powers to develop home zones, but groups concerned about children's safety and play are supporting the idea. Last year the government set up nine home zones to try out the idea. The zones are in London, Leeds, Manchester, Nottingham, Peterborough, Plymouth and Sittingbourne.

Curriculum Links

Primary Geography Unit 12 (Year 5): Should the high street be closed to traffic?

Objectives met by this resource:

 Children should learn how places can be managed and improved.

 They should learn to draw up reasoned plans to identify solutions.

 They should learn to propose environmental change in an area.

 They should learn to discuss an issue using a range of evidence.

Lesson ideas

Form groups and allocate a range of roles to each: eg a young parent, a resident who wants to park, a driver who uses the road as a shortcut. Ask each group to debate the issue of turning a street into a home zone. Ask each to prepare a presentation of its views on traffic in a residential street and the pros and cons of turning it into a home zone. Then take a vote.

webTitle: NHS 'must speed up change'

fields.headline: NHS 'must speed up change'
fields.trailText: The president of the General Medical Council, Sir Donald Irvine, will today vent his frustrations at the unwillingness of doctors to move faster to change the old NHS paternalistic culture.
fields.body:
The president of the General Medical Council, Sir Donald Irvine, will today vent his frustrations at the unwillingness of doctors to move faster to change the old NHS paternalistic culture.

His hard-hitting speech will warn that the government is waiting in the wings to take over if public confidence in the medical profession is not restored.

Sir Donald, whose agenda for reform of the profession has been consistently blocked by hard-line members of the British Medical Association, will say that much more must be done to demonstrate that doctors are no longer arrogant inhabitants of ivory towers.

"The cultural flaws in the medical profession show up as excessive paternalism, lack of respect for patients and their right to make decisions about their care, secrecy, and complacency about poor practice. These all contribute to a picture which leads the public to believe that a lot of doctors put their interests before that of their patients," he will say in a lecture at the Royal Society of Medicine tonight.

The BMA and the GMC have come to blows over reform, most notably at the BMA conference last summer, where a vote of no confidence in the GMC, the doctors' regulatory body, was passed. Sir Donald believed the problem was the reluctance of some elements at the BMA to take on board revalidation - the five-yearly "MOT" intended to prove that doctors remain fit to practice in the years after they qualify.

The timing of today's attack is significant. The report into the organ scandal at Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool is imminent, and the Bristol Royal Infirmary inquiry is soon to report. Both are likely to spotlight doctors' failings.

Sir Donald will be hoping that the reports serve to concentrate medical minds on signing up to reforms. He will say in the speech that it is time to abandon "the tired rhetoric of good intentions" and adopt the "robust revalidation that the public expects".

webTitle: Prince Charles reignites GM food debate

fields.headline: Low-tech beats GM, says prince
fields.standfirst:
Charles backs revolutionary system to aid starving
Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Prince Charles yesterday reignited the GM debate by endorsing a revolutionary agricultural system that claims to prove that the 800m facing hunger in developing countries can grow far more food by adopting simple farming techniques than by going down the hi-tech GM route favoured by Tony Blair and US corporations.
fields.body:
Prince Charles yesterday reignited the GM debate by endorsing a revolutionary agricultural system that claims to prove that the 800m facing hunger in developing countries can grow far more food by adopting simple farming techniques than by going down the hi-tech GM route favoured by Tony Blair and US corporations.

Addressing a conference at St James's Palace on the benefits of "sustainable" agriculture, the prince said: "Arguments for hi-tech agriculture are increasingly accepted without question, and their possible long term consequences on the environment and economies are not being given sufficient attention.

"One of the most commonly raised arguments raised by those in favour of GMs is that they are necessary to 'feed the world'. But where people are starving, lack of food is rarely the underlying cause. There is a need to create sustainable livelihoods. I would argue for a more balanced approach. Sustainable agriculture provides a pointer to what can be achieved."

The prince, representatives of large corporations, charities and academies around the world heard that almost 9m poor farmers in more than 50 developing countries were witnessing 50 to 150% yield increases with huge environmental and social benefits.

"Sustainable agriculture" has been developed largely over the past decade and aims to save water, regenerate soils by using manures, forgo deep ploughing to prevent erosion, reclaim unproductive land, and minimisethe use of pesticides and fertilisers. It is close to organic agriculture which the prince has long favoured.

The usual claim for GM foods is that they increase yields between 5 to 10%, but, say critics, hi-tech farming may undermine small farmers who mostly save their own seeds and cannot afford the new technology.

Leading GM companies and governments have highlighted the growing global food crisis and tried to promote the controversial technology by claiming it could "feed the world". Last year, Mr Blair said that GM foods could "bring benefits for mankind".

The research by Essex University, funded by the Department for International Development, Greenpeace and Bread For the World, collated data from more than 200 projects growing food on more than 29.8m hectares (75m acres), and found "astonishing" results.

"We set out to see if farmers can improve food production with cheap, low-cost, locally available technologies and inputs, and whether they can do this without causing further environmental damage," said Jules Pretty, director of the University of Essex centre for environment and society.

"We found that for 4.42m small farmers practising sustainable agriculture on 3.58m hectares average food production per household increased 73%. For the 146,000 farmers on 542,000 hectares cultivating crops like potato and cassava the increase was 150%; and on larger farms total production increased by 46%."

The research showed that almost all the projects made better use of local natural resources and involved people working together as groups. "It seems to work best in the poorest areas," said Prof Pretty. "We can start to see real improvements."

There is a need to create sustainable livelihoods. I would argue for a more balanced approach. Sustainable agriculture provides a pointer to what can be achieved." The prince, representatives of large corporations, charities and academies around the world heard that almost 9m poor farmers in more than 50 developing countries were witnessing 50 to 150% yield increases with huge environmental and social benefits. "Sustainable agriculture" has been developed largely over the past decade and aims to save water, regenerate soils by using manures, forgo deep ploughing to prevent erosion, reclaim unproductive land, and minimisethe use of pesticides and fertilisers. It is close to organic agriculture which the prince has long favoured. The usual claim for GM foods is that they increase yields between 5 to 10%, but, say critics, hi-tech farming may undermine small farmers who mostly save their own seeds and cannot afford the new technology. Leading GM companies and governments have highlighted the growing global food crisis and tried to promote the controversial technology by claiming it could "feed the world". Last year, Mr Blair said that GM foods could "bring benefits for mankind". The research by Essex University, funded by the Department for International Development, Greenpeace and Bread For the World, collated data from more than 200 projects growing food on more than 29.8m hectares (75m acres), and found "astonishing" results. "We set out to see if farmers can improve food production with cheap, low-cost, locally available technologies and inputs, and whether they can do this without causing further environmental damage," said Jules Pretty, director of the University of Essex centre for environment and society. "We found that for 4.42m small farmers practising sustainable agriculture on 3.58m hectares average food production per household increased 73%. For the 146,000 farmers on 542,000 hectares cultivating crops like potato and cassava the increase was 150%; and on larger farms total production increased by 46%." The research showed that almost all the projects made better use of local natural resources and involved people working together as groups. "It seems to work best in the poorest areas," said Prof Pretty. "We can start to see real improvements."

webTitle: Soulful Craig David looks set to sweep Brit awards

fields.headline: Soulful Craig David looks set to sweep Brit awards
fields.trailText: Craig David may not win any points for cutting edge pop, but with four nominations for next month's Brit Awards announced yesterday, the soulful king of Southampton R&B music looks set to shrug off lesser pretenders to his throne.
fields.body:
Craig David may not win any points for cutting edge pop, but with four nominations for next month's Brit Awards announced yesterday, the soulful king of Southampton R&B music looks set to shrug off lesser pretenders to his throne.

In his nine-month meteoric rise to fame, 19-year-old David has sold an impressive 3.5m albums, and his feat has been acknowledged with nominations in the Best British Male Solo Artist, Best British Dance Act, and Best British Newcomer categories.

David, who shot to fame with his single Fill Me In last year, picked up three gongs at the Music of Black Origin (Mobo) Awards last October.

Other acts that feature well in this year's Brit nominations include the newcomers Coldplay, who received three nominations, and the Oxford based Radiohead, whose recent album Kid A has been a smash on both sides of the Atlantic.

"Are they or aren't they about to split up" girl group All Saints are given a much-needed fillip with a nomination for Best British Group award, though they face stiff competition from acoustic rockers Coldplay, who receive three nominations, Toploader, Moloko, and the mighty Radiohead.

Former Housemartin Fat Boy Slim, aka Norman Cook, picks up nominations in the Best British Dance Act and Best British Male Solo Artist categories.

Sartorial tastes will be put to the test as quick-change artist Britney Spears, pop stalwart Kylie Minogue, and the ubiquitous Madonna go head to head in the international category.

Self-styled bad boy Eminem is also nominated in the Best International Male Solo Artist, along with his angelic opposite Ronan Keating and Latin star Ricky Martin.

Also in the running is Dido, nominated in the Best British Female category.

Despite selling albums by the thousands in the USA, she has yet to release any singles in Britain.

It was also announced yesterday that the Irish rock heroes U2 will be honoured at the Brits ceremony when they receive an award for outstanding contribution to music - something of a change from last year, when the far less experienced Spice Girls were given the award.

The ceremony will take place on February 26 and will be hosted by the TV presenters Ant and Dec.

Best British group
All Saints, Coldplay, Moloko, Radiohead, Toploader

Best British album
Coldplay/Parachutes, Craig David/Born To Do It, David Gray/Lost Songs, Radiohead/ Kid A; Robbie Williams/Sing When You're Winning

Best British dance act
Artful Dodger, Craig David, Fat Boy Slim, Moloko, Sonique

Best British male solo artist
Badly Drawn Boy, Craig David, David Gray, Fat Boy Slim, Robbie Williams

Best British female solo artist
Dido, Sade, PJ Harvey, Jamelia, Sonique

Best British newcomer
A1, Atomic Kitten, Lolly, Point Break, Richard Blackwood, Coldplay, Toploader, Muse, Badly Drawn Boy, Death in Vegas, Craig David, DJ Luck & MC Neat, Sweet Female Attitude, Architects, MJ Cole, Artful Dodger, Sonique, Shaft, Oxide & Neutrino, Chicane

Best pop act
Britney Spears, Ronan Keating, S Club 7, Steps, Westlife

Best soundtrack
AIR: The Virgin Suicides, American Beauty, Billy Elliot, Bjork, Selmasongs, Shaft, The Beach

Best international group
The Corrs, Santana, Savage Garden, U2, Westlife

Best international newcomer
Jill Scott, Kelis, Lene Marlin, Pink, Westlife

Best international male solo artist
Eminem, Ricky Martin, Ronan Keating, SisQo, Wyclef Jean

Best international female solo artist
Britney Spears, Jill Scott, Kylie Minogue, Madonna, Pink

webTitle: Salford estates fight to turn back tide of decay

fields.headline: Salford estates fight to turn back tide of decay
fields.trailText: Run down is a description which barely conveys the extent of boarded up properties, graffiti and litter associated with the Seedley and Langworthy estates in Salford, where residents already have a say in their community.
fields.body:
Run down is a description which barely conveys the extent of boarded up properties, graffiti and litter associated with the Seedley and Langworthy estates in Salford, where residents already have a say in their community.

The estates, with 75% of the housing owner occupied, suffer from a phenomenon which many thought had disappeared in the early 1990s. Terrace houses once worth £30,000 are now routinely sold for as little as £3,000.

The Seedley and Langworthy Partnership is working to regenerate the areas. At the next board meeting, the issue of whether it needs a neighbourhood manager will be discussed.

The partnership has six members who are residents on its board, which meets every six weeks.

Locals can also voice their concerns via the Seedley and Langworthy Initiative, which brings together four of the area's residents' associations.

Hazel Blears, Salford MP, who chairs the partnership, said: "One of the exciting things about the neighbourhood managers is they work across local authorities, health services and police to exercise political muscle. I will be seeking to get this issue on the agenda at the next partnership meeting."

She said the partnership was absolutely committed to making sure the project was community led.

"We have got a master plan, which is a vision for the next seven to 10 years. There are four main tasks - improving the living environment, young people, crime and community safety and economic development skills."

She said people in the area had lost confidence and there was a lot of conflict and anger.

"We want to recreate the sense of community which we had 30 years ago. Where people would look out for each other and not just shut their door and walk away."

Many people living there feel that the speed of change is too slow.

It takes time to filter money from the single regeneration budget through to the community. In 1999 the partnership secured a £13.7m SRB grant.

But the money is being used in many positive ways. Victims of repeated crimes can get money to buy alarms and window locks.

In April the Sure Start Centre will open, a place where young families can go for advice on healthy liv ing. It will include mothers and toddlers groups, a community cafe and toy library.

The Seedley and Langworthy Initiative has a shop on Langworthy Road, which opened in 1999 where residents can voice concerns about problems on the estate.

Marion Gattens, who chairs the initiative, said the majority of people in the area used the shop. "They will go in if they have a problem with their housing benefit or rubbish accumulating outside. People feel that they will get answers to their questions and that we will have some sort of clout to deal with the council."

She blames many of the estates' problems on unscrupulous landlords rehousing people there in the 1990s who had previously been evicted from council estates.

"They only wanted people on income support because there was more money in it," she added. "Then other people would leave the street and those left behind would not have the support of their neighbours. I live around here and half my street have left - it can be quite frightening."

But she said the area was improving and the Chimney Pot community centre had reopened and was being used by older children.

webTitle: Railtrack needs rescue rights issue

fields.headline: The thin controller with fat losses
fields.standfirst: Railtrack needs rescue rights issue
fields.trailText: Railtrack needs rescue rights issue.
fields.body:
City trainspotters wanting to continue collecting Railtrack's extraordinary numbers had better get themselves some fatter, wider notebooks because, as emergency thin controller Steven Marshall admitted yesterday, the figures are set to fly off the page.

It beggars belief that a business enjoying a nationwide monopoly, into which £15bn of public funds is being poured over the next five years (on top of the public billions already spent), can contrive a financial forecast that puts projected net debt at £8bn by end-March 2003. After the latest upward revision of the financial costs of Hatfield, current borrowings stand roughly equal with shareholder funds at around £3bn. So Mr Marshall was telling us yesterday that Railtrack is about to become insolvent.

The company requires an early drawdown on the money already promised from the exchequer and needs the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, to cut the remaining straps on the performance/ ticket price straitjacket. Otherwise the board will have to resign, because it will be in breach of companies legislation.

What in heaven's name were chairman Sir Philip Beck and the last chief executive, Gerald Corbett, thinking of last autumn when they raised the dividend?

Squaring these eye-popping numbers with the stock market's sanguine reaction yesterday (Railtrack's perceived value slipped just 2.5% to 968p) is not easy. As Robert Peston of CSQuest.com, a research service for fund managers, points out, the City is reading statements from the Strategic Rail Authority and Mr Winsor as a declaration that the government will not let Railtrack go bust. But what this is not, Mr Peston adds, is "a commitment from HMG that it will underwrite the current share price and market capitalisation of £5bn."

He cannot see Gordon Brown, who actually understands the concept of risk capital, providing the necessary assistance without an upfront contribution from Railtrack's shareholders, and the analyst comes to the equity investment view that "Railtrack's shares are set to tumble and fast."

That seems a sensible enough conclusion. But it will not get us to work or home on time.

Ideology aside, this business needs a rescue rights issue - the traditional form of which entails a strong outsider (the government) underwriting a heavily discounted offer (at 100p a share, say, on a 10-for-one basis), which provides both a large ownership stake and a big stick with which to beat the management into shape. Mr Brown should just get on with it.

Sabre-rattling

Bill Richardson has made a habit of high-profile lobbying trips around Opec producers during his tenure as Bill Clinton's energy secretary, but his finely honed diplomatic skills are unlikely to prevent the cartel agreeing production curbs when it meets in Vienna later this week.

Indeed, Mr Richardson - in London yesterday after a tour through some of the key Gulf Arab states - conceded as much when he spoke of the need to make any cuts "as small as possible".

Size will be the crucial factor. Modest reductions at a time when slowing global growth is already expected to reduce demand for oil need not be too damaging to the price, helping to keep supply and demand in line and producing both a profit for Opec and manageable energy costs for industrialised nations.

But deep cuts to sustain an artificially high price could tip the world economy into recession and, in the process, deprive the oil producers of the extra revenue they are hoping to raise.

The US Federal Reserve cited the impact on growth of escalating energy costs as one of the reasons for its emergency interest rate cut earlier this month but latent inflationary pressure means there is a limit at which it can loosen monetary policy to offset higher oil prices.

Opec was sabre-rattling yesterday, threatening to deprive the West of 1.5m barrels a day (about 5% of Opec's total output). While better than talk of cuts of 2m to 3m barrels a day, this is nevertheless a significant reduction which has the potential to do much harm, especially at a time when supplies from Iraq remain subject to the whim of Saddam Hussein.

Inflation figures due out later today in Britain are expected to reveal a sharp drop, largely due to falls in the price of oil and petrol towards the end of last year. But big production curbs by Opec could send it back up again.

This need not be too worrying since underlying price pressures remain subdued, but nervousness about the future direction of inflation could be another reason - along with the forthcoming Budget - for the Bank of England's monetary policy committee delaying widely expected interest rate cuts.

webTitle: Depleted uranium waste to be dumped on public tip

fields.headline: Depleted uranium waste to be dumped on public tip
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Thirty thousand bags of nuclear waste containing depleted uranium are to be dumped on a municipal waste tip three miles from Preston on the river Ribble in Lancashire.
fields.body:
Thirty thousand bags of nuclear waste containing depleted uranium are to be dumped on a municipal waste tip three miles from Preston on the river Ribble in Lancashire.

The uranium is in powder form and is more radioactive than the material used to make shells and missiles fired in the Gulf and Kosovo wars.

British Nuclear Fuels yesterday confirmed that the uranium is mixed with PVC clothing, paper and other flammable materials, contaminated as a result of operations at its Springfields plant near Preston where fuel is manufactured for nuclear power stations.

The bags weigh between 5kg and 15kg each and will total about 300 tonnes. The uranium content will be limited to 0.2% by weight or about 20 grams per bag of natural uranium, BNFL has confirmed.

This kind of waste used to be taken to the BNFL-owned tip at Drigg in Cumbria and buried in concrete, but the site is filling up. The company says its operations are safe: "BNFL takes its environmental responsibilities seriously and operates strictly in accordance with the site licence and authorisations from the environment agency."

The total uranium dumped will be about 600kg, but this will be sent to the tip over a period of more than a year. BNFL confirmed it would be packed in plastic bags.

The company accepts the uranium present is 50% more radioactive than in normal depleted uranium because it contains active material normally only present in enriched uranium. This material, uranium 235, is stripped out of raw uranium ore for making nuclear weapons and is used in reactors to superheat steam. Some is left in the waste and dumped with the rest of the uranium oxide.

A BNFL employee, who alerted the Guardian to the dumping, said yesterday: "The plastic bags will be the only form of containment used, and will be closed using just a cou ple of strips of adhesive tape. At the landfill site the bags are driven over by a large earth mover with spike metal wheels. The possibility of bags bursting is obvious."

If the tip were to catch fire, uranium oxide could be carried in smoke to Preston, or to Blackpool 10 miles away, the source added.

According to the source the decision to dump the waste on a municipal tip was driven by the chronic lack of official dumps - Drigg is the only low-level nuclear waste tip in Britain. BNFL charges universities and the NHS for dumping nuclear waste there. "The volume and activity of the [Springfields] waste could seriously affect the future of the Drigg site," the source said.

BNFL accepts the company has a further 50,000 drums of similar waste at Springfields with "nowhere yet to dispose of them". The drums are not suitable for municipal disposal.

The proximity of a large gas main to the uranium disposal site also concerns the BNFL employee, as does the tip's long-term future. When uranium decays it breaks down into radon gas - a well-known cause of lung cancer.

"What if some time in the future houses or factories are built on the site?" the employee asked. "This often happens on old landfills, what about the disturbance of the ground or radon from the decay of uranium?"

Tony Brown, marketing manager for Lancashire Waste Services, which operates the tip, confirmed it took low-level radioactive waste from BNFL but said it was tested by both the waste company and the environment agency to check it was within limits. He was not aware it contained depleted uranium.

The BNFL employee claimed the company had misled the agency about the dangers. But BNFL insisted the agency had been kept fully informed.

An agency spokesman said: "We do not believe that a responsible company would try to mislead us but these allegations are serious and we will look into them."

webTitle: Hoggart: Sketch

fields.headline: Bullets bounce off Labour's fighting men
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Labour politicians adore being defence ministers. All those crisp uniformed officers, all those secrets, the code words, those wonderfully mysterious initials, vast plastic-covered maps bristling with pins, and best of all, the kit!
fields.body:
Labour politicians adore being defence ministers. All those crisp uniformed officers, all those secrets, the code words, those wonderfully mysterious initials, vast plastic-covered maps bristling with pins, and best of all, the kit! Bright green radar screens, screaming fighter planes, gigantic submarines, supercomputers and more guns than a boy could dream of, especially my own favourite, the belt-fed wombat.

Tories hate their enjoyment of these simple pleasures. They feel instinctively that only the Conservatives understand such things. Labour, so far as they're concerned, is the party of nuclear disarmament ("CND Hain!" shouted a Tory at one point yesterday, even though the by now rightish foreign minister Peter Hain was not even present), plus pacifists, Soviet sympathisers and lefty fifth columnists who would sell off our navy to fund drop-in centres for asylum-seeking lesbians.

It's nonsense, of course. The chance of any Labour minister telling all those officers at the MoD that he's sorry, but the money is needed to fund a centre for peace studies in Islington, does not exist. They wouldn't dare. But they wouldn't want to, either.

Take Lewis Moonie, the softly spoken junior defence minister, who was asked how many aircraft the ministry was planning to buy for the RAF. He listed them all with relish. "Including aircraft on order, current plans require 232 European fighter multi-role aircraft, 25 A-400 transport aircraft, 25 C130J transport aircraft, 21 Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft, eight Chinook Mk III support helicopters, 22 Merlin Mk III support helicopters, five modified global express jets"

And that was not all. There were aircraft to be leased, and aircraft that could not be announced because they would be so multitudinous that it was impossible to number them yet. The general impression he gave was that the government would not rest until every family in the land had a bomber, or at least a fighter, of their own.

No one is tougher than Mr Mucho Macho Man, John Spellar, the minister for the armed forces, who declared that the Royal Navy building programme would "project Britain's power around the world". (It was Mr Spellar who, a year ago, inserted a letter "n" into the word "cuts". Yesterday he spoke about the role of "phalanx". It was a nerve-shredding moment. But he got it right.) Rachel Squire, the Labour MP for Dunfermline West, demanded that the government "reaffirm its commitment to warship building and maintenance", a sentiment which, if uttered at any Labour conference in the early 1980s, would have had her hauled down from the platform by enraged delegates and stripped down for parts. (For a lot of people, pacifism was an excellent outlet for their aggression.)

But that was then. Now, the Tories keep trying to penetrate this armour. But they need a few depleted uranium shells if they are going to stop Geoff Hoon and his team of fighting men. Someone asked sarcastically about the shortage of RAF manpower. Didn't this mean we were approaching a new era of unmanned flight? "Unmanned flight is a capacity of the party opposite," said Dr Moonie, to wild applause from the jingoists and warmongers on his own side.

None of it matters. The bullets bounce off titanium-clad New Labour.

webTitle: MoD has no case to answer over shootings, says barrister

fields.headline: MoD has no case to answer over shootings, says barrister
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence has no case to answer or position to defend regarding the deaths of 14 unarmed civilians shot by soldiers 29 years ago in Derry, a barrister told the Bloody   Sunday inquiry yesterday. Lawyers for those bereaved and injured criticised the MoD in earlier statements to the tribunal, chaired by Lord Saville, which has been sitting in the city's Guildhall since March.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence has no case to answer or position to defend regarding the deaths of 14 unarmed civilians shot by soldiers 29 years ago in Derry, a barrister told the Bloody Sunday inquiry yesterday. Lawyers for those bereaved and injured criticised the MoD in earlier statements to the tribunal, chaired by Lord Saville, which has been sitting in the city's Guildhall since March.

Around 1,000 witnesses will be called to give evidence at the inquiry, which is expected to last two years. It was set up by Tony Blair after a long battle by the families of the dead.

But on the first day after the Christmas recess, Ian Burnett QC denied allegations that the MoD was being obstructive or uncooperative in helping to uncover the truth of what happened at the civil rights march on January 30 1972.

He did, however, admit that most of the army documents and photographs relating to the incident had been lost or destroyed, as have two rifles believed to have been used in the shooting, which he claimed were accidentally disposed of due to a computer glitch.

But he insisted the facts leant toward human error and circumstance rather than a grand conspiracy to conceal or get rid of evidence and that the MoD had done its utmost to locate personnel and papers.

"Herculean efforts have been made to locate anything of conceivable relevance. Vast amounts of time, energy and manpower have been commit ted to providing assistance to this inquiry," he said.

Lord Saville is to rule in the next couple of weeks on an MoD-Home Office request that sensitive security information and identities of military personnel involved be kept confidential. Lawyers for the families are contesting this issue.

Yesterday, Lord Saville said he was investigating allegations by the former MI5 agent David Shayler which raised doubt about the credibility of an intelligence agent known as "Infliction", who had claimed that Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness, the former IRA commander in Derry, had fired the first shot on Bloody Sunday.

Mr Burnett told the inquiry the MoD had a duty of protection as the soldiers' employer but its backing for their applications for anonymity should not be seen as an attempt to thwart the inquiry or be unfair to the families.

He said only around 3% of MoD papers on any subject would have been retained this length of time.

Most, he said, would have been shredded within a few years, and that it was common practice to get rid of intelligence documents as soon as they were no longer of operational value, while Northern Ireland military HQ would never have sent their files to the MoD archives.

He said an independent police investigation would show why the two rifles in army storage were destroyed.

But he said it could probably never have been proved conclusively that the rifles were used on Bloody Sunday and it was unlikely they would have yielded any useful forensic evidence.

webTitle: Israel breaks off talks after killing of settler

fields.headline: Israel breaks off talks after killing of settler
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli tanks rolled out along the roads of the Gaza Strip yesterday, reimposing their blockade on the territory after the kidnapping and murder of a Jewish settler.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem and  Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
Israeli tanks rolled out along the roads of the Gaza Strip yesterday, reimposing their blockade on the territory after the kidnapping and murder of a Jewish settler.

The discovery at dawn yesterday of the body of Roni Tsalah brought an abrupt halt to a week of diplomatic activity, with Israeli and Palestinian officials trying to map out the course of future negotiations after President Bill Clinton leaves office this weekend.

It also ended a week-long relative reprieve for the 1.1m people of the Gaza Strip, whose imprisonment by Israel's blockade had been eased as part of the talks.

Yesterday, as the runways were shut down at Gaza's airport, border crossings closed, and concrete barricades put up on roads to slice the territory into four pieces, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, cancelled last night's meeting between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators.

Officials from both sides said later that the talks could resume as early as today. However, with Israeli troops standing by as Jewish mobs clambered over the sand dunes to fire on Palestinian homes in the southern Gaza Strip and smash greenhouses and cars with rifle butts in retaliation for Tsalah's killing, tempers were running high on both sides.

Israeli soldiers shot dead a Palestinian stone thrower near the West Bank city of Nablus yesterday, and both sides now dread a new surge in violence that could destroy determined efforts to renew security arrangements and to move forward on negotiations for a final peace settlement.

The Israeli army said Tsalah was abducted from a packing plant on Sunday night. His car, which like many settlers' vehicles carried an electronic tracking device, was driven to the Palestinian town of Khan Yunis and set alight. He was shot once in the head, apparently with his own gun.

"It is an unforgivable and abominable crime," Mr Barak said in a statement. "The murderers will not be let off. Israel will reach them and they will be punished."

The armed wing of the Islamist group Hamas said it was responsible for Tsalah's killing, but Israeli officials, as is routine in these cases, also blamed Yasser Arafat and the Palestinian Authority.

"A murder like this cannot be committed without an instruction from above," the Israeli deputy prime minister, Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, said.

Palestinian officials said Mr Barak's decision to cancel the talks and reimpose the blockade was evidence that he was not interested in securing a settlement. Tsalah's killing "does not justify this kind of collective fatal punishment", said Ahmed Qureia, speaker of the Palestinian parliament.

Hours later, an aide to Mr Barak announced that the talks were back on. The change of heart is typical of Mr Barak, whose eyes are now fixed on Israel's elections for prime minister next month.

Near Nablus, three masked men shot dead a Palestinian man said to have helped Israeli hit squads hunting down commanders of Fatah militias. He was at least the sixth man to have been summarily executed by Fatah militants.

Palestinian authorities yesterday yielded to international criticism of the execution by firing squad of two men suspected of spying for Israel. Announcing an amnesty for collaborators, the justice minister, Freih Abu Meddein, said: "We will have no problem pardoning whoever comes and makes a full confession."

In Stockholm and Brussels, the European Union yesterday expressed "deep regret" at Saturday's executions.

webTitle: Hopes rise at Nissan as EU backs aid

fields.headline: Hopes rise at Nissan as EU backs aid
fields.trailText: Britain's chances of winning a £200m contract to build the new Nissan Micra in Sunderland improved dramatically last night when EU officials signalled that Brussels will definitely approve a £40m government grant designed to encourage the Japanese company to choose the UK over France.
fields.body:
Britain's chances of winning a £200m contract to build the new Nissan Micra in Sunderland improved dramatically last night when EU officials signalled that Brussels will definitely approve a £40m government grant designed to encourage the Japanese company to choose the UK over France.

The European Commission had said it harboured serious doubts about the aid. But a senior EU official yesterday told the Guardian the grant would now be rubber-stamped at a meeting tomorrow.

Nissan said last night there were other factors, such as the government's position on the euro, to be taken into account before it made a final decision on where the new model would bebuilt.

Towards the end of last year the commission canvassed the motor industry and member state governments to see whether anyone had serious objections to the state aid package but there were none.

"Nobody has complained and nobody has intervened. It will go through," the official disclosed yesterday.

Brussels had originally suspected that the rival French factory was not a viable alternative but merely a ploy by Nissan to secure the £40m. However, it has seen figures showing it would cost £80m more to produce the Micra at Sunderland than in France.

Fraser Kemp, Labour MP for Houghton and Washington East where the Sunderland plant is located, yesterday emerged from a meeting in Brussels with officials responsible for the case in an upbeat frame of mind.

"I'm more quietly confident that I was before I came. They said that the UK government had put up a very impressive bid for the grant." He cautioned, however, against raising expectations of the 1,300 workers in Sunderland whose jobs hinge on the decision.

A Nissan company spokesman confirmed yesterday that the firm's president, Carlos Ghosn, will take a decision on where the new Micra will be produced before the end of this month.

French carmaker Renault has a 36.8 % stake in Nissan and it is Renault's Flins factory in France which is competing to make the new model, due to be rolled out in 2003.

Nissan's head of UK corporate affairs, Andrew Horne, said the grant was a factor "along with progress made in cost cutting and the euro/sterling exchange rate. But it... is a close thing."

Nissan, together with other carmakers such as Ford, has repeatedly warned that the government's failure to sign up to the euro could jeopardise its UK investment plans.

"You can't make any money producing cars outside the euro zone and 75% of [Sunderland's] production goes to Europe," said Mr Horne. "We're talking about an eight- or nine-year production cycle here and we don't know what the exchange rate will be during that period."

The £40m would be spent upgrading the Sunderland plant, the most productive car factory in Europe, which employs 5,000 people directly and thousands of others in the auto supply industry.

webTitle: Infobank denies shortfall

fields.headline: Infobank denies shortfall
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Infobank, the e-commerce software developer that became one of the many victims of last year's internet sector share price collapse, yesterday issued a bold statement insisting that its revenue expectations for 2000 would be met.
fields.body:
Infobank, the e-commerce software developer that became one of the many victims of last year's internet sector share price collapse, yesterday issued a bold statement insisting that its revenue expectations for 2000 would be met.

The announcement failed to assuage market fears over technology stocks as Infobank shares moved down 5p to 251.5p.

The company, which last March had a share price of more than £40 before falling more than 75%, said strong growth in revenues would bring in £1.3m in the final quarter of 2000. This compares with £0.7m for the third quarter.

"Against a background of the development and introduction of InTrade 5 [the company's upgraded core software product], Infobank is pleased to have demonstrated continuing strong growth," the company said in a statement to the stock exchange.

"In addition, Infobank starts 2001 with over £2m of contracted revenue expected to be recognised in the current year."

Some analysts had been looking for signs that exponential growth was in the pipeline at Infobank, although most do not expect it to reach profit until the final quarter of 2002.

David Johnson, of stockbroker Beeson Gregory, said forecasting the fortunes of Infobank was hampered by a lack of detail on how revenue had been derived. While the company looked likely to exceed his forecast for revenue for 2000, it was unclear how much was organic growth, from acquisitions, one-off set-up fees or transaction royalties.

Elise Horowitz, of house broker Lehman Brothers, said the company would be hit by £11m in exceptional charges for a series of one-off investments when it delivers its full year results next month.

She said they were still trying to keep staff costs under control without slowing revenue growth, but now employed 291 people rather than the budgeted 280.

"It is always very difficult to manage cost structures without affecting revenues," she said. The company said operating expenses for the fourth quarter would be £14m.

Ms Horowitz said that the company's fortunes largely rest on the reception of InTrade 5, early responses to which were promising. In the meantime, Infobank has £93m in cash.

Infobank accompanied yesterday's trading statement with news that it has signed a deal with internet firm Etnoteam to jointly market and manage InTrade in Italy.

webTitle: Age of the entrepreneur is 45

fields.headline: Age of the entrepreneur is 45
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Despite the much-heralded emergence of the dressed-down young turks of the dot.com world - not to mention the supposed rise of women in business - it appears that the typical British entrepreneur remains a greying, suited male who may well be in charge of a manufacturing or retail firm.
fields.body:
Despite the much-heralded emergence of the dressed-down young turks of the dot.com world - not to mention the supposed rise of women in business - it appears that the typical British entrepreneur remains a greying, suited male who may well be in charge of a manufacturing or retail firm.

According to a report released today by accountancy firm Ernst & Young, the average British entrepreneur is aged 45 and 10 times more likely to be a man than a woman. He also employs an average of 350 workers and his company enjoys a turnover of £40m, with a sales growth rate of 31%.

Many entrepreneurs are unable to claim to have built a business empire from scratch - 25% of those surveyed bought into their company - reflecting a "historic reluctance" among venture capitalists to fund start-ups, the report suggests. Only 16% of them own all of their business, with most holding a stake of less than 25%.

David Wilkinson, head of entrepreneurial services at Ernst & Young, said that aside from debunking a number of myths around the youthful internet entrepreneur, the report also highlighted the need to nurture the new economy as it faces a slowdown.

"The recent ups and downs among dot.coms has undoubtedly cast a shadow over entrepreneurship in some people's minds and if a slow-down does start to take effect, entrepreneurship in the UK will be under serious threat," he said.

"The truth is, many of our most successful businesses are being run by entrepreneurs, who are having a huge positive effect on wealth and job creation. In order to encourage this spirit, we need to have an accurate understanding of its importance. We can't let our views be clouded by the stock market meltdown in one particular sector."

The report, which surveyed 600 entrepreneurs across Britain last summer, also found that an unexpected number were still engaged in Britain's maturer industries, with 10% working in retailing and wholesaling, and a similar figure in charge of manufacturing businesses.

However, the most popular sector remains technologies and telecommunications, which attracts 27% of entrepreneurs, followed by business services, which pulled in 14%.

Mr Wilkinson said the findings showed that there was no age limit on entrepreneurial drive, but added that Britain desperately needed women role models to encourage others to follow.

Only 8% of the nation's business-builders are women, though the figure rises to 13% in London and 10% in the rest of the south of England. The lowest figure (4%) was recorded in the central UK region, with the north and Scotland showing 5% and 6% respectively.

The report found that the bulk of entrepreneurs (59%) are aged between 35 and 49, with only 12% below 35 and almost a third (31%) over 50. While the number of women entrepreneurs is small, it looks set to grow as they are, on average, years younger than their male counterparts.

The report claims its subjects create, on average, 91 jobs a year, but offers no figures for how many they later sack.

The report found that the bulk of entrepreneurs (59%) are aged between 35 and 49, with only 12% below 35 and almost a third (31%) over 50. While the number of women entrepreneurs is small, it looks set to grow as they are, on average, years younger than their male counterparts. The report claims its subjects create, on average, 91 jobs a year, but offers no figures for how many they later sack.

webTitle: At this price?  IG Group

fields.headline: At this price?  IG Group
fields.trailText: Spread betting is weaving its way into the fabric of society, according to IG Group, which says punters include "retired civil servants, vicars, taxi drivers and old ladies".
fields.body:
Spread betting is weaving its way into the fabric of society, according to IG Group, which says punters include "retired civil servants, vicars, taxi drivers and old ladies".

IG is one of several fast growing companieswhose customers bet on share price movements, economic indices or other financial events. The advantage is that spreads are tax-free and offer greater gains, or losses, than ordinary fixed-odds betting.

IG yesterday announced a 79% leap in half-year profits to £7.08m, helped by surging demand for "contracts for differences" - the latest way of placing a highly geared bet on the market.

The shares took the opportunity for a breather, sinking 14p to 495p, having risen from 240p since flotation in July. The current price values the business at £260m - high, but not exceptional, for a company expected to make full-year profits of £14m.

IG's cautious chairman, Stuart Wheeler, helpfully provided a breakdown of risks facing the company with the results. The biggest concern lies with the Chancellor, who is reviewing tax on bookmakers. At present, fixed-odds betting carries a duty on each transaction while spread betting is almost entirely tax-free.

Mr Wheeler reckons the most likely outcome is a tax on the profits from both types of flutter. That will put off some punters and could slow IG's growth. The firm is also facing more competition - the ballooning profits to be made from spread betting have not escaped the attention of City entrepreneurs.

IG's expansion has been rapid - it now has 140 staff, up from 115 at flotation, and has rented an extra floor of office space. Profits from sports betting are rising more slowly, up 23% to £1.06m. This area is gradually benefiting as more sports become available on digital television.

IG is likely to continue attracting tax-averse punters in search of a quick buck. Given the uncertainties ahead, and the shares' rapid recent rise, the price looks high enough. Investors should consider taking profits.

webTitle: Chat has impact on BSkyB

fields.headline: Chat has impact on BSkyB
fields.trailText: A rumour that a large share placing is on the way can have a dramatic effect on the company concerned.
fields.body:
A rumour that a large share placing is on the way can have a dramatic effect on the company concerned.

Institutions resist the temptation to increase their holdings, knowing that they can buy cheaper if the placing does occur, while hedge funds tend to go "short" of the company in question - selling borrowed shares in the hope of buying them back at a lower level.

Such chatter has been hampering the progress of a number of blue chips in the past few trading sessions.

First, there was HSBC , off 16p to 987p, unsettled by talk that 7% shareholder, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, is looking to dump a large chunk of its stake. Then there was gossip that Banco Santander had hired CSFB to manage a placing of its 9.6% stake in Royal Bank of Scotland , up 4p to £16.10.

Now the tittle-tattle is concentrating in BSkyB, the satellite broadcaster. The very plausible tale doing the rounds yesterday was that media group Vivendi Universal is about to offload its 22.73% stake in the satellite broadcaster.

That Vivendi is a seller is not in question - it agreed to offload the holding back in October as a means of gaining approval for its merger with Seagram of Canada - but market sources maintain that a placing at a discount to the prevailing share price is just one option. Another would be an asset swap, a move that would limit the damage to BSkyB's shares, which ended down 35p at £11.60.

Elsewhere in the media world, Granada Media moved higher after Merrill Lynch analyst Neil Blackley upgraded his rating on the company to "accumulate".

Mr Blackley, readers may remember, was the analyst who triggered a run on Granada Media shares (then 573p) back in September when he slashed his profits estimate for the broadcaster, citing the "softness" of ITV advertising. Things have changed and, with the shares now at 425p, he thinks they represent good value.

With Wall Street closed for the Martin Luther King holiday, London dealers experienced one of the dullest trading sessions in recent memory. There was almost a total absence of fresh stories for the punters to chase. In fact, the only things moving prices were weekend press tips or recommendations from City analysts.

Market turnover was 1.5bn, well down on the 2.5bn seen several times last week, as institutional investors stayed on the sidelines. "Without Nasdaq to provide a lead, institutions do not feel comfortable dealing. It is as simple as that," said one senior trader.

Nonetheless, the FTSE 100 did manage to eke out a 4.8 point gain, closing at 6,170.3, as strong performances from oil heavyweights Shell , 17.5p stronger at 566.5p, and BP , 15p higher at 570.5p, ahead of Wednesday's Opec meeting, offset weakness in the telecom issues.

Rattled by reports that it is poised to cut its dividend, BT fell by 20.5p to 690p while Cable & Wireless lost 27p to 945p.

Other notable fallers included Boots , down 23p to 549p, on fears that today's trading update will disappoint.

Meanwhile, the FTSE Techmark 100 ended 13.02 points higher at 2,596.16, helped by the likes of Kingston Communications , 18p better at 269.75p, and Atlantic Telecom , up 9p to 108p as fears about future funding receded after peer KPNQwest completed a junk bond issue.

Vehicle-tracking specialist Trafficmaster fell back 31.75p to 380p, after ABN Amro placed its earnings forecasts under review following a meeting with the company. According to dealers the Dutch banking group is not convinced the company will make its sales targets.

Lower down the ladder, chatter that MMT Computing has received another bid, possibly around the £8.50 level, pushed its shares up 5p to 515p, while the clothing retailer Arcadia added 8p to 108p, on hopes of bumper sales news from the Christmas season.

webTitle: Former brothel madams took horsey set for £3m ride

fields.headline: Former brothel madams took horsey set for £3m ride
fields.trailText: Two former brothel madams were told yesterday they could face jail after creating an illusion of wealth to con members of equestrian high society.
fields.body:
Two former brothel madams were told yesterday they could face jail after creating an illusion of wealth to con members of equestrian high society.

Australians Evelyn Burton and Lyla Andre were the toast of horse racing events as they sipped champagne and ordered around a small posse of servants.

Posing as successful businesswomen, they regularly arrived in a gold Rolls-Royce or stretched limousine. The pair were even presented to the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh at the Royal Windsor Horse Show after their £176,000 sponsorship pledge secured them seats in the royal box.

But the promised cheque bounced as they sought to defraud wealthy members of the "horsey set", Wood Green crown court in north London was told. An investigation by the serious fraud office found victims were persuaded to invest in Westgate Development Corporation, a US registered firm, hoping for spectacular returns.

But victims ended up losing more than £550,000, with numerous other creditors saddled with unpaid bills in a conspiracy whose value is estimated to be £3m.

The list of victims included Michael Bullen, a former equerry to the Queen, who was left $100,000 out of pocket.

Swedish businessmen Mats Anderson and Goran Agneuk lost £185,000, while Frank Wright and Ed Vogel from the US lost £184,000, Belfast businessmen Henry Curry and James Morrison lost £93,000, as did Kevin Childerhouse from Norfolk.

Burton, 56, pleaded guilty to one charge of conspiracy to de fraud, between October 1996 and March 1998, in which she was accused of teaming up with US lawyer Daniel Wright.

Andre, 50, pleaded guilty to one charge of retaining a wrongful credit and two of evading a liability by deception. These offences concerned deceiving the Rt Hon Mary Ann Wragg, a former president of the Arab Horse Society, and Margaret Morgan.

Burton and Andre, both living at a bail hostel in north London, were warned they may face jail for the offences before the case was adjourned until February 9 for reports.

webTitle: New bids mire Bryant merger

fields.headline: New bids mire Bryant merger
fields.standfirst: Building market faces four way tussle
fields.trailText: Building market faces four way tussle.
fields.body:
Housebuilder Bryant Group watched its merger plans with Beazer yesterday become a four way takeover tussle as Persimmon and Taylor Woodrow joined in.

The proposed marriage, announced last month, would have created Domus, a new £870m group which would have been one of Britain's biggest housebuilders.

But the plans were mired in confusion after construction group Taylor Woodrow tabled a formal £523m bid for Bryant just minutes before shareholders were due to vote on the deal.

Last night Bryant rejected Taylor Woodrow's latest offer but hinted it would be open to an improved bid.

In a rejection statement, the company said: "Bryant continues to believe that Domus will provide far superior opportunities for value creation than a combination with Taylor Woodrow."

But, noting the approach had not been final, he added: "The board will continue to take all necessary measures to maximise shareholder value. Bryant's egm has been postponed until January 26 to allow the board time for further discussions.

One analyst said: "Taylor Woodrow has put everything they have got on the table and if they pay more than this their own shareholders will reject the offer."

Bryant had, on Friday, rejected Taylor Woodrow's £512m previous hostile bid.

Yesterday also saw Persimmon, the housebuilder, confirm weekend reports that it was considering a bid for Beazer which is believed to be in the region of £500m.

The company intends to submit an offer proposal to Beazer's board, if the Domus deal collapses, by no later than January 19, although it admits its plans are "not certain".

In a statement it said: "Such an offer proposal would be at a greater level than the current value of the Bryant proposal and would include a cash element of at least 50%."

Industry observers said both approaches may have arrived too late in the day with many institutional investors having already decided to back the merger.

It is understood that 77% of Beazer shareholders have voted in favour of the Domus deal. Analysts also questioned the timing of Taylor Woodrow's approach and suggested they would risk a shareholder revolt if the offer was eventually increased.

"I don't think they have covered themselves in glory," said one. "Why didn't they make an approach when Bryant shares were at 95p? It seems a very poor strategic judgment."

The intensifying battles of consolidation had a significant impact on the share prices of all four companies involved.

As the London markets closed last night, Beazer had jumped up 6p to close at a new year high of 174p, while Bryant put on 3.5p to end the day at 185.5p.

Persimmon failed to impress its shareholders and watched its stock price sink 8p as a result to 269p, while Taylor Woodrow also slipped, dropping 1.5p to 170p.

webTitle: Precious metal Sanctuary scores multimedia success

fields.headline: Precious metal Sanctuary scores multimedia success
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Sanctuary Group yesterday reported bumper on- and off-line business for its expanding entertainment industry interests.
fields.body:
Sanctuary Group yesterday reported bumper on- and off-line business for its expanding entertainment industry interests.

The company which last year acquired British record company Castle Music, and America's CMG International Records, said turnover increased 91% to £44.1m, up from £23.1m in 1999.

Pre-tax profit for the period to the end of September 2000 rose by 63% to £4.1m, up from £2.5m.

Andy Taylor, chief executive of Sanctuary, said: "I have been very pleased with the organic growth of our existing business and the integration of the two major acquisitions of Castle Music and CMG International Records. They have created a very strong record company that has a lot of potential for continued growth in the future."

The company's catalogue includes music by established rock acts such as Black Sabbath, The Kinks and Iron Maiden. Others as diverse as Megadeth and country star Dolly Parton (right), have signed up with Sanctuary.

Mr Taylor added that the group had developed the artist management side of its business, adding to its roster Elaine Paige, Dennis Waterman and Ray Davies from The Kinks.

The new media division also reported significant progress. "In new media, the launch of [heavy metal website] Metal-is.com in May 2000 was highly successful with the site enjoying a monthly number of unique users of 170,000 by December 2000."

In TV production, the company has just completed its third series of The Tribe (above), a programme shot in New Zealand and set in a post-apocalyptic world where there are only young people. The series is being shown on Channel 5. Atlantis High, a spoof high school soap, was also commissioned by Channel 5 for 52 half-hour episodes.

One analyst said: "The results look pretty good, in line with what the market was expecting."

The shares rose 1.5p to 74.5p and the dividend was increased to 0.25p.
