webTitle: Europe faces battle of the bulge bracket

fields.headline: Europe faces battle of the bulge bracket
fields.standfirst: US banks prepare fresh assault on growth market
fields.trailText: US banks prepare fresh assault on growth market.
fields.body:
Continental Europe is fast becoming the world's top growth market for investment banking and Wall Street's "bulge bracket" houses are gearing up for a fresh assault.

The introduction of the euro, the prospect of deregulation-led consolidation within leading sectors and a growing acceptance of a more Anglo-Saxon approach to capitalism are among factors attracting attention.

"There is a real sense that shareholder value has become more than just a mantra for [European] managers. There is a realisation that Deutschland AG, for example, will either sink or swim on how it performs globally," said one US banking source. Certainly Germany - where finance minister Hans Eichel's tax reforms have opened the way for the dismantling of cross-shareholdings which have handicapped merger and acquisition activity for years - is top of the list for US houses.

As the Vodafone bid for Mannesmann showed, Rhineland capitalism has embraced, albeit grudgingly in some areas, the concept of hostile cross-border takeovers. Frankfurt's skyline, which boasts a growing phalanx of skyscrapers, bears eloquent testimony to what is happening to Germany's finanzplatz.

Among the US houses Goldman Sachs, for example, aims to have 800 staff in Germany within two years. That is still relatively modest compared with the London operation but is double the present level. The bank is looking to the German operation, too, to help keep its London dealing room busy.

Italy, Spain and France have their at tractions, too, as financial markets expand, retail investors turn to equities and deregulation forces corporate restructuring.

For some, Spain lacks the depth in terms of corporate infrastructure of Germany but changes in the energy sector, for example, offer the prospect of asset swap deals both inside and outside the Iberian peninsula.

France ,with its network of relationships and a still substantial state presence in the corporate sector, is perhaps more of a challenge to outsiders. But a new generation of managers led by the likes of Jean-Marie Messier have ambitions which are providing plenty of scope for investment banking's corporate deal makers.

European banks are aware of the challenge. "Europe is the growth market for global investment banking. The market is growing faster than in the US and will continue to do so for the foreseeable future," according to one European banker.

"US houses are all very keen to get in there [continental Europe] in a big way."

According to some observers, Europe's attractions are enhanced by what is happening elsewhere. The US market is seen as both mature and fiercely competitive.

"The US is always going to be very important to the investment banks but it is very efficient and competitive. It is hard to see anyone being able to increase their market shares startlingly," said one observer. But the prospect of a slowing global economy is likely to make investment bankers keen on any area which shows signs of bucking the trend.

Although the incumbent Europeans are braced for a struggle, they believe they have an edge, even if that differs from bank to bank.

While Germany's biggest bank, Deutsche, has gone head to head with the Americans, its smaller rival Commerzbank is looking to prosper on the basis of its existing customer base among the mittelstand (mid-sized) companies which are the backbone of the German economy. "We have 5,000 mittelstand customers. The Americans don't have anything like that," said a spokesman.

Others will rely on a hefty presence in all the important European capitals from Lisbon to Moscow to help see off what has traditionally tended to be a London-based challenge. "In the past the American in vestment banks have had a big presence in London and then smaller teams in one or two of the other financial centres like Frankfurt and Paris, trying to cover the whole of continental Europe including emerging markets," said one.

According to Antoine Morgaut, Paris-based manager for head hunters Robert Walters, the skills in demand in France are in public offerings, asset management, and mergers and acquisitions. As business that moved to more liquid markets in London in the first half of the 1990s moves back to France, Mr Morgaut argues that the investment banks which stayed, European as well as American, are investing again. "There is a cycle. Every 10 years everything changes from top to bottom. Right now we are at the top."

Those tempted to believe the Americans will find it hard to take on the Europeans should remember there were plenty of people ready to shrug off the threat of American inroads into London. Yet look what happened. Rest assured, le défi américain will be formidable.

According to Antoine Morgaut, Paris-based manager for head hunters Robert Walters, the skills in demand in France are in public offerings, asset management, and mergers and acquisitions. As business that moved to more liquid markets in London in the first half of the 1990s moves back to France, Mr Morgaut argues that the investment banks which stayed, European as well as American, are investing again. "There is a cycle. Every 10 years everything changes from top to bottom. Right now we are at the top." Those tempted to believe the Americans will find it hard to take on the Europeans should remember there were plenty of people ready to shrug off the threat of American inroads into London. Yet look what happened. Rest assured, le défi américain will be formidable.

webTitle: US suitors circle Community Hospitals

fields.headline: US suitors circle Community Hospitals
fields.trailText: Several leading US healthcare groups are circling Community Hospitals, which admitted yesterday that it was back in takeover talks after the collapse of its £230m sale to Bupa last month.
fields.body:
Several leading US healthcare groups are circling Community Hospitals, which admitted yesterday that it was back in takeover talks after the collapse of its £230m sale to Bupa last month.

Advisers to Community disclosed that the firm had received at least five approaches. Industry sources believe the front-runners include US firms HCA Columbia and United Surgical partners.

General Healthcare, Britain's biggest private hospital chain, is also said to be interested, and US firm Tenet has been mentioned as an outsider.

Community Hospitals has 21 hospitals, containing about 840 beds. It is Britain's fourth largest private hospital chain, offering cosmetic surgery such as breast enhancements as well as acute medicine.

Trade secretary Stephen Byers blocked a 650p-a-share takeover by Bupa, on the grounds that the insurance firm could end up with a dominant position in private medicine.

Bupa's adviser, Schroder Salomon, was ordered to sell its 27% stake in Community and is thought to be pressing for a takeover of the entire business.

Healthcare analyst Paul Saper of LCS International said a takeover could value Community at up to £250m, or 700p a share: "The general feeling is that they've done rather well over the last six months."

The industry has benefited from a government decision to put more NHS patients in private hospitals.

Shares in Bedford-based Community Hospitals' jumped 20p to 562p.

fields.trailText: Title of the day
fields.body:
Title of the day

If they do ennoble former prime minister John Major after the general election perhaps he should take heed of the views of his former neighbours in Brixton, south London. Sixty per cent of those surveyed by newspaper New Nation, said they would be happy if he became Lord Major of Brixton. However 10% polled said they'd never heard of him.

Beer of the day

Strangers Bar, the MPs' watering hole in the House of Commons, has installed a new guest beer, Titanic. Whatever could they mean?

Today

Commons: Environment, transport and the regions questions. Children's commissioner for Wales bill, second reading. Westminster Hall: Backbench debates include rural policing, health of air passengers, teacher shortages in Essex, andflooding in Shrewsbury. Lords: Social security fraud bill, second reading.

webTitle: ITV abandons peaktime target

fields.headline: ITV abandons peaktime target
fields.trailText: ITV has abandoned its annual promise to advertisers of hitting a set peaktime audience share after failing to reach its target for 2000.
fields.body:
ITV has abandoned its annual promise to advertisers of hitting a set peaktime audience share after failing to reach its target for 2000.

The network, under increasing pressure from the growth of new channels, managed a peaktime share of 37.1% last year, against a target of 38.5%.

ITV executives yesterday outlined broader targets for 2001 including investment in the daytime schedule to narrow the 4% gap on BBC1 and arresting the slide in ABC1 and 16- to 34-year-old viewers.

A spokeswoman for ITV said the new goals responded to the demands of advertisers. "It is more important to the market that we hold down BBC1 than focus on a single peaktime target," she said.

Five main measures include maintaining the peaktime lead over BBC1 of 7.4% and attracting the biggest audiences in digital TV homes, where ITV has a 20.7% share and BBC1 19.2%. Advertisers took the last as suggesting ITV will soon agree terms to appear on the Sky Digital platform.

The final target is to deliver similar levels of "big audience" programming - shows which deliver audiences of more than 5m - as last year. There were 1,700 such shows in 2000.

Daytime commitments include a £20m investment in the relaunch of motel soap Crossroads at lunchtime, teatime soap Trafalgar Road and reality show Public Property. The network is also emphasising "event TV" with Popstars, Survivor - the number one US show - and the return of Premiership football.

Bob Wootton, of the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, said: "Prescriptive targets are a nice idea but frankly not too practical. ITV has taken a very pragmatic view."

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: The parliamentary ombudsman is to be asked to investigate the government's role in the Equitable Life crisis as calls for compensation to affected policyholders grow louder, writes Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
Equitable clamour grows

The parliamentary ombudsman is to be asked to investigate the government's role in the Equitable Life crisis as calls for compensation to affected policyholders grow louder, writes Rupert Jones.

It emerged last month that as early as November 1998, the treasury had serious concerns about Equitable's solvency. On December 8 the 239-year-old insurer closed its doors to new business and imposed new conditions on existing policyholders after losing a legal battle over pension promises and then failing to find a buyer.

Conservative and Liberal Democrat MPs are stepping up their attempts to get a wider inquiry established.Vincent Cable, the Liberal Democrat trade and industry spokesman, said yesterday he would be asking the parliamentary ombudsman to look into the role of the various regulators including the treasury and the department of trade and industry.

AstraZeneca £43m boost

Anglo-Swedish pharmaceuticals group AstraZeneca is investing £43m in its Macclesfield plant in northern England, where it makes the schizophrenia drug Seroquel.

The new facilities, expected to be operational in 2002, will help meet growing demand for the company's flagship central nervous system product.

Seroquel, which belongs to a class of drugs known as atypical antipsychotics, registered sales of $293m (£198m) in the first nine months of last year, 83% up on the same period in 1999.

The product, launched in 1997, is also under development for the treatment of psychoses in Alzheimer's disease and for mania.

Schneider and Legrand merge

French electrical equipment makers Schneider Electric and Legrand announced a €6.72bn (£4.2bn) merger yesterday to create a world leader in low-voltage electrical components.

Schneider, one of the world's largest electrical engineering companies, will pay seven of its shares for every two shares of Legrand, offering a 19.8% premium over Legrand's Friday closing price of €222.

The companies said the combined group would have a pro forma net profit of €840m euros for 2000 on sales of €12.4bn. The deal is expected to generate revenue and cost savings of €210m from 2003.

BAA profits from rail chaos

Air operator BAA said the chaos in the nation's railway network contributed to a huge rise in the number of domestic passengers last month.

Passenger numbers across BAA's seven UK airports rose to 8.8m in December, an increase of 11.2% compared to the same period last year.

The number of people using domestic air routes, excluding the Channel Islands, increased by 14.3%, with around 150,000 more passenger trips than usual recorded during the month.

Stansted remained the fastest growing airport in the UK with a passenger increase of 31.1% during the month, to 866,300.

London Heathrow and Gatwick recorded an increase of 7.5% and 12.8% respectively. The most buoyant sector was European scheduled traffic, up 8.8%, which accounted for 44.7m passengers.

webTitle: AT&T defies order to sell stake

fields.headline: AT&T defies order to sell stake
fields.trailText: AT&T said yesterday it has no intention of responding to a US federal communications commission order to sell its stake in Time Warner Entertainment, according to reports on website CNNfn.com. Instead, the group said, it would pursue its plan to spin off its Liberty Media television programming unit.
fields.body:
AT&T said yesterday it has no intention of responding to a US federal communications commission order to sell its stake in Time Warner Entertainment, according to reports on website CNNfn.com. Instead, the group said, it would pursue its plan to spin off its Liberty Media television programming unit.

The cable and long-distance phone company had been given until yesterday to explain why the FCC should not require the share sale to meet regulatory conditions placed on the company's purchase of MediaOne last year.

The FCC gave AT&T until May 19, 2001 to divest its 25% stake in TWE - a limited partnership that houses most of AOL Time Warner's movie, cable and television production assets -abandon its stake in Liberty Media or shed11.8m existing cable customers.

However, AT&T officials maintain that the plan they filed with the commission to pursue a tax-free spin-off of Liberty Media meets requirements, and pledged to comply with the commission's order by the May 19 deadline.

AT&T said it would pursue the Liberty Media spin-off, if the internal revenue service declared it tax-free. If not, the company said it would pursue the Time Warner Entertainment divestiture.

The issue is complicated by the recent presidential election. Committee chairman William Kennard will officially resign at the end of this week.

webTitle: Tesco piles on price-cutting pressure

fields.headline: Tesco piles on price-cutting pressure
fields.trailText: Tesco yesterday underlined its position as Britain's top supermarket by reporting a 6.9% annual increase in like-for-like sales over Christmas and the new year.
fields.body:
Tesco yesterday underlined its position as Britain's top supermarket by reporting a 6.9% annual increase in like-for-like sales over Christmas and the new year.

It aims to stay ahead of rivals by delivering cuts in food prices on top of the £500m reduction in the past two years.

Results for the seven weeks to January 6 were driven by increasing non-food sales, rapidly developing international stores and expansion into retail services. Total UK sales were up 10.5% although this included an extra day's trading because of the way holidays fell.

The strong figures, which compared to 0.7% growth announced by Sainsbury on Friday, led to a 2.5p rise in Tesco's share price to 260.5p amid analysts' talk of profit estimates being upgraded.

Tesco said its growth was partly driven by lower prices. Overall deflation in its British stores was minus 0.4%.

A powerful international performance was built on the back of 32 store openings overseas as far from headquarters in Cheshunt, Hertfordshire, as Thailand and Taiwan. Tesco has added 3m sq ft of trading space, a 45% increase on the previous 12 months. International sales over Christmas and the new year rose 50%.

The strategy of increasing its offerings of non-food goods also paid off with record sales in all areas, including the delivery of 14,000 DVD players and 8,000 widescreen televisions.

Expansion of Tesco.com to cover 90% of the population also enhanced performance with sales across the net rising 400% on last year. The company has taken on 400 staff, allocated 10,000 additional delivery slots and delivered 30m products.

Michael Dennis, food retail analyst at SG Securities, said the results were better than expected. "It suggests the whole of the fourth quarter could be stronger than anticipated."

He has assumed Tesco full year profits for 2000-01 will come in at around £1.06bn and there were reports last night that the consensus was rising from £1.05bn to £1.06bn.

House brokers Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley are understood to be planning to upgrade their estimates to around £1.06bn.

 A good holiday performance was also reported by JJB Sports, Britain's largest independent sports retailer, which said like-for-like turnover for the 49 weeks to January 7 was up 8.4%.

This provided relief for the City, which feared heavy pressure on sales, and resulted in JJB Sports shares rising 18.5p to 555p.

webTitle: GKN talks to Australians about link up

fields.headline: GKN talks to Australians about link up
fields.trailText: GKN yesterday disclosed that it was in talks with Australia's Brambles Industries about merging their industrial services arms and floating the resulting multi-billion pound company.
fields.body:
GKN yesterday disclosed that it was in talks with Australia's Brambles Industries about merging their industrial services arms and floating the resulting multi-billion pound company.

The British engineering group saw its shares rise 41p to 802p after explaining it was looking at a "nil premium" merger of the two businesses. It said its industrial division was successful but sat uneasily with its automotive and aerospace activities.

GKN and Brambles have already been involved in two major international joint ventures, the CHEP pallet pooling business and the Cleanaway waste disposal industry.

Both these and other separately operated activities are expected to be placed inside a new company which would probably use the Brambles name and be listed in both London and Sydney.

With rumours leaking out about the talks, GKN issued a statement in London insisting agreement on the proposals could not be guaranteed.

It said: "The discussions are at a relatively early stage and legal, structural financial gov ernance and regulatory issues in Australia and the UK will need be resolved before any agreement can be concluded."

Brambles has seen its stock market value fall sharply after saying its 2001 earnings growth was likely to be flat. It is operating without a financial director and has a chief executive in John Fletcher who is expected to stand down in March after eight years in the job.

Sources close to the talks suggested GKN might supply the top management for the new business which could be built around the existing Brambles group.

GKN has been under pressure from shareholders to provide more transparency and value from an industrial services division which accounted for 27% of its first half operating profit of £286m.

The joint venture pallet rental business of GKN and Brambles, which rents out crates to supermarkets in Europe and North America, has grown faster than other division at both companies.

GKN also has been restructuring its under-performing aerospace group with 600 jobs being cut in Britain and the US.

webTitle: Obituary: Neil Hawke

fields.headline: Neil Hawke
fields.trailText: Although a sturdy fast medium bowler for Australia in the mid-1960s - during which period he took 91 wickets - and an Aussie Rules footballer of some note, it was the destiny of Neil Hawke, who has died aged 61, to be remembered for his batting.
fields.body:
Although a sturdy fast medium bowler for Australia in the mid-1960s - during which period he took 91 wickets - and an Aussie Rules footballer of some note, it was the destiny of Neil Hawke, who has died aged 61, to be remembered for his batting. Shortly after lunch on the third day of the final Test at the Oval in 1964, he edged an outswinger from Fred Trueman to Colin Cowdrey at slip, making the Yorkshireman the first to reach 300 Test wickets.

Hawke was a workhorse bowler, a spear carrier to Graham McKenzie's bounding emperor, who hustled his way to the crease with a run that took some starting, but then delivered a "heavy" ball from a muscular open-chested action that lent him inswing and, as a variation, more often than not involuntary, a leg cutter that snapped away from the batsman.

His wickets, from 27 Tests between his debut against England at Sydney in February 1963 and his final match at Lords in June 1968, came at a cost of 29.41, and he took 458 first-class wickets over a 10-year period. His robust lower order batting gave him a serviceable first-class average of 23.

Hawke was born in Cheltenham, South Australia, and educated at Woodville school. He excelled at Aussie Rules and played for the Port Adelaide and the West Torrens sides. In 1963, he was in the South Australia side at the Melbourne cricket ground that defeated Victoria for the first time. It was during a 1966 Rules match that he broke his collar bone, which almost certainly curtailed his time at the top as a cricketer.

Hawke signed as a professional cricketer for Western Australia in 1959, moving the following summer to South Australia, for whom he played for eight years before one final season with Tasmania, prior to a sojourn in England.

Early in 1963, he took six wickets for South Australia against MCC at Adelaide, a match in which Cowdrey made a triple century, and was chosen against England for the fifth and final Test of the series, taking two for 51 and nought for 38 in a drawn match.

He was to wait another year for his second cap, when he was drafted into the second Test of the series against South Africa at the MCG after Ian Meckiff had been no-balled for throwing in the first at Brisbane. In the fourth Test, he bowled 39 eight-ball overs, taking six for 139 as South Africa made 595. In the final Test, batting at number 11, he made an undefeated 16 in 75 minutes, to deprive South Africa of the time to chase a modest target and win the series.

Only five of Hawke's subsequent 22 Tests were at home; he toured England twice, in 1964 and 1968, as well as India and Pakistan, West Indies and South Africa. He took five wickets against England at Headingley in the first Test of the 1964 series and, at the end, in Trueman's match, managed six for 47, a personal performance bettered only by the seven for 105 he recorded against MJK Smith's side in Sydney in January 1966, a match which England won by an innings.

Hawke's bowling peak had occurred in Georgetown nine months previously, when he had match figures of 10 for 115 in a 212-run defeat for Australia. He ended that series in the Caribbean as the highest wicket-taker on either side, with 24 at 21.83.

In the years before county cricket accepted overseas players without prequalifying, his all-round ability made him a natural for cricket in the Lancashire leagues in England.

He enjoyed several successful seasons with Nelson, after which he still remained in the county until his return to Australia in 1980. By this time though, he was already an ailing man. Following bowel surgery, he contracted an infection, and subsequently fought courageously against kidney failure, liver damage, hepatitis and a dozen heart attacks, enduring more than 30 operations in the process.

He is survived by his wife Beverley.

In the years before county cricket accepted overseas players without prequalifying, his all-round ability made him a natural for cricket in the Lancashire leagues in England. He enjoyed several successful seasons with Nelson, after which he still remained in the county until his return to Australia in 1980. By this time though, he was already an ailing man. Following bowel surgery, he contracted an infection, and subsequently fought courageously against kidney failure, liver damage, hepatitis and a dozen heart attacks, enduring more than 30 operations in the process. He is survived by his wife Beverley. Neil Hawke, cricketer, born June 27 1939; died December 25 2000

webTitle: Appreciation: Michael Williams

fields.headline: Michael Williams
fields.trailText: Michael Williams (Obituary, January 13) spoke his first words as Dr Watson at 10.15am on October 9 1989, in a one-off Radio 4 adaptation of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's A Study In Scarlet.
fields.body:
Michael Williams (Obituary, January 13) spoke his first words as Dr Watson at 10.15am on October 9 1989, in a one-off Radio 4 adaptation of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's A Study In Scarlet. I was Sherlock Holmes, and at 6.45pm on May 26 1998 we completed the last scene of The Hound Of The Baskervilles, having recorded the entire canon of 56 short stories and four novels. We were the first pairing of doctor and sleuth to achieve this, and it was a matter of pride to us both. We are a staple question in pub quizzes, and Michael liked that. We both liked pubs.

I had been a fan of Michael Williams since the late 1960s, when I would come up from Sidcup and sit in the Aldwych Theatre gods when the Royal Shakespeare Company's London seasons were in their pomp. The RSC staged contemporary drama - Pinter, Mercer et al - that people queued for. Michael was the best Fool in King Lear ever; I was a fan.

By the time we had polished off the Holmes/Watson job, I could have run a club for him. Michael kicked the blimpish old buffer that Nigel Bruce had made of Watson into the archives. Here was an ex-army officer, "an eternal man of action" with "an experience of women which extends over many nations and three separate continents" - Michael was always quoting that one - intelligent, trustworthy, honest and with no mean deductive powers.He weans Holmes off cocaine, keeps him sane and they have a shared love of "all that is outside the humdrum routine of everyday life". Watson might regard Holmes as "the most perfect reasoning machine the world has ever seen". But you would not catch Michael doing "You amaze me Holmes!" acting.

We both enjoyed the derring-do, the chase, the "murder, 'orrible murder!" in the stories, but we preferred to be back in those strange little lodgings, in an England of empire and aspidistra. Give us the sounds of crackling fire, the ticking of the grandfather clock and the clip-clop of hansom cabs on Baker Street outside, and in that place, just the two of us, with gentle tweaking from our directors, Enyd Williams and Patrick Rayner, and usually in a script by our main adapter Bert Coules, we would like to think that we could cook up a bit of jazz.

Radio can be the most testing of mediums. Michael passed every time - he could not hit a false emotional note for toffee. He would dip into what he called his "little green baize acting bag" and pull out blazing rabbits of emotional intensity. Listen to The Final Problem, Michael's favourite story. "It encapsulates everything that I think of the Watsonian character as being," he said, "his intelligence, his perceptiveness, his emotional commitment to Holmes and his deep, deep hurt at the end."

I visited Michael a few times in the last weeks of his bloody awful illness. His wife, Judi Dench, made wonderful lunches, which he watched me eat. We drank far too much champagne. Sharing a passion for gardening, we would usually wind up with a hike around his land.

The last time I was there he pointed out a dead or dying apple tree close to the house. His grandson Sam was playing beneath it. It was a splendid old specimen, nobbled by a virus and something nastily "scabby". Wasted away, the remains of something once beautiful and bountiful. "I suppose I should chop it down," he said, "but it's Jude's washing line."

We finally came up with something less drastic; underplant it with clematis Montana and Armandii, rambling roses, a winter flowering jasmine, a goer of an ivy - Paddy's Pride, perhaps. The line would be saved, the dead tree could become the framework for something beautiful again.

At the close of His Last Bow, the two old friends have a last quiet talk. Bert Coules's script reads:

Holmes: "Good old Watson. You're the one fixed point in a changing age."

Watson: (a warm vocal grin)

Holmes: "There is an east wind coming all the same."

Watson: "Yes."

Holmes: "It'll be cold and bitter, and a good many of us may . . . wither before its blast."

Watson: "Holmes."

Holmes: "But a better land will be in the sunshine when the storm's cleared . . . Come on, my friend. Time we were on our way."

webTitle: Obituary: Milt Hinton

fields.headline: Milt Hinton
fields.standfirst: Jazzman who fought segregation and chronicled musicians' lives
fields.trailText: Jazzman who fought segregation and chronicled musicians' lives.
fields.body:
Milt Hinton, who has died aged 90, was one of the longest-serving double bass players in jazz, and a figure of unusual complexity. As a session musician, he was an important standard bearer for racial equality. He was also a considerable photographer and, with his book Bass Line, the author of a unique jazz social history.

His father had been taken from Liberia to the United States with his family by missionaries. He left before Hinton's birth in Vicksburg, Mississippi, leaving the child to be raised by his mother and grandmother, herself born into slavery. At the age of eight, the youngster witnessed a lynching, an event that would remain an indelible memory. Soon afterwards, the family left for Chicago, part of African America's great migration northward.

Hinton took violin lessons but, before turning professional, spent a short period involved with Al Capone's booze racketeering. He took up the bass and worked with the city's top leaders, including Eddie South, Tiny Parharn and Erskine Tate.

In 1935, he joined the prestigious Cab Calloway Orchestra, where he remained for 26 years. Singing hits such as Minnie The Moocher, Calloway was a popular entertainer who hired the best musicians and worked at the celebrated Cotton Club. Leading his trombones was Keg Johnson, who got Hinton the job and encouraged his early interest in photography, teaching him darkroom procedures while they were on the road and introducing him to Leica cameras.

Throughout his Calloway days, Hinton carried a camera in his pocket. He documented the joys and rigours of the travelling life and, in the south, the indignities of segregation. These latter images, depicting eminent jazzmen standing beside "Colored Only" signs, retain an ability to shock, although to Hinton and his colleagues, they were snapshots, made for amusement rather than as political statement.

When Calloway disbanded in 1951, Hinton was out of work. He freelanced around New York with Count Basie, Louis Armstrong and others until a chance meeting with Jackie Gleason changed his life for ever. He knew Gleason, then a television personality, from his days as a nightclub comedian, and it was he who arranged immediately for the bassist to be hired for a record date. There, he was acknowledged by the regulars, all of them white.

For Hinton, this recognition went deeper than individual satisfaction, for de facto segregation still kept African Americans out of the studios and the best-paid musical work. He, together with trumpeter Joe Wilder, pioneered the breakthrough. In a musicians' community politicised by the civil rights struggle, he was admired for his diplomatic savvy and re spected for his racial politics and demeanour.

Hinton's jazz recordings alone run into the thousands but, by the end of the 1950s, he had become a ubiquitous figure in the commercial studios. To refuse work in such a competitive field was unwise, so he worked around the clock - keeping an instrument at each major studio.

Meanwhile, he became an integral part of rock 'n' roll, laying down the beat behind countless hit records. Some of his most notable commercial work involved other eminent jazzmen, and a quartet in which he played with pianist Hank Jones, drummer Osie Johnson and guitarist Barry Galbraith became known, unofficially, as the New York Rhythm Section. In constant demand, Hinton backed singers as diverse as Paul Anka and Jackie Wilson, and was nicknamed "Judge" because of the standard he set.

Harmonic experiments in the 1940s with Dizzy Gillespie made him a forerunner of modern jazz bass players and, later, during the generational consolidation inspired by the black politics of the 1960s, he was among the elder statesmen welcomed on to the bandstand by the most avant-garde of young musicians. In the early 1970s, he played in the New York Bass Choir, where his presence lent majesty to explorations uniting Ron Carter, Richard Davis, Sam Jones and others. Twenty years later, he was honoured by a special day at New York's Knitting Factory.

For years, Hinton's photography was an insider's secret. Shooting at recording sessions during playbacks and breaks, he provided valuable insight into the priorities of fellow artists. Yet while a poignant image of Billie Holiday at her last session became known, it was not until David Berger, at Temple University, Philadelphia, began cataloguing Hinton's vast collection that the value of his enterprise was revealed. Following the publication of the two books, Bass Line (1988) and Over Time (1991), photographic requests poured in.

Hinton was revitalised by this unexpected interest. He was nearing 80 in 1988, when I visited him to talk about his photography but, while he was helpful, it was hard to guide the conversation away from musical reminscence. It was his wife, Mona, who sensed what was required.

They had married in the Calloway days, and she played an important role in organising his hectic life. During Art Kane's 1958 Esquire session that produced a famous photograph of 57 musicians on a Harlem doorstep, it was Mona who shot movie footage, and this, with Hinton's own stills, contributed to A Great Day In Harlem (1994), the award-winning movie about that day.

She survives him, together with a daughter and grand-daughter.

Milton John Hinton, musician and photographer, born June 23 1910; died December 19 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Oliver King

fields.headline: Oliver King
fields.standfirst: A distinguished scientist, he pioneered ideas in animal welfare
fields.trailText: A distinguished scientist, he pioneered ideas in animal welfare.
fields.byline: Chris Gaskell and Gordon McGregor Reid
fields.body:
In its formative years just after the second world war, Chester Zoo became one of the great loves of Oliver "Joe" King, who has died aged 85. A distinguished scientist and veterinarian, he was professor of animal husbandry at the University of Liverpool from 1969 until 1982.

At the university, he published widely, his books included Veterinary Dietics (1961) and An Introduction To Animal Husbandry (1978). At the zoo, he helped to define its functions and strategic purposes, which included excellent animal welfare. He also played a significant role in the zoo's direct management in the latter days of its founding director George Mottershead.

King had joined Liverpool as a lecturer in animal husbandry in 1941, when the university acquired the site for its veterinary field station at Leahurst, the first at a British veterinary school. Much of the success of that concept of a field station, as well as that of the animal husbandry department itself, can be ascribed to his endeavours. His work as a staff member and warden of the Leahurst stu dent hostel, departmental head and dean was crucial.

Ever since acquiring his qualification as a veterinary surgeon in the late 1930s, King's career had shadowed the progress of Chester Zoo, and thus the North of England Zoological Society. His work at Chester was valued enormously. He became a zoo member, then a council member and, from 1972 to 1986, council chairman, guiding it during the last years of Mottershead's life and taking over the society during the interregnum following his death.

King's management style was firm, but tempered with a willingness to forgive staff errors. One day, making an early morning zoo round, he saw what he thought was a dead camel. Appalled that the public would shortly be admitted, King harangued the staff. Chastened keepers immediately jumped into the paddock and attempted to lever up the prostrate camel with a stick, whereupon the beast lurched to its feet and moved off. King smiled faintly: "Well," he observed, "I suppose I cannot be right all of the time."

King was educated at Berkhamsted grammar school, and qualified at the Royal Veterinary College in 1937. After posts in veterinary practice, and at the college, he was appointed to Liverpool. Over the years, he was an officer of many of his profession's organisations, including, in 1980, president of the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons. He served on the Council of the British Veterinary Association for 15 years.

With his veterinary contemporary, Mary Branker, King was one of the founders of the Universities Federation for Animal Welfare (UFAW). Today, this organi sation links academia with the world of animals, including zoos. King was particularly pleased that Chester, which he regarded as "his zoo", won UFAW's principal award in 1999 for the twilight zone bat cave and its contribution to improving welfare standards for the threatened Rodrigues Island fruit bats.

An honorary vice-president of the North of England Zoological Society from 1987 to 1989, King maintained a passionate interest in zoo affairs to the end, and will be greatly missed. A committed Christian, he was a reader of the Church of England for 53 years.

Gracious, genuinely interested, many generations of students have reason to be grateful for his guidance and understanding. His fortitude during his illness was humbling, as was his care of his wife Helen during her long illness.

John Oliver Letts King, veterinarian, born December 21 1914; died December 11 2000

webTitle: Blair has agreed missiles project, claim Tories

fields.headline: Blair has agreed missiles project, claim Tories
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Ministers last night rejected Conservative claims that they have privately told US officials that Labour will agree to a request to upgrade the Fylingdales early warning system in North Yorkshire "providing they did not ask that question before the next election".
fields.body:
Ministers last night rejected Conservative claims that they have privately told US officials that Labour will agree to a request to upgrade the Fylingdales early warning system in North Yorkshire "providing they did not ask that question before the next election".

In angry exchanges in the Commons, the Tories' combative defence spokesman, Iain Duncan Smith, likened the tactic to "Dr Doolittle's push-me, pull-you - hoping that something will turn up before the election".

As the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, insisted that it was too soon to decide Britain's attitude towards the still-theoretical national missile defence project - dubbed "son of Star Wars" - the Conservative claim that Tony Blair has already said yes to Washington was vigorously denied.

Mr Blair wants to play it long, with a "yes, but" approach to any request from the new Bush administration. "If you want to influence Washington, especially Bush's Washington, you have to talk to them and advise them not to proceed without the agreement of Russia, China and Europe. Don't do anything unilateral," one minister explained.

Many Labour MPs are instinctively against the concept, an anti-missile shield which European governments fear will decouple US defence needs from the wider Nato alliance. But William Hague last week said a Tory cabinet would agree to update the radars near his Richmond constituency as a show of pro-American leadership.

Mr Hoon said it was "a lack of judgment for the leader of the Opposition to blunder about dealing with this issue before even the US itself has reached a conclusion".

He added: "It hardly seems sensible to commit ourselves to something that the Americans may or may not decide to commit themselves to."

It could prove an early awkward test of Anglo-US friendship because president-elect George W Bush has signalled a determination to press ahead.

Mr Duncan Smith had claimed that some ministers are hostile to the project despite MoD warnings that the threat from rogue states is growing. "Doesn't that explain why in the last year and a half, you and your colleagues have been going to Washington and letting them know, privately, you would be willing to upgrade Fylingdales, providing they did not ask that question before the next election," he asked.

It also emerged yesterday that British troops in the 1991 Gulf war were not warned of the dangers of exposure to depleted uranium in shells. The junior defence minister, John Spellar, confirmed: "DU was used for the first time in combat in the Gulf and I think the evidence is that to some units that information did not get down at the time. However, there is no evidence of a higher level of illness arising from such conditions."

Mr Hoon also said there was "no specific evidence" to link DU to particular illnesses. It did not stop Plaid Cymru MP, Dafydd Wigley, from accusing the government of a "cover up" in the light of parliamentary answers given to him in the past.

Labour's John McFall (Dumbarton) also argued that "given that the ministry was warned 10 years ago on this issue ... is it not the fact now the burden of proof should be on the ministry, rather than on individuals who are ill having to prove that their illness is a direct result of this DU?"

fields.body:
The government and the Arts Council were last night accused of trying to backslide on their vow to aid beleaguered regional theatres.

The row erupted as fears grew that the £37m rescue package secured by the culture secretary Chris Smith in the wake of the Boyden report, which warned of imminent meltdown if decades of underfunding was not reversed, would not provide the promised panacea.

When the windfall was announced in July, Mr Smith said the money should "try and resolve once and for all the endemic problems of regional producing theatres up and down the country".

But in a letter to Arts Council chairman, Gerry Robinson, obtained by The Guardian, the directors of 10 of the country's top theatres warned that the council was in danger of "squandering" the cash by spreading it too thinly throughout what the council called the "wider theatre ecology".

Sparks later flew when a delegation of directors met Mr Robinson after delivering the letter. There are likely to be further clashes tomorrow when the council briefs regional theatres on their initial plans for the cash.

In several strongly worded passages, the letter warned that by "diluting the government's new money for theatre across the entire sector it could leave unresolved the crisis that was the genesis of the whole exercise.

"This we believe to be misguided and in danger of squandering this unique and unrepeatable opportunity to secure much of the regional producing theatres for the foreseeable future," the letter added.

A report by management consultant Peter Boyden concluded that many of Britain's 50 surviving regional producing theatres are technically insolvent, others are hanging on by their fingernails while being asked to perform a "myriad of social and educational tasks" they are not being properly funded for.

He found many produced "safe" work to survive as they were unable to commission writing which might attract younger audiences.

Yesterday the Arts Council confirmed that "not everyone would be happy...and not every regional theatre would be a winner." when its plans for the extra funding - which does not start until next year - is published in March.

There was further disquiet at the revelations that the council intended to give much greater support to children's and ethnic minority theatre and to "back talent as much as buildings in the theatre of the 21st century".

This was seen as an indication that a sizeable slice of the money could go to touring theatre companies, the majority of which are based in London, rather than to regional producer theatres.

The letter from the regional directors points out that the reason so many theatres under perform is that they are "extremely financially fragile" and therefore cannot back talent properly.

But the letter claims that the regional arts boards, to whom Robinson plans to devolve much of the Arts Council's power and money, are already devising a plethora of "schemes or bidding initiatives" for the new money rather than giving it directly to the theatres.

A Department of Culture spokesman said the money was never intended solely for the 50 regional producing theatre identified by Boyden. "You have to look at the whole theatre ecology. This is a substantial amount of funding and it would be wrong to single one area out to the exclusion of others. The Arts Council agreed with that."

webTitle: Lab's plight 'may hurt UK research'

fields.headline: Lab's plight 'may hurt UK research'
fields.trailText: Pharmaceutical companies might move their research abroad if animal rights campaigners succeed in closing down a leading laboratory, the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Pharmaceutical companies might move their research abroad if animal rights campaigners succeed in closing down a leading laboratory, the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, said yesterday.

The Cambridgeshire research firm, Huntingdon Life Sciences, is concerned that it could lose its backing from the Royal Bank of Scotland because of a fierce campaign against its work.

The Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty campaign has targeted the firm and its employees for months and has now turned its attention to its suppliers and backers. The firm is negotiating with the bank on the extension of a £22m loan.

Lord Sainsbury said on BBC Radio 4's World at One: "If HLS was shut down that would mean it was more difficult for medical research to take place in this country. Certainly some jobs would go abroad, and some pharmaceutical companies would say, 'We're not going to put our research facilities in the UK'.

"If we are going to have our lives and our children's lives saved by drugs we're not so hypocritical that we'll say that research should not take place.

"We have strong laws about the safety of drugs, and that means that experiments do have to take place."

He added: "There's a principle that banks should abide by: they should make those decisions on commercial grounds unless they are genuinely of the view that the activities in question are ones they would not want to support."

The research firm accused the activists of "financial terrorism". The managing director, Brian Cass, said: "The government should be looking at the criminalisation of organisations like Shac, which have been formed... to cause the demise of legitimate companies like ours."

webTitle: Schools accused of failing to push anti-bullying policies

fields.headline: Schools accused of failing to push anti-bullying policies
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Schools still fail to deal with bullying despite being required to have policies to counter the problem, a survey has found.
fields.body:
Schools still fail to deal with bullying despite being required to have policies to counter the problem, a survey has found.

In September 1999 the government instructed schools to maintain an anti-bullying strategy. But a report by the charity Young Voice, published tomorrow, said that the strategies were often inadequate, unknown or not enforced. "There is a world of difference between having a stated policy and implementing it," said Adrienne Katz, one of the authors.

In the survey of 2,772 pupils, 45% of boys and 43% of girls said their school did not have a policy. Of those who said their school did, only 49% of girls and 54% of boys thought it was working. Thirteen per cent of boys and 12% of girls said that they had been severely bullied, and 47% of boys and 42% of girls less severely bullied; 35% of boys and 26% of girls admitted having bullied someone.

"While some schools are to be applauded for their innovative and vigorous efforts, too many are ignoring the problem," the report said. "Some have interventions, but they are not effective. Too many schools have impressive anti-bullying statements only in their prospectus."

Some headteachers told the authors that publicising the policy would make parents think the school had a worse problem than it had in reality.

Despite increased government concern, the findings were remarkably similar to surveys in 1996 and 1998, the authors said, and violence among girls might be getting worse.

Bullying in Britain, by Ms Katz, Ann Buchanan and Victoria Bream, also qualified the message of the government's anti-bullying campaign, Don't Suffer in Silence, launched by the education secretary, David Blunkett, last month.

"Certain younger boys, who had been encouraged to report every incident to the teacher, developed a learned helplessness about dealing with even the slightest name calling incident on their own," the authors said. "They began to believe that they were wimps, and everyone else believed it too. Teachers' responses became dulled if the same child reported what seemed trivial incidents too often."

Ms Katz said: "I am not 100% sure that the policy of 'you must tell someone' is itself going to protect victims."

The survey was done last March, six months after the government's directive. But Ms Katz said an anti-bullying strategy had been recommended for many years.

Each school should create a policy to fit its circumstances, she said. Effective strategies involved the whole school, parents and the wider community. In some schools, some pupils were trained in listening and problem solving, an approach endorsed by the government. "Without having the children's participation you are missing a key piece of the jigsaw." According to the report, victims were twice as likely to tell another student than a teacher.

The anti-bullying message should be reinforced in assemblies, on notice boards, in class and at parents evenings, the report said.

Improved classroom management could be more successful than blitz campaigns.

The report acknowledged that a successful policy might bring an increase in incidents reported. But it said that good strategies reduced bullying by up to 55%.

Some 30% of exclusions were for bullying, and a further 14.9% for verbal abuse. But bullies were more popular than victims, providing "fertile ground for creating new bullies".

Bullies and victims often shared problems, including depression or suicidal thoughts and violent parents. Among severely bullied boys, 42% had experienced violence from an adult, and 61% had thoughts of suicide. Among boy bullies, 38% had these thoughts and 9% had attempted suicide.

Bullies were much more likely to have been attacked at school or to have been threatened.

I was an easy target

Jo, from Essex, is 17 and doing well in sixth form. She was bullied at primary school and again at secondary school when she was 13. The second time was the worst.

'It wasn't anything physical; it was just every single day - name calling, things like that. It was two girls. I was an easy target because I wouldn't fight back. They did seem to enjoy it. I don't think they realised how much they were hurting me.

They were trying to disrupt my work. They seemed to be jealous because I was quite good at school. It went on for a year. The worst times were going home and just crying with my mum, feeling there was nobody who was going through the same thing.

My mum went to tell a teacher. I liked the teacher, so I thought it was probably the best thing, but I was a bit worried about it.

The next day the teacher told me she would tell my other teachers. They made sure they kept an eye on it. The head of house decided it would be better not to do anything. They would have just had more of a go at me.

It carried on for a few months longer. By that time I was talking to my friends about it. Then it got less and less. The bullies for some reason turned on each other.

If they'd excluded them and brought them back, they would have made life worse for me. I felt sorry for them that they had to resort to bullying to be popular.

They introduced a policy on bullying the [next] year. Schools need to have a policy that will work for the school, not just a bit of paper they can put in front of parents and the public.'

 Bullying in Britain, Young Voice, 12 Bridge Gardens, East Molesey, Surrey, KT8 9HU; £14

webTitle: City machismo makes way for diversity

fields.headline: City machismo makes way for diversity
fields.trailText: A leading investment bank yesterday moved to tackle the macho, male-dominated image of the City by appointing a new head of "diversity" - rather than the more common "equal opporunities" - in an attempt to attract more women recruits.
fields.body:
A leading investment bank yesterday moved to tackle the macho, male-dominated image of the City by appointing a new head of "diversity" - rather than the more common "equal opporunities" - in an attempt to attract more women recruits.

Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, owned by Citigroup of America, which is one of the three biggest financial services companies in the US, intends first to target gender before turning to race and other "diversity" issues later.

Lynne Fisher, yesterday named as director of diversity in Europe, refused to reveal the current mix between men and women in the workforce or admit to any targets for the future. She insisted, however, that positive discrimination would be avoided.

"We want a meritocratic environment," Ms Fisher said.

"We believe our strong competitive positioning in the industry is enhanced by focusing on the importance of fully valuing and respecting individual differences among our staff, to reflect the diversity of our global client base."

The new role of diversity director is being created at a time when sexual and racial discrimination are receiving greater attention in the City after a series of adverse employment tribunal rulings.

Such cases are thought to have increased the awareness of employers to the issue although the Schroder Salomon Smith Barney announcement is in line with the policy of its parent company in the US which requires each of its operations to have a head of "diversity".

It was not immediately apparently how Schroder Salomon Smith Barney's diversity programme differs from equal opporunity units set up by other big employers.

Schroder Salomon Smith Barney employs some 3,500 people in Europe and has been formed through a series of acquisitions, most recently of the investment banking business of Schroders.

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: It is never particularly easy, as readers will have noticed, being John Prescott. But the latest murmurs from the DETR are more depressing than a 12-hour train journey from Retford to Peterborough: Derek Plews, Prescott's longtime departmental minder and a veteran civil servant, is abandoning him.
fields.body:
It is never particularly easy, as readers will have noticed, being John Prescott. But the latest murmurs from the DETR are more depressing than a 12-hour train journey from Retford to Peterborough: Derek Plews, Prescott's longtime departmental minder and a veteran civil servant, is abandoning him.

This alone would seem to confirm suspicions that the deputy PM is about to lose the transport brief, but Plews's future plans are the final insult: he has taken the job of head of communications for none other than the Association of Train Operating Companies - which must therefore be, contrary to popular opinion, only the second-most despised transport organisation in Britain.

 Disrespectful elements in this paper have taken some MPs to task for not being accessible by email, but no such criticism will stick to Jeff Rooker, social security minister and MP for Birmingham Perry Barr. When constituent Jawaid Yaqoob used the website www.Faxyourmp.com to fax the minister an email, he received a swift reply in the post explaining that Rooker will follow up his query - just as soon as he sends him a letter including his signature.

 To our growing panic, a detailed search of the national papers over the last four days reveals no quotes whatsoever from Professor Cary Cooper of UMIST, the psychologist so famously accommodating of deadline-burdened journalists that he is usually to be found quoted in several features a day. We'll give it one more day, and then we're calling the police.

 One ought, in this day and age, to be able to type obscene internet addresses into one's web browser without fear of nasty surprises, but no: the address www.bigbollocks.com leads the unwary directly to the front page of BBC Online.

 A problem of undeniable national importance is encountered by author and journalist Kevin Cahill in the course of researching a forthcoming book on land ownership in Britain: nobody seems to know how big the country is. Downing Street pleads ignorance, as does the department of the environment and the office for national statistics and the Welsh, Scottish and Northern Ireland offices, apparently hinting that it may be a state secret. The diary's calls to GCHQ and Post Office Tower are not returned, which probably isn't surprising, what with them not really existing and everything.

 An alarming study from the University of North Carolina reveals American science textbooks to be riddled with errors, of which one of the most serious appears to be a photograph of Linda Ronstadt bearing the caption: "A silicon crystal." "Slight errors can become rooted in students' minds for life," the authors warn. "They believe that what they read in books is true!"

 Uri Geller's online novel, Nobody's Child, gets off to a spoonbendingly good start, and Uri is keen to make it even better with suggestions from the public. "But I'd better warn you that any ideas and suggestions you send me become automatically copyrighted," he writes apologetically. "I do have to be careful that no one suggests a twist in the plot and then sues me for royalties. (My lawyers made me say that!)" It's a warning worth heeding: these are the lawyers, after all, who helped Uri avoid a potential lawsuit from a woman who accused him of having made her pregnant by telepathically bending her contraceptive coil. We consider ourselves warned.

 Troubling news from the world of cognitive neuroscience. Muriel Vogel-Sprott, professor of psychology at Canada's University of Waterloo, has just completed a study for the journal Alcoholism, and the findings make worrying reading. "Drinkers can sometimes display foolish, inappropriate or harmful behaviour," Vogel-Sprott reports, "that they would not exhibit when sober."

webTitle: Beckers settle divorce out of court

fields.headline: Beckers settle divorce out of court
fields.trailText: Becker versus Becker, the bitter celebrity bust-up which had threatened to turn into a long, highly publicised and diplomatically sensitive legal battle, was yesterday brought to an abrupt end.
fields.body:
Becker versus Becker, the bitter celebrity bust-up which had threatened to turn into a long, highly publicised and diplomatically sensitive legal battle, was yesterday brought to an abrupt end.

A court in Munich announced that the retired tennis star, Boris Becker, and his wife, Barbara, had been granted a divorce in a hearing behind closed doors. The speed with which the ruling was made - barely a month after their separation - astonished German family lawyers.

A couple must normally be separated for a year before a divorce is granted in Germany. Exceptions can, however, be made if the court is persuaded that a delay would cause hardship.

Mr Becker and his lawyers had argued in separate proceedings in the United States that the publicity surrounding the case could increase the security risk to his children. His wife has contested this.

Yesterday's ruling, which only Mr Becker was in court to hear, put an end to the most talked about marriage in Germany - an inter-racial partnership that disconcerted many of the tennis ace's fans at first, but which came to be acknowledged as symbolic of an increasingly multi-ethnic society.

Its collapse had threatened to take on an even wider dimension. After initially ruling out a divorce and declaring that his wife could have custody of their sons, Mr Becker abruptly changed direction.

He filed both for divorce and sole custody of the children. And in a further, and potentially explosive move, he sought help from the German authorities, claiming that his sons had been abducted by their mother.

Mrs Becker, the daughter of an American, had flown to the family's holiday home in Florida with her children, Noah Gabriel, six, and Elias Balthasar, one, after the announcement of the separation. Her lawyers counter-claimed that Mr Becker had attempted to kidnap his sons on a Christmas visit to Florida.

His application for their return was lodged under the auspices of the 1980 Hague convention, which says that the children of split marriages should be returned to their country of habitual residence.

The convention is among the thorniest issues in relations between Germany and the US. America claims that German courts persistently violate the agreement by failing to hand back children abducted to Germany.

A US court decision in favour of such a high-profile German celebrity as Mr Becker would almost certainly have prompted heated controversy.

Last week, a judge in Miami who had been asked to rule on applications from both parties, gave them 10 days to settle their differences out of court. But there was no indication that they would be divorced before the deadline expired.

Mr Becker had earlier failed in a bid to get the proceedings held in private and faced the uneasy prospect of starring in a prolonged, televised courtroom drama.

A German press report at the weekend said the Beckers had agreed on arrangements for the children and a financial settlement. Mr Becker's German lawyers confirmed yesterday that the parents would share custody of their children and had agreed on dividing property. But they said that the figures that had been reported were too high.

The tabloid Bild am Sonntag reported that the deal involved Becker paying a lump sum of DM30m (almost £10m) to his estranged wife. He was also said to have undertaken to pay for the upbringing of their two children.

Such an arrangement would represent a resounding victory for Mrs Becker, who had been guaranteed only DM5m in a prenuptial agreement.

Under the reported terms of the agreement, Mrs Becker would have the right to choose whether to live in future at the couple's apartment in an up-market condominium on Fisher Island near Miami or at their villa in Munich.

A court in Munich announced that the retired tennis star, Boris Becker, and his wife, Barbara, had been granted a divorce in a hearing behind closed doors. The speed with which the ruling was made - barely a month after their separation - astonished German family lawyers. A couple must normally be separated for a year before a divorce is granted in Germany. Exceptions can, however, be made if the court is persuaded that a delay would cause hardship. Mr Becker and his lawyers had argued in separate proceedings in the United States that the publicity surrounding the case could increase the security risk to his children. His wife has contested this. Yesterday's ruling, which only Mr Becker was in court to hear, put an end to the most talked about marriage in Germany - an inter-racial partnership that disconcerted many of the tennis ace's fans at first, but which came to be acknowledged as symbolic of an increasingly multi-ethnic society. Its collapse had threatened to take on an even wider dimension. After initially ruling out a divorce and declaring that his wife could have custody of their sons, Mr Becker abruptly changed direction. He filed both for divorce and sole custody of the children. And in a further, and potentially explosive move, he sought help from the German authorities, claiming that his sons had been abducted by their mother. Mrs Becker, the daughter of an American, had flown to the family's holiday home in Florida with her children, Noah Gabriel, six, and Elias Balthasar, one, after the announcement of the separation. Her lawyers counter-claimed that Mr Becker had attempted to kidnap his sons on a Christmas visit to Florida. His application for their return was lodged under the auspices of the 1980 Hague convention, which says that the children of split marriages should be returned to their country of habitual residence. The convention is among the thorniest issues in relations between Germany and the US. America claims that German courts persistently violate the agreement by failing to hand back children abducted to Germany. A US court decision in favour of such a high-profile German celebrity as Mr Becker would almost certainly have prompted heated controversy. Last week, a judge in Miami who had been asked to rule on applications from both parties, gave them 10 days to settle their differences out of court. But there was no indication that they would be divorced before the deadline expired. Mr Becker had earlier failed in a bid to get the proceedings held in private and faced the uneasy prospect of starring in a prolonged, televised courtroom drama. A German press report at the weekend said the Beckers had agreed on arrangements for the children and a financial settlement. Mr Becker's German lawyers confirmed yesterday that the parents would share custody of their children and had agreed on dividing property. But they said that the figures that had been reported were too high. The tabloid Bild am Sonntag reported that the deal involved Becker paying a lump sum of DM30m (almost £10m) to his estranged wife. He was also said to have undertaken to pay for the upbringing of their two children. Such an arrangement would represent a resounding victory for Mrs Becker, who had been guaranteed only DM5m in a prenuptial agreement. The retired tennis star also faces a paternity suit in London where a woman claims that her nine-month-old daughter is the result of a hurried liaison with Mr Becker in a cubbyhole above a restaurant.

webTitle: Cambodia moves closer to Khmer Rouge trials

fields.headline: Cambodia moves closer to Khmer Rouge trials
fields.trailText: Cambodia yesterday took a major step on the road to prosecuting members of the former communist Khmer Rouge regime. The upper house of parliament unanimously passed a UN-sponsored bill to establish courts to try the suspects.
fields.body:
Cambodia yesterday took a major step on the road to prosecuting members of the former communist Khmer Rouge regime accused of genocide when the upper house of parliament unanimously passed a UN-sponsored bill to establish courts to try the suspects.

Two weeks after being passed by the lower house, all the senators present yesterday voted to approve the legislation which has been delayed by months of haggling as legislators feared for their lives.

Many members of the ruling Cambodian People's party, including the prime minister Hun Sen, were once cadres of the Khmer Rouge, serving under the dictator Pol Pot during his four brutal years in power from 1975 to 1979.

At least 1.7m people were either executed or died from disease or starvation during the period that became known as the "killing fields".

The government minister in charge of the legislation, Sok An, reassured the senate and the international community during the two-and-a-half days of debate that no one would automatically be immune from prosecution.

"The law doesn't list the names of the people [it will try]. The law talks about the principles and the formula [for the tribunal]," Sok An said. "The judges will take the law and implement it. So there is no doubt that [no one will be beyond the law]. Whoever must be under the law will be under the law, including the lawmakers."

There had been widespread fears that several senior members of the regime might escape justice, particularly the former Khmer Rouge foreign secretary Ieng Sary. He was given a partial amnesty after he defected with 10,000 supporters in 1996 and now lives freely in north-west Cambodia. His move led to the collapse of the Khmer Rouge as a fighting force two years later.

No Khmer Rouge leaders have ever been tried and only two are in detention - long-time military leader Ta Mok and Kaing Khek Iev, better known as Deuch. Deuch ran the notorious S-21 torture centre in the capital Phnom Penh, from which only seven out of more than 14,000 inmates emerged alive.

Despite yesterday's milestone it is still expected to be months before any trials begin because the government has yet to agree court procedures and technicalities with the UN, which is playing a major role in the process.

These discussions are not expected to begin until the bill has been ratified by the constitutional court, which could take several weeks, and signed into law by King Norodom Sihanouk. It took months of frantic negotiations before the world body agreed to the substance of the Khmer Rouge law.

Cambodians will make up the majority of the judges and prosecutors but the UN appointees will have the power of veto over all indictment decisions, including those on who is not to be prosecuted.

Hun Sen said last week he expects the first trial to begin by the end of the year.

webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Gods and monsters
fields.trailText: Everyman: The Hallelujah Kid | Cleopatra's Palace | Coronation Street
fields.body:
Poor Sean Walters. At 14, he was a rabid evangelical preacher who warned his congregation of demons and devils in a style that left them looking as if he had turned a sandblaster on them. Ever the martyr, he saved others, touching them with his healing hands and shouting in their ears, but never once asking for new hair for himself, despite a Rod Hull-esque coiffure.

"God is sick and tired of seeing lesbianism", Sean bellowed in typical religious lunatic fashion. "He is sick and tired of gayanism [I'm not too sure what this is but it sounds like it might be fun], homosexuality, perversion...." So enthralled was the audience, not one person suggested God stop watching Channel 4. Instead, they kneeled before Sean and shook, spoke in tongues and fell on the floor. Perhaps they had inhaled fumes from the Elnet keeping the Shredded Wheat in place on his head.

At 19 though, he had lost his fire - and brimstone - and was withdrawn and melancholy. He had no pals, no interests other than preaching, no normal life. He did have new hair but even that wasn't much of an improvement: he looked like one of 'N Sync. And his little brother Jacob had usurped him, and was himself all set to become an ordained minister in the American Church of Insane Bible Bashers. This church even had a museum full of papier-mché dummies of Great Evangelists from the Past including the interestingly named Oral Roberts (or Relief as he was known to his friends).

The peculiar story of Sean, Jacob and their dad, Mike Walters, was told in Everyman: The Hallelujah Kids (BBC1). Bad hair evidently ran in the family, as did a logic-defying belief that the path the Walters' boys had taken was the true one. The True One, even.

While not a bad person, Mike Walters and his fundamental beliefs had clearly had a detrimental effect on Sean, who, it was disclosed, was slightly autistic. He was having nightmares about demons while his father entertained plans of filling a 1,000-capacity church in the town of LaFontaine, Indiana (pop: 1,000). With seven-year-old Jacob echoing Sean's youthful sermons, this was a tragic portrait of a family that was in crisis but didn't realise it, led by a man who would probably refuse to recognise it anyway.

Everyman wasn't as comprehensive and incisive as it might have been, but it was an intriguing, doleful documentary nonetheless. The quiet moments between film maker Christopher Morris and Sean during which Morris asked such simple questions as "Are you happy?" (to which Sean replied he was not because "the Devil has fought me too much") added emotional depth to what might otherwise have been an Aren't These Folks Mad? programme. (Of course, these folks were mad, but that's not a point that takes 50 minutes to make.)

Everyman was at its most poignant when it became clear that Sean would be more miserable without his belief because that is all he ever had. Hanging on to something out of fear of what you would do without it is a sorrowful situation indeed.

Cleopatra's Palace (Channel 4) did something quite spectacular. It managed to make an exciting discovery - that of the eponymous palace in 10m of water off Alexandria - and a thrilling subject - Cleopatra comin' atcha - dismally dreary and utterly charmless. Seemingly bought in from the Discovery Channel, this was the kind of thing you expect on cable in the middle of the day. With reconstructions of ancient Egypt, complete with pouty actresses in Cleopatra-ish make up, it was a waste of time and liquid eyeliner.

Someone who could do with clasping an asp to her bosom, Deirdre seems intent on revealing all to Mike about his Scottish son, Adam, in Coronation Street (ITV). But all is not well with Susan, who bears more than a passing resemblance to Van der Valk, and with her son. They live, we learned, in Bearsden.

Adam wanted to live in "the city" but it was "too expensive". Yet Bearsden is the most expensive part of Glasgow in which to live. I smell a rat. Do they only live in Salford and simply not want Ken to visit them? Is that Jimmy Krankie playing Adam? The truth will surely out.

More worrying than all, though, are Ken's attempts to get all young and funky by hiking his jeans up round his nether regions and wearing the pants equivalent of a Wonderbra. His overly prominent genitalia are enough to put you off your Cream Eggs.

webTitle: Getting personal with... Noddy Holder

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Noddy Holder
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Noddy Holder
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? Noddy, of course - a kid at school gave it me when I was seven years old and I've been stuck with it ever since. Everybody calls me Noddy except for my mum and a couple of aunts, who still call me Neville.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? Well I haven't personally lied about it, but early press agents shaved a couple of years off each of us in Slade when we had our first hit, and I still see articles thirty-odd years later with the wrong age.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Shy, retiring ex-pop star requires dirty lady!

What was the last illegal thing you did? Not guilty of nothing, your honour.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? I'm very good at filling hot water bottles when my missus has got period pains.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? Sooty.He can't shout at you.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? RH

Has a critic ever made you cry? You've got to be kidding!

What would you advertise without a fee? My mum's home-made pickled onions - the best in the world.

What would you never advertise? Virgin trains - surely no explanation necessary! They've made me late for too many shows and appointments.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning? There's nothing worth losing any kip over.

What takes you to a "happy place"? A couple of large vodkas usually does the trick.

Noddy Holder stars in a new series of The Grimleys, which starts on Monday 22 January.

webTitle: Pass notes: Captain Scott

fields.headline: No: 1801 Captain Scott
fields.trailText: As in the daring and courageous polar explorer? Erm, yes, but it turns out brave Captain Scott might not have been such a hero after all.
fields.body:
As in the daring and courageous polar explorer? Erm, yes, but it turns out brave Captain Scott might not have been such a hero after all.

Not another good man gone south. Hmmm . . . it appears he didn't give enough (that is, any) credit to the man who rescued him - one Captain William Colbeck - after his ship became marooned in the Antarctic ice.

You mean he gave him the cold shoulder? Very good. Yes, it seems that Scott had rather a chip on his shoulder about being rescued by someone beneath him socially.

Frozen out, you could say. So how come it's making waves now? Enough with the puns. It seems the National Maritime Museum is going to restore Colbeck to the roll-call of British polar heroes, for his mission to help Discovery and blast it free of the ice with dynamite.

So what's the story? Apparently Colbeck rescued Scott twice. The first time, in 1903, Scott refused assistance and allowed only the infirm - including Ernest Shackleton - to be taken. Scott remained for the winter, continuing his scientific monitoring.

How heroic! What about the second rescue? The Discovery found itself in trouble again in 1904, and Colbeck literally blew it out of the water. Until now, Scott's claim that a miraculous swell had freed the ship was believed.

So Colbeck's ship has come in? Stop it. Yes, Colbeck is finally getting the recognition he deserves. Photographs showing the ice being blasted - withheld until now under copyright laws because the photographer couldn't be identified - are to be shown at the National Maritime Museum.

But it was Scott who was first to the south pole. Well, not quite. He reached his destination only to find he had been beaten by his rival, the Norwegian Roald Amundsen.

Oh yes, that's right. And unfortunately he and his team died on the return journey.

Do say: "First the worst, second the best."

Don't say: "I'm just going to temporarily erase you from history. You may be some time . . ."
