webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Afternoon Play: The Natural Selection Of Margret | America And The World
fields.body:
Patricia Hannah has drawn on a 70-year-old real-life mystery for her Afternoon Play: The Natural Selection Of Margret (2.15pm, Radio 4). An eccentric German doctor, Friedrich Ritter, and his mistress, Dore Strauch, arrive on Floreana island in the Galapagos. Heading to where Charles Darwin had been inspired, they hoped to create an earthly paradise. The unexpected arrival of Baroness Wagner de Bousquet and her assorted toyboys soon put paid to that.

The imminent arrival of George W Bush (pictured) in the White House has inevitably fluttered European dovecotes. Gavin Esler presides over a special debate to consider the new president's impact on America And The World (8.0pm, Radio 4). Will the ABM treaty be revoked in favour of a new Star Wars defence system? Will a recession heighten the present transatlantic trade disputes? An international panel of experts gathers to make an informed assessment.

webTitle: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Cheshire
fields.trailText: Cheshire
fields.body:
Before the arrival of the modern chemical industry and the introduction of artificial fertilisers, our ancestors back in the 17th and 18th centuries had to rely on the natural fertilisers provided by their farm animals to feed the soil and grassland and so produce another year's harvest. To this was added the practice of spreading marl, a fine-grained sedimentary rock, especially in those areas of Cheshire where the marl was at or near the surface, and as a result thousands of ponds were created.

A look at the local OS Maps shows just how many of the marl pits still exist; farmland all around the village can be seen to be honeycombed with blue dots. Although a large number of the 86,000 thought to have existed in the heyday of the marl pit may have gone, Cheshire is probably still the pond capital of England. Our local ponds have enjoyed some protection under the Wildlife and Countryside Acts, as they have been found to be breeding areas for the great crested newt, that small amphibian which, in the past, has put a halt to many a building project.

However, judging by recent developments around the valley, if the project is considered important enough and an alternative site provided for the newts, they can be moved and the ponds lost. Fortunately, a further safeguard has now been imposed, with English Nature declaring an area of some 870 acres, including over 120 ponds, at the western end of the valley, a Site of Special Scientific Interest, in order to protect one of the largest known breeding populations of the great crested newt in the UK.

webTitle: Portrait: Martin Sheen

fields.headline: All the president's manias
fields.standfirst: Martin Sheen is revelling in the role of US President Bartlet in the TV series The West Wing, opening here this week. But, as he tells  Fiona Morrow, his real-life political activism gave the studio a scare
fields.trailText: Martin Sheen is revelling in the role of US President Bartlet in the TV series The West Wing, opening here this week. But, as he tells  Fiona Morrow, his real-life political activism gave the studio a scare.
fields.body:
Recently Martin Sheen has taken to keeping a tape of Hail To The Chief in his pocket and, when driven around the Warner Bros lot in Burbank, California, he slips it into the shuttle van's player, winds down the window, and waves magisterially to anyone who happens to be passing. It's not that heading the hottest show on US network television has gone to his head, it's more that he's having a ball and he wants everyone to know about it.

"I'm having the time of my life," he beams.

We're sitting in the Oval Office, Sheen's current place of business where he plays President Josiah Bartlet of The West Wing, a fact which clearly still tickles the hell out of him. And so it should: with nine Emmys and some 20m viewers, The West Wing is the best thing that could have happened to the 60-year-old actor, still best known for performances he gave in Badlands, and Apocalypse Now - over two decades ago.

But a populist drama series set behind the scenes at the White House wouldn't be on everyone's most-likely-to-succeed list, and, given that the show largely consists of interior dialogue scenes about the political process, it's a pretty good indication of how sharp the scripts are that it has taken off so unequivocally.

For Sheen though, the possibility of addressing the social issues he regards as vitally important - poverty, alcoholism and gun control, among many others - to a potentially huge audience was always going to be hard to resist: "It's not an accident I got this part," he suggests. "If Bartlet had been a Republican, you wouldn't see me sitting here, I promise you."

A reformed alcoholic and drug abuser, Sheen has devoted his life to the causes which his hatred of injustice and deeply held Catholic faith draw him to. He's known for flying off at the first sign of trouble to put himself on the line for what he believes in; he has been arrested more than 70 times for the causes he supports. His engagement with grassroots politics may give Warners a mild headache, but it has undoubtedly added a certain frisson to an already highly charged show, and anyway, Sheen is not about to put his life on hold for them: "They've never gotten in my face about my activism, and it would be a very serious mistake if they were to do so," he says emphatically. "They knew who I was, and what I stood for when they offered me the job."

Despite the protestations of writer Aaron Sorkin and producer John Wells (also of ER), Sheen is quick to see similarities between Bartlet and the outgoing president, one of his heroes, Bill Clinton. "Bartlet is a very intelligent man, with great heart and a great sense of humour who plays fair and enjoys being the president. I think all of these qualities are reflective of Clinton, who I think history will reveal as a great president."

He has little sympathy with the post-Lewinsky critics: "I think it should have been just the opposite - rather than condemnation for his sexuality, we should have celebrated that he could accomplish such great things, and be so human. It's a sad reflection of our country that we still haven't dealt with our sexuality."

Despite his enthusiasm for the project, Sheen is not without criticism; he is greatly frustrated by Bartlet's willingness to bomb the Middle East at any opportunity, and he remains unsure of the rosy glow in which the president is always framed. "We can be too sentimental, but then I think that is how the office is generally seen - and, God save us, presidents do become sentimental," he laughs, adding "We had an old actor in there who was precious little else."

The biggest single criticism of The West Wing - a show which has hooked liberals and conservatives alike - is that Bartlet is just too good to be true. When I suggest to Sheen that (much as I love the drama) it's just too soft, too aspirational, too schmaltzy a view of politics to really hit home, he whispers conspiratorially, "I agree with you".

Sheen's own politics are inseparable from his religion: "Your faith has to cost you something, otherwise you have to question its value. I do the things I do because I cannot not do them and feel good about being human. Our faith, our religion, has to connect us to our humanity because that's how we find ourselves in others. I just try and be as human and as giving as I can be and know that it will never be enough."

When I suggest that he's sounding too good to be true himself, he lets out a peal of laughter before offering a different analysis: "My faults are known to those closest to me, are rumoured by those furthest away, and are confirmed to my confessor where they belong."

webTitle: Jungle Janes

fields.headline: Some like it hot
fields.trailText: Jumping aboard the send-people-off-to-survive-in-the-wilderness bandwagon, Channel 4 tonight screens the first of its Jungle Janes films, in which a 12-strong bunch of Herefordshire women commit themselves to a trek through the Brunei jungle.
fields.body:
Jumping aboard the send-people-off-to-survive-in-the-wilderness bandwagon, Channel 4 tonight screens the first of its Jungle Janes films, in which a 12-strong bunch of Herefordshire women commit themselves to a trek through the Brunei jungle.

As Castaway 2000 (and Big Brother) have proved, the voyeuristic appeal of this type of programme lies chiefly in seeing how the participants relate to each other when the going gets tough, not in how they overcome physical challenges. Acknowledging this essential soap-opera quality, the first episode introduces us to three of the women, Dicky, Alex and Gwenda, intercutting their preparations for leaving home with their first reactions to jungle living.

Perhaps influenced by the series-stealing success of Ben, the unashamedly posh Prince William-alike in Castaway 2000, no pretence is made that the 12 are a representative sample of British women - these are solidly Sloaney ladies, and their decision to make the trip was the result of a dinner party discussion.

Dicky is the no-nonsense matron of a prep school, whose retired naval officer husband harrumphs dismissively at her decision to seek adventure, muttering darkly about "a mother's place being in the home".

Alex, a wine merchant much given to declaiming poetry, is clearly nervous. Her farmer husband leads her huffing and puffing across the mild green fields of Hereford in preparation - spliced with footage of Alex close to despair mid-jungle as a poisonous snake is discovered.

Gwenda, meanwhile, is the wife of the expedition leader, Ken, a retired army major. Expressing a desire to experience the sort of adventure Ken has known professionally, she also insists that she will not regard him as her husband during the trek. After an introductory foray into the jungle results in the women getting hopelessly lost, and Ken confides to camera his concerns about the trip ahead, both sentiments look set to be tested to their limits.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: An Ideal Husband | Clerks | Best Laid Plans | They Died With Their Boots On
fields.body:
An Ideal Husband

(Oliver Parker, 1998)

2.15pm, Sky Premier

Rupert Everett is in his element as Lord Goring, the assured hero of Parker's entertaining adaptation of the Oscar Wilde play. Goring's life of extreme leisure is interrupted when he has to come to the aid of his stuffy friend Chiltern (Jeremy Northam): a ghost from his shady past (Julianne Moore's sparky, troublemaking Mrs Cheveley) having returned to threaten his political career. Wilde's debate on public and private virtue is still pertinent, and if the direction is a little stodgy, the cast more than makes up for it.

Clerks

(Kevin Smith, 1994)

10pm, FilmFour

It cost around $28,000 to make and, stuffed with appropriately cheap gags, it's an absolute steal. Smith's comedy revolves around the lives of store clerk Dante (Brian O'Halloran) and his chum Randal (Jeff Anderson), and the scenes in which they deal with outraged customers have the scabrous zest of Groucho Marx. Plus the debate on whether The Empire Strikes Back is better than Return Of The Jedi (of course it is).

Best Laid Plans

(Mike Barker, 1999)

11.30pm, Sky MovieMax

Brit director Barker comes on like Mike Figgis with this enjoyable neo-noir tale about a young man (Alessandro Nivola, building on his impressive appearance as Nicolas Cage's brother in Face/Off) who owes big money to the nastiest man in Tropico, USA. Reese Witherspoon as his girlfriend and Josh Brolin as a pal leading him into a dodgy heist are canny performers in an uneven but at times ingenious little drama.

They Died With Their Boots On

(Raoul Walsh, 1941)

2.40pm, TCM

"They" being the Seventh Cavalry at the Little Big Horn. This was the first of several spectacular Walsh/Errol Flynn films, Flynn's Custer riding roughshod over accepted historical truths, turning the arrogant general into a noble peace-seeker and sympathiser with the Plains Indians. And it's done with a magnificent flourish: swirling battles, and a charming Flynn-Olivia De Havilland romance gives it some emotional depth.

webTitle: Boston Law redresses the balance

fields.headline: The whole truth
fields.standfirst: After years of watching LA Law and Ally McBeal, we should in theory all be experts in the American legal system. But we're not, says  Jacques Peretti  , as a new series - Boston Law - brutally demonstrates
fields.trailText: After years of watching LA Law and Ally McBeal, we should in theory all be experts in the American legal system. But we're not, says Jacques Peretti , as a new series - Boston Law - brutally demonstrates.
fields.body:
When I was 14, I regularly bunked off school. But instead of doing what you're supposed to do when bunking off school - going down the arcade and ineptly smoking fags - I'd stay at home and watch Crown Court.

Crown Court was a staple of afternoon TV throughout the late 70s and early 80s. Long before cameras were allowed into real courts to eavesdrop on the misfortunes of the low-level criminal, this creaking procedural drama, staged on a cardboard set with cardboard extras, became compulsive viewing for the 14-year-old truant. Zen-like in its complete absence of pace, each case would last a week, with the verdict on Friday. It invariably culminated with an accused old lady tearfully clutching her handbag in the dock as she waited to find out if she'd been found guilty of stealing a packet of biscuits from Asda.

Last week, TV attempted to return to Crown Court territory with Judge John Deed, written by GF Newman, the writer of the ground-breaking 1970s drama about bent cops, Law & Order. Crown Court, I realised as I watched Judge John Deed, was alive and well. Like Crown Court, Judge John Deed portrayed the legal system in all its pedantic, nit-picking glory, using hardcore jargon without recourse to a crib sheet of expositional puff.

In America, by contrast, lack of dramatic exposition is taken to its natural conclusion without any discernable effect on the viewer: jargon is used as a camp, high-octane flow of information, pulsing through the action and even getting its own starring role. Brief bursts of techno-guff are slotted between the smouldering Noah Wylie close-ups.

For flashing-light soap operas such as ER and NYPD Blue, which attempt to inject a bit of authenticity by peppering the script with an incessant stream of procedure speak, the result can be counter-productive. ER's "hundred-over-eighty-BP-normal" has become a comedy cliché, begging for a spoof by French and Saunders.

Curiously, American legal dramas, unlike their British counterparts, eschew jargon. Having watched four series of Ally McBeal, I defy you to find a single useful nugget of information about the US legal system buried in all the whimsy.

Amy Jenkins's This Life, hugely influenced by American drama (and very little by Crown Court, alas) paid lawyer-like attention to the detail of how to roll a spliff or throw a meaningful glance in a strobe-lit club, but treated the actual business of law as a tedious distraction.

The documentary series Boston Law, which starts tonight on BBC1, attempts to redress the balance, focusing in impressive detail on the real life, day-to-day chaos of a Boston criminal court.

Each month, half a million Americans face criminal charges. 80 per cent of them cannot even afford an attorney (let alone one who dances with babies and sees unicorns).

Boston Law's star, if you like, is Lisa Medeiros: a defence lawyer who, standing in the Kafkaesque swirl of a court corridor, must meet clients seconds before she represents them. Already dealing with the case of a junkie with a broken leg, she must grasp the case details of a Puerto Rican man who has beaten his mother. He cannot speak English. Minus an interpreter, Medeiros relies on the help of a man who happens to be sitting next to her, another Puerto Rican defendant about to go to court, to explain the case.

Frightening and, indeed, dramatic as the American justice system portrayed in Boston Law is, one cannot help wondering why American legal dramas don't get a little more real about their subject.

In the light of Boston Law's surreal twists (you couldn't make it up - to use the cliché), Ally McBeal starts to look quite different. Less escapist fantasy than a whimsical allegory about the lottery of the judicial system. Nothing Ally McBeal could do, however, would compare with Lisa Medeiros simply doing her job.

Following the OJ Simpson trial, a bright new dawn was predicted for the depiction of the real-life legal system on US TV. Audiences, it was claimed, were no longer simply interested in glossy LA Law-style soap opera masquerading as legal drama, but had developed an appetite for complex cases broadcast live on TV.

Murder One, the epic legal drama series, was commissioned off the back of the OJ trial. Trumpeted as a breakthrough in star-free casting, with a complex, sprawling narrative, the series nevertheless flopped. The network persevered with the show, dropping the characterful (ie ugly) Daniel Benzali and bringing in an actor who looked as if he'd walked straight out of a Gillette advert. Murder One was axed for good and the OJ effect on US legal drama was buried once and for all.

I still have high hopes that the Murder One/Crown Court format will rise again. Maybe it will be in a drama using the rolling news channels - the much maligned "media circus" - who provide the real energy and spin on a terminally long trial.

There may be a gaping hole between Ally McBeal and Boston Law, but one just as great exists between Boston Law's Lisa Medeiros and her clients. A man she helps avoid prison shows his gratitude by blanking her.

In reality, as in drama, the accused are unknowable. Perhaps he was not, as Medeiros felt, being rude, but simply conforming to what was expected of a television criminal.

 Boston Law, tonight, 10.35pm, BBC1

webTitle: Student teachers wanting employment should start early

fields.headline: Holy grail for class of 2001
fields.standfirst: Student teachers searching for employment are being advised to start early.  Helen Carter  reports
fields.trailText: Student teachers searching for employment are being advised to start early. Helen Carter reports
fields.body:
The course has been a "very short, sharp shock into teaching", admits Tracy Munro. She now expects to carry on learning and progressing as a teacher when she starts her first job.

Like other trainee teachers in January, the PGCE student at Manchester Metropolitan University is searching appointments pages and trawling the internet for information.

"I don't have romantic notions of teaching young ladies in a grammar school," says Munro. "I am looking for an inner-city school in Salford or Manchester because I want to stay in this area and my family live around here."

She aims to stay in her first job for between five and 10 years.

"I am talking to my friends about what sort of things I am applying for. It is something that we share as a group. We have just got some information through from the National Union of Teachers, which is a guide to getting our first job, which is useful. I am also looking in the Guardian on Tuesdays and in the Times Educational Supplement.

"It is a slow process, most of the job ads get placed in May or June, but we have been advised to start looking and applying now so we have time to think about what we are applying for."

Munro, 32, says her immediate concern is to be a good class teacher and she is not looking to get involved in the fast-track scheme.

"When choosing a school, we can evaluate information from Ofsted reports and from just looking around and asking people," she says.

She said as many of her friends are teachers, there was always someone who had connections with the schools she was interested in applying to.

Vicki Leng is also doing the same course at MMU, but she hopes to work in a different environment.

"I would like to be in a school for three or four years before moving on," she says. "I think that is the best way because it is a steep learning curve. It is unhealthy to stay in a school for life. After leaving your first school, I would hope that you would take what you had learned there with you and move on."

Leng, 23, says she is looking for a school with a mixed catchment area of inner-city students and those from the suburbs.

"Because of my background, it would be a challenge to work in this situation," she says. "Like most people on the course I am from a middle-class background.

"When I'm looking for a teaching appointment I look for information on the net as well as Ofsted reports. At an interview you can glean information about the school from its displays and the attitude of the kids towards the teachers and vice versa.

"Other jobs I have done felt less important than teaching. I worked doing temping as a receptionist and at a nursing home, where I was seeing people at the end of their life. It is very different working with people at the beginning of their life."

Ron Dixon, head of Cheadle Hulme College in Cheadle Hulme, says trainee teachers are now better prepared when they apply for their first job. "They have an understanding of current issues relating to a particular subject. People who are going through training now are better equipped with relevant information than they were a number of years ago.

"Training is much more focused now. They need to know their specific subject and classroom management."

Ron Dixon would be looking to employ someone who could teach a whole range of people with varying abilities and disabilities. They also need to have an approach that is sympathetic and empathic.

"Assuming we call them to interview, we are then trying to assess how they might be in front of a class for a brief period of time."

He says it gives them an idea of what someone is like, their personality and whether they have a spark and sense of enthusiasm about their subject.

"We are now going through a crisis of recruitment, which is particularly bad in some parts of the country," he says. "We are partially cushioned from it at this school because we have such a low turnover of staff.

"But over the last few years we have seen fewer people applying for jobs and not necessarily the same quality of teachers."

"When I'm looking for a teaching appointment I look for information on the net as well as Ofsted reports. At an interview you can glean information about the school from its displays and the attitude of the kids towards the teachers and vice versa. "Other jobs I have done felt less important than teaching. I worked doing temping as a receptionist and at a nursing home, where I was seeing people at the end of their life. It is very different working with people at the beginning of their life." Ron Dixon, head of Cheadle Hulme College in Cheadle Hulme, says trainee teachers are now better prepared when they apply for their first job. "They have an understanding of current issues relating to a particular subject. People who are going through training now are better equipped with relevant information than they were a number of years ago. "Training is much more focused now. They need to know their specific subject and classroom management." Ron Dixon would be looking to employ someone who could teach a whole range of people with varying abilities and disabilities. They also need to have an approach that is sympathetic and empathic. "Assuming we call them to interview, we are then trying to assess how they might be in front of a class for a brief period of time." He says it gives them an idea of what someone is like, their personality and whether they have a spark and sense of enthusiasm about their subject. "We are now going through a crisis of recruitment, which is particularly bad in some parts of the country," he says. "We are partially cushioned from it at this school because we have such a low turnover of staff. "But over the last few years we have seen fewer people applying for jobs and not necessarily the same quality of teachers."

webTitle: Scrapping level 1 GNVQs will put off students

fields.headline: Don't cut away the first rung
fields.standfirst: Scrapping level 1 GNVQs will put off students, warns  Judith Norrington
fields.trailText: Scrapping level 1 GNVQs will put off students, warns Judith Norrington
fields.body:
The design of the new vocational GCSEs may have looked like a regularising process. After all, we have had GCSEs for many years leading to academic A-levels. Isn't this just a way of providing balance, satisfying the need for an equivalent route up to the new vocational A-level (until recently, the advanced GNVQ).

I am not alone in the college sector in believing that for many students this change could actually be a step backwards. Our current qualifications can be seen as a ladder with three rungs or levels. Level 1 provides a starting place for some, though not all, taking formal examinations, level 2 is intermediate and level 3 is the equivalent to advanced level.

The secretary of state for education has previously spoken approvingly of the increased number of young people taking level 1 courses. However, the DfEE has recently announced it is asking the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority to sweep away level 1 qualifications, such as GNVQ part 1, so that level 1 and level 2 qualifications will be blurred into one. In future, the only way you will get a level 1 is by not doing very well at a level 2 qualification.

The DfEE's press release on the new vocational GCSEs appears to be disingenuous, describing the change as to "put in place a further rung in the coherent ladder of vocational learning". It appears to me the reverse. A rung is about to be removed.

Several thousand young people currently take foundation GNVQ qualifications. For many it is the first time they have achieved a qualification and demonstrated success in learning. The change will reduce opportunities for the next generation of students.

The principal of Portsmouth college, Tom Espley, says that level 1 is a great confidence booster for many students and an effective way of recruiting many who will move on to level 2. Getting rid of level 1 will have serious consequences for student retention, he says.

We will not only lose the level. The vocational GCSE may well be designed to be more like the academic GCSE, a trend that has been apparent in the increasingly less vocational advanced GNVQ, or vocational A-level, as it is now called. We then lose a different teaching approach. The approach to learning within the foundation GNVQ is different and it often motivates those who have found other forms of study less approachable.

 Judith Norrington is the Association of College's director of curriculum and quality.

webTitle: Interview: Andy Williams, king of easy listening

fields.headline: 'I took LSD three or four times. Maybe that's why I'm cool'
fields.standfirst: Andy Williams, king of easy listening, talks to  Caroline Sullivan
fields.trailText: Andy Williams, king of easy listening, talks to Caroline Sullivan
fields.body:
It's so strange to be so popular here. I did Top of the Pops 30 years ago, and to have a new generation of young people listening and liking it is fantastic." Andy Williams has never been cooler than he is right now. Actually, you might say that he has never been cool until now. Coolness was something he left to others, while he satisfied Middle America's taste for what he calls "better music".

That began to change in the mid-1990s, when this better music, otherwise known as easy listening, was adopted by a faction of British clubbers and became perversely fashionable under the name lounge. Williams and fellow lounge progenitors Tony Bennett and Burt Bacharach were lauded for never straying from their Sta-Prest sound.

The decisive crossover moment came when Fiat used Williams's old hit Music to Watch Girls By in a commercial two years ago, introducing a new generation to his mellifluous baritone. The re-released song made the top 10, and a cash-in compilation, In the Lounge With, was also successful.

The latest instalment of his comeback is his first British tour in 20 years, which starts in Belfast tonight. He claims it's also his last British tour, because he's getting on a bit and would rather play golf at his "French-style chateau" in Branson, Missouri (one of six houses he owns around the US). Branson is an Ozark Mountains town known as the "Las Vegas of the Bible Belt" due to the many middle-of-the-road stars who live and perform there year-round. The Osmond Family Theatre is a mile down Route 76 from Williams. "They do their show on ice skates," he offers with a gently sardonic smile.

Williams, 73 last month, does a gruelling 12 shows a week in his own $8m Moon River Theatre, named after his signature tune. Hewn out of Ozark limestone, the building is the only place in Branson to have been featured in Architectural Digest. The foyer boasts a Henry Moore sculpture and works from Williams's collection of Pollocks and De Koonings, although "not the important ones. The locals don't really appreciate them. They're not into art that much." Who'd have thought the man who calls himself Mr Christmas ("In America I'm Mr Christmas, because I've done six Christmas albums. There's a big market for them there") was a serious art collector?

Saying that, to look at him you wouldn't know he was Mr Christmas. There's not a Pringle sweater to be seen in his hotel suite. No cardigan. No kitsch at all, in fact, unless you count his pale green spectacles, the same shade as his herbal tea. If anything, he is starting to seem like Mr Cool Rockin' Grandad.

Unlike most Americans of his vintage, he has even hung onto his figure. "I've followed the Pritikin low-fat diet for about 20 years. Who wants to be fat? There's so many fat people in America. They're nice people," he adds, not wanting this to be taken as criticism. "They're just fat."

He has already offended Branson by using the words "damn" and "ass" in his act. He almost got picketed. So it must be a relief to be in swinging London, eh? He laughs. "If I was 24, I wouldn't go to Branson, I'd live here or New York. But I have a great life. We got 7,000 tourist buses at my theatre last year. The front door of my house goes onto the golf course and the back looks onto a lake."

What he doesn't have back home is the admiration of younger people who see him as the emperor of all things easy. The Andy Williams revival is mainly a British phenomenon, but he's happy with that. "In the States, lounge has different connotations," he says. "I've made jokes that when I get old I'll end up in a seedy hotel lounge in Bakersfield [California] doing a flash act - singing a bit, then wearing a raincoat and flashing 'em." He hawhaws fruitily.

That's almost shocking coming from a native of Wall Lake, Iowa. Andy started singing there at the age of eight, the youngest member of the four-boy Williams Brothers. During his 1930s youth the family moved to Chicago, Cincinnati and finally Los Angeles, where they got their break doing backing vocals on a Bing Crosby record, Swinging on a Star. He croons mistily into his cup: "Would you like to swing on a star, carry moonbeams home in a jar?"

No surprise, then, to learn that the adolescent Williams never went through a rebellious phase. "You mean smoking or drinking? I was doing that anyway; I didn't consider it rebellious. My dad did screw me up, though. His philosophy to get us to work was to say, 'You're not as good as the others out there', so you had a lack of self-esteem as you grew up. I still have it now - that's why I work so hard."

Has he tried therapy? "All therapy does is make you forgive your father. It doesn't take away the low self-esteem. It's still in my brain."

He hit a crisis in the early 1970s when his marriage to his first wife, Claudine Longet, began to unravel. He and Longet, a French singer who was later convicted of the manslaughter of her second husband, were so unhappy that Williams decided to try an unconventional treatment recommended by his doctor. If anyone from Branson is reading, look away now.

"He said, 'You're having some problems, so you might consider LSD treatments. Maybe you and your wife should try it, because you're breaking up.' It was illegal in America because of Timothy Leary, so I went to the Hollywood Hospital in Canada - my wife didn't come - and did it three or four times two days apart.

"It was interesting," he remembers dryly, cradling his cup in both hands. "Some of the trips were good, some bad. They guide you through it and suggest colours, etcetera. You go back and see yourself being born, see yourself pooping in your diapers, you go through a lot of stuff. It changed me - I came out realising that the only things important to me were family, friends and love. Maybe that's why I'm so cool."

Who would believe it? Apparently, the drug's only adverse effect was a short-lived partiality to bell-bottoms and long hair. "Only a little longer, though," he says hastily. He has never had a flashback, and has mainly positive memories of the "treatment", but he never repeated the experience.

Now that he has outed himself, younger artists will undoubtedly flock to work with him on his next project, a duets album. The success of Tom Jones's Reload LP has encouraged him to have a crack himself, and he's already musing about potential partners. He would like to get, for starters, Pavarotti, Whitney Houston and Britney Spears.

Britney Spears? Isn't he setting his sights a bit low?

"Well, I'd like Madonna, but if we don't get her, then Britney. It's like in the old movies, where if you couldn't get Marilyn Monroe for a role you'd go for the second or third choice."

At which point his manager, Tennyson Flowers (the name was inherited from a great-uncle named after Alfred Lord), arrives with a photographer, the signal for the emperor of easy to say goodbye. He half rises, proffers a hand and sinks back onto the sofa in one casual movement that barely disturbs the crease in his slacks. Impressive.

 Andy Williams plays the Waterfront Hall, Belfast (028-9033 4400), tonight, The Point, Dublin (00-3531-836 3633), tomorrow, the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), on Friday, then tours.

webTitle: Furthermore: Words of comfort

fields.headline: Words of comfort
fields.standfirst: Wanna job in a college? The competition is fierce, warns  Donald Hiscock
fields.trailText: Wanna job in a college? The competition is fierce, warns Donald Hiscock
fields.body:
I have received many letters and e-mails from final year degree students asking me about working in the glamorous world of further education. Most correspondents begin with something along the lines of how they have always cherished the thought of a career in education but are a bit put off by the sheer number of applicants who are fighting for that big break in FE.

Well, I am taking this opportunity to reply to all these bright-eyed hopefuls by dispensing some inside information. While it is not possible to answer every single query I do hope that the thousands of you who have begged me to help you in some small way to achieve the ambition of a lifetime will accept the following crumbs of comfort.

Let's consider those upsetting rejection letters. Do keep trying. I have known people who have repeatedly been turned down for jobs in their main subject only to reapply for an area in which they are mostly deficient. To their delight they were offered a job, usually commencing later that afternoon. So, if no one seems to want a lecturer in sociology then try teaching mechanical engineering instead.

This leads me on nicely to my next point, which is that getting in to the college should be your main objective. Accept any job going. It is well known that several college principals have started out as temporary catering assistants, making the tea for high-powered management boards. So put up with a few years in the kitchen, knowing that you are only a few short steps away from a private health care package and a coveted reserved parking space.

Why not try work shadowing? But don't think this means tagging along next to a busy lecturer as she moves from the Powerpoint presentation to the video-conferencing suite. Aim to work inside the engine room of the college, alongside the administrators. Learn about managing financial crises, find out what a redundancy package looks like (it's probably not a box tied up with a bow), dabble in high-level merger mongering or maybe get to know a member of the teaching staff by his first name (only joking).

If you still can't get inside the modern world of further education, then perhaps you should resort to enrolling as a student. Just hang around outside the admissions office on your mobile phone for a few minutes and someone is bound to fix you up with a course. And you can afford to be choosy. Don't be afraid to negotiate on the work you are expected to do. Above all, avoid any course that expects you to sit through an exam. After all, you are in search of the real student experience.

The most popular question I am asked is what is a typical day in the life of a lecturer? The quick answer is that there isn't one, but you probably haven't read this far for a clever-dick answer like that. My normal day is not all glamour and adrenalin rush. But it is certainly a rush. Be prepared for a caffeine-fuelled academic roller coaster ride. You will always be in demand to dispense wisdom, perhaps offer some consolation or be asked for your signature. You will get to sign a lot of leaving cards for colleagues. Writing good luck next to an unfamiliar name becomes second nature after a while.

So good luck in fulfilling your ambition. (Remember: the contents of a college may differ from those described in this column.)

webTitle: Rostrum:

fields.headline: Just the business
fields.standfirst: Why is a subject that is a big hit with students shunned by government and education, asks  Ian Abbott
fields.trailText: Why is a subject that is a big hit with students shunned by government and education, asks Ian Abbott
fields.body:
Which subject had nearly 40,000 candidates at A-level in 2000 with almost 60,000 on GNVQ programmes? Add in those students doing the subject as part of other programmes such as leisure and tourism, health and social care and NVQ. The same subject is not included in the national curriculum yet had 100,000 entries at GCSE last year. Don't forget it's also been one of the fastest growing subjects in Higher Education over the last 25 years. Still not worked it out? The answer is, of course, business studies.

A success story by anyone's standards. Yet if you're not a lecturer of business studies I wouldn't expect you to know the answer because, despite the popularity of the subject with parents and students, it gets relatively little recognition from the government or public bodies. Even in colleges, where the subject has proved to be a major attraction to students, business studies does not usually generate a great deal of attention. The BBC refuses to include business studies in the digitalcurriculum it is developing. The government excludes PGCE business studies trainees from joining the recently announced fast-track initiative.

Yet colleges experience a constant demand from students to provide a range of business courses. At GNVQ, for example, business has proved to be by far the most popular subject area and has been important in attracting full-time students from the school sector. Why has business studies got such a low profile? Is it because of the negative way in which business is portrayed in the media? A recent survey, by the Institute of Economic Affairs, of post-eighteenth century literature reported that, with very few exceptions, writers have presented a negative view of business. The traditional images are those of the hard-hearted capitalist or the boring accountant. These caricatures are often found in current TV programmes; just look at your favourite soap opera. These stereotypes still exist despite the efforts of business people such as Anita Roddick to promote a more enlightened picture of modern business practice.

The present government, especially the chancellor of the exchequer, is very keen to promote enterprise and the development of entrepreneurial activity. Business studies can contribute to both by developing a better understanding of how business and the economy operate and by fostering an enterprising approach. However, it is not just concerned with profit and loss. A business studies course will, for example, include consideration of social, consumer, health and safety and ethical issues.

In many cases business studies courses have successfully incorporated a wide range of educational initiatives introduced by central government. Practical teaching approaches, different assessment strategies, the utilisation of infor mation and communications technology can all be found in a business studies course. The new Advanced Vocational Business, for example, provides numerous opportunities for the delivery of key skills. The development of links between education and business is at the core of many business courses

Yet despite this record of success business studies is often treated as a second-class subject. Is it because business studies lecturers are too modest or are just too busy getting on with their jobs? Is it a reflection of the negative way in which business has been portrayed, and the anti-business culture which has developed in certain sectors of society? Is there still a feeling that business studies is not a real academic subject?

What we need to do is to foster a more positive view of business which will, in turn, encourage greater understanding of a modern, vibrant economy. Lecturers can contribute to this by making sure that senior management is fully aware of the success of the subject. The government could assist by giving business studies a much higher profile and recognising the significant achievements which have taken place in one of the most relevant and successful subject areas. Additional funding and recognition would help. Inclusion rather than exclusion from major educational initiatives would be a start. So how about it Mr Blunkett and Mr Brown?

 Ian Abbott is PGCE economics and business studies coordinator at the Institute of Education, University of Warwick.

The traditional images are those of the hard-hearted capitalist or the boring accountant. These caricatures are often found in current TV programmes; just look at your favourite soap opera. These stereotypes still exist despite the efforts of business people such as Anita Roddick to promote a more enlightened picture of modern business practice. The present government, especially the chancellor of the exchequer, is very keen to promote enterprise and the development of entrepreneurial activity. Business studies can contribute to both by developing a better understanding of how business and the economy operate and by fostering an enterprising approach. However, it is not just concerned with profit and loss. A business studies course will, for example, include consideration of social, consumer, health and safety and ethical issues. In many cases business studies courses have successfully incorporated a wide range of educational initiatives introduced by central government. Practical teaching approaches, different assessment strategies, the utilisation of infor mation and communications technology can all be found in a business studies course. The new Advanced Vocational Business, for example, provides numerous opportunities for the delivery of key skills. The development of links between education and business is at the core of many business courses Yet despite this record of success business studies is often treated as a second-class subject. Is it because business studies lecturers are too modest or are just too busy getting on with their jobs? Is it a reflection of the negative way in which business has been portrayed, and the anti-business culture which has developed in certain sectors of society? Is there still a feeling that business studies is not a real academic subject? What we need to do is to foster a more positive view of business which will, in turn, encourage greater understanding of a modern, vibrant economy. Lecturers can contribute to this by making sure that senior management is fully aware of the success of the subject. The government could assist by giving business studies a much higher profile and recognising the significant achievements which have taken place in one of the most relevant and successful subject areas. Additional funding and recognition would help. Inclusion rather than exclusion from major educational initiatives would be a start. So how about it Mr Blunkett and Mr Brown?  Ian Abbott is PGCE economics and business studies coordinator at the Institute of Education, University of Warwick.

webTitle: When Prince Charles went to night school

fields.headline: Gone to pot
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston delves into a muddy corner of the Prince of Wales' past
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston delves into a muddy corner of the Prince of Wales' past
fields.body:
Eton and Gordonstoun, eat your hearts out! Oxford and Cambridge - ya boo sucks with knobs on!

Further education has found its own royal connection. The sector's Cinderella years could soon be history.

No less a personage than the heir to the throne, Charles Prince of Wales, once attended a further education college, it is being claimed.

It all happened during those crazy 1960s days when the prince was an undergraduate at Cambridge University.

Flower power was budding. Student revolution was foaming. The old order was starting to totter. And His Royal Highness, legend has it, enrolled for an evening class in pottery.

One way or another pot was a bit of a buzz word at the time. There is no suggestion though that the prince stumbled on the clay craft in mistake for something else. He already had a bona fide interest in making things from wet clay which had started during his time at Gordonstoun, that rather bracing sounding public school in Scotland with the emphasis on fresh air.

The university didn't then - and probably still doesn't - teach this art, and so he popped down the road to what was then the Cambridgeshire College of Art and Technology (CCAT).

Alas, the Cambridgeshire College of Art and Technology has long since perished and all student records with it. Royal scholars will snuffle in vain for documentary evidence.

Nevertheless, yesterday, this didn't prevent the prince's being seriously considered for a prize on the strength of his ceramic salad days.

His Royal Highness has been nominated by Cambridge Regional College for one of the Association of Colleges' gold awards for former students who have made names for themselves. Why? Because the college is one of the offshoots of the Cambridgeshire College of Arts and Technology.

"I had no idea that Prince Charles had enrolled," admits Ann Limb, Cambridge Regional College's principal. "I was told by Mike Malone-Lee."

He is the vice-chancellor of the other offshoot of the Cambridgeshire College of Arts and Technology: Anglia Polytechnic University.

"It's certainly part of the mythology that the Prince did a pottery course while he was an undergraduate of Trinity College Cambridge," he says.

A vice-chancellor's word should be good enough. But Guardian Further needs harder proof. Where's the evidence, we ask.

"It's known, it's just that our records aren't very good," he replies.

What about survivors from that era? Surely somebody remembers a diffident young man and bodyguard joining their pottery class?

Ian Gordon, then an English lecturer at Cambridgeshire College of Arts and Technology, later dean of the arts school at Anglia Polytechnic University, recalls: "Everyone knew that Prince Charles, when he was an undergraduate, either in his first or second year, did an evening class for one term and it was in pottery.

"For security reasons it was asked that it should be kept quiet."

There are no records of what the prince actually made. Maybe he was doing the classic thing and saving a few shillings on Christmas presents.

Perhaps in some cupboard in the Queen's apartment in Buckingham Palace lurks a wonky vase which is hastily retrieved and put on a table when the eldest son comes for lunch.

Or perhaps the corgis take it in turn to trough from a bowl which isn't quite so round as the others but actually holds more.

Was the detective allowed to have a bash or did he have to watch everyone else having fun?

The committee yesterday considering the royal credentials for a gold award knew none of the answers. All it had was Ann Limb's citation: "I am sure that by being chosen as a Gold Award Winner, he would make a positive statement about the role which artistic and creative education plays in lifelong learning."

webTitle: School for brickies

fields.headline: School for brickies
fields.standfirst: Universities are using their muscle to insist building workers are trained, reports  John Crace
fields.trailText: Universities are using their muscle to insist building workers are trained, reports John Crace
fields.body:
Construction firms bidding for contracts in the lucrative university market may soon have to agree to get their staff properly trained as part of the deal.

The cost of the training would be shared between contractor and university, under a new scheme currently being trialled by Cambridge, Oxford, Bristol, UMIST and UCL.

Lawyers are still finalising three best practice clauses which would be included in every university construction contract if the pilot is successful, says David Adamson, director of estates for Cambridge university.

"But the main elements will be to establish what training the contractor has done that is relevant for the job in question, what extra training would the contractor do if they got the job that the client would not have to pay for and what training would the contractor want to do for the project that the client would have to pay for."

Collectively, the universities have a great deal of financial muscle; with over £3bn to spend on projects each year, they are one of this country's largest and most influential private sector construction clients and following on from the requirement for certification - mostly through the national Construction Skills Certification Scheme - which is becoming mandatory on most sites, the building industry is on the verge of a major cultural revolution.

"Construction does not have a certification ethos," says Jerry Lloyd, communications director for the Construction Industry Training Board (CITB). "The problem is not so much with the 16- and 17-year-olds who are leaving colleges with NVQs or SVQs but with older, existing workers, such as the 30- to 40-year- old brickies who have no formal training. However, this is changing; with on-site assessment and other training schemes hundreds of thousands of people may become qualified over the next few years."

The lack of qualified construction staff masks an even greater problem within the industry: a lack of staff in general. Jerry Lloyd estimates 370,000 more jobs will be required over the next five years; this works out at roughly 74,000 new recruits per year, of which 64,000 will replace those leaving the industry and 10,000 are new jobs due to the current construction boom. If these targets are not met, the CITB believes that skill shortages will emerge in occupations such as carpenters, joiners, bricklayers, plumbers and electricians.

Construction remains this country's largest industry, employing one in 14 members of the working population, but it has lost ground to other industries, such as IT, that offer better salaries and career prospects. Not to mention life expectancy; the accident rate in construction rose from 3.8 to 4.5 reported fatalities per 100,000 last year compared to a national average of 0.8 in all industries, down from 0.9. This year the industry has launched a major charm offensive to win back recruits; full-page adverts have appeared in the national press with training and job development well to the fore.

Much of the training will be provided by the industry itself, and the costs are unlikely to be passed on to the clients. Or if they are, the clients will gain in the long run. "The notion that the cheapest tender always wins is a mug's game," said Lloyd. "Better trained staff will produce a higher quality of workmanship as well as helping to eliminate hold-ups in supply chain management and architects' idiocies. This represents real savings to the client."

If the Cambridge-led project becomes an industry standard, there could be even better news ahead, with clients underwriting some of the job- specific training costs. "The scheme has got to be attractive to both parties," says Adamson. "Good construction companies will want to work with clients who offer these terms, not just because they will get some workforce training included, but because it's so much easier to work with thinking clients who understand the business."

webTitle: The first test for the Learning and Skills Council

fields.headline: Uneasy partners
fields.standfirst: Two species now prowl the new post-16 landscape, marking out their ground. Will they hunt together or will the fur fly?  Nick Tester  reports
fields.trailText: Two species now prowl the new post-16 landscape, marking out their ground. Will they hunt together or will the fur fly? Nick Tester reports
fields.body:
Amid the stream of government bumf about the new post-16 regime will soon appear something marked "protocol".

It sounds terribly important. In fact this key guidance to the 47 Learning and Skills Councils is crucial, because before they can plan any type of coherent training provision they need to talk to all sorts of organisations - from colleges to voluntary and community groups and those in the private sector.

Ministers believe the emerging structure will only get a decent foundation to succeed if the Learning and Skills Councils are first equipped with the right language to perform in a collaborative way, and if they have sensitive listening ears to pick up the vital, though often conflicting, signals pointing to strategic training provision.

The intended source of intelligence for the councils are the 101 Learning Partnerships being set up across the country. These voluntary bodies have been invested with two important functions, according to Baroness Blackstone.

"Firstly, they will reach out into local communities and find out what local learning and skills needs really are," she declares. "They will be able to provide the new local Learning and Skills Councils with invaluable information and advice on individuals' and employers' needs."

The Learning Partnerships' second role is to offer a "forum for collaboration" so that all the providers can work in a harmonious way, delivering cost-effective training, leaving no glaring gaps and avoiding wasteful duplication.

Sounds simple but, inevitably, the picture is quite complicated, mainly because there is no consistent pattern. Some Learning Partnerships - the invention 18 months ago of former lifelong learning minister George Mudie - are in advanced stages of operation, but many more remain non-existent and there is little immediate likelihood of them be setting up.

Georgina Cowen of York Consulting Limited, a Leeds-based organisation that is in the middle of a three-year programme to evaluate the Learning Partnerships, cites Wiltshire/Swindon and Bournemouth/Dorset as two areas where the partnership ideal has moved on quickly, and where coherent notions about provision are coming together. "But in other areas there is confusion," she says, "and the Learning Partnerships have struggled to get their act together."

Her group, which has been commissioned to do the study on behalf of the DfEE, laments a "nightmare" scenario, although she is also at pains to claim there is a lot of positive stuff going on.

"The Learning Partnerships came out at a time when policy was rather confused. But with the new legislation that has changed and, already, the benefits can been seen to be enormous.

"The most exciting thing is the way they can reach out and involve non-traditional training organisations, charities and religious bodies, especially in the area of basic skills teaching. They have the potential to pull these resources together and ensure far more people are engaged with the learning environment," she says.

According to Dr John Brennan of the Association of Colleges, less than one-third are effective. "The government is trying to encourage partnerships in all sorts of directions, not just to do with learning. But the reality on the ground is that while some Learning Partnerships have settled down, many others have not done so because there is a lack of commitment or an unwillingness to behave as partners in the new venture."

Too often, Brennan adds, the rewards are simply not clear enough to justify the time and effort needed by personnel and other senior managers to bang heads and reach rational planning decisions. "But there are opportunities here as well as threats and anyone failing to adapt will be quickly left behind."

This is a serious worry for ministers and their official words of encouragement will attempt to raise the game, by pointing out how the Learning Partnerships are seen as a powerful voice, exerting huge influence over the way the Learning and Skills Councils spend the total of some £6bn at their disposal.

Part of the problem is uncertainty over who actually takes the initiative. Words like "lead body" are being discouraged since the partnership is anticipated to comprise of equals, with representatives of the local education authority, further education college, local trade unions and private trainers, including employers, all sharing the load. A bit of a bureaucratic burden, particularly as the Learning Partnerships need to move fast if they are to act as a conduit for the Learning and Skills Councils, warns Sue Taylor of the Learning and Skills Development Agency (formerly the Further Education Development Agency).

"They have a very useful part to play in the new structure and some strong relationships have already been formed. Now the task is not just getting up and running, but giving value."

The big question, however, is how they will dovetail with the Learning and Skills Councils and avoid petty rivalry and other distractions. Ministers think there is no reason why these two "distinct but complementary" organisations can't work together to map out the sort of intricate and increasingly flexible learning facilities demanded locally. Certainly the Learning and Skills Councils, usually covering large geographical areas, will need a firm grasp of the local labour market, not least if they are to play their part in meeting national training targets. And they reckon only Learning Partnerships can give this information, the advice will state.

Helen Gilchrist, principal of Bury College remains positive. "We have a history in Bury of talking to each other, so our Learning Partnership has been able to make very good progress in terms of initiatives and promoting post-16 learning, especially among adults," she explains. "It is proving to be a very good vehicle for getting people to work together."

She also thinks the Learning Partnerships will have an important job carrying forward the recommendations of the new area-wide inspections of learning courses.

Tensions will rise, however, when the Learning Partnerships are forced to rationalise some of this provision.

"The test will be when they have to allocate significant amounts of money, but there still fails to be enough to go round everyone," Gilchrist warns.

"It has been a frustrating year for Learning Partnerships," says Cowen. "That's why the new guidance from the DfEE is so vitally important. It will give the partnerships the boost that is surely required and help us measure how they are facing the challenge before them."

webTitle: Lecturers' protest leaves students in the lurch

fields.headline: Poor marks
fields.standfirst: It was only a lecturer's protest. But for one group of Liverpool John Moores students the crude, contradictory exam paper was the last straw.  Lee Elliot Major reports
fields.trailText: It was only a lecturer's protest. But for one group of Liverpool John Moores students the crude, contradictory exam paper was the last straw. Lee Elliot Major reports
fields.body:
The students on the BSc degree course in outdoor and science education at Liverpool John Moores University had been forewarned that their examination paper would be hand-written. But nothing could have prepared them for the paper they were confronted with as they nervously took their seats last December for an exam on "environmental issues and change" - a paper that would contribute to their final degree marks.

The paper will go down as one of the shoddiest examinations ever to be presented to a group of university students. Six questions were untidily scrawled over two sheets of photocopied A4 paper; words and phrases in the questions had been crossed out and replaced by others written in margins; some parts of questions had been crossed out altogether. The presentation would be considered unsuitable for revision notes, or student answer sheets, let alone the examination itself.

To top it all, accompanying one question was a remark (from the university's academic moderating board) complaining that the question was ambiguous and unclear. The question, however, remained unchanged.

For a group of the 120 students who took the exam, it was the last straw after a series of disappointments during the four-year course. "If this had been a one-off incident, we would probably have swallowed it, but there have been problems throughout the four-year course," said one of the students, all of whom wish to remain anonymous.

The degree produces graduates who can teach outdoor activities such as climbing as well as science, and so teacher-training placements are an integral part of the course. But many students question whether the placements were situated in the ideal places for students to learn their trade. Most schools were more than 50 miles away from Liverpool, and many were under special measures after receiving criticism from teaching inspectors. One student was even placed in a school that was closing two weeks after his practice finished.

Then there was the case of the lecturer who didn't turn up to any lectures. Unfortunately, the same lecturer was in charge of a field trip, which was aborted after it was realised only too late that no accommodation had been booked for the students.

The university says that it has been unaware of any of these problems, as no complaints have been made up to now.

All this changed after that exam. As the students huddled together afterwards to discuss what action to take, they faced a number of dilemmas. Some argued that to speak up would only belittle the degree. But others had had enough.

Apart from anything else, the exam paper inevitably affected the performance of many students. "Question three comes up every year," complained one, "but I didn't answer it because of the remarks over its ambiguity. I answered another question even though I hadn't revised for it."

The exam paper had not been typed up as part of ongoing industrial action against cuts and reorganisation at Liverpool John Moores. It is a familiar story in the academic world: budget shortfalls, voluntary redundancies, rationalisation. The lecturer who set the exam is a member of the academic union, Natfhe, and delivered it in hand-written form as a protest against the rationalisation.

A key accusation from the academic appears to be that the university does not have enough administration staff to type up examination papers - an accusation that is flatly denied by the university management.

As far as the students are concerned, the university should not offer such a course if it cannot deliver it. "It's a bit like me turning up to teach a rock-climbing session and having no rope to teach with," one argued. University officials agree that it was unacceptable to present an exam in such a poor state.

"It was absolutely appalling that any students should be presented with a paper like that," said Janet Martin, press officer for the university. Martin stressed that this was the action of one member of staff. She also said that no students would suffer, now that they had appealed to the university.

A module assessment board will decide what action to take in two weeks' time. No one yet knows how the board will resolve the issue. Will it make the students take the exam again? Should all the marks be upped by 15%, or should everyone receive one score? Whatever the conclusions, the outcome is likely to leave the students with a sour taste in their mouths.

There are other complaints concerning the four-year course. At the end of one module, one lecturer told the students that they wouldn't go too far wrong if they revised the 1997 examination paper. He was true to his word: the 1997 paper was all but repeated - with one extra question added.

The students also claim that they were told on enrolling that they could choose to finish the degree in three years - without the teacher training element. But this option was later withdrawn. The university, however, denies that it ever offered students such an option.

The upshot is that the students will not be able to benefit from the financial incentives that have been introduced by the government to attract more people on to teacher training courses. The government now offers £6,000 for students on one-year PGCE courses. But the students were told in no uncertain terms that they might not be taken on again if they finished the four-year BSc course a year early and tried to reapply for PGCE places at the university.

"We could have been earning a salary which would help to pay off our debts - rather than taking out extra loans," said one student. "The university moved the goal posts after the course started."

But nothing could have prepared them for the paper they were confronted with as they nervously took their seats last December for an exam on "environmental issues and change" - a paper that would contribute to their final degree marks. The paper will go down as one of the shoddiest examinations ever to be presented to a group of university students. Six questions were untidily scrawled over two sheets of photocopied A4 paper; words and phrases in the questions had been crossed out and replaced by others written in margins; some parts of questions had been crossed out altogether. The presentation would be considered unsuitable for revision notes, or student answer sheets, let alone the examination itself. To top it all, accompanying one question was a remark (from the university's academic moderating board) complaining that the question was ambiguous and unclear. The question, however, remained unchanged. For a group of the 120 students who took the exam, it was the last straw after a series of disappointments during the four-year course. "If this had been a one-off incident, we would probably have swallowed it, but there have been problems throughout the four-year course," said one of the students, all of whom wish to remain anonymous. The degree produces graduates who can teach outdoor activities such as climbing as well as science, and so teacher-training placements are an integral part of the course. But many students question whether the placements were situated in the ideal places for students to learn their trade. Most schools were more than 50 miles away from Liverpool, and many were under special measures after receiving criticism from teaching inspectors. One student was even placed in a school that was closing two weeks after his practice finished. Then there was the case of the lecturer who didn't turn up to any lectures. Unfortunately, the same lecturer was in charge of a field trip, which was aborted after it was realised only too late that no accommodation had been booked for the students. The university says that it has been unaware of any of these problems, as no complaints have been made up to now. All this changed after that exam. As the students huddled together afterwards to discuss what action to take, they faced a number of dilemmas. Some argued that to speak up would only belittle the degree. But others had had enough. Apart from anything else, the exam paper inevitably affected the performance of many students. "Question three comes up every year," complained one, "but I didn't answer it because of the remarks over its ambiguity. I answered another question even though I hadn't revised for it." The exam paper had not been typed up as part of ongoing industrial action against cuts and reorganisation at Liverpool John Moores. It is a familiar story in the academic world: budget shortfalls, voluntary redundancies, rationalisation. The lecturer who set the exam is a member of the academic union, Natfhe, and delivered it in hand-written form as a protest against the rationalisation. A key accusation from the academic appears to be that the university does not have enough administration staff to type up examination papers - an accusation that is flatly denied by the university management. As far as the students are concerned, the university should not offer such a course if it cannot deliver it. "It's a bit like me turning up to teach a rock-climbing session and having no rope to teach with," one argued. University officials agree that it was unacceptable to present an exam in such a poor state. "It was absolutely appalling that any students should be presented with a paper like that," said Janet Martin, press officer for the university. Martin stressed that this was the action of one member of staff. She also said that no students would suffer, now that they had appealed to the university. A module assessment board will decide what action to take in two weeks' time. No one yet knows how the board will resolve the issue. Will it make the students take the exam again? Should all the marks be upped by 15%, or should everyone receive one score? Whatever the conclusions, the outcome is likely to leave the students with a sour taste in their mouths. He was true to his word: the 1997 paper was all but repeated - with one extra question added. The students also claim that they were told on enrolling that they could choose to finish the degree in three years - without the teacher training element. But this option was later withdrawn. The university, however, denies that it ever offered students such an option. The upshot is that the students will not be able to benefit from the financial incentives that have been introduced by the government to attract more people on to teacher training courses. The government now offers £6,000 for students on one-year PGCE courses. webTitle: UK Fulbright has good reason to be concerned with Congress changes

fields.headline: Altered states in America
fields.standfirst: UK Fulbright has good reason to be concerned with Congress changes, says  Huw Richards
fields.trailText: UK Fulbright has good reason to be concerned with Congress changes, says Huw Richards
fields.body:
James Moore still recounts with horror an incident following the last time the US swung to the right: "A young Republican staffer told me 'We don't need you any more. We've won the war economically, politically and militarily.' It was naive, but very worrying."

That experience six years ago helps to explain why Moore and his staff at the UK Fulbright Commission will watch the transition in Washington DC, and in particular in Congress, with more than academic interest. It did no harm that President Clinton attended Oxford (albeit on a Rhodes rather than a Fulbright grant) or that their programmes are named after their creator Senator William Fulbright - Arkansas's most famous political son before Clinton - but funding for their long-established reciprocal postgraduate scholarship programme comes from Congress.

Moore, executive director of the commission since 1993, says: "People assume we have an endowment. In fact we are publicly funded - two thirds of our money comes from the US and one third from Britain."

While the proportions were fixed by treaty in 1948, the actual amounts of money are not and the US grant is reviewed annually. It has been static in cash terms - a real terms cut - over the past decade.

Many national Fulbright commissions have been cut heavily and Moore reckons Britain has done well to retain its funding in cash terms. Last year's US grant was $845,000.

Having a key paymaster prone to mood swings does concentrate the mind: "We need to convince the people who pay for the programme that they are getting value for money. The best way of doing that is to show that it brings money into the US or makes people abroad think better of it."

A useful element in this is their US-UK Grant and Education Advisory Programme, reckoned to have been consulted by 70% of the 8,000 British students - each believed to be worth $25,000 a year - currently in the US.

Nevertheless, the scholars - this year 22 from the US and 23 from the UK - on the one-year programme are the most important advertisement. British alumni include academics such as Brian Fender, Michael Atiyah and the late Malcolm Bradbury, politician Charles Kennedy, choreographer Siobhan Davies, writer Peter Ackroyd and the architect Richard Rogers.

While well established, the programme is far from unchanging. Every two to three years, members of the commission (chaired by the US Embassy's Public Affairs counsellor Pamela Smith) and staff go into retreat to review the programme fully. This has led to a cut in the number of scholarships to a little over 20 in each direction, aimed at making them attractive to the very best candidates.

In the 1999 annual report, Moore characterised the identikit Fulbrighter "a first-class honours degree... but will also have been president of his or her student body, have been leader of a university voluntary organisation and an active participant in team sports."

One of Moore's most important innovations on joining Fulbright in 1993 was to move away from a heavily academic focus - 80% of the 600 Fulbright alumni in Who's Who are academics - to attract future business leaders as well. Today there are plenty of MBAs, many sponsored by business, among UK scholars.

But success also brings new headaches - one issue likely to figure at the next retreat later this year is how to compete in a world in which talented 20-somethings may be offered huge Wall Street salaries.

A longer-established problem has been how to counteract Oxbridge dominance on both sides of the Atlantic. Even though the programme is graduate-only, interest in the case of Laura Spence, the sixth-former denied an Oxford place who went instead to Harvard, is seen as one explanation for a 41% increase in hits on the commission's website last year.

In large red letters, the site carried the message: "The Fulbright programme is not just for Oxbridge". Moore says: "Not enough of our scholars come from non-Oxbridge universities, but then not enough non-Oxbridge candidates apply."

Oxbridge accounts for nearly 30 per cent of applicants - as Moore points out "much higher than the proportion of graduates from Oxbridge". He thinks one way of selling the programme to other universities would be getting articles about its programme into the student press, but has had little success so far.

"We tend to run into complaints that we are elitist - and of course we are. But we think there are many more students with high academic qualifications, leadership skills and an interest in extracurricular activities outside Oxbridge than in, and we want them."

Americans come from a wider range of universities, but their applications create a similar problem. Moore explains: "Most want to go to Oxford. This is partly because they have an excellent operation in the US, and partly because of Clinton."

But faced with ferocious competition - there are around 700 applications for 20 to 25 places - this may not be a wise choice: "Somebody who says they want to go to Southampton because of its excellence in oceanography has clearly done their homework and will have the edge in selection over someone who wants to go to Oxford just 'because it's Oxford'," says Moore.

Wherever they go, he has little doubt about the programme's main benefit: "It isn't just that they learn about another country. They also learn a great deal about their own country and how others see it. And that is particularly valuable for Americans."
