webTitle: Higher browsing

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: News and research from around the country
fields.body:
The third degree

 Oxford has been doing its best to modernise its image and counter accusations that bureaucracy is turning the university into a lame duck. So on Sunday night the fellows of All Souls, that bastion of intellectual rigour, were due to be seen parading around the quad bearing the Lord Mallard on a chair and singing the Mallard Song.

It only happens once a century - in 1901 the Lord Mallard was Cosmo Lang, a future Archbishop of Canterbury (strange rituals can be a good career move, ask any mason). And for the first time women fellows will be mallarding - that's modernisation for you. All is revealed at: www.all-souls.ox.ac.uk/events/mallard.html

 Bill Taylor's group investigating whether students should be charged extra fees to help finance universities is having to look over its shoulders. As general election fever hots up, all sorts of proposals for Labour's expected second parliamentary term are being aired. In a Fabian Society report on the reform of private schools, Professor Harry Brighouse argues that extra university fees could yield the money needed to boost spending in state schools. "People are spending the money before we have even worked out how we might raise it," said a bemused Taylor last week.

The doomsday scenario for university heads is that they incite the wrath of the nation for charging fees, only for the money to be siphoned off elsewhere. The group's report will be delivered to vice-chancellors in March, and a conference to discuss the conclusions is set for early April - a good month before the general election is due.

 Stories? gossips? Contact us:

donald.macleod@theguardian.com

lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News

Student dropouts could be costing the taxpayer £200m a year, MPs were told last week. The estimate came from Professor Mantz Yorke, who produced the only major study on student dropouts two years ago, as he gave evidence to an inquiry into retention rates in universities by the House of Commons education committee. Official figures show that 17% of students fail to finish degrees, but dropout rates vary dramatically for different universities and colleges.

Yorke also called on universities to reform the first year of degree courses, which often involve examinations for students as early as the first term. Two-thirds of students bail out of degree courses during the first year. Yorke said that more support was needed for new students, particularly those from working-class backgrounds.

Research news

Hunky science

How can men make themselves irresistable to women? Put on a deep booming voice, mention that you already have a partner and pretend you have recently been down the gym. So, at least, say a series of academic studies published in recent weeks.

United we stand

Concern that the forces of devolution would bring down the UK-wide Research Assessment Exercise have proved unfounded. Mirroring the decisions by the English funding chiefs, the Scottish Higher Education Funding Council has concluded that most block research grants for Scottish universities should continue to be allocated on the back of the results of the assessment.

Universe

History lesson

For those huddled masses of historians yearning to be free (or at least get a better job), the US is once more the land of opportunity. Job openings in the field increased 15% in 1999-2000 over the previous academic year, according to the American Historical Association. It notes it is not just the rich private institutions who are hiring, and that while most posts are in American history, East Asia is also in demand.

Hole in the mouth

Japanese police authorities arrested a former private university professor and a medical college professor on charges of leaking national dentistry examination questions. In response, the president of the private Ohu University has said that he will resign.

webTitle: On the board

fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
The curriculum development committee meets again within the fortnight. At the last, I failed miserably to raise satisfactorily the question of the evangelical Christian flavour of school assemblies. The position of Mr Richardson, the head, was unclear since his deputy, Mrs Mills, did all the talking. She, evidently, is an enthusiast. Mr Richardson remains inscrutable, but as on so many aspects of the school's life, he betrays a weary passivity: seeking the path of least resistance seems to define his leadership.

This approach to the management of the school seems inadequate, even maddening. Somehow, inexperienced as I am as a governor, I expect some more inspiring example from him. But, at these committee meetings, I begin to acquire some insight into why the head might seem so immobilised.

The sheer volume of paperwork is daunting. Every subject on the school curriculum has to have both a policy and an action plan written up. Without going into the detail of content, the policy defines broadly the aims and objectives in that subject: chiefly, the targets for levels of attainment at various stages. Then the action plan is more like a spreadsheet that sets out a series of measures, with dates, by which the school can judge whether it is "delivering" on the policy. These, of course, need updating every year at least, which essentially means a constant process of reviewing and rewriting.

Clearly, this is all part of a long, historical drive towards better management and accountability, enforced by the more rigorous school inspection system and the publication of Ofsted reports and league tables. Yet the jargon of targets and performance indicators is peculiarly disabling: you look at this stuff and there seems to be nothing to comment on; it all looks well and good, but it tells you nothing about what is actually being taught in the classroom. These policies simply establish a series of hoops through which the school can be seen to jump.

There is something oddly demoralising about this - and, of course, it represents a huge amount of extra paperwork for the senior management team, which is already bombarded by directives from the education department. I can't keep up with all the printed material that comes at governors, and this can only be a fraction of what the headteacher receives. No wonder Mr Richardson has acquired a certain philosophic passivity.

Some of his staff are less quiescent. This meeting soon devolves into a long moan on the part of teachers about how prescribed - and proscribed - their lessons now are by the national curriculum.

"All the creative stuff is out the window," complains Miss Roberts. "When we were doing medieval history, we used to make shields - you know, heraldic shields. The children loved it, making up their own emblems, and they learned something too - about the barons and feudalism and all that. But now there's no time: making shields is not in the curriculum, so you can't do it."

"Oh, surely you can bend the rules a bit?" I ask naively.

"No, you really can't," she answers, warming to her theme. "If I had an inspector in my class and they saw the shields on the wall, they'd know it wasn't part of the curriculum. They'd want to know when, how and why. It'd be a mark against me."

"That really seems a shame," I agree.

"All of us who have been in teaching for years are really fed up," chips in Mrs Mills. "Everything now is dictated by the bureaucrats at the DfEE. And that Blunkett, he's such a... a... Tory!"

I am astonished by this outbreak of Spart-ishness from the deputy head. Frankly, I'd taken her for a bit of a Tory.

Mr Richardson looks resigned.

webTitle: Why formal lessons for preschoolers may be a good idea

fields.headline: A is for aim high
fields.standfirst: Last week, formal lessons for preschoolers came under fire. But many parents - and a few teachers - like to see three-year-olds sitting in rows tracing the alphabet.  Joanna Moorhead  finds out why
fields.trailText: Last week, formal lessons for preschoolers came under fire. But many parents - and a few teachers - like to see three-year-olds sitting in rows tracing the alphabet. Joanna Moorhead finds out why
fields.body:
Take two nursery schools, two miles apart. On the surface they're much the same. Little feet pound the corridors, excited voices fill the air. Colourful artwork on every wall, coat pegs at child-height. Miniature washrooms, busy noticeboards. Display tables and home corners. Smiling staff, racks of books.

But while much unites the private Blundells in Battersea with its state counterpart, Balham Nursery School, a philosophical gulf divides them. Blundells is, in its own motto, "a traditional teaching nursery": chat with principal Susan Stevens about the establishment she founded 10 years ago and within minutes she'll have mentioned how advanced her charges are educationally, how "every child who leaves here has a reading ability two years above his or her actual age", how the local schools rave about how well her alumni get on. Of course Stevens wants you to know her children are happy and that they have consideration for others and are self-confident: but their academic abilities are her first boast.

Contrast Balham, where head Ann Douglas's claim is that, while the children who leave her school may not necessarily be able to read and write, they have learned how to learn, and what the purpose of learning is. Self-confidence and self-respect are the watchwords at Balham: consideration for others, and being aware of others' needs, are given a high priority. Douglas rejects any suggestion that the nursery is "free and easy" in allowing children to choose their own activities and in taking a lead from the pupils rather than imposing a structure on their time: in fact, she says, that illusion belies the strong observational basis on which staff operate. Children have the chance to choose what they do, but they are watched and what they choose is noted: if they need help to extend their play, and to move on, it is given.

At Blundells the timetable includes French and ballet, and from the age of three children have two half-hour formal lessons a day in which they learn their phonic alphabet, or to recognise their numbers. They complete workbooks in which they practise pre-writing skills and, later, actual writing skills. "They love it," maintains Stevens. "Often what they achieve is far ahead of our expectations, and of their own and their parents' expectations. There's so much children can learn at this stage - my granddaughter (a pupil at the school) knew her phonic alphabet by the age of two years and two months. We've got two-and-a-half year-olds who can count up to 20 in French, and who know all their colours - even in French!"

All of which makes Blundells sound suspiciously like the sort of establishment that Barry Sheerman MP, chair of the House of Commons education subcommittee, last week denounced as being too formal and pushy. He said he had witnessed three- and four-year-olds sitting in rows tracing the alphabet, and was quoted as saying he'd be "happy" to see nurseries of that type go out of business.

But whatever the education sub-committee has to say about it, that's unlikely to happen. Blundells and many like it are thriving: Stevens says her waiting list is a mile long and if you don't get your infant down as a small baby, she or he will never get a place. That's because there are plenty of parents around who do like to see concrete results, even from a pre-school. And it isn't just down to boasting: many parents do believe, and Stevens believes this too, that children who have a grounding in the three Rs do better at their primary or prep schools. "It gives them a flying start," she says.

Graeme Gaughan agrees. His daughter Mya is three and a half, attends Blundells and is already starting to read and write. "They give her worksheets and make sure her hand writing is neat and tidy and legible," he says. "At the age of three, I think that's quite acceptable. They put a big emphasis on education and I think it's very sensible. I've a nephew who went to a conventional nursery and I don't think he was anything like as academically prepared for primary school as Mya is going to be. "I have to admit I was a bit dubious about paying out £60 a term for French lessons, but it has paid off and she can now count to 20 in French and knows a lot of French songs. I didn't have these opportunities when I was a child and it's great to be able to provide them for my own daughter."

French isn't an option at Balham Nursery. There, staff put a strong emphasis on taking their cue from the children themselves when it comes to setting up themes and activities. Deputy head Helen McAuley explains that just now there's a penchant among the children for making dens and hidey holes in the garden and around the house. "We could just let them get on with it, or we could ban it - but we do neither," she says. "What we do is follow their cue: if they like hidey holes we'll use them as a tool. So we've made dens around the place and put books and pens and paper in them. We're trying to use what interests them to extend their play and to give them opportunities to learn through it."

While the outdoor space at Blundells is a small, Tarmac-covered area where children are taken twice a day to play, at Balham Nursery the philosophy is that the large outdoor space the nursery is lucky enough to have is an "outdoor classroom". The children have continual access to it (except at mealtimes and group time), and Ann Douglas believes a lot of informal learning goes on there. "There's so much negotiating, so many opportunities to learn about sharing," she says. "And a child who doesn't want to sit indoors and start writing letters might very well decide to write 'keep out' on the den he's making, or 'one way' on the traffic route he's setting up for the cars. This is learning at their pace, in context. We're not making learning something artificial, in a setting apart from the world they're part of. This is learning grounded in their own experience."

The milk table sums up the Balham Nursery philosophy. The cartons of milk and a jug of water are set out on a table in the middle of the nursery, and the children have access to it all morning. They have to decide when they want a drink (learning to meet their own needs), take and open a carton and insert a straw (fine motor skills required), then label it with their name (letter recognition).

"Young children don't learn in a subject-based way," says Ann Douglas. "They learn through their senses, and through talking and asking questions. What we're trying to do here is build on what they already know, and to give them an environment in which they feel secure and valued."

Like Blundells, Balham is over-subscribed. Most parents who've had one child there do all they can to secure a place for younger offspring. "My eldest daughter went to a private nursery where I think so much of what they did was to make parents feel they were getting their money's worth," says Annette, a mother of four. "She was holding a pen and learning to write at three. At the time I quite liked it, but now she's nine I think it has actually impeded her writing in the long run. At Balham Nursery, where my son went, it looks like it's all play but I think there's a lot more going on than that. Helen said to me once that it's no good sitting them down and forcing them to write at that age - what you need to do is introduce writing as a purposeful play activity, like writing in the home corner, and I do feel that's the right approach. Dominic is in reception class now and he's really enthusiastic about learning and about reading and writing, so it certainly seems to have worked."

Margaret Lochrie, chief executive of the Pre-School Learning Alliance, shares many of Annette's reservations about formal pre-schools. "To some extent it's horses for courses - there's certainly a huge range of ability among three- and four-year-olds," she admits.

"But we're against the over-formalised approach. Giving children of three worksheets is a waste of time when they can't even hold a pencil. And they won't get anything from the phonic alphabet until they have an understanding of the printed word, and know that text goes from left to right across a page. Our real concern is that these things are being introduced before the basics have been established, and there's evidence that doing that may be counter-productive, or possibly even harmful.

"We're not saying formal learning for pre-schoolers should never happen, but you've got to be very, very careful about it. In general, one-to-one attention and the opportunity for lots of play is far more important at this stage than phonics and number work."

webTitle: If you ask me...about repeating a GCSE year

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My son is in year 10 this year. He is 14 and the youngest in his class. His performance is OK, but I feel he is being stretched by the demands of his study. I am also concerned that being young, he might not get the high GCSE grades he aspires to, while if the commencement of his GCSEs is delayed for one year, he will certainly obtain such grades. Would you advise me to postpone his GCSEs a year, in order to get better grades? And will he still be able to do his GCSEs at school, rather than at college, given that his date of birth is in the middle of August 1986?
fields.trailText: Should my son postpone his GCSEs a year in order to get better grades?
fields.body:
Michael J Cooper, headteacher, The Latymer School, London

There is no set answer to your problem. However, it is essential you talk to your son's school - his head of year or a deputy headteacher. In my experience, very few pupils suffer from repeating a school year, provided they can be accepted, and they accept the new social group of pupils. Even if he does repeat a year, there is no guarantee that his GCSE grades will improve significantly. If he is conscientious and hard-working, I should expect only a marginal difference.

My concern would centre on his maturity to cope with work in years 12 and 13. This will require a much more self-disciplined and personal approach to study that generally comes with maturity. Any decision must involve a three-way discussion between yourself, your son and the school.

Factors that should be considered are teachers' current predictions for success at GCSE; evidence of likely success from cognitive ability tests (Cats) and key stage 3 Sat results, together with your son's approach to study and school life in general.

In the end the decision must be one with which you and your son are happy rather than being based upon the possibility of better GCSE grades. Grades are important, but so is the need to develop personal skills, eg. leadership, teamwork, time management, so necessary to future employment. These can so often be influenced by our social group as well as by the opportunities offered outside lessons or in the community.

Prof Helen Cowie, educational psychologist at the University of Surrey

The first point I would make is, what does your son feel about this? You say you feel he is being stretched - but does he feel he's being stretched? And is he more stretched by his studies than the other youngsters around him? Schoolwork is designed to stretch young people and that isn't necessarily a sign there's a problem. How does your son get on with his peer group? Is he happy and does he have lots of friends? Basically, if he's happy, I'd leave him where he is. He may surprise you and not do too badly at GCSE.

The only reason to move him, in my opinion, would be if there was something really serious going on - bullying, for example. Otherwise, I'd think very carefully about moving him away from friends who he's happy with. It sounds as though you're very anxious, which is understandable, but do think about whether what you've outlined is a problem for your son, or for you.

George Turnbull of the Assessment and Qualifications Alliance, examining board

There's certainly no age limit to when you take your GCSEs - you can take them as young or as old as you like. From the age point of view, holding him back wouldn't be a problem, but from other points of view it might be. As soon as you do that, you'll be labelling your child as "different", and that's not necessarily going to be good for him. It's true that children mature at different ages, and it's true that the way the academic year is organised means August-born youngsters are virtually a year younger than some of their counterparts in class, but that doesn't necessarily affect their performance.

As you're worried, though, why not consider getting a tutor to give your son that little extra bit of help that is probably all he needs? Bear in mind that by the time he reaches his A-levels, the age disparity will be even less important than it is now - so even if he gets Bs and Cs in his GCSEs rather than As, it should be making less of a difference by A-level.

Next week:

The ideal time for my family to take our annual holiday this year overlaps one week with the autumn term. I'd rather not take my children out of school (they'll be going into years 3 and 5 at primary), but I don't think it will do them any harm. My children's head makes clear she takes a dim view of parents requesting time off in term time, but can she stop me?

Do you have a problem with your childÕs education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each fortnight we are asking leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your ÒproblemsÓ, marked ÒIf you ask meÓ, to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, faxed to 0171-239 9933, or e-mailed to: education.letters@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Leader: let children suggest the schools they want

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.standfirst:
Let them suggest the schools they want

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Let them suggest the schools they want.
fields.body:
The government cannot get enough of educational initiatives. Citizenship classes, value-added league tables, reducing class sizes and extending literacy hour to secondary schools are all on secretary of state for education's agenda. Before embarking on any of these innovations, teachers' unions, academics, businesses and occasionally parents are consulted. The only people who are not being consulted about these changes are those they effect - the children.

In no other area of public life is the consumer of a service so unrepresented. No local authority or voluntary organisation can secure government funding for any project without first proving that it has undergone a thorough "consultation process". So why are schoolchildren never consulted when new educational measures are introduced or on the rare occasion when a new school is built? Why are children not given a voice in the future of their education?

In 1967, they were. Our sister paper, the Observer, ran a competition called The School I'd Like. Almost 1,000 school pupils submitted entries proposing an educational establishment of their dreams. More than 30 years later, the Guardian is running a second School I'd Like competition. It is a chance for young people themselves to propose changes for the classrooms of the coming century.

It may be an even harder challenge than it was in 1967. Sats exams, Ofsted inspections and the national curriculum leave little leeway for independent work. The burden upon both teachers and children is to meet targets and satisfy league tables. Their timetable is tight. But unless we take time to ask the children what they hope to gain from the minimum 13 years they will spend being educated at the taxpayers' expense, we will never get it right. We hope the School I'd Like competition will initiate and encourage a consultation process with children. It is then up to the adults at the Department of Education to listen to them.

webTitle: So you want to learn... brewing

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: Brewing
fields.trailText: Brewing
fields.body:
Scushe me. (Hic)! Yes, what?

D'you work (hic) in that big brewery over there? Yes.

You a brewer then? That's right, and if you don't mind...

Thasha luvverly job innit? I'm late, I've got to...

Luvverly, luvverly job. Yes, thank you, now I must...

You make beer then (hic)? Yes, that's right, now...

How djew get tha luvverly job? Look, I've got to...

No, go on, tell us. How djew become a brewery then? Brewer! The word's brewer.

Thash right. An' how djew get that then? Actually my official title is technical brewer.

Ooooh! Tenticle brewer, ay? Washthat then? Well, it recognises that brewing is a biochemical process.

Yeah. Often tashtes like it, in all. I mean it involves mixing malted barley and other cereals with water, boiling the mixture with hops, cooling it and then fermenting with yeast. This is a much simplified explanation but it highlights the many processes involved.

Jolly goo'. But what djew do? In large breweries the technical brewer takes responsibility for one aspect of the brewing process. In small speciality breweries he or she is likely to take overall responsibility for the whole process, including quality assurance, research and product development.

Ver' good. And how djew get into that? Entrants to the industry are predominantly graduates in chemistry, biotechnology, biochemistry or microbiology.

Wha' just to make a pint of beer? Certainly.

What about training? People starting out in the brewing industry are expected to gain two professional qualifications set by the Institute of Brewing.

Wharrare they? The Associate Membership Examination, which covers all the major scientific and engineering processes involved in brewing and requires a mixture of academic study and on the job training. On completion the candidate becomes an associate member of the Institute of Brewing. The Diploma master brewer, an expert level qualification which follows on from the Associate Membership Examination is usually taken after at least four years in the industry.

Wharrabout pay? Salaries start at £15-20,000.

(Hic).

Telephone: 020-7486 4831

Website (which has some good careers resources): www.blra.co.uk

 Institute of Brewing, 33 Clarges Street, London W1Y 8EE

Telephone: 020-7499 8144

 International Brewers' Guild, 8 Ely Place, Holborn, London, EC1 6SD

Telephone 020-7405 4565

 learndirect 0800 100900 www.learndirect.co.uk may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

webTitle: Resources: Key stage 1 - Light and dark

fields.headline: Chase your shadow and dodge the sun
fields.trailText: Resources: Key stage 1, light and dark
fields.body:
If you are outside on a sunny day, you will see your shadow on the ground. Your shadow is there because light cannot travel though you. Shadows are made when something blocks the light. If you look around, you will see other objects that have shadows too. Light cannot travel through anything that is not see-through. We say these things are opaque. We can use shadows to help us tell the time.

Do you know what makes shadows?

* Shadows are formed when a person or opaque object stands in the path of light from the sun or strong light. * Shadows are usually the shape of the object that is forming them but they can be stretched or made shorter depending on where the light is coming from.

* To find out more about this, draw around your shadow at different times of the day and see what happens.

Making a shadow clock

You will need: a pencil, a strip of wood (about 5cm wide), and a lump of Plasticine.

* Do this on a sunny morning but don't look at the sun directly.

* Stick the plasticine at one end of the wood.

* Press the pencil into the Plasticine. You have made a clock.

* Take your clock outside and put it down so it faces the sun.

* Tilt the wood until the pencil makes a shadow across it. Mark the shadow on the wood.

* One hour later, mark the shadow. Do this every hour.

How could you use the clock to tell the time?

Are shadows always the same?

Shadows are cast by the sun as its position in the sky changes. The length of the shadows also changes through the day. The shadows will be shortest in the middle of the day when the sun is directly overhead. In the morning and the afternoon the shadows will be longest because the sun is lower in the sky. Draw around your shadow at different times of the day and see what happens. Is it what you expected?

Curriculum links

Primary Science Unit 1D (also links to 3F): children should learn that some things block light (opaque) and cause shadows. Light does not bend round things.

Objectives met by this resource:

* Children learn that in the day the position of the sun in the sky changes.

* They learn that shadow positions can be used to tell time.

* They learn to measure variations in shadow lengths and intervals.

* They learn about the dangers of looking directly at the sun.

Lesson ideas

This sheet can be copied as part of a light-and-shadows display. Mark the position of feet and shadows, and decide how to record changes in shadow length and position. Discuss recording this. Make clocks and record times at intervals; predict shadow positions. Other lessons could look at translucent and opaque materials.

webTitle: In the shadow of the Confederate flag

fields.headline: In the shadow of the Confederate flag
fields.standfirst: Julian Borger in Washington on how the ghosts of the American civil war are haunting the new administration
fields.trailText: World dispatch: Julian Borger in Washington on how the ghosts of the American civil war are haunting the new administration.
fields.body:
Some old wars, like old soldiers, never die. Some never entirely fade away either. The American civil war is a prime example. It may appear to recede into the distance of history, only for its cannons to sound again, alarmingly close, in modern ears.

These past few days have demonstrated the war's undying capacity to define Americans. While in South Carolina, black demonstrators marched on Monday, Martin Luther King Day, to have the battle flag of the Confederacy removed from the grounds of the state capitol, two cabinet nominees were under scrutiny in Washington for their attitudes towards the war and its ever-present subtext, slavery.

Gale Norton, the interior secretary designate, appears to have run up her own flag in a 1996 speech in which she waxed nostalgic for the Confederacy and argued "we lost too much" when the Union emerged victorious.

She was careful to point out that she was referring not to slavery, a circumstance she euphemised as "bad facts" - only to the gain of centralised federal power at the expense of individual states.

That may have been discreet enough to save her confirmation from becoming a battle for survival, but it was not enough to appease some black leaders, who see the phrase "state rights" as no more than a stalking horse for the "good old days" of slavery and cotton.

Meanwhile, John Ashcroft, George Bush's pick as attorney-general, is in very similar hot water. In 1998, he gave an interview with a pro-Confederate journal called Southern Partisan, which largely runs articles written by apologists for the old South, who tend to blur the hard outlines of its racist past in a mist of nostalgia.

It once marketed T-shirts celebrating the assassination of Abraham Lincoln over the words of his assassin: Thus tyrants always.

Ashcroft - who is fighting off accusations of racism due to his staunch opposition to the promotion of a black judge in 1999 - praised the magazine for "setting the record straight".

"We've got to stand up and speak in this respect or else we'll be taught that these people were giving their lives, subscribing their sacred fortunes and their honour to some perverted agenda," he told the magazine.

The fascination with the war retains its grip because it is really a proxy for the continuing skirmishes over race that have accompanied this election from beginning to end. It remains, for all its disguises, the strongest tide running beneath US politics.

Just as for black Floridians, the multiple screw-ups of that state's election process were too much of an echo of an unlovely past to be mere incompetence, so the words "states' rights" and phrases such as "perverted agenda" and "Southern pride" all have meanings burdened with history.

To use them with such abandon suggests gross insensitivity, at the very least. But over 130 years after the last shot was fired, it will probably not be enough to stop Norton or Ashcroft in their tracks. Their confirmation hearings, however, will be a compelling debate on the visceral pivot of American history.

webTitle: Child psychiatrist shortage undermines services

fields.headline: Child psychiatrist shortage undermines services
fields.trailText: Children with mental health problems are failing to receive the help they need because of a shortage of child and adolescent psychiatrists and inter-agency confusion about dealing with those with behavioural disorders, according to a report.
fields.body:
Children with mental health problems are failing to receive the help they need because of a shortage of child and adolescent psychiatrists and inter-agency confusion about dealing with those with behavioural disorders, according to a report.

Health and social services agencies are facing sharp increases in the referral numbers of children with mental health problems, including increasing numbers of emergencies. The report, Whose crisis?, by children's mental health charity YoungMinds adds that most areas of the country do not have the in-patient beds to cope with the most disturbed cases.

Preliminary findings from a separate study by the Royal College of Psychiatrists (RCP), funded by the Department of Health (DoH), show that there are "widespread concerns" nationally about the provision of emergency facilities, a lack of beds and arrangements for severe and high-risk cases among psychiatrists.

The RCP study based on questionnaires sent to 454 psychiatrists, of whom 60% replied, said they had concerns about these areas and about the use of adult psychiatric wards and paediatric wards for children with mental health problems when an appropriate bed cannot be found.

The study, due to be published before Easter, will include the first survey of in-patient child psychiatric services in England and Wales. Until now there has been no central record within the NHS of how many units exist in the UK and no comprehensive details about what services they provide.

So far it has identified 81 units in England and Wales, each with an average of 12 beds. Around 25% of units are independently funded, about 50% take emergency referrals and 25% operate on a five-day a week basis, and in these units there are clear problems with accepting emergencies.

The YoungMinds report calls for a commitment from the government that in-patient provision for child and adolescent mental health services (CAMHS) should no longer be treated as a "Cinderella" service in terms of resources. It also says that the national service framework (NSF) for mental health, which lays down minimum standards of treatment for adults, should be extended to cover the needs of babies, children and adolescents.

The report says that in some parts of the country, child and adolescent psychiatrists have to refer to units some distance away from the child's home, which causes considerable problems in terms of planning and case management. Even when there is a clear diagnosis and agreement that an immediate admission is required (for instance within 24 hours), it regularly takes more than three days to find a CAMHS bed and "two to three weeks to secure a bed is not unusual", says the report.

YoungMinds director Peter Wilson said: "We have seen a rise of up to 20% in referrals of children with mental health problems in some areas and the reasons for them are more complex now."

"The adult mental health lobby is very strong and this is one of the reasons why children's services have suffered. There is also a perceived lower status of consultant child and adolescent psychiatrists than adult psychiatrists and this is one factor in explaining why there are shortages in some areas.

"Extending the NSF to children's services would be a major step forward in improving children's mental health services," Mr Wilson added.

Jan Douglas, head of children's services at Middlesbrough council in Teesside, who helped to draw up the report, said: "CAMHS are vastly under-resourced and another problem is the recruitment and retention of qualified staff.

"A third issue is the skill mix between health and social services because services can vary depending on how the two agencies collaborate in a geographical area. There is definitely a shortage of consultant child and adolescent psychiatrists and perhaps it is not seen as a very attractive post as they are under pressure from parents, GPs and social services.

"There has been some extra money in the past year from the government for developing children's services and we received £28,000, which is not much. We used that to fund a community psychiatric nurse to liaise with CAMHS professionals. In contrast, if we need to place a child in secure accommodation, it will cost us around £2,000 a week, so any extra money would have to be substantial to make a difference."

Disorders dealt with by CAMHS range from the emotional such as phobias, anxiety and depression, to conduct disorders such as stealing, fire-setting and anti-social behaviour, and developmental disorders such as delays in acquiring skills such as speech.

Around 10% of five to 15-year-olds in England, Scotland and Wales have some type of mental disorder, according to the largest national survey of its kind carried out by the Office for National Statistics in 1999. Children of families in social class 5 (unskilled occupations) were around three times more likely to have a mental health problem than those in social class 1 (professionals) - 15% compared with 5%.

webTitle: The battle to shape Liverpool

fields.headline: The battle to shape Liverpool
fields.trailText: The battle for control of Chavasse Park represents the missing piece in the jigsaw of the renaissance of a city once regarded as Britain's basket case, writes Helen Carter.
fields.body:
At first glance it is just a patch of green parkland on the edge of Liverpool city centre, but it is probably the most important piece of real estate anywhere in the country.

The battle for control of Chavasse Park represents the missing piece in the jigsaw of the renaissance of a city once regarded as Britain's basket case.

The park links the heart of Liverpool with the bars, restaurants and museums on the waterfront around the 19th-century Albert Dock, the largest group of Grade 1 listed buildings in the country, drawing more than 5m visitors annually.

Chavasse Park is a ragged shape and is easily recognisable for the huge steel yellow submarine - a visual testament to the Beatles' hit film.

For years, Liverpool has not been short of symbols of a proud cultural and industrial past. But until recently it has been stuck in a timewarp, unable to grab the urban riches which have revitalised other cities. Now all that has changed.

Two developers are fighting it out for control of Chavasse Park, a 20 acre site worth millions of pounds - for the privilege of redeveloping a centre which could cost £200m.

On one side, is a controversial self made builder from Liverpool. On the other is one of Britain's wealthiest men.

Bill Davies, chairman of Walton Group, is up against the Duke of Westminster, chairman of Grosvenor Group Holdings, who owns much of Belgravia in central London and swaths of rural England.

Grosvenor has produced plans as part of the city's £800m Bluecoat Triangle development, which embraces the Chavasse site, as well as a large chunk of the city.

Green land

It is understood that the Grosvenor plan, launched next week, will essentially retain Chavasse Park as green land.

The Bluecoat Triangle plan divides Liverpool into four quarters for development. The first quarter in Hanover Street would retain and renovate derelict buildings. The plans are thought to widen Paradise Street, creating a boulevard.

Originally the Chavasse site was due to be the location of a national discovery park. But the plans were abandoned when millennium commission grants were not secured.

It then emerged that the property developer Walton Group, which had made an agreement with Liverpool city council's previous Labour administration in 1996, was legally entitled to develop the land as a retail complex following the failure of the discovery park plan, an ambitious multimedia centre.

The developer and the council have been locked in legal battles ever since. Last summer, Mr Davies launched a high court action claiming the council had breached his human rights by delaying considering a planning application.

Mr Davies claimed the council was deliberately trying to block his proposal in favour of the Bluecoat Triangle scheme.

"I have been disappointed that the city council has not been prepared to enter into a serious dialogue about the detail of the scheme, which after all is being designed to satisfy the requirements of our contract with them."

Mr Davies, 65, said he had been prepared to invest in the city in good times and bad. But Walton Group has often been accused of dragging its feet on the redevelopment of other key sites in Liverpool, including the Exchange Flags building.

The company has been asked by English Partnerships, the £4.45m grant for the renovation of the Exchange Flags building.

"English Partnerships has made a detailed investigation into a £4.45m city grant paid to the Walton Group during 1992-94," said a spokeswoman. "Various discrepancies have been identified in claims for grant funding and legal proceedings have been issued."

Aspirations

Mike Storey, leader of Liverpool city council, described Chavasse Park as a wonderful piece of land. "We must ensure that there is a development which fits our aspirations for the 21st century. It is the missing piece of the jigsaw puzzle which brings everything together in Liverpool."

Louise Ellman, Labour MP for Liverpool Riverside, said she felt there was something strange about the way the original agreement was made between the council and Walton. It was essential that the legal position of ownership of the land was clarified. "Given the importance of the site, it is essential that we are confident about the developers," she said.

Although dogged by controversy, Walton has not been short of style. One of the most respected architects in America has designed Chavasse Park's flagship building. Philip Johnson is renowned for designing the International Place in Boston and Momentum Place in Dallas.

"The Chavasse Park design brings a world-class landmark, tying the city centre to the waterfront," he said. "Liverpool has to recreate the water. We have the dock; we have the water; we have the city. But they don't seem to meet."

Steve John, spokesman for Walton Group, said the site could be as important to Liverpool as the Guggenheim Museum was to Bilbao.

He said that research commissioned in 1999 found that although 5.2m visitors came to Liverpool, the majority parked their cars at Albert Dock and visited the attractions there, but did not cross the busy three-lane carriageway linking it to the city centre. In the Walton Group's plan, a footbridge would solve this problem.

Mr John added that the plan, which would be completed in 2004, could work alongside the Bluecoat Triangle scheme, due to open in 2007-08.

But Walton Group's plan was severely criticised by the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment, an independent review body of planning applications.

In its report, the commission concluded: "We found very little which we could support in this project... It would cause a fundamental shift in the city's retail centre of gravity which would be to the detriment of existing areas; in terms of regeneration of the city centre it would make things worse rather than better."

A spokesman for Grosvenor said the Bluecoat Triangle plan was something it was very committed to because it shared the objectives and aims of the city council - to regenerate the heart of Liverpool.

"The scheme breathes new life into Liverpool and it is a fairly substantial mixed use of retail, leisure and residential with a contemporary feeling," he said.

It has yet to be seen whether the duke or the home-grown builder will triumph in the battle for Chavasse Park.

webTitle: Koeman: Barcelona made 'an historic error' selling Figo

fields.headline: Koeman: Barcelona made 'an historic error' selling Figo
fields.trailText: Former Barcelona player Ronald Koeman has called the decision to sell Luis Figo to Real Madrid "an historic error."
fields.body:
Former Barcelona player Ronald Koeman has called the decision to sell Luis Figo to Real Madrid "an historic error."

"The worst thing of all is that not only have we lost him but that, at the same time, we have strengthened our rivals. We have allowed Real Madrid to become even stronger than they were before," he told the Barcelona based Sport newspaper.

Figo, who was recently presented with the European Player of the Year award, moved to Real for a world record £40m last July. The Portugal international has been in fine form in recent matches and scored the opening goal in Real's 4-0 win over Real Oviedo on Sunday.

Dutchman Koeman, who scored the winning goal in Barcelona's only European Cup triumph in 1992, said he found it hard to get used to the former Barcelona idol sporting the colours of their fiercest rivals.

"I have to say that at first my eyes were stinging when I saw him kitted out in white. He gave everything, even in training and we shouldn't have let him go in the way he did."

I am afraid that it is an historic error on the part of Barcelona," he added.

webTitle: Review: Temporary Accommodation, Whitechapel Gallery

fields.headline: The raw and the rubbish
fields.standfirst: Temporary Accommodation is the dumbest show the Whitechapel Gallery has ever seen, says  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Temporary Accommodation is the dumbest show the Whitechapel Gallery has ever seen, says Adrian Searle.
fields.body:
The exhibition Temporary Accommodation opened at the Whitechapel Art Gallery last Friday. I have already visited the show three times. I just can't get enough of it. I keep going back to make sure that it was only a dream after all, and because I am a masochist.

Temporary Accommodation is one of those narcissistic projects that institutions like to mount now and again just to prove how liberal and open they are, even to the talentless, and to demonstrate how radical and in touch with the young, the vital, the iconoclastic they can be.

In the small gallery at the top of the stairs in the Whitechapel, there are people working at computers, furrowing their brows, having phone conversations. Apparently, they are busy arranging cake-making competitions, hands-on healing sessions and talks by Christian preachers. They're setting-up language classes - Latin for beginners, Japanese, True Danish - and generally hanging about looking purposeful. These extra-curricular activities are outlined in a depressing little programme that also includes spoof horoscopes and adverts.

You walk through, and try not to make eye-contact. This feeble-minded charade of inclusiveness makes me want to puke. Somewhere amidst this ridiculous programme is a series of screenings of films by Bas Jan Ader, who died during a sailing trip across the Atlantic in 1975. His work meditated on the relation between art and life. But let's not confuse them, especially when the life on offer here seems so lousy.

Further on, a man called Simon Faithfull is doing pixillated drawings on the walls, on sheets of plastic and on boards. He has cluttered his space with ladders, powerful lights and a home-made polythene hot air balloon, which wafts about on its tether above a naked gas jet. The balloon has gone up all right. The drawings, so far, show a pair of binoculars, surveillance cameras, views of the traffic on Whitechapel High Street, a naked tree. Looking, I go all empty and dead inside. I try to find the "strong metaphorical qualities" signposted in the press release, but I can't - or won't, more like, because a refusal to engage is as much my right as anyone else's.

Tariq Alvi, born in Newcastle, raised in Newham, currently a resident of Rotterdam, occupies the entire ground floor gallery. Alvi is 35, and this is only his second solo show, anywhere. Alvi is both showing completed work and treating the gallery as his studio - or, rather, giving the impression that he's working here. It is difficult to tell what is complete, what is in progress, what is raw material, and what is merely en route to the rubbish bin. On the press day last Thursday, there was a man's beige suit folded on the floor. By Saturday the suit had been screwed to a wooden board. Is this a Saint Sebastian gag? Deconstruct: Saint Sebastian pierced by arrows, suit drilled with screws; screws, screwing; beige suit, man; Catholic martyr, gay icon. Or perhaps not.

Alvi's work is all in a state of suspension, or flux, between one state and another. That is how he works, that is the thing that he does. He pins things up above his mantelpiece and over his desk, he covers tables with a litter of porn mags, newspaper cuttings, photos and drawing pins, glue-sticks and plastic beads. Lengths of chain and all those pins add a frisson of something or other, something "Ouch!" and something "Ooh!" Here are actual noticeboards and life-size photographs of the walls of the artist's studio-apartment, where Post-Its and photocopied Spanish still lifes are stuck next to private letters and Hugo Boss advertising beefcake. There's club flyers and gallery invites, postcards, doodles, phone numbers. Some of this stuff is displayed on false walls angled out into the gallery, so you wedge yourself in there to get a good look.

The problem is that I don't really care about any of it, even as I try to get a fix on Alvi from the accumulated evidence. He goes to clubs. People write to him. He likes art, he works hard at his career. He's gay, I guess, intelligent and inquisitive. He prefers clutter to emptiness. He has a nice decorative sense and an eye for colour. He takes maps of cities and fills in the squares and streets and parks with coloured pens, turning them into pretty pictures (nothing wrong with that) that look like clothing in paintings by Klimt. He morphs images of male lions together, to make it look as if they're humping. He gives us shredded slices of his life.

I imagine Alvi concentrating, scissors in hand, nursing his enthusiasms. It all looks a bit stoned and fitful and driven by an entirely private logic. I feel a vague echo of Alighiero e Boetti and of Daniel Spoerri, updated, but none of it takes me very far. The stuff Alvi collects and snips and sticks together is on its migratory route between its point of origin and its ultimate resting place - either as art or rubbish. This is a slim space in which to operate, an entirely theatrical demonstration of artistic doubt and aspiration.

Alvi surely knows this as he sieves and screws and glues away. He cuts away at a catalogue of mail-order jewellery, snipping out bracelets and eternity rings for a pinboard arrangement. He cuts newspaper footage into little ticker-tape insects - cockroaches and bugs and fanciful spiders - turning tabloid columns into parasitic bugs. His work tables, with their cargos of half-finished things, magazines and materials, are heavy with clues and potential, but my voyeuristic interest in his working process goes unrewarded. The thousands of torn-up shreds of paper that litter the gallery floor make me think of entropy, my energy slowly ebbing away. One thousand snapshots of rubbish and graffiti and corners in Amsterdam's red-light district fill a whole wall, but I can't recall a single detail.

GK Chesterton, in one of the more bizarre of his 1920s Father Brown stories (in which an unassuming Roman Catholic priest played amateur sleuth) wrote something to the effect that the criminal was like the artist, the detective like the critic. We can look at Alvi's show as the scene of the crime, but what crime was it?

Back upstairs, Szuper Gallery, a group originally from Munich but now London-based, show some videos. One documents a party staged for the camera, with drinks and music and animated conversation. Under the footage runs a text, detailing a real-life art heist that took place in Venice last year. A gang set up a very sophisticated Mametian con trick and fooled at least three dealers into parting with valuable paintings before disappearing.

The heist - which involved a fake family apartment, a dying grandmother, an absent collector and his garrulous, plausible son - was better than anything in the exhibition, and better yet than Szuper Gallery's description of it. The con showed daring, guile, an understanding of art dealer mentality, a sense of theatre and staging, and loads and loads of front. The crims may have been con artists, but they were artists just the same. The criminal here is only a curator.

Temporary Accommodation, which has been curated by Andrea Tarsia, will be forgotten, as just about the dumbest show the Whitechapel has ever held. Someone, I suppose, will try to tell me it was "brave".

In March the Whitechapel will celebrate a full century in its current location. A moment to pause, then, as public spaces all over London deal with what one might call the Tate Effect, and are forced to redefine their individuality, their particular slant on current art in the light of Tate Modern's success. Temporary Accommodation might have seemed like a bright idea to someone, but it is ghastly and amateurish in just about every way. Curatorial spin and theoretical fuzzy logic can't save it. Later this year, Iwona Blazwick, lately head of exhibitions at Tate Modern, takes over the reins from Catherine Lampert as director of the Whitechapel. Let's move on.

· Temporary Accommodation: Alvi, Belt, Faithfull and Szuper Gallery is at the Whitechapel Art Gallery, London E1 (020-7522 7888) until March 4.

webTitle: Searching the world for a mayoral model

fields.headline: Searching the world for a mayoral model
fields.standfirst: A foreign view of directly elected mayors
fields.trailText: Korean voters want to dump some of the city mayors they elected five years ago, and they're furious they have to wait for the next election to do it. Birmingham could soon be in the same position. Chris Game asks if Tony Blair has learnt anything from foreign experiences
fields.body:
The diagnosis was PMP - prime ministerial paranoia. Ludicrously self-important though it sounds, I recently became convinced Tony Blair was following me around. First in Seoul, then a few weeks later in Moscow - wherever I was working, there within days would be Mr Blair - and on the flimsiest pretexts.

Britain was under water, the rail service collapsing, fuel protests threatened, yet the PM was tracking me across the globe. Then I realised - it was undercover mayoral research. With legislation passed that opens the door for councils to have directly elected mayors, it was time for the PM to see some of them in action. Much easier than gathering your evidence first and risk it ruining the rhetoric.

Perhaps it was mayoral recall the PM was interested in when he took that flight to Korea. It is a front-page topic, as Koreans learn the hard way that they, like us, have no political mechanisms for the early removal of incompetent or inefficient mayors.

Most mayoral systems provide for removal either by a vote of the legislature or council - a kind of impeachment - or through a popular vote following a citizen petition.

But our government decided no such provisions were necessary. In a delightfully Yes, Minister form of argument it claimed a recall mechanism would make mayors "unique among those in the UK directly elected to an office in that they could be replaced, despite their democratic mandate, by actions of either their electorate or others".

That is the whole point of accountability through recall. Listen, though, to the prime minister, Jim Hacker, and his right-hand man Sir Humphrey. Really unpopular mayors, the government argued, especially if pressured by party or public opinion, "may choose to resign". Just like unpopular or incompetent ministers do, presumably.

Korea was an interesting choice for Mr Blair. Mayors there have been directly elected only since 1995, but to a visitor in Seoul they seem to be everywhere. Subway platforms are lined with near-identical posters, all featuring seemingly exclusively male mayors welcoming you with outstretched arms to the cultural and agricultural delights of their respective districts. There are more than two dozen of them in Seoul alone, just as there could be in London in a few years' time.

The Koreans are now urgently working out how they can get rid of some of them. If ministers want voters in my own city of Birmingham and elsewhere to opt for powerful directly elected mayors in forthcoming referendums, they might be well advised to do the same.

Birmingham's democracy commission last year published the results of its wide-ranging enquiry into how the city's council might reform its politics. One of the commission's most emphatic findings was that, while many electors were attracted to the principle of electing a mayor, they became more sceptical on learning that there would be no way of removing one who was not up to exercising such a concentration of personal power competently and democratically.

That is the essence of mayoral systems - concentrated personal power - and there are few better places to observe it in action than Moscow, now utterly transformed by the remarkable mayor Yuri Luzhkov. He is described as having an "edifice complex" bigger than a French president's, and his postmodern architectural projects are all over the city.

Some are admirable, like the reconstructed Cathedral of Christ the Saviour or the replica Resurrection Gate to Red Square, both destroyed by Stalin. Some are just gross, notably the vast monument of Peter the Great bestriding a frigate on the banks of the Moskva.

But there is much more. Parks, streets and buildings have been cleaned up; crime prevention prioritised; restaurants, luxury hotels and shopping malls opened; public holidays declared; and Moscow's most popular (and tax-favoured) soccer club, Spartak, have won and retained the Russian cup.

Plus, of course, the city has a metro system that Londoners would kill for. Everyone knows about the palatially decorated stations, with their marble, mosaics and life-sized statues. Most striking, though, is the system's sheer efficiency - flat-rate 10p services every 90 seconds on all lines throughout peak periods - and the fact its 160-station network is still annually growing.

In the early 1990s Mr Luzhkov, a strong Boris Yeltsin supporter, persuaded the president to let Moscow opt out of the country's nationwide privatisation campaign. Instead of selling everything off, he kept a big stake in almost every enterprise for the city, while at the same time encouraging massive foreign investment.

Today, the city administration either owns or has shares in nearly 2,000 corporations - oil and gas, telecommunications, broadcasting and publishing, railways, a pasta factory, and a McDonalds-challenging chain of Slavic fast food restaurants.

Mr Luzhkov's control of Moscow is tsar-like. But he is charismatic and electorally untouchable, winning 90% of the vote in 1996 and 71% three years later.

If it were not for the rest of Russia's instinctive hatred for all things Muscovite, he would have been an even more serious presidential challenger to present president Vladimir Putin than he was. Certainly he is a far more dominant - and threatening - municipal presence than London mayor Ken Livingstone could ever be, at least with the restricted powers at the latter's disposal.

Provincial city mayors might be another matter. As heads of unitary or metropolitan authorities, they would control the full range of local services and fund-raising methods. In the absence of any recall provision, it seems quite possible that electors will more readily trust the integrity of a candidate who is not an established party politician - the kind of person, in fact, that Tony Blair wants to attract into local government. This is, at least partially, because the government wants to shake up political control in some of those authorities that, like Birmingham, have effectively become one-party councils.

The city has at least one potential non-party candidate in the local historian and popular BBC radio personality, Dr Carl Chinn. His populist campaign last spring to save car production at Longbridge could almost have been a rehearsal for a high profile mayoral bid, and, political inexperience notwithstanding, he admits he is seriously considering the idea.

He is insistent that he would run as an Independent - just like Martin Bell and Ken Livingstone - and already Birmingham's Liberal Democrats have hinted that, by not fielding a candidate of their own, they might support him. If ministers really want to break their own party's 17-year hold on the city's local government, their refusal to consider a mayoral recall mechanism might just achieve it.

webTitle: Deadline to end split on transfers

fields.headline: Deadline to end split on transfers
fields.standfirst:
European leagues issue go-it-alone ultimatum to world game's ruling body
The transfer crisis made simple
fields.trailText: Uefa have issued a go-it-alone ultimatum to the world game's ruling body following a high-profile war of words over Fifa's dealings with the Eurpean Commission on player transfers.
fields.body:
European football leaders are to set a deadline to try to form a united front on proposed changes to the transfer system and heal the growing rift with Fifa; otherwise they will open their own discussions with the European Commission.

An emergency meeting of Uefa's executive committee will today discuss demands made by representatives of Europe's 13 top leagues that Fifa be issued with the deadline and fall in line or be ostracised, with Europe going it alone in negotiations to change the transfer system.

The calls for Europe to press ahead independent of Fifa were issued at a meeting in Switzerland yesterday where representatives of the 13 leagues met to discuss how progress could be made following a high-profile war of words between Fifa and Uefa.

While no time limit has been set, Uefa is anxious to resolve the matter as quickly as possible and the commission is insisting it wants a settlement by the end of January.

Uefa and European league officials are also demanding that Fifa withdraw the document that it submitted to the commission last week outlining its proposed changes to the transfer system, which sparked off the most serious row to hit world football in recent years.

The meeting in Switzerland heard widespread condemnation of Fifa and its decision to submit the document - dismissed by Uefa yesterday as "a non-paper" - without consulting Uefa. Representatives of the 13 leagues urged Uefa that, unless agreement could be reached with Fifa, then European football's governing body should register as an interested party in the transfer issue, allowing it to negotiate directly with the commission.

Some European football officials want the deadline to be issued for Monday, when a joint Fifa-Uefa working party meeting is to take place. However, Uefa ruled yesterday that no further meetings would take place unless agreement was reached between the two organisations and assurances given that there would be no more unilateral actions.

There is a growing feeling that Fifa must be given a chance, despite anger at its actions, given that the commission and football appear so close to agreement on how the transfer system can be amended to comply with European law.

A statement from Uefa and the European leagues said that the proposals submitted by Fifa last week were damaging to European football.

Fifa wants to give players the right to terminate contracts at three months' notice, which is opposed by Uefa. European football's governing body is also unhappy at Fifa's proposed system for compensation for clubs where a player's move is in dispute.

The Uefa statement said: "No further meeting should be held with Fifa unless certain principles are agreed.

Uefa and the leagues express their regret at recent developments in light of the progress that was being made in the discussions to secure a positive solution to the transfer issue."

Mike Lee, director of communications at Uefa, said yesterday: "We have convened an emergency meeting of our executive committee where we will report the results of today's meeting and the strength of feeling from the European leagues.

Despite the tough talking from European football officials, a deadline to withdraw the Fifa document issued by Uefa was ignored yesterday.

Fifa officials insisted that the document was not a firm set of proposals and that any other deadlines issued by Uefa would be considered.

A Fifa spokesman said: "We are still waiting to hear from Uefa. Just because the deadline to withdraw the document has passed does not mean it is the end of the matter. The commission said that it would still examine Fifa's documents, even though it does not have Uefa's backing.

A spokesman said: "We will be examining the document and are taking it very seriously, even if it is not a concrete set of proposals. We are hoping to meet officials next week to try and resolve the issue."

webTitle: Pick of the week

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: Bill Clinton gets in touch with his inner child; a sad wigmaker holes up during the 1665 London plague; Dante's Inferno given the animated treatment; a post-apocalyptic game of chicken
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton gets in touch with his inner child; a sad wigmaker holes up during the 1665 London plague; Dante's Inferno given the animated treatment; a post-apocalyptic game of chicken
fields.body:
President Clinton - Final Days
(www.alwaysindependentfilms.com)
This week William Jefferson Clinton finds himself out of a job. Anyone curious about how he's been passing his time lately will find all the answers in this self-mocking spoof video created for the White House correspondents dinner, which has recently found its way onto the Web. Yes, that really is Slick Willie himself mowing the lawn, fiddling the vending machines and making Hillary's packed lunch. There's something curiously appealing, but also faintly bemusing, about watching the most powerful man in the Western world cut loose like a teen slacker for the camera and riding his bicycle around the corridors of power. Blink and you'll miss the Kevin Spacey cameo, but Bill himself turns in a creditable performance in this aw-shucks mockumentary. (KS)
 View the film

The Periwig-Maker
(www.atomfilms.com)
Brother and sister team Steffen and Annette Schaffler's dark, richly produced animation combines cinematic quality with a rare trait - restraint. Their tale of a repressed wigmaker, shut up in his house against the ravages of the 1665 London plague is both exquisitely mounted and finely calibrated. Kenneth Branagh's measured narration unfolds a story of regret and redemption, which is full of sadness, but never drops into sentimentality. Visually it's wonderfully realised, from the long opening shot through a wealth of atmospheric period detail in every scene. For once, believe the superlative onsite reviews - this is a little gem of a movie, quite unlike anything you'll see elsewhere. (KS)
 View the film

Kozik's Inferno
(www.wildbrain.com)
Dante's Inferno might not sound like ideal material for a cartoon, but this 12-part animated series attempts to make light of the great poet's most famous and diabolic work. Director Frank Kozik's version undeniably lacks the darkness of the most venerable of horror stories, but it does work well as a primer. More of a Dante for Beginners than a divine comedy, but a good way in to the work nevertheless.(SD)
 View the film

The Joust
(www.ifilm.com)
A post-apocalyptic game of chicken is the subject for this admirable Dutch short. The whole thing is digitally rendered in some very handsome computer game graphics and the gracefulness of the animation more than makes up for the wafer-thin plot. Like Mad Max only more atmospheric. (SD)
 View the film

webTitle: Pop review: Gary Lucas

fields.headline: 'Sideman' Lucas out on his own
fields.standfirst:
Gary Lucas
Borderline
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Gary Lucas
Borderline
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
One man, several guitars and countless effects pedals could have been as grim a live proposition as a solo album from a minor member of Level 42. Gary Lucas, however, had other ideas.

While far from a household name, Lucas, from Syracuse, New York, has played with quite a few since his professional debut in 1973, as the guitarist for the European premiere of Leonard Bernstein's Mass. Lucas has played alongside such luminaries as Lou Reed, Nick Cave, Bryan Ferry and DJ Spooky, but his reputation rests on his tenure with Captain Beefheart's Magic Band circa 1982's Ice Cream for Crow, and writing and playing contributions to the opening two tracks of Grace, the only proper album by Jeff Buckley. Buckley was an alumnus of Lucas's Gods and Monsters ensemble, as are Mary Margaret O'Hara and Matthew Sweet.

Two parts Glenn Branca at his most inventive, one part Leo Kottke at his most complex, Lucas could have spent an evening name-dropping or mired in the bitterness of a perennial sideman, but instead he simply showed what the wider world has been missing. The opening demolition of Kraftwerk's Autobahn - "an old folk song" - gave way to a shredded, Hendrix-style Amazing Grace, a twisting of Albert Ayler's already corkscrew Ghosts, a supple instrumental trundle through Grace itself, and a slew of originals.

Crucially, there was little in the way of guitar histrionics and contorted facial expressions; trouper that he is, Lucas - big velvet jacket, big jaunty hat, big heavy eyelids - simply got on with it in good-tempered fashion. He sang occasionally, supplying an effective Delta voice on the cotton-picking Let's Go Swimming and more worldly tones when the initially ferocious Coming Clean quoted Dylan Thomas during its quieter sections. The cotton-picking Police Dog Blues transcended an unpromising title to soar into a feast of intriguing, subtle wizardry, underpinned with a core of accessibility: for all his dexterity, Lucas always stayed the right side of a guitar shop demonstration.

His finest moment was The Wall, a brief, beguiling instrumental, played, as ever, with intricate precision, but so full of quietly contrasting, whistleable melodies, there could have been a whole band up there with him. In truth, he doesn't need anybody else.

webTitle: Bank of Scotland bars bill payers from England

fields.headline: Nothing personal, but don't come in
fields.standfirst:
Bank of Scotland bars bill payers from English branches

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland bars bill payers from English branches.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland is planning to bar personal customers from its English branches. Instead, the Edinburgh-based bank intends to give customers pre-paid envelopes and tell them to ring a call centre.

The move could require at least 17,000 customers in England, where BoS has 20 branches, to change their banking habits. While BoS is not closing the branches, it wants them to be used only by corporate and small business customers.

According to letters sent out last week, all personal banking accounts are to be moved to the BoS 24-hour a day Phoneline service.

While the BoS is to allow customers to pay money into their accounts through their branches, the bank is asking customers to post all other correspondence such as payment for bills including the bank's own credit card.

BoS's decision to try to keep personal customers from its branches comes at a time when it is trying to seal a merger with Abbey National. The talks, however, have been stalled by a move by Lloyds TSB to try to persuade Abbey National to agree to a takeover. It comes a year after Barclays found itself surrounded by controversy after customer protests at its decision to close 171 branches on one day.

BoS customers will be required to use the Phonelink service and restrict their use of branches for paying in from March 1. Account numbers and sort codes will not be affected.

Customers who decide to use the prepaid envelopes to pay in cheques are being warned by BoS that they will need to wait an extra day when withdrawing funds against English banks' cheques.

A spokesman for BoS said: "It is a change for some people but it's not radical. It's a development of the services. It's going to be a better service through Phoneline".

Of the 20 BoS branches in England, one has never offered a counter-style service. BoS has traditionally catered for small businesses in England. It also has, however, 700,000 personal customers in England, for a variety of products including current accounts and loans. It has 326 branches in Scotland.

webTitle: Opera review: Falstaff

fields.headline: Falstaff
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
This is Verdi year, and the Royal Opera is marking the centenary of his death with a revival of Falstaff, which - although astonishing in parts - doesn't do the work justice.

The flaw lies in a gaping disparity between stage and score. Graham Vick's production - unveiled in 1999 and planned as a showpiece for the Opera House's new stage - is a gaudy, hi-tech effort, which aspires to bawdry and coarse humour. Codpiece jokes abound; the characters are sometimes pushed towards caricature; the vibrant designs don't so much dazzle as blind; and the set's platforms and lifts crank and whirr noisily, intruding on the music.

Such riotous ebullience might just work in Shakespeare's The Merry Wives of Windsor, but it sits uneasily with Verdi, who was after something more subtle, muted and profound - a celebration of life's bittersweet richness, viewed from the point of contented old age. This awkwardness is thrown into sharper relief by Bernard Haitink's interpretation, which sometimes stresses the bitter at the expense of the sweet, shading the tone of the whole towards glowing autumnal nostalgia where some might prefer a deft lightness of approach.

At its centre, however, is a Falstaff of greatness from the Italian baritone Paolo Gavanelli. There's a fatness in his voice that matches his waddling girth, a sensuality of sound and vibrancy of tone that capture the old rogue's unbreakable vitality. When the merry wives' jokes have gone too far and both his pretences and his clothes have been stripped away (making him look like an enormous rotund baby), he still asserts monumental dignity.

His teasers and tormentors, however, are unevenly cast. Simon Keenleyside's Ford is a dangerous, vulpine creature, who tracks Falstaff obsessively, exploding into his jealousy monologue with a venom that can't quite disguise the fact that his voice is fractionally too small for the role. Patricia Schuman makes Alice a smoky-toned, manipulative woman. But the young lovers are less convincing. Sally Matthews, replacing the indisposed Jenny Grahn as Nannetta, has a stroppy wilfulness way in excess of the demands of the music, which she floats with spine-tingling beauty. Steve Davislim's once exquisite tenor has thickened to a point where Fenton no longer suits him. Bernadette Manca di Nissa's Mistress Quickly is voiced with fruity indecency but is dramatically staid.

For all that, Gavanelli unquestionably makes the evening worthwhile.

 In rep until January 30. Box office: 020-7304 4000.
